abstract: In the Senate, petitions in favor of a Bankrupt law, and advocating emancipation, were pre  sented. A bill was passed authorizing the Secretary of the Interior to strike from the pension roll ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, petitions in favor of a Bankrupt law, and advocating emancipation, were pre sented. A bill was passed authorizing the Secretary of the Interior to strike from the pension roll an names or persons who take up arms against the Government. A bill authorizing the detail of Naval officers for the inspection of vessels, before troops are embarked upon them, was passed. The joint resolution appropriating $35,000 for the expenses attending the exhibition of the products of American industry at the coming World's Fair in London was debated and finally rejected, 22 to 17. a bill to secure the completion of the Southwest branch of the Pacific Railroad was appropriately referred. The bill to prohibit American citizens from embarking in the Coolie trade was passed.

abstract: Speaker H J Raymond on national financial policy Congress should adopt during war crisis, speech, NYS Assembly
snippet: Speaker H J Raymond on national financial policy Congress should adopt during war crisis, speech, NYS Assembly
lead_paragraph: I desire, Mr. Chairman, before the question is taken upon these resolutions, to say a few words in regard to them. We have submitted to us two sets of resolutions which are intended to express the sentiments of the people of the Slate of New-York for the guidance of Congress and the Federal Government as to the financial policy to be adopted in carrying on the war during the present year. One of these series of resolutions comes to us with the high prestige of a report from the Committee on Ways and Means; the other is offered as a substitute by an individual member of this House. I can easily understand that it is the disposition of every member to acquiesce in the form given to this expression of opinion by the Committee without hesitation. And if any one on this floor has a special reason for wishing to sustain that Committee and adopt, without hesitation, whatever it may report, certainly I am in that position. But yet reasons may present themselves to my mind strong enough to convince me that, either through haste or misconception, the Committee may not at all times adopt the best mode of expressing the sentiments of the people of this State. That happens to be my conviction in reference to the resolutions that have been offered by the Committee on the subject of our national finances. I prefer the resolutions offered by the gentleman from Tioga (Mr. TRACKY) and shall endeavor to give the grounds of that preference.

abstract: If the last  files of the London Times and Post are to be believed, our unsuspecting country has just been the recipient of a favor of surpassing magnitude. England, it is claimed, has "by ...
lead_paragraph: If the last files of the London Times and Post are to be believed, our unsuspecting country has just been the recipient of a favor of surpassing magnitude. England, it is claimed, has "by a salutary display of firmness and force brought us to our senses!" There is something provokingly comic in the pompous, irresistible, jubilant air of these writers, which is all the more piquant from their own serene unconsciousness of the buffoonery of their intemperate carnival. The British people, or at least a fragmentary dominant section of them, are, it seems, so ecstatic with triumph, so intoxicated with self-complacency at their marvelous success in "teaching the Yankees a lesson," as to forget that England has herself received one. We have no wish to disturb Mr. Bull in any of his exuberant little excesses. They can do no harm except to himself; while they undoubtedly afford amusement to his neighbors. But if he will now, as inevitably he must, make up his mind peacefully to forego the absurd and unrighteous belligerent powers over neutral merchant vessels on the high seas, against which we have just given the most emphatic reclamation which any people ever had it in their power to pronounce, he may, without the slightest umbrage to us, allow the frantic war chiefs of his venal Press to sound imaginary alarms, and dream of impossible victories; sow the seeds of discord, revel in mad visions of bloodshed, and inflate the childish bubbles of national vanity to their heart's content. The public opinion of Europe and of this country will, however, refuse to judge the intelligent masses of the English people by the hired ravings of a corrupt insensate Press. And, as for ourselves, we have the gratification of knowing that, in our solution of the Trent difficulty, wo have not only acted in conformity with our national honor, and given a new force and a wider range to the principles of international law, advocated by FRANKLIN, JEFFERSON, MADISON, CLAY, and all out leading statesmen, but have found ourselves, without a war, able to obtain for this country and for Europe just and honorable concessions, such as no war, however costly, has ever yet been able to wrest from Great Britain. In this object we have the sympathy of France. Russia, also, with Austria, Prussia and Belgium, have espoused the same good cause; and the present temper of the great Powers of Europe is such, that either by special treaties, or preferably by an international Congress, the diplomatic victory we have won will certainly be made so decisive, that hereafter, in time of war, the interests of commerce will receive more complete protection, and the exclusive privileges of an arrogant naval Power, over neutral vessels at sea, will be for ever exploded.

abstract: In the Senate, favorable reports were made on the bill making an appropriation to support the Government for the fiscal year; authorizing the Canal Board to reduce the expenses of printing; ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, favorable reports were made on the bill making an appropriation to support the Government for the fiscal year; authorizing the Canal Board to reduce the expenses of printing; amending the act to lay out the northern portion of this City ; amending the Brooklyn and Newtown Railroad act; for the better regulation of the Brooklyn firemen, and relating to offences committed against Joint Stock Companies. Notice was given of a bill for the better protection of gas consumers in the State. Among the bills introduced was one for the withdrawal of the circulating bills of incorporated banks whose charters have expired ; one authorizing the construction of a railroad in Kings and Queens Counties, and one for the better security of human life in the Metropolitan Police District. The resolution to instruct the New-York Senators in Congress to vote for the expulsion of Mr. BRIGHT, was then taken up and debated with much warmth until the adjournment, but no vote was taken.

abstract: The following changes have taken place in the Fortieth New-York Volunteers, (Mozart Regiment,) stationed at Camp Sackett, Virginia: Lieut.-ColEGAN has been transferred to the Quartermaster's ...
lead_paragraph: The following changes have taken place in the Fortieth New-York Volunteers, (Mozart Regiment,) stationed at Camp Sackett, Virginia: Lieut.-ColEGAN has been transferred to the Quartermaster's Department at Washington. First Lieut. G.O. BARLOW, of Company H, has resigned, and private FLETCHER, Company G, has been promoted to a Second Lieutenancy. Col. WARD, of the Thirty-eighth, (Scott Life Guard,) is acting as Brigadier-General in Gen. HEINTZELMAN's Division. The divisions commanded by Gens. FRANKLIN, SUMNER and HEINTZELMAN, each in its turn sends out a regiment for three days' picket duty between Mount Vernon and Fairfax Road. Letters from the camps say that no men are to be seen among the country people, who are represented as being extremely poor.

abstract: Our readers will find in another column a communication in relation to the proposed Solicitor of Customs. The writer thinks we were misinformed in some of the most impor- ...
lead_paragraph: Our readers will find in another column a communication in relation to the proposed Solicitor of Customs. The writer thinks we were misinformed in some of the most important of the facts which we stated, a few days ago, in relation to the legal business of the United States arising under the Revenue laws. We argued that the statement that there were six hundred suits now pending under those laws was a very great exaggeration. We still think that it is such, and that it is our correspondent, and not ourselves, who is misinformed. Let us see.

abstract: A few minutes before 6 o'clock, yesterday morning, a fire was discovered in the five-story brick building, No. 191 Pearl-street. A part of the upper portion of the building was occupied by John M. MOORE & CO., manufacturers of green glassware. Their stock was entirely destroyed. The first floor, basement and cellar were occupied by the Carbon Oil Company, the proprietors of which state that they have suffered very little damage. The Company were insured for $5,000 in the Atlantic and United States Insurance Companies. JOHN M. MOORE & CO.'s loss will amount to about $1,000, upon which there is no insurance. R.J. NEIDLINER, who occupied the third and fourth floors' lost about $2,000 worth of property. He is insured in the Home and Firemen's Insurance Companies. The fifth floor was occupied by PATRIcK WALSH as a sample-room. His loss is $400, upon which there is no insurance. The building is owned by J.M. WARD. It was damaged to the extent of $6,000, and is fully insured. No. 189 Pearl-street was damaged to the amount of $500. It is owned by E. PATRICK MURRAY. Fully insured. The basement of the latter building was occupied by E.F. HOLEROOK, dealer in window glass. His stock was considerably damaged by water. No. 193 Pearl-street, owned by the Wolf estate, was damaged about $200. Fully insured. It was occupied by WELTZ & VETTER, dealers in cheese and cigars. Their damage of stock was about $1,600, upon which they have an insurance in the Manhattan, Merchants' and Royal Insurance Companies for $8,000. HOPKINS & BROS. also occupied a portion of this building. Their damage by fire and water will amount to about $600; fully insured. The total loss by this fire is estimated at $12,000. The flames were first discovered on the second floor of No. 191, by a patrolman of the First Precinct Police. The origin of the fire is not certainly known, though it is believed to have been caused by coals in an ash barrel.

lead_paragraph: Among the advices brought by the Africa is the sequel of the correspondence, opened by Lord RUSSELL'S dispatch of Nov. 30, between the Foreign Office in London and our Department of State. The case of the British vessel Eugenia Smith was referred to in the response of the British Secretary to Mr. SEWARD's answer in the Trent business, as naturally to be governed by the precedent thus established. But it appears that the intimation had not been awaited at the State Department. Simultaneously with the release of SLIDELL and MASON, Mr. SEWARD intimated to Lord LYONS that Messrs. ZACHARIE and ROGERS, American citizens removed from the Eugenia Smith, under suspicions similar to those which prompted the act of Capt. WILKES, would be at once discharged from Fort Lafayette, and permitted to return to their homes in the South. With equal readiness, and without delaying for a formal application for redress, one or two minor irregularities arising from the blockade, were arranged to the satisfaction of Lord LYONS; so that on the last day of 1861 every international question pending between this Government and that of England was fully and perfectly settled.

abstract: It would be comfortable if anything from rebel sources in regard to the war could be believed. Yet, it is very likely that the above news from the Georgia coast is true, in so far as it reports the appearance of ...
lead_paragraph: It would be comfortable if anything from rebel sources in regard to the war could be believed. Yet, it is very likely that the above news from the Georgia coast is true, in so far as it reports the appearance of a National naval force at the points indicated; and it is like enough that the object it had in view was the one mentioned; and it is possible that a "battle lasting fifty minutes" took place between our force and Commodore TATNALL's rebel fleet; but it is extremely doubtful whether the results were as light for the rebels as they choose to put them. The fact that our gunboats engaged TATNALL's men-of-war apparently well down the river, and that, at latest accounts, the rebel "fleet" had arrived safe up at Savannah, looks very like as if TATNALL had had as bad luck this time as on one or two former occasions, and had turned tail as unceremoniously as has lately been his wont.

abstract: The Hamburg steamship Bavaria, Capt. MEIER, from Hamburg 13th inst., and Southampton 15th, at 9 P.M. arrived yesterday morning after a most tempestuous passage. From the 22d to the 29th, ...
lead_paragraph: The Hamburg steamship Bavaria, Capt. MEIER, from Hamburg 13th inst., and Southampton 15th, at 9 P.M. arrived yesterday morning after a most tempestuous passage. From the 22d to the 29th, she had very heavy gales from the northwest, during which she lost four boats and damaged three of her remaining ones, stove bulwarks, etc. Also, lost overboard four seamen and disabled three others. She has a largo cargo and a number of passengers.

abstract: We have important intelligence from the rebel States, by way of Fortress Monroe. Dispatches from Augusta and Savannah, Ga., render it probaable that the capture of the latter place by the ...
lead_paragraph: We have important intelligence from the rebel States, by way of Fortress Monroe. Dispatches from Augusta and Savannah, Ga., render it probaable that the capture of the latter place by the the National forces will be soon effected. The dates from there are to Wednesday last, at which time a number of National vessels had passed up behind Little Tybee Island to the north end of Wilmington Island, thereby cutting off communication between Fort Pulaski and the city. At last accounts six of them were at Wall's Cut, and seven at the head of Wilmington Island, commanding the channel of the river. Two steamers with provisions for Fort PULASKI had been convoyed by TATNALL'S "Fleet" down the river, but our gunboats opened upon them, and compelled them to return to Savannah. The rebels boast, however, that the Fort is provisioned for six months, and that it cannot be taken by any force which the Government can bring against it. All of which remains to be proved.

abstract: England has made the Stone Blockade a diplomatic question. It is broadly hinted she may make it a casus belli. Incredible though the announcement may seem, it is not permit- ...
lead_paragraph: England has made the Stone Blockade a diplomatic question. It is broadly hinted she may make it a casus belli. Incredible though the announcement may seem, it is not permit to doubt it; and we print in another column various extracts in relation to the question, which may well be read with mingled emotions. We are told that Earl RUSSELL has been appealed to to intervene in the matter, and that the Secretary rejoins that he had already sent dispatches to Lord Lyons in December "expressing the dissatisfaction of the British Government at such a procceding, and strong hopes that it would not be repeated at any other port."

abstract: The  House of Representatives, at the instance of the Van Wyck Investigating Committee, yesterday made a call upon the Secretary of the Treasury for a most comprehensive account.
lead_paragraph: The House of Representatives, at the instance of the Van Wyck Investigating Committee, yesterday made a call upon the Secretary of the Treasury for a most comprehensive account of the cost of the Custom-house establisnment in this city, past and present. The salary, emoluments, and perquisites of every nature, in all its ramifications. We do not know that the developments will prove as rich for Mr. VAN WYCK as the perquisites aforesaid are to the Collector, Surveyor, and their fellows; but it is well that the public should know something of the actual figures. The prerogatives of the establishment might also be referred to with profit. They have increased, are increasing, and ought possibly to be diminished. At all events, the time is not propitious for adding another legal arm to this local service in the shape of a Solicitor of Customs.

abstract: The Canadian journals  which have exhibited such a spirit of bitter hostility to the National Government, have been sadly puzzled how to conduct themselves of late. The Toronto Leader, for instance, ...
lead_paragraph: The Canadian journals which have exhibited such a spirit of bitter hostility to the National Government, have been sadly puzzled how to conduct themselves of late. The Toronto Leader, for instance, found abundant themes for discussion in the Trent case, and the suspension of specie payments by our banks; but when the rebels sustained that disastrous defeat in Kentucky it doubted and denied the facts until Gen. THOMAS made his official report; and then, --local matters suddenly assumed such imporance that it could only find space for a bare statement of the result. Just at present the Leader makes the comparatively trifling losses sustained by the Burnside Expedition a text for most jubilant discourses upon the difficulties of the task which the National authorities have before them, and now that its masters over the water have fallen to finding fault, with the stone blockade of Charleston, the Leader will probably, in the course of a few days, awake to a conviction of the barbarous outrage which has been committed.

abstract: Editorial proposes future strategy for war
snippet: Editorial proposes future strategy for war
lead_paragraph: An eminent military authority of this country, has recently prepared some carefully considered strategical views of the campaign, which have been laid before members of Congress, and, we believe, also before the War Department. This gentleman, in opposition to the received opinion, takes the ground, not only that no "Advance from Washington" is intended; but that none ought to be made, if it were practicable. The only results, he states, of Gen. McCELLAN's forcing the rebels from their intrenchmenls, would be the occupation of Richmond -- a barren and unimportant triumph -- and the retreat of the Confederate forces by various roads to the South and Southwest; they at the same time, destroying bridges and railroads behind them and sweeping the country clear of forage and supplies. All that the South would lose by the retreat would be the ground of Virginia, while our armies could not pursue the retreating enemy. Their military power would be unimpraired, and they could soon collect a new army from the heart of their territory. Washington, therefore, he considers the worst feasible base of military operations against the South. "The true military principle," he says, " requires that a base of operations be selected as near as possible to the heart of the enemy's country, and from which the lines of movements upon the decisive points shall be as short as possible." Our object should be to advance immediately, and on such a line as to conduct to the heart of the rebellious States, gaining a position where, with a large army, we can prevent the enemy's forces from concentrating, and can strike them in detail, at the same time cutting the Confederacy in two.

abstract: -- In the Virginia Legislature, on Jan. 25, as we learn from the Richmond Examiner, a Committee of five was appointed "To provide for more effective measures to prevent, the escape of slaves to the enemy." Accepting the Confederate theory on this subject, that the attachment of negroes to their masters is so strong that they cannot be enticed to leave them, the labors of this Committee will be light; that, taking the facts as they are we imagine that Messr. WOODHOUSE, BAKER, COLLBIE, WILSON and MURDOUGH, will soon [???] that they have a difficult task on their hands. It is a matter of historical record that South Carolina planters have found pistols and rifles not sufficiently effective to accomplish the result which these legislators desire to attain. It is a little difficult, therefore, to see what stronger motives than these can be brought to bear upon the obtuse negro, who is so blind to his own interests as to incur the risk of instant death in order to find shelter within the National lines. The report of the Committee will be looked for with interest.

abstract: The steamship Ericsson, attached to the Burnside Expedition, having on board the D'Epineuil Zouaves, arrived at Fortress Monroe on Friday afternoon, being ordered to return there by Gen. BURNSIDE, on account of her inability to cross the ...
lead_paragraph: The steamship Ericsson, attached to the Burnside Expedition, having on board the D'Epineuil Zouaves, arrived at Fortress Monroe on Friday afternoon, being ordered to return there by Gen. BURNSIDE, on account of her inability to cross the bar at Hatteras Inlet. She left the Inlet on Monday, but was driven out to sea by a storm, and thus detained. She reports that at the time she left, the great body of the Expedition was preparing to move to its destination, which was believed to be Roanoke Island. Some of the vessels had already started in that direction. This movement, however, may have been only a ruse, to throw the rebels on the wrong scent. Intelligence received at Fortress Monroe represents that at Norfolk and Richmond the greatest parts prevailed regarding the Expedition, and there is little doubt that before this it has effected a lodgment somewhere. A released National prisoner, who reached Fortress Monroe on Friday, was accompanied by a detective from Richmond to Norfolk, who took the greatest care that no paper should be brought away. They probably contained some information of the Expedition.

abstract: At 6  o'clock yesterday morning a disastrous fire occurred in the Bowery, which resulted in the total destruction of three four-story brick buildings, and one two-story frame building. Several other adjacent buildings were very much damaged before the fire could be extinguished.
lead_paragraph: At 6 o'clock yesterday morning a disastrous fire occurred in the Bowery, which resulted in the total destruction of three four-story brick buildings, and one two-story frame building. Several other adjacent buildings were very much damaged before the fire could be extinguished. The fire originated in the porter-house of HENRY MURPHY No. 280 Bowery. From this building the flames spread with great rapidity to the adjoining buildings, which were occupied as stores and tenement-houses. When the firemen arrived at the spot, nearly all that part of the block on the west side of the Bowery, below Houston-street, was in flames; and this, notwithstanding the fact that the firemen were promptly on hand, and did everything in their power to arrest the progress of the flames. Mr. MURPHY's establishment was reduced to ashes in a short time. His loss on stock is estimated at $1,000. He is insured for $1,500 in City Companies. He occupied a part of the building as a dwelling. Some of his furniture was saved, but it is estimated that $800 worth of it was entirely destroyed. Upon his furniture there was no insurance.

abstract: -- The largest product of pig iron ever made from one blast furnace, was made last week by one of the furnaces at Scranton, Penn. It was three hundred and fifty-six tons, gross weight. The fuel used was Scranton anthracite coal, and the ores chiefly used were from New-Jersey.

abstract: Lectures on zoology at Brooklyn Institute, NYC
snippet: Lectures on zoology at Brooklyn Institute, NYC
lead_paragraph: The first of a series of six lectures was delivered by Prof. AGASSIZ, at the Brooklyn Institute, on Sunday evening, Jan. 19, 1861. The room was filled at an early hour. On the platform appeared Hon EDWARD EVERETT and Rev. Dr. FARLEY, who opened the meeting with prayer. Dr. OLIVER HULL, then stated, for the information of the audience, that these lectures were delivered in accordance with the benevolent intention of Mr. GRAHAM, who left a bequest in his will of $12,000, the interest of which was to be devoted to maintaining an annual course of lectures on "The Power, Wisdom and Goodness of God, as Manifested in His Works." The present was the fourth annual series. Dr. HULL then introduced Prof. AGASSIZ.

abstract: Editorial explains why Great Britain and France are unlikely to intervene
snippet: Editorial explains why Great Britain and France are unlikely to intervene
lead_paragraph: The British Government, eager to interfere in the American quarrel, made the best use of the opportunity afforded by the affair of the Trent. The resentment and jealousy of the British people had been aroused by the indignity offered their flag. There was a valid ground of war. It was impossible, without a powerful and indeed extraordinary reason, to take part with the Pro-Slavery South against the free North. It would never answer for the champions of civilization to become the champions of Slavery. But the Trent business was a direct question with which no difficulty about the odiousness of alliances had to do. Practically, England would be aiding the South; in form, it would be vindicating its own honor, intolerably outraged, against an insolent and an impenitent offender. But the opportunity, thanks to the good sense of the American "mob," and the prudence of the American Government, was destroyed by Mr. SEWARD's dispatch of Dec. 26, and the subsequent redress of other minor complaints of Her Majesty's Government; and, armed to the teeth and ready to strike the blow that should end the American controversy, the British Ministry was suddenly bound over to keep the peace. Not only was the international pretence swept from beneath its feet, but the satisfaction of the British people at escape from a war with their kindred, was too demonstrative to be disregarded.

abstract: The importance of establishing paper mills throughout the South, says the Richmond Examiner, is at once obvious. Thousands upon thousands of dollars invested in printing materials are now lying idle and unproductive for want of paper. No other branch of business in the South has suffered more than the printing business, and that mainly for the want of paper; and this, too, when the manufacture of paper would be the most princely profitable business imaginable. The ends of rope, waste cotton, pieces of bagging, and other articles used in the manufacture of paper, could be procured in quantities sufficient for all purposes, and would be cheerfully and gladly given. Sites would be donated, and doubtless premiums could be obtained by parties wishing to start business, and yet our capitalists, with a stolid indifference which is wonderful, make no move in the matter, and to the cry of paper, which comes from all parts of the South, they remain foolishly indifferent.

abstract: During the month of January the marine disasters were very numerous and heavy in consequence of the severe stormy weather and terrible gales that have prevailed almost incessantly throughout the whole time. Seventy-seven vessels are included in the list of which thirty-seven were foreign, mostly British. The loss of so many foreign vessels is explained by the fact that, on account of the risks of war, neutral vessels have been in great demand for conveying grain to Europe, thus bringing into use many vessels that in time of peace could not get an American [???] to cross the Atlantic. The above number does not include the vessels lost that belonged to the Burnside Expedition.

abstract: The second lecture of the series was given at the Brooklyn Institute on Sunday evening, Jan. 26. The subject of the relative standing or gradation of the animal kingdom, said Prof. A., is one which has ...
lead_paragraph: The second lecture of the series was given at the Brooklyn Institute on Sunday evening, Jan. 26. The subject of the relative standing or gradation of the animal kingdom, said Prof. A., is one which has long engaged the attention of naturalists, and the favorite idea has been that there is an unbroken natural chain from the lowest to the highest -- "from the Monad to Man," as the phrase is. This theoretical view, upon severe and careful scrutiny, has been found to be not true, as stated, but yet the investigation has led to the discovery of an actual gradation within certain limits in different classes of animals. The discovery of the existence of four great plans of structure gave this theory a check, but it has since revived again under the question of the origin of species. Prior to the knowledge of the four plans it was evident to naturalists and philosophers that man was superior to the rest of the animal creation especially in the development of the brain. It was shown by KAEMPFER that the ourang-outang came nearest to man, and the natural conclusion was that there was a gradual descent from air-breathing to aquatic animals, such as whales (erroneously supposed to be fishes,) and thence to gill-breathing fishes. With reference to the lower orders of creation, it seemed unnecessary to pursue the theory which appeared to be so plain among the higher beings; but it was supposed that the same gradation would be found below, and then the bulk of the lower animals were reduced in this view to a few types. Worms were supposed to form some connecting link with snails, eels, and elongated vertebrates; and then shell-fish were erroneously associated with worms, and microscopical animals were considered as mere animal globules capable of sustaining existence. Thus the series was supposed to be established of one unique series from the Monad to Man. But, in attempting to campelt this series, difficulties began to arise, until at lenght the conviction prevailed, that instead of one there were many series; and the question was, what are the limits of those series? It was necessary to consider some of the facts bearing upon the question before proceeding to consider the order and succession in which beings have been introduced upon the earth, For of the two theories now entertained, viz.: Either that all animal species have been developed from the lowest to the highest, one from the other, or that they have all been created as they are. One or the other must be false. And if we have no unique series from the lower to the higher, then the first theory becomes less probable than it otherwise would appear. But the consideration of this question necesarily involves the consideration of the classification of animals, and I will begin with the Vertebrates. Before I proceed at once, however to the question, I may, perhaps, make the nature of the investigation more clear by introducing a comparison from the study of language. Take the common word "father." In the Latin and Greek it is "pater;" in the Italian "padre;" in the German "vater," and in the French "pere." Now a law has been detected by the German philologists, in the gradual transformation of letters, which is as unerring as any other law of nature. It is found that the hard letters have, in the course of time, softened. Thus b, p and ph, which are equal to for v in pronunciation, have succeeded each other very much in the same manner as d, t and th, or as g, k and ch. Thus the Greek and Latin "pater" becomes, in the Gothic, "phthar;" in the Italian "padre;" in the German, "vater," in the French, "pore," and in the English "father." So it is impossible to mistake the genitive connection of these words. And you may carry the investigation still further into the study of animals. It is a sort of etymological science, seeking for the origin of things beyond mere external appearance. Among Vertebrates there are four classes, viz.: Fishes, reptiles, birds and mammals. They stand on the average in that order one above the other. Fishes being the lowest and mammals the highest. For a century no naturalist has doubted that this is their relative order.

abstract: PICKPOCKETS IN A STAGE EXCITING SCENE.. Officers NIXON and GRASSAL of the Thirteenth Precinct, yesterday arrested THOMAS FARLEY and JAMES RADIHAN upon the charge of robbing Mrs. SARAH SIDNEY, of No. 90 Broome-street, of a purse containing a considerable amount of money.
lead_paragraph: PICKPOCKETS IN A STAGE EXCITING SCENE.. Officers NIXON and GRASSAL of the Thirteenth Precinct, yesterday arrested THOMAS FARLEY and JAMES RADIHAN upon the charge of robbing Mrs. SARAH SIDNEY, of No. 90 Broome-street, of a purse containing a considerable amount of money. The thieves sat beside Mrs. SIDNEY in one of the Dry Dock stages, and when they arrived in the neighborhood of Chatham-square, she discovered her loss, and at once gave the alarm. Both of the accused parties pulled the strap and sprang toward the door of the stage, but the lady was too quick for them. She closed the door and held it fast, at the same time crying loudly for the Police. Fortunately, there were a couple of those officials in the immediate vicinity, who came to her relief. In the meantime the culprits alighted from the vehicle, and ran in different directions. Then began a chase of a very exciting character, and to those who witnessed it considerably amusing. RADIHAN threw the lady's purse into an area, as he was running, doubtless hoping thereby to divert the attention of his pursuer for a few moments. They were both soon taken into custody, however, and upon searching them, there were found upon the person of RADIHAN, the sum of $98 folded in small pieces of paper, and concealed in different parts of his clothing. The accused were committed in default of bail.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a petition for the passage of the Metropolitan Health bill was presented. Favorable reports were made on the bill concerning the liabilities of husband and wife ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a petition for the passage of the Metropolitan Health bill was presented. Favorable reports were made on the bill concerning the liabilities of husband and wife and the bill to amend the act for the benefit of married women so as to permit them to insure the lives of their husbands. The financial resolutions passed, on Friday, in the Assembly were received, laid on the table, and ordered to be printed. Notice was given of a bill to compel Insurance Companies to make a speedy settlement with their creditors. The bill to incorporate the Homoeopathic Medical College of New-York was introduced ; also the bill to amend the law relative to the money apportioned to School District Libraries. The bill relating to the Agents of Foreign Insurance Companies doing business in the State was passed. The resolutions, instructing Senators HARRIS and KING to vote for the expulsion of Mr. BRIGHT, were then considered until the adjournment, which was made until Monday evening.

abstract: -- We commend the Journal of Commerce editors to a careful study of a series of recent articles in its own columns on the power of the Government to regulate the currency of the country, and to support its own Treasury through the trial of War. From the signature to these communications, "G.B.B.," we presume the writer to be a gentleman of practical business sagacity, who was more intimately connected with the Journal in its better days. He was never known, we believe, to attempt to controvert the argument of a neighbor, and close by yielding the main fact. The present editors deny that the notes of the Bank of England are now a legal tender, unless the Bank pays coin on demand, which in time of peace it is well enabled to do. But they add that "the Notes were made an ABSOLUTE ender during the Napoleonic wars." An admission significant enough for our purpose, surely.

abstract: -- Not to mention the great battle on the Potomac, which, in popular belief, is now, as it has been any time the last year, "impending," nor the general engagement which is imminent at Bowling Green, there are a number of smaller fights certainly on the tapis, and of which we may have news any day this week. The public look first, of course, for news from Gen. BURN SIDE. Has that gallant man, after weathering the terrific storm, landed his forces on some part of the secession coast, assaulted some rebel town or fortification, and captured it amid a blaze of glory like unto that in which the forts at Hilton Head were captured? -- Further South than the supposed scene of BURNSIDE's operations, a battle seemed impending, at latest rebel accounts, somewhere in the vicinity of Savannah. Our fleet, if the rebels may be credited, had got "in the rear" of Fort Pulaski, and were apparently on the eve of extending their operations inland. It is certainly to be hoped that they did so. In the southern part of Missouri a pretty heavy light is now daily impending. PRICE claims in have ten thousand rebels at Springfield, and certain it is that a good many more than ten thousand Union troops are now every day getting nearer and nearer to that rebel headquarters. Looking at the point at which our forces were when last beard from, it seems likely enough that, they may be within striking distance of Springfield this week. It is shrewdly suspected by some, that we are likely again to be surprised by some handsome little affair in Kentucky within a very short while -- this same, however, in the western part of the State. A strong body of troops, not long ago, left Paducuh for somewhere, and, at latest accounts, bad not been heard from; and the rebels at Paris, Tenn., were so afraid that the expedition is bound for that town, that they were panic-stricken, and were hurrying their negroes southward with all possible speed, it was to be hoped that there was ground for a rebel panic. It has seemed for some time that, a battle was impending somewhere in the neighborhood of Romney or Winchester, in Virginia. The rebel JACKSON, with a force estimated at from ten to twice-ten thousand men, has been actively flitting about there for the past fortnight; and Gens. LANDER and ROSECRANS are "threatening" him; and as Gen. BANKS has an immense force not, a hundred miles off, it is hard to see why there should not be, if there is not, a battle impending with the audacious rebels. There appears every probability that, during the week of which this is the first day, we shall have news of battles at more than one of the points mentioned, and perhaps at some other points unsuspected. May they all prove as glorious triumphs to our arms as the two last battles recorded in our columns.
lead_paragraph: -- Not to mention the great battle on the Potomac, which, in popular belief, is now, as it has been any time the last year, "impending," nor the general engagement which is imminent at Bowling Green, there are a number of smaller fights certainly on the tapis, and of which we may have news any day this week. The public look first, of course, for news from Gen. BURN SIDE. Has that gallant man, after weathering the terrific storm, landed his forces on some part of the secession coast, assaulted some rebel town or fortification, and captured it amid a blaze of glory like unto that in which the forts at Hilton Head were captured? -- Further South than the supposed scene of BURNSIDE's operations, a battle seemed impending, at latest rebel accounts, somewhere in the vicinity of Savannah. Our fleet, if the rebels may be credited, had got "in the rear" of Fort Pulaski, and were apparently on the eve of extending their operations inland. It is certainly to be hoped that they did so. In the southern part of Missouri a pretty heavy light is now daily impending. PRICE claims in have ten thousand rebels at Springfield, and certain it is that a good many more than ten thousand Union troops are now every day getting nearer and nearer to that rebel headquarters. Looking at the point at which our forces were when last beard from, it seems likely enough that, they may be within striking distance of Springfield this week. It is shrewdly suspected by some, that we are likely again to be surprised by some handsome little affair in Kentucky within a very short while -- this same, however, in the western part of the State. A strong body of troops, not long ago, left Paducuh for somewhere, and, at latest accounts, bad not been heard from; and the rebels at Paris, Tenn., were so afraid that the expedition is bound for that town, that they were panic-stricken, and were hurrying their negroes southward with all possible speed, it was to be hoped that there was ground for a rebel panic. It has seemed for some time that, a battle was impending somewhere in the neighborhood of Romney or Winchester, in Virginia. The rebel JACKSON, with a force estimated at from ten to twice-ten thousand men, has been actively flitting about there for the past fortnight; and Gens. LANDER and ROSECRANS are "threatening" him; and as Gen. BANKS has an immense force not, a hundred miles off, it is hard to see why there should not be, if there is not, a battle impending with the audacious rebels. There appears every probability that, during the week of which this is the first day, we shall have news of battles at more than one of the points mentioned, and perhaps at some other points unsuspected. May they all prove as glorious triumphs to our arms as the two last battles recorded in our columns.
headline: {'main': 'IMPENDING BATTLES.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'IMPENDING BATTLES.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: On Friday morning last JOHN CANFIELD, stevedore, left his residence in Rapelyea-street, Red Hook Point, to go to his business in New-York, and was expected home that night. He did not return, ...
lead_paragraph: On Friday morning last JOHN CANFIELD, stevedore, left his residence in Rapelyea-street, Red Hook Point, to go to his business in New-York, and was expected home that night. He did not return, and the latest tidings of him that could be obtained were brought to light by a woman named ELIZABETH SCHOONMAKER attempting to sell a watch belonging to deceased, which was identified by the person to whom she offered the watch for sale, and he, knowing that CANFIELD had mysteriously disappeared, caused her arrest. Subsequently, TIMOTHEUS VOLZ, a boarder at Mrs. SCHOONMAKER's, was also arrested on suspicion of knowing something about the matter.

abstract: Editorial on British objections to stone blockade; cites past British use of same method
snippet: Editorial on British objections to stone blockade; cites past British use of same method
lead_paragraph: The eloquent denunciations of the London journals against the stone blockade are seriously marred by the discovery they are beginning to make that this device, far from being a "republican innovation," as they rashly styled it, with a chuckle, is a genuine old trick of John Bull himself. Our late London files contain communications from correspondents of an antiquarian turn of mind, detailing various cases of the kind they have turned up in the course of their reading, and proving that England has repeatedly practiced the sinking of stone-laden vessels as a means of obstructing an enemy's ports. We have already cited in these columns several of the instances mentioned by the London correspondents, but there are two now cases quoted that are new and particularly pat. The first is the case of Alexandria. On the evacuation of the city and port, and the embarkation of the British troops, in 1807 five vessels laden with stone were sunk in the narrow passage by which the English squadron, under command of Admiral LEWIS had entered, and then sailed, concluding that it would be the last exit of any vessel from the port -- erroneously, however, as has subsequently appeared. The other instance is the choking up of the entrance of Doulogne harbor in 1804, and the following piece of diplomatic correspondence in the matter has a great historic interest. It is the official letter of instructions from Lord HOBART to "Sir A.S. HAMMOND, Controller of the Navy:
headline: {'main': 'Stone Blockades in English History.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Stone Blockades in English History.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- For one thing, at least the rebels is deserve credit -- their skill in torturing to death loyal citizens whom they dare not hang. Some weeks ago Judge PICKINS, of Knoxville, Tenn., was arrested because he would not swear allegiance to JEFF. DAVIS and his confederates. His wife and daughter soon afterward sunk into their graves under the pressure of their great grief and anxiety, and the Knoxville Register, of Jan. 15, states that the Judge himself died a few days since, while being transferred from Tuscaloosa, where he had been held as a prisoner of war to Mobile. How many removals were needed to dispose of this sturdy patriot the Register does not state.

abstract: It affords us pleasure to publish in another column a well-timed letter, from Mr. GEORGE OPDYEE to the Secretary of the Treasury, on the use of a National circulation for the financial ...
lead_paragraph: It affords us pleasure to publish in another column a well-timed letter, from Mr. GEORGE OPDYEE to the Secretary of the Treasury, on the use of a National circulation for the financial emergencies of the war. In times past we have had occasion to differ with Mr. OPDYKE on his theory of a Bullion Bank. But whatever he may have said or argue in favor of such a theory in a season of profound peace, it is quite evident that he has postponed his peculiar views to a more auspicious time than the present, and we heartily command his good sense and patriotism for it. The present letter is especially useful in pointing out the practical advantages of a National Circulation of $150,000,000, over the exclusive use of interest hearing Treasury Bonds, to he left to the mercy of the open market, or the other alternative of paying out to the public creditors the twenty-years' stocks of the Government, which would inevitably become more seriously depreciated in market value.
headline: {'main': 'Our Bankers on United States Currency.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Our Bankers on United States Currency.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Mr. MASON's bill, introduced on Saturday, provides that no securities, contracts or obligations, negotiable or others, not secured on real estate, nor for a less amount or value than $250, to be hereafter made, and to be paid or performed within four months from the issuing or making thereof, shall be subjected to the prohibitions, nullities, forfeitures, penalties or disabilities of the laws of this State relating to the interest of money; Provided, however, that contracts made by or with any banks or association for the purpose of banking, shall be excepted from the provisions of this act.

abstract: Advices from Vera Cruz, to the 6th of January, are received by the arrival at this port of the brig E. Baldwin -- not so late, however, as previously received. The combined fleet of the Allies consisted of about thirty vessels. About seven thousand Spanish soldiers had been landed, but no French or English. A few shots had been fired at the pickets outside the city, but no fighting had taken place, as the Spaniards had made no effort to advance. The Spaniards in the interior were leaving rapidly, and a ship-load of them had been sent to Havana. No business whatever was being done at Vera Cruz, as all the Mexican merchants had left.
lead_paragraph: Advices from Vera Cruz, to the 6th of January, are received by the arrival at this port of the brig E. Baldwin -- not so late, however, as previously received. The combined fleet of the Allies consisted of about thirty vessels. About seven thousand Spanish soldiers had been landed, but no French or English. A few shots had been fired at the pickets outside the city, but no fighting had taken place, as the Spaniards had made no effort to advance. The Spaniards in the interior were leaving rapidly, and a ship-load of them had been sent to Havana. No business whatever was being done at Vera Cruz, as all the Mexican merchants had left.

abstract: -- We learn from an authentic source at Washington that the panic in our Stock market on Saturday, growing out of the Africa's news, is wholly unauthorized by the nature of the very friendly dispatches from abroad received at the State Department by the same, arrival. The intervention articles in some of the English papers are believed to be the mere inspiration of the secession emissaries in London and Paris.

abstract: The Boston Journal says: "We know of a case of an industrious firm in Texas, who had a store filled with goods of the value of twenty thousand dollars, which was all taken from them. In another case, the head of a family remained at the South, while the mother and daughter came North. Communication was interrupted, funds failed to reach the unfortunate females, poverty followed with rapid pace, the mother sickened and died, while the daughter is now an inmate of an insane asylum.

abstract: THE STORM. -- The snow storm of Friday morning caused a slight delay in the arrival of some of the trains on the New Jersey road. On the New-York and Erie road, beyond Sufferns, the snow fell to a depth of about two feet, and some of the trains on Saturday night came in about three hours behind time. The sleighing on the roads leading from Jersey City was in excellent condition yesterday, and the livery-stable keepers were unable to supply the demands made upon them for vehicles.

abstract: A very large assemblage was gathered last evening in the Collegiate Church, corner of Twenty-ninth-street and Fifth-avenue, the object being to hear addresses from eminent Divines, upon the necessity of providing for the religious necessities of the army, by furnishing the troops with tracts and reading generally of a religious character. Similar meetings for the same purpose have been held by other denominations in the City, and in every case the response has been not more prompt than liberal.

abstract: Mr. GRAU'S highly successful season of opera will terminate on Friday next; this brevity being rendered necessary by reason of the approaching concerts of Mr. GOTTSCHALK, for which all the leading artists of the opera have been engaged. To-night "La Traviata" will be given for the last time, with Miss KELLOGG in the role of Violetta. A new baritone, of whom report speaks highly--Signor YPOLITO--will make his debut in the role of Germont.

abstract: To the People of Kentucky:  When the present war between the Confederate States and the United States commenced, the State of Kentucky determined to remain neutral. abstract: Mrs. FRY, wife of the gallant Col. S.S. FRY, of the Fourth Kentucky Regiment, received a letter at Danville, Ky., on Friday last, from Col. F., written after the battle near Somerset. He details in the letter the manner in which he killed Gen. ZOLLICOFFER, which varies somewhat from the many statements we have seen. Col. FRY was in the act of leading his regiment into a charge upon the Mississippians, when Gen. ZOLLICOFFER, accompanied by his aid, rode up to him and said, "You are not going to fight your friends, are you? These men (pointing to the Mississippians) are all your friends." In the meantime ZOLLICOFFER's aid fired upon Col. FRY, wounding his horse, from which wound the animal died. Col. FRY then turned and fired upon ZOLLICOFFER with fatal effect. Gen. Z. evidently labored under the impression that Col. FRY was a rebel officer. The stories about the old intimacy of the two officers are all untrue. They had never met before, nor did Col. FRY know the rank of the officer upon whom he fired, as the evidences of his rank were covered by a cloak which Gen. ZOLLICOFFER wore in battle.
lead_paragraph: Mrs. FRY, wife of the gallant Col. S.S. FRY, of the Fourth Kentucky Regiment, received a letter at Danville, Ky., on Friday last, from Col. F., written after the battle near Somerset. abstract: There were a few applicants at the General Service recruiting offices last week, of whom four were enlisted, and the rest rejected, on examination by the Surgeon, who, very property, will not pass any man who does not appear likely to stand the fatigue ...
lead_paragraph: There were a few applicants at the General Service recruiting offices last week, of whom four were enlisted, and the rest rejected, on examination by the Surgeon, who, very property, will not pass any man who does not appear likely to stand the fatigue and hardship incident to active service. About fourteen men were enlisted for the Fifth Artillery, the Corps of Engineers, and the Eighth, Eleventh and Twelfth Infantry. Several boys were sent to Governor's Island on trial, to learn the fife and drum. The company of music boys, who are quartered in the South Battery, now numbers about one hundred and twelve enlisted, and fifteen on trial. Twenty-eight more will have to be enlisted before the company reaches the strength fixed by the War Department. During the whole of the Winter the sleeping accommodations provided for the citizen boys on trial, have been of the worst description. The South Battery was not large enough for the number of boys on the Island, and the ten-pin-alley, a long, low, wooden structure, was set apart as a dormitory for the boys on trial, and such of the enlisted boys as could not find room in the battery. The citizen boys were not provided with even one blanket, and those who were not fortunate enough to obtain a share of the other boys' blankets, had to sleep without any other covering than their ordinary clothes. There was only one serviceable stove in the ten-pin-alley, and the place was infested with rats; the comfort of sleeping there may therefore be easily imagined. It is only right to say, that the Sergeant in charge of the boys -- an old soldier of thirty-five years' experience -- is not responsible for this state of things; but it is also only right that attention should be called to it, and that boys who are sent on trial should be treated with some little consideration.

abstract: A.T. TRALL, M.D., the founder of the New-York Hydropathic Institute and Hygeio-Therapeutic College, announces a course of lectures in Washington City, commencing on Tuesday evening, Feb. 4 1862, in favor of the Hygienic and against the Drug Medical system. He promises to demonstrate to the satisfaction of all unprejudiced minds, by facts, logic, experience, and all the data applicable to the issue, that the mortality in our army of typhoid fever, pneumonia, measles, &c., is wholly unnecessary, and that the system of medication which he teaches would save the lives of thousands of our officers and soldiers; and he announces his willingness to explain his positions in the halls of Congress, and defend them against all criticisms and objections from whatever source. Let him be heard.
lead_paragraph: A.T. TRALL, M.D., the founder of the New-York Hydropathic Institute and Hygeio-Therapeutic College, announces a course of lectures in Washington City, commencing on Tuesday evening, Feb. 4 1862, in favor of the Hygienic and against the Drug Medical system. He promises to demonstrate to the satisfaction of all unprejudiced minds, by facts, logic, experience, and all the data applicable to the issue, that the mortality in our army of typhoid fever, pneumonia, measles, &c., is wholly unnecessary, and that the system of medication which he teaches would save the lives of thousands of our officers and soldiers; and he announces his willingness to explain his positions in the halls of Congress, and defend them against all criticisms and objections from whatever source. Let him be heard.

abstract: The "Alpine Musical Association," conducted by Prof. MARCUS COLBURN, paid a handsome tribute to the Warren Rifles, on Friday evening last. About twenty-five of the ladies and gentlemen of the Association visited the regiment at the Red House, Harlem, and spent nearly two hours in singing some of our finest patriotic melodies. Col. BIDDLE, with nearly all the officers, were present, and the men in full force, crowding the barracks to its utmost capacity. Towards the close of the entertainment the men, in full chorus, sang on army song, after which one of the gentlemen made a brief farewell address to the regiment, which was appropriately responded to by Col. BIDDLE, who returned thanks to the ladies and gentlemen for their courtesy and their kindness.
lead_paragraph: The "Alpine Musical Association," conducted by Prof. MARCUS COLBURN, paid a handsome tribute to the Warren Rifles, on Friday evening last. abstract: A portion of an interesting correspondence between a Boston merchant and Major VINTON, of the Quartermaster's Department, of New-York, appears in Saturday's Boston Commercial Bulletin. It appears that the Boston merchant addressed a note to Gen. ...
lead_paragraph: A portion of an interesting correspondence between a Boston merchant and Major VINTON, of the Quartermaster's Department, of New-York, appears in Saturday's Boston Commercial Bulletin. It appears that the Boston merchant addressed a note to Gen. MEIGS, suggesting the importance of having in the Quartermaster's Department some one who is acquainted with the manufacture of army cloth in all stages, intimating that if this was not done, the Government would be severely taken in, as the proposals advertised were defective. Gen. MEIGS courteously referred the letter to Major D.H. VINTON, Quartermaster in New-York, who is charged with providing clothing and material for making it, for the army. Major VINTON replied with some acrimony, as will be seen by the following extract:

abstract: -- The determination of the Government to effect a general exchange of prisoners will give hardly less satisfaction to the public than an announcement of an immediate advance upon the enemy at all points. The prolonged imprisonment of more than a thousand brave men, who did not run away from Bull Run, has brought grief to numberless firesides, and through months of suspense families and friends have awaited impatiently some action on the part of Government affording a hope that the prisoners should be restored to their duty if not to their households. Economists have measured the cost not only of supporting a legion of rebel prisoners here at the North, but of providing for the maintenance of our own brave fellows in Southern prisons, and of their deserted families. Especially grievous has been the case of the officers, whom the rebel Government selected as hostages for the safety of the privateersmen in our custody. With their fate uncertain, while their actual condition was one of peculiar privation, they might justly yield to despondency, in view of the avowed resolution of the Government to treat the men on whose lives their own depended as pirates and felons, rather than as prisoners of war. The reversal of this determination must be of itself a profound relief.

abstract: We doubt if any other locality in the country can present a more dismal and uncomfortable picture of wretchedness than is exhibited at the present time throughout the realm of Chickamoxen and adjacent townships. abstract: BOOKS FOR THE NEWSBOYS.--Our little friends the newsboys of the Rome, No. 128 Fulton-street, are fond of reading, and they have favorite authors. Their library, it is to be regretted, contains few of the works of these, and some of the few, including the pictorial lives of WASHINGTON and ABBOT's Napoleon, ...
lead_paragraph: BOOKS FOR THE NEWSBOYS.--Our little friends the newsboys of the Rome, No. 128 Fulton-street, are fond of reading, and they have favorite authors. Their library, it is to be regretted, contains few of the works of these, and some of the few, including the pictorial lives of WASHINGTON and ABBOT's Napoleon, have been fairly used up in perusal. If the benevolent desirous of the mental improvement of these worthy lads would send them some books by MAYNE REID, MARRYAT, DICKENS or Peter Parley, they would be gratefully welcomed. They are quite partial to works of travel. The works of Dr. BARTH, CHAILLU, of gorilla fame, or of Dr. LIVINGSTONE, would be received with special applause and favor.

abstract: -- The business of withdrawing troops from Manassas, where they are not wanted, to Kentucky, where they are wanted, is already begun by the rebel leaders. Gen. BEAUREGARD, we are told, in leaving for his new command in Western Kentucky, took with him fifteen thousand men. This depletion of the rebel force on the Potomac, at the very moment when the expiration of the term of enlistment is about to diminish their numbers still more seriously, will no doubt suggest to our General-in-Chief, if not the possibility of annihilating the mere fragment of an army in front of his lines, the propriety of transferring a large body of his troops, no longer needed for the defence of the Capital, to the seat of war in the West.

abstract: The Fortress Monroe correspondent of the Philadelphia Inquirer says:  "On the 15th instant the steamers blockading the Rappahannock River observed a schooner standing out of Thompson's Creek, about a mile and a half from the mouth of the river, and standing up the river, as if to make away from the gunboats, keeping close to the shore. lead_paragraph: The Fortress Monroe correspondent of the Philadelphia Inquirer says: "On the 15th instant the steamers blockading the Rappahannock River observed a schooner standing out of Thompson's Creek, about a mile and a half from the mouth of the river, and standing up the river, as if to make away from the gunboats, keeping close to the shore. The Mystic was ordered to give chase, and succeeded in beaching the schooner, when the crew of the latter vessel deserted her and made the shore in safety.

snippet: Editorial on current efforts to establish legalized national currency; editorial on efforts being made in Congress to expel Bright; editorial on efforts in progress to establish legalized national currency
lead_paragraph: The parties who have raised the issue with the Government of the right and policy of making the United States Notes a uniform tender, by authority of law, will perhaps soon learn, from the highest financial source in the Administration, that, but for their own efforts to discredit the Demand Notes of the United States without this feature, no such exercise of law might have been deemed necessary. The reluctance of Mr. CHASE to making anything but Gold and Silver a legal tender in the payment of debts, under any ordinary circumstances, is well known to his friends and to the Finance Committees of Congress.

abstract: -- There can be no doubt that the object of the naval movements and operations at the mouth of the Savannah River, reported to us by the rebels, is to prepare the way for the capture of the City of Savannah. There are two ways of reaching the city by water -- one by going directly up the Savannah River, which route is strongly defended by Fort Pulaski, and the other by threading round the waterway, between the islands in the rear of Fort Pulaski, and emerging into the river above the fort, or else by landing at the hamlet of Bonaventure, and marching thence to the city without entering the Savannah River at all -- the latter of which routes would be quite impracticable from the fact that the road passes through a swampy country, and might be easily defended by a few guns. The rebels had these inland waterways defended by batteries -- one on Wilmington Island, of whose operations in throwing shells at our force on Tybee Island we have occasionally heard, and one on Augustine Creek, to the south. Obstructions, somewhat like our stone-fleet, which so offends the London Times, had also been placed in the channel by the rebels; and with these various defences, the Savanese thought their town unapproachable by our ships. But it would seem that our forces had gone to work and cleared a passage for the gunboats up the very best way that could be selected. By the rebel admission, that we hold possession of the north end of Wilmington Island, it would appear that the shelling of the island by our fleet, which they mention, had been successful in reducing the works upon it; and by their admission that "the Yankees were engaged in removing the obstructions from the channel," it appears that our operations were proceeding unmolested. These operations can of course lead to but one point -- Savannah. The reported cutting -- off of Fort Pulaski from the city is of value as a means of reducing that fort; but, as the city can probably be captured at once, while the reduction of the fort would be a matter of time, it is altogether likely that our success in these preliminary operations, will be speedily followed by the capture of the city.
lead_paragraph: -- There can be no doubt that the object of the naval movements and operations at the mouth of the Savannah River, reported to us by the rebels, is to prepare the way for the capture of the City of Savannah. There are two ways of reaching the city by water -- one by going directly up the Savannah River, which route is strongly defended by Fort Pulaski, and the other by threading round the waterway, between the islands in the rear of Fort Pulaski, and emerging into the river above the fort, or else by landing at the hamlet of Bonaventure, and marching thence to the city without entering the Savannah River at all -- the latter of which routes would be quite impracticable from the fact that the road passes through a swampy country, and might be easily defended by a few guns. The rebels had these inland waterways defended by batteries -- one on Wilmington Island, of whose operations in throwing shells at our force on Tybee Island we have occasionally heard, and one on Augustine Creek, to the south. Obstructions, somewhat like our stone-fleet, which so offends the London Times, had also been placed in the channel by the rebels; and with these various defences, the Savanese thought their town unapproachable by our ships. But it would seem that our forces had gone to work and cleared a passage for the gunboats up the very best way that could be selected. By the rebel admission, that we hold possession of the north end of Wilmington Island, it would appear that the shelling of the island by our fleet, which they mention, had been successful in reducing the works upon it; and by their admission that "the Yankees were engaged in removing the obstructions from the channel," it appears that our operations were proceeding unmolested. abstract: Arriving by the best approach, which is the Eighth-avenue Railroad, the visitor is "set down" at a very inviting gateway, (providing he is romantically inclined.) and passing the roughly-hewn portal, perceives," not the breath of cows," but the yet suggestive ...
lead_paragraph: Arriving by the best approach, which is the Eighth-avenue Railroad, the visitor is "set down" at a very inviting gateway, (providing he is romantically inclined.) and passing the roughly-hewn portal, perceives," not the breath of cows," but the yet suggestive aroma of stable, which, viewed as a hygienic feature, is not objectionable; and, after overcoming certain neck and ankle jeopardizing obstacles in the way of planks laid at misapplied angles, he finds himself fairly "at sea" in the bleak expanse just now so strictly affected by the beauty and fashion of the Metropolis, because it is the fashion. It is a severer task than the Flora McFlimsey sisterhood would ever be induced to undertake -- this equipping for the boyish exercise of skaking -- were it not absolutely an edict of Queen Fashion.

abstract: DIVEN, a member of Congress from this State, in a letter written for publication, and which will be found in another column, says that the President stated the other day in his presence that there was probably but one man in the country more anxious for a battle than himself, and that man was McClellan.
lead_paragraph: -- The Hon. Mr. DIVEN, a member of Congress from this State, in a letter written for publication, and which will be found in another column, says that the President stated the other day in his presence that there was probably but one man in the country more anxious for a battle than himself, and that man was McClellan. "The President repudiated, in words of withering rebuke, the charge that he, or Mr. SEWARD, or Gen. MCCLELLAN, were tampering or delaying, out of any consideration for rebels or rebel institutions, or that they indulged any thought of ending the war by any means other than conquest on the battle-field." The first of these statements is particularly gratifying at this moment, when the nation feels somewhat impatient and disheartened at the long inaction of our mighty army on the Potomac; and in his theory of the means and mode of ending the war, also, the President shows that his convictions are in accord with those of the entire country. The masterly inactivity which some have represented as the fixed policy of the General Commanding, is thus authentically repudiated; and the charge of trifling or playing with so monstrous a thing as this rebellion, on the part of the responsible conservatives of the Government, is put at rest by the President himself. He knows, as well as any one else, that nothing but hard, sharp, quick, overwhelming blows against this rebellion will ever restore unity or peace to the nation; and with him in this opinion the Cabinet and the Generals whom he has appointed entirely agree. Having this belief, there can be no doubt that the blows will be dealt as soon as it is possible to deal them. Those semi-Secessionists who abuse Congress, and the Press, and the army, and the great body of the people, for their strong desire for active operations, should turn their criticism upon the President and the General-in-Chief command; for there is but one man in the country more anxious for a battle than the President, and that man is Gen. MCCLELLAN.

abstract: The Harrisburgh correspondent of the Philadelphia North American writes:  "The Governor has made a request to the War Department, after the consolidation of the various infantry regiments is completed, that this force shall be formed into a division embracing all three of the arms of the service, like the McCall Division, composed entirely of Pennsylvanians. I like the idea very much.

abstract: Nobody will be incurably afflicted to learn that the discussion of Senator BRIGHT'S loyalty is drawing to an end. There has been little doubt on the public mind at any moment of the Senator's secret sympathies with the rebellion. The letter of last Spring, introducing Mr. LINCOLN to President DAVIS as a cunning ...
lead_paragraph: Nobody will be incurably afflicted to learn that the discussion of Senator BRIGHT'S loyalty is drawing to an end. There has been little doubt on the public mind at any moment of the Senator's secret sympathies with the rebellion. The letter of last Spring, introducing Mr. LINCOLN to President DAVIS as a cunning artificer of fire-arms, added no depth to the popular impression of his disloyalty. It was not needed to satisfy anybody that had accident made him a citizen of Kentucky instead of Indiana, he would have followed openly the fortunes of BRECKINRIDGE. But accident has prevented any such rashness, and necessity, if nothing else, has led the Senator to profess the most fervent fidelity to Law and Constitution, and his fellow-committeemen attest the zeal with which he promotes every measure tributary to the suppression of the rebellion. The case may therefore be treated, so far as the simple question of loyalty is concerned, as admirably balanced. BRIGHT once inclined to the side of treason, and should, therefore, be unseated; he has since remained nominally faithful, and should, therefore, hold his place. And in this equilibrium of argument the Senate may well hesitate at a decision.
headline: {'main': 'The Case of Senator Bright.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Case of Senator Bright.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Editorial on possible re-enlistment of Confederate soldiers whose terms of duty are about to expire
snippet: Editorial on possible re-enlistment of Confederate soldiers whose terms of duty are about to expire
lead_paragraph: The strength of JEFF. DAVIS' Government will be put to a severe strain this month during which the term of enlistment of a considerable proportion of the men now in the Confederate camps will expire. The rebel leaders, accordingly, are looking with some trepidation to the chances of inducing them to reenlist, or, failing in that, to the means of raising another levy for their army as numerous as that which they have had in the field for some months past. It is a somewhat complex question, and depends in great measure on our own action what solution it shall receive. We are very far from sharing the illusion of some that the Southern army is destined to "melt like snow" at the expiration of the term of enlistment, and yet there is not the smallest doubt that we can give things such a turn as to make the raising of another Southern army an impossibility. The rebel leaders themselves are not without serious apprehensions. "It were foolhardy and unwise," says the Memphis Appeal of the 16th of January "to conceal the fact that the profoundest statesmen in the Confederacy entertain great apprehensions on the subject of reenlistment, involving, as we believe, results pregnant with weal or woe to the Confederacy." It seems, however, that, to begin with, they are going to try the persuasive power of eloquence -- in which the South has always had immense faith. Accordingly, the Southern journals are just now filled with eloquent "Appeals," a number of which we published yesterday, calling on the troops to reenlist, and couched in the extraordinary language which Southern journals are fond of employing. "When the necessities of the Government become known," exclaims a Richmond journal, "and the fact is understood that their country now appeals to them for their services as sole conservators of the national ark that has been rescued from the polluting hands of a Vandal enemy, will our volunteer soldiers [???] to respond? "Twere a base calumny [???] patriotism, if it is not high treason, to [???] the suspicion that they would not." And yet it is perfectly obvious that the suspicion is "harbored." It is in the same spirit that the Virginia Legislature has lately passed a resolution stating that they "do not doubt the readiness of the Virginia volunteers to continue their present organization, when assured that this further sacrifice for their country is earnestly desired by the General Assembly to aid in repulsing our insolent invader," &c., &c.; but, at the same time, prudently adding a clause demanding that they shall reenlist. The seductive power of eloquence is also tried directly on the army, and the Southern camps resound with clangorous appeals from the commanders to their soldiers, couched in such ludicrous terms as to give one a strange impression of the men to whom such hortations can be seriously addressed. Judging from the fortune of Gen. BRAGG, however, the success of these martial monitions is not very promising. His "appeal" was of the very highest pressure, and yet he has been compelled to give up the best of his troops from their disinclination to reenlist.

abstract: In the Senate, Saturday, a petition for the passage of the Metropolitan Health bill was presented. Favorable reports were made on the bill concerning the liabilities of husband and wife, and the bill to amend the act for the benefit of married women so as to permit them to insure the lives of their husbands.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, Saturday, a petition for the passage of the Metropolitan Health bill was presented. Favorable reports were made on the bill concerning the liabilities of husband and wife, and the bill to amend the act for the benefit of married women so as to permit them to insure the lives of their husbands. The financial resolution passed, on Friday, in the Assembly were received, laid on the table, and ordered to be printed. Notice was given of a bill to compel Insurance Companies to make a speedy settlement with their creditors. The bill to incorporate the Homoeopathic Medical College of New-York was introduced; also the bill to amend the law relative to the money apportioned to School District Libraries. The bill relating to the Agents of Foreign Insurance Companies doing business in the State was passed. The resolutions, instructing Senators HARRIS and KING to vote for the expulsion of Mr. BRIGHT, were then considered until the adjournment, which was made until Monday evening.

abstract: Editorial on attitudes in France
snippet: Editorial on attitudes in France
lead_paragraph: The letter published in the TIMES of Tuesday, from "A Frenchman," stated clearly, and we believe correctly, the present feeling in Paris, and therefore in France, toward this country. France lends a willing ear to the representations of the rebel agents, and she does so because, first, in case of a war between France and Great Britain, she supposes the sympathies of America would be with the mother-country, and that in case of a successful invasion by French forces, we should not be able to "resist the appeal made by old England in distress," and next because France conceives it to be her interest to divide the Republic, for the chance of finding an ally, and the certainty of securing a customer, in one of its fragments. All that we learn of what is going on in Paris confirms this view of the French appreciation of the relative position of the two countries.

abstract: THE BODY BROUGHT TO THIS CITY--THE INQUEST. The remains of MICHAEL NOLAN, of the Naval Brigade, who was killed at Fortress Monroe, on the 29th of January, by a fellow soldier named McMANN, were brought to this City on Saturday, and delivered ...
lead_paragraph: THE BODY BROUGHT TO THIS CITY--THE INQUEST. The remains of MICHAEL NOLAN, of the Naval Brigade, who was killed at Fortress Monroe, on the 29th of January, by a fellow soldier named McMANN, were brought to this City on Saturday, and delivered to his friends. Coroner NORRIS was notified, and he held an inquest on the body yesterday, at the house of Mrs. ANN BRENNAN, No. 90 Duffield-street. The only witness examined was Dr. DANIEL AYRES, who made a post mortem examination, and testified that death was caused by a gun-shot wound, the ball having passed through the liver, and also breaking the eleventh and twelfth ribs. A verdict in accordance with these facts was rendered. The deceased formerly resided in this City, and has several sisters and brothers here now. He was twenty-one years of age. The following letter received by Mr. FRANK CLAVEL, gives the particulars relative to the murder:
