abstract: United States Supreme Court last week decided anothercase that for some time attracted considerablelocal attention In this State -- the case of JOHN D. HAGER,formerly of New Brunswick, against. E.A. STEVENS, R.F. STOCKTON and others. The plainths was astockholder in the old Transportation Companyknown as the Napoleon Company, which had someconnection with the Camden and Amboy RailroadCo. for a number of years. After selling out thisstock to the Company at a large advance, HAGER attemptedto have a new account taken of its businesstransactions, and a restatement made of the value ofhis stock, on an allegation that he had been deceived,misled, &c. The Circuit Court having dismissed hisbill, a year or two since, with some pretty severe remarksupon the course he had taken in pursuit ofmore money from the defendants, he appealed to theSupreme Court, and the case was argued a few weekssince by S.B. RANBOM and REVERDY JOHNSON for theappellant, and J.P. BRADLEY for the respondents.We understand the decree of Judge GRIER has beenunanimously affirmed, with costs. -- Newark Advertiser,Feb. 1.

abstract: The announcement, made last month, that the Cabinet at Washington had telegraphed permission for the British troops, then on their way to Canada, to land at Portland, Maine, and go forward by the Grand Trunk Railroad, seems to have been specially distasteful to the Senate of Maine. Accordingly that body instructed...
lead_paragraph: The announcement, made last month, that the Cabinet at Washington had telegraphed permission for the British troops, then on their way to Canada, to land at Portland, Maine, and go forward by the Grand Trunk Railroad, seems to have been specially distasteful to the Senate of Maine. Accordingly that body instructed Gov. WASHBURNE to open a correspondence with Secretary SEWARD, for the purpose of ascertaining the exact truth in the matter. This correspondence, though relating to a question which has itself grown obsolete, has yet an intrinsic historical interest, and it will be found in full elsewhere. To the inquiry of Gov. WASHBURNE, Mr. SEWARD answers in the affirmative, and states that, he was influenced in the matter by the consideration that much suffering and risk, through the snow and ice of a Northerly Canadian voyage, might he spared the troops by allowing them to pass through the territory of the United States by that line of railway communication which British enterprise has extended to the fine seaport of Portland. The principle upon which this concession was made to Great Britain is, that "when humanity, or even convenience, renders it desirable for one nation to have a passage of its troops and munitions through the territory of another, it is a customary act of comity to grant it, if it can be done consistently with its own safety and welfare." And he cites as a parallel instance the privilege which the United States continually enjoy of transporting troops upon the Panama Railroad, across the territory of the Republic of New-Granada. To have withheld, at this time, an act of comity which would have been cheerfully granted at any other, would, Mr. SEWARD forcibly argues, have been simply to show that our Government mistrusted the assurances of friendship and respect it was then receiving from the Government of Great Britain.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday a joint resolution from the Legislature of Ohio was presented, instructing the Ohio members of Congress to use their influence to secure an amendment of the Naturalization laws, so as to grant naturalization to for-... eigners serving in the army during the war. It was referred. Resolutions of the Legislature of...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday a joint resolution from the Legislature of Ohio was presented, instructing the Ohio members of Congress to use their influence to secure an amendment of the Naturalization laws, so as to grant naturalization to for-... eigners serving in the army during the war. It was referred. Resolutions of the Legislature of Michigan were also presented, urging the Government to put down the rebellion in the speediest manner possible. A memorial from the San Francisco Chamber of Commerce, in favor of a restoration of the warehousing system was presented and referred Mr. HARRIS, of New-York, presented petitions in favor of homoeopathic physicians in the army, and asking for the repeal of the Reciprocity Treaty with Canada; also, the resolutions of the New-York Legislature in favor of each State assuming and levying its quota of the National tax. Mr. CHANDLER, of Michigan, offered a resolution which was laid over, directing the Committee on Commerce to inquire into the expediency of abrogating the Canadian Reciprocity Treaty. A resolution was offered by Mr. POMEROY, of Kansas, and laid over, asking information relative to the Lane Expedition, and the late order of Gen. HUNTER assuming the command. The joint resolution appropriating $3,000 for the purchase of atton seed for [???] general distribution, was reported back from the Committee on Patents with an amendment, limiting the appropriation to one thousand, and passed after some debate. The same Committee was directed to inquire into the expediency of making an appropriation to aid in the experiment of manufacturing flax as a substitute for cotton. A petition from the merchants of Boston, against any alteration of the warehousing system, was presented. The resolution directing the removal of the army bakeries from the Capitol was passed. After some other unimportant business, the Senate went into Executive Session and afterwards adjourned.

abstract: Poor old BENNETT, CUT off by the stern dictum of public opinion from openly plotting treason, is reduced to the pitiful dodge of making game of the social arrangements of the White House.
lead_paragraph: Poor old BENNETT, cut off by the stern dictum of public opinion from openly plotting treason, is reduced to the pitiful dodge of making game of the social arrangements of the White House. It appears that Mrs. LINCOLN, bored to death by the doleful creatures of army contractors and the like she sees around her, has issued cards for a [???] dansante at the White House on Wednesday evening. BENNETT yesterday pitches into the proposed party furiously, and calls it, among a string of other hard names, "a social blunder much to be regretted!" Now, why a "social blunder?" Why not a political "blunder," a diplomatic "blunder," or any other "blunder?" The fact is, BENNETT speaks by the card, or rather by the want of card. For did he not send on to the capital that illustrious [???] of the Herald office, the Chevalier WYKOFF, expressly to see if he could not get an invitation to the [???] But WYKOFF returned ticketless. Hinc [???] That's the whole secret of his "heart-burnings," "sore disappointment and chagrin," and perfectly accounts for his yesterday's tirade about the "social blunder much to be regretted."
headline: {'main': 'A SOCIAL BLUNDER.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A SOCIAL BLUNDER.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Judge Sibley, of Rush, Genesee County, died inthat place on Friday last. He was born in Sandlake,Rensselaer County, in 1786. In [???] he removed toGenesee County, settling in Rush two years afterward,and married the lady who still survives him in1807. In 1812 he removed to Riga, returning to Rushabout 1835, where he resided to the day of his death.In the war of 1812-15, Judge S. was a volunteer, andserved on the frontiers under Col. Swift. In civil affairshe performed his share of duty as a citizen. Hewas a Supervisor for his town before the County ofMonroe war organized, and since, was one of theearly Members of the Legislature from Genesee,Canal Superintendent. Collector of the Port of Genesee,under Polk, and County Judge. He also heldvarious other appointments, and was a number oftimes nominated for Congress by the Democrats.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--VERDI'S opera of "La Traviata" was played here last evening, the cast being mainly the same as last season. A change of some importance, however, was effected in the role of Germont, which on this occasion was intrusted to a debutante Signor YPOLITO. Since the departure of Sigor Gas-...
lead_paragraph: SIER, and the death of poor AMODIO, we have had [???]baritones that we could honestly be proud of; although,until lately, there has been no scarcity in thesupply, good or bad. Of those who rank among thesecond and third classes, there have been some extremelyfavorable specimens; and it would not be libelous,perhaps, to say that we have done better thanmost countries, with baritones of the fourth class.Our thrift, indeed, with this voice, has rather annoyedthe public, and to this circumstance may be ascribedthe addition to Mr. GRAU's company effected in theperson of Signor YPOLITO. It is something, decidedlyin this gentleman's favor that he belonged to Mr. MAXMARETZEK's opera troupe, for the irrepressible MAXwas never known to engage a singer who did not possessat least an abundant voice. A. glance at the catalogueof our singers will reveal the almost forgottenfact that the best of the numoer, with scarcely an exception,were brought out by Mr. MARETZEK, andgained their reputation under his [???]. It has beenhis way to engage young, rising and willing talent,rather than to secure a musty reputation, withnothing to back it but pomposity and a clear sense ofextortion. Signor YPOLITO forms no exception to theMaretzekian rule. He is blessed with a rotundbaritone voice, not very extensive in its upwardrange but good in quality, and particularly full inthose parts where emotion [???] interest is most likely toshelter itself. The full effect of Signor YPOLITO'svocal gifts were not [???] last night, owing to acreditable degree of nervousness on his part, and to atendency which it provoked to give undue and some:what spasmodic emphasis to passages that scarcelyneeded it. Thus the second act, where the gentlemanhas his best opportunity, was occasionallymarred by efforts to do too much, and by evident relapsesfrom the same. But these were so slight thatthe value of Signor YPOLITO as the best baritone wehave had since AMODIO was only the more apparent.When he knows our public better he will, we are sure,be able to give a good account of himself.

lead_paragraph: BOARD OF ALDERMEN--MORE VETOES--A FLAGMAN TO BE APPOINTED--WASHINGTON'S BIRTHDAY-- GOWANUS BARDOR.--A regular meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held last evening, Alderman FRANKS, of the Sixth Ward, in the chair. abstract: A flag of truce, accompanying dispatches from Gen. JOHNSTON, commanding the Rebel Army at Manasses, to Gen. McCLEELLAN, came to our lines on Sunday. The bearer, a Captain in the Virginia Cavalry, was stopped at our outposts, and not allowed to come any further.
lead_paragraph: A flag of truce, accompanying dispatches from Gen. JOHNSTON, commanding the Rebel Army at Manasses, to Gen. McCLEELLAN, came to our lines on Sunday. The bearer, a Captain in the Virginia Cavalry, was stopped at our outposts, and not allowed to come any further. The contents of the rebel dispatches have not yet been made public, and much speculation was indulged in yesterday in Washington regarding them - more especially in view of the fact that a Cabinet meeting was held, at which Gen. MCCLELLAN was present for the space of an hour.

abstract: We published yesterday a valuable letter, from an esteemed Manchester correspondent, which gives a luminous view of the state of things in the cotton districts of England, and of her prospects touching an adequate supply of the indispensable staple.
lead_paragraph: We published yesterday a valuable letter, from an esteemed Manchester correspondent, which gives a luminous view of the state of things in the cotton districts of England, and of her prospects touching an adequate supply of the indispensable staple. After all, the Calcutta Englishman has proved a better prophet than the London Times. It has at last become evident that the British mill- owners have no chance of obtaining a sufficiency of cotton from India for the present season. Whether the contrary will be the case in the remote future, remains to he seen; but for the supply of immediate wants, the British manufacturer need not look to England's Oriental dependency. Nor does India's failure to meet the pressing demands of the Liverpool market arise so much from inability as from indisposition. The Hindoo planter will not enter extensively into the cultivation of cotton, unless a monopoly of the British custom and remunerative prices be guaranteed to him. These, however, are conditions which the British dealer is not inclined to accept. He still prefers the American article whenever he can get it, and objects to paying the Indian merchant the same price for a commodity containing twenty-five per cent. of dirt, that he pays for the well- prepared and superior product of the South. "Handle and clean your crop properly," says Mr. Bull to the Hindoo, "and you shall receive its full value." But the Hindoo thinks that a person in Mr. B.'s circumstances should not be over nice, and therefore insists on having dirt and all purchased from him! Now, great as are Brother John's necessities, he will not submit to be thus imposed on, and so cotton cultivation languishes in India, and the home market has no chance of an adequate supply thence.

abstract: We re ceive this morning, by way of Hampton Roads and Washington, an echo from the cannonading at the point, or points, at which Gen. BURNSIDE seems to have commenced operations. The Captain of a vessel,
lead_paragraph: We re ceive this morning, by way of Hampton Roads and Washington, an echo from the cannonading at the point, or points, at which Gen. BURNSIDE seems to have commenced operations. The Captain of a vessel, which has arrived from the coast of North Carolina, reports that on Tuesday - a week ago to-day - he heard heavy firing in the rear of Beaufort, N C.. and again, two days after, as he proceeded northward, he heard heavy firing in the direction of Roanoke Island. If this firing was from our fleet, as it certainly must have been, it would seem that Gen. BURNSIDE after getting his vessels safely within Hatteras Inlet, had divided his fleet into two bodies, one of which was dispatched southward and the other northward, and operations had been begun in both directions at the points indicated in the dispatch. We may have to wait a day or two yet to learn what success attended our action; for it is unlikely we will receive any definite or reliable information until a dispatch boat arrives from our fleet. Appearances indicate, however, that the action was unfavorable to the rebels, for the last passenger who arrived at Fortress Monroe (on Friday last, two days after the last mentioned firing) from the South by flag of of truce was accompanied from Richmond by a detective, who was instructed not to allow him to carry any papers with him, or to hold any communication with anybody on his way. It was the man's belief, from what he saw, that something had occurred which it was not desirable should be known here. If the news had been in any way unfavorable to us, it would undoubtedly have been promptly transmitted, well colored with exaggerations and false- hoods.

abstract: A gentleman, living twenty-two miles south of the late battle-field at Mill Spring, on the main road leading South, gave me quite an interesting account of the flight of the rebels, and the manner in which they conducted themselves while in Wayne and Clinton counties, which I now furnish you.
lead_paragraph: A gentleman, living twenty-two miles south of the late battle-field at Mill Spring, on the main road leading South, gave me quite an interesting account of the flight of the rebels, and the manner in which they conducted themselves while in Wayne and Clinton counties, which I now furnish you. My informant resides in Wayne County, and remained at [???] during the time the rebels occupied that part of the State. He is a reliable gentleman of good sense. He says the Confederates had about 10,000 infantry, well provided with guns, but of an indifferent quality -- squirrel rifles and flint-lock muskets principally; 2,000 cavalry, well drilled and well armed, and quite efficient, all of them being armed with guns and pistols, 18 pieces of cannon, 16 brass pieces, and two Parrot guns. The rebels admitted that they were completely routed, and that Gen. ZOLLICOFFER was killed. On their way back to Tennessee, there were fractional parts of brigades, going in a body, and with some order, but the remainder were going in squads of from one to twenty-five or more. They passed informant's house with about 125 two-horse wagons, and four pieces of artillery, under Gen. G.B. CRITTENDEN, and he was said to be [???]. They were throwing, away everything that impeded their flight, and were selling blankets at $1 25 apiece, and pistols (navy revolvers) at $6 and $7, in Tennessee or Georgia money. He says that about 500 cavalry went back on horses, the remainder were either captured, killed, or lost -- at least one-third of the men who went back were without guns or anything else, the other two-thirds had their guns, and some of them other articles; all of them were in great haste to get along, and committed no depredations on their return, other than to take horses, or mules, or something to eat. So hungry were they, that they actually eat the soap grease that his mother had laid aside to make soap. The rebels say that they lost in killed, drowned and missing, from 700 to 1,500. A large number were drowned in crossing the Cumberland River, and this is attested by other persons seeing their bodies below Mill Spring in the river. BALLIE PEYTON, Jr., was also killed in the fight, and is now at Somerset. JAS. S. CRISMAN was a candidate for the rebel Congress, and had his handbills out a few days before the fight. He left with the rebels, his family being at Sparta, in Tennessee. The flight of the rebels was so precipitate, that no election was held in Wayne County, on the 22d inst., (the time fixed for electing rebel Congressmen.) SHELBY [???], Jr., late member of the Legislature from Wayne County, was wounded in a skirmish a few days before the battle and is now lying dangerously, [???] not fatally, wounded at Dr. LONG's in Clinton County; the general opinion is that he has "his Tights" to his heart's content. He was making up a company of cavalry at the time he was wounded. The rebels lost from 6 to 10 a day with sickness, during their stay in Kentucky. A large number of those who were in the fight said they were going home to stay there, and none of them would reenlist at the expiratioa of their term of service -- all, or nearly all of them being twelve months recruits, their time will expire in February, March and April, 1862. They took large quantities of corn, wheat, &c., while in Wayne and Clinton, but generally paid for it in Tennessee, Virginia or Georgia money, or Confederate scrip. Quite a number of the leading Secessionists left with them from Monticello and other parts of Wayne County. They left perhaps, 100 troops in Wayne and Clinton, who are, or have been, sick or wounded. Clinton and Wayne Counties are now clear of Confederate soldiers, who are able to do mischief, and great is the rejoicing of the Union men of those counties.

abstract: AUDACIOUS ROBBERY OF GOVERNMENT FUNDS-- SEVERAL THOUSAND DOLLARS STOLEN--ESCAPE OF THE THIEF.--We have been informed that a daring robbery was committed on Saturday afternoon in Nassaustreet, by which the United States Government is likely to be the loser of several thousand dollars. It is said that Mr. HENDERSON,
lead_paragraph: AUDACIOUS ROBBERY OF GOVERNMENT FUNDS-- SEVERAL THOUSAND DOLLARS STOLEN--ESCAPE OF THE THIEF.--We have been informed that a daring robbery was committed on Saturday afternoon in Nassaustreet, by which the United States Government is likely to be the loser of several thousand dollars. It is said that Mr. HENDERSON, the Navy Agent, sent his office boy to Mr. CISCO, the Sub -- Treasurer, with a draft to be cashed. The lad obtained the money and locked it up in a tin box, that he might carry it easily and securely. He had walked as far as the Post-office on his way back to the Navy Agent's, when a man overtook him and said that Mr. Cisco desired him to deliver a letter, which he passed to him as he spoke, at the office of a Mr. SPRING, No. 12 Nassau-street, Room No. 10. The boy did not hesitate to comply with the request, and on going to the place mentioned he found Mr. SPRING's name upon the door, but no person in the apartment, as Mr. SPRING had moved. Supposing that the person of whom he was in search might be in an adjoining room, which opened from the main office, the lad entered, and a man instantly seized him, covering his head with a cloth and tying it tightly about his neck. The boy screamed for assistance, but the man ran off with the box of money before the occupants of the other offices in the building could ascertain what had occurred. The information upon which this paragraph is written was received from an unofficial source, but it is believed to be perfectly correct.

abstract: In early times the wounded were killed, or tortured,or allowed to die, as might please the victor.In modern warfare, the wounded on the battle-fieldis protected in his misfortune; the wounded enemy isa sacred person; he is of course a prisoner, but musthe provided for by him into whose hands he fallsWhen this is not done the people have become againbarbarous. The wounded of both parties should be treated the same. At the time of the Crimean war, aRussian officer was taken prisoner, and treated likea prisoner of war. He was, however, recognized asone who had been seen to instigate the soldiers tobayonet wounded soldiers on the ground. He wastried by a Court-martial, found guilty and executed.

abstract: -- The New-York correspondent of the Boston Post makes a number of random and false statements in relation to Judge BETTS, stating that he has made �a sort of family arrangement� by employing his relations in the Federal Courts in this City; that his son is the Clerk of the Court, and also holds a lieutenant's commission;and that a grandson has a salary of $1,500, and is attendingcollege at the same time. The facts are that Judge BETTS' son is clerk of the United States District Court, but he held that office before the appointment of Judge BETTS to the Bench, and is now living in a tent on Hatteras Banks, his deputy performingthe duties of the Clerk of the Court. The grandsonof judge BETTS is in college, and during vacationmakes about $200 per year by copying, &c., &c.; thatis all. The Prize Commissioners are in no way relatedto the Judge, nor have they a nephew acting asclerk, nor is the selling of prizes turned over to a son-in-lawof Judge BETTS. -- N.V. Eve. Post.

abstract: The Senate of the Delaware Legislature has followedthe example of the House and passed the actdeclaring the forfeiture of the lottery privileges grantedsome years ago to RICHARD FRANCE, of Baltimore.Appended to the grant was a condition that FRANCEshould pay to the State $720,000, paid in semi-annualinstallments of $18,000, and, upon failure, the grant tobe of no effect. In July last, FRANCE failed to pay the$18,000. But he had made sale of the franchise toJOHN A. MORRIS, who paid the $18,000 over to the Statein October, nearly four months after it was due. Thequestion arose whether the acceptance of this moneyafter it was due would be a waiver on the part of theState of its right of forfeiture. But the legal opinionis that though MORRIS might be the assignee of FRANCE,yet FRANCE owed the money to the State when MORRISpurchased the franchise, and the subsequent paymentdid not relieve the franchise of its liability tobe declared void arising from the detention of themoney beyond the day of payment. The reasoningupon this point of the report made to the Legislature,is as follows:

abstract: FELLOW-CITIZENS: In a few days the Provisional Government of the Confederate States will live only in history. With it we shall deliver up the trust we have endeavored to use for your benefit, to those more directly selected by yourselves. The public record of our acts is familiar to you, and requires no...
lead_paragraph: FELLOW-CITIZENS: In a few days the Provisional Government of the Confederate States will live only in history. With it we shall deliver up the trust we have endeavored to use for your benefit, to those more directly selected by yourselves. The public record of our acts is familiar to you, and requires no further explanation at our hands. Of those matters which policy has required to be secret, it would be improper now to speak. This address, therefore, will have no personal reference. We are well assured that there exists no necessity for us to arouse your patriotism, nor to inspire your confidence. We rejoice with you in the unanimity of our State, in its resolution and its hopes. And we are proud with you that Georgia has been "illustrated," and we doubt not will be illustrated again by her sons in our holy struggle. The first campaign is over; each party rests in place, while the Winter's snow declares an armistice from on high. The results in the field are familiar to you, and we will not recount them. To some important facts we call your attention:

abstract: Editorial on "lies" told about war in US and Great Britain
snippet: Editorial on "lies" told about war in US and Great Britain
lead_paragraph: Lord BACON somewhere says that" a mixtureof a lie doth ever add pleasure;" but ifhis Lordship were living at the present day,we are inclined to think that he would havefound the mixture altogether too strongto be at all pleasant. Was there ever seen,since the world began, so monstrous a cropof falsehood as have sprung up out of the presentrebellion? It would seem as if the fatherof lies himself had come down in power, finding his especial home, of course, in thatregion where the "sum of villainies" hasbrought forth its appropriate yield of treasonand other crimes, but not, by any means, confininghis operations to that quarter.

abstract: The emphatic refusal of Mr. SEWARD to permit the use of his name in connection with the next Presidential canvass, was announced, yesterday, in our Washington correspondence. Some ardent but injudicious friend of the Secretary of State, impresssed, no doubt, by the magnitude of that statesman's recent services in saving the country from a collision with a European Power, had sought permission to associate.
lead_paragraph: The emphatic refusal of Mr. SEWARD to permit the use of his name in connection with the next Presidential canvass, was announced, yesterday, in our Washington correspondence. Some ardent but injudicious friend of the Secretary of State, impresssed, no doubt, by the magnitude of that statesman's recent services in saving the country from a collision with a European Power, had sought permission to associate his name with the Presidency. The suggestion is met, not only with a prompt negative, but with an eloquent rebuke. Mr. SEWARD declares his intention to end his public career with his retirement from his present office. He conceives himself entitled, by half a lifetime of energy devoted entirely to the service of his State and country, to a discharge from further active duty, and of this right he is disposed to avail himself. When the Union shall be restored, the administration of the laws replaced in its customary channel, and a new era of National peace, prosperity and progress inaugurated, the Secretary will demand his dismissal from a service wherein his labors will have so essentially contributed to the salvation of the people.
headline: {'main': 'Mr. Seward and the Presidency.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Mr. Seward and the Presidency.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Editorial on Gen. Halleck reguiring oath of allegiance from citizens of Missouri
snippet: Editorial on Gen. Halleck reguiring oath of allegiance from citizens of Missouri
lead_paragraph: Gen. HALLECK is evidently determined to "swear" every rebe in Missouri. A short time ago the Secessionists in the St. Louis Chamber of Commerce thought they had achieved a triumph over the Union members by electing officers of their own ilk for the year; but no sooner had the rebels and semi-rebels been elected to their places, than the whole of them president, secretary, directors and all the other officers -- were peremptorily required to take the most stringent oath of allegiance, under penalty -- if they attempted to exercise their functions -- of being arrested for contempt, and punished according to the laws of war. At the same time, the president, secretary, librarian, directors, and other officers of the Mercantile Association, were required to follow the same course, or be punished in the same penalties. In our last issue again we published another order from the same source, dated at St. Louis, requiring the President, Professors and Curators of the University of Missouri to subscribe to the oath of allegiance, and if any one failed to do so, and yet attempted to exercise his official functions' he should be tried and punished as for a military offence. �The institution,� says Gen HALLECK, �having been endowed by the Government of the United States, its funds should not be used to teach treason or to instruct traitors.� And the authorities of the University are advised to expel from its walls all persons who, by word or deed, favor, assist or abet the rebellion. The Presidents and Directors of all Railroad Companies, are also required, under penalty, to take the oath. Neither must they employ any conductor, engineer, station-master, agent, or any other employe, who has not taken the oath. No contract will be made by Quartermasters with any man until he shall have taken the oath. All clerks, agents and employes in the service in that Department, must take the oath; and any officer who shall keep in employ any man who has not been sworn, shall be arrested and tried. All clergymen, professors, teachers, and, indeed, all the white men in Missouri, are requested by Gen. HALLECK to come forward at once, and attest their allegiance to the Government, so that they may be known and recognized, and distinguished from rebels.
headline: {'main': 'SWEARING THE REBELS.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'SWEARING THE REBELS.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A bill will be introduced in the Legislature providing that every slave 35 years of age and upwards, shall be free within 90 days after its passage; and all slaves under 35 shall become free as they reach that age; and that from and after the 1st day of January, 1872, there shall not be Slavery or involuntary servitude, except as a punishment for crime. Males born of a slave mother after the passage of the act, shall be held as indented servants until the age of 21, and females until they are 18. The above provisions are based upon the condition that ï¿½Congress will, at [???] present session, engage to pay to the State of Delaware,in bonds of the United States, bearing interest at the rate of six per centum per annum, the sum of $900,000, in ten annual installments, $90,000 to be payable on some day before the first day of September, 1862, to establish a fund for securing full and [???] compensation to the owners of slaves who shall have been divested of their property by force of the act in question. The bill provides for the appointment of an assessor in each county, who shall estimate the value of the slaves, and fix the price which shall be paid for them. The salary of the State Treasurer shall be raised when the act goes into operation from $500 to $1,000, on account of his increased responsibilities and duties in making payment to the owners for their slaves. If Congress will make the appropriation of $900,000 for this purpose, we think every man in the State will esteem the act calculated to promote the interests of our people. Many of the slaveholders would gladly exchange their slaves for money, which they could use in payment for their lands and contemplated improvements. We are informed that many of thelargest slaveholders favor the measure.

abstract: DETERMINED TO ANTICIPATE THE LAST CALL. As the Jersey City ferry-boat Gregory was crossing the river yesterday forenoon, one of the passengers, who was standing upon the stern of the boat, was seen to take off his cap, deposit it upon the deck, together with a business card, and then leaped overboard.
lead_paragraph: DETERMINED TO ANTICIPATE THE LAST CALL. As the Jersey City ferry-boat Gregory was crossing the river yesterday forenoon, one of the passengers, who was standing upon the stern of the boat, was seen to take off his cap, deposit it upon the deck, together with a business card, and then leaped overboard. The alarm was given, and upon the boat being stopped, the ferry hands succeeded in rescuing the man in an insensible condition, who proved to be GEORGE R. BRETTELL, an English locksmith doing business at No. 114 1/2 Newark-avenue, Jersey City. BRETTELL was taken home by Chief of Police MARINUS, and Dr. ZABRISEIE was called in and finally succeeded in saving his life. A few evenings since BRETTELL was found lying insensible in the street by Officer BRADLEY, and upon being taken home it was discovered that he had swallowed laudanum. Some time since BRETTELL cut his throat, but the skill of a surgeon saved his life. No cause is assigned for these acts.

abstract: By an official notice from the Treasury Department, we learn that provision has been made for the payment in coin of the interest on the three years United States bonds, at the office of the Assistant Treasurer in this City. They must be presented by the 19th inst., with the necessary schedules. Notice is also given of the readiness of the Treasury Department to redeem the Treasury...
lead_paragraph: By an official notice from the Treasury Department, we learn that provision has been made for the payment in coin of the interest on the three years United States bonds, at the office of the Assistant Treasurer in this City. They must be presented by the 19th inst., with the necessary schedules. Notice is also given of the readiness of the Treasury Department to redeem the Treasury notes payable in one year from date. The whole work of issuing the fifty million United States notes will be finished to-day. Official notice has been received from the Governor of California that that State will assume and pay its share of the direct war tax.

abstract: Editorial on bill pending in US Congress to appoint diplomatic representatives; Editorial on bill pending in US Congress to appoint diplomatic representatives
snippet: Editorial on bill pending in US Congress to appoint diplomatic representatives; Editorial on bill pending in US Congress to appoint diplomatic representatives
lead_paragraph: In his message to the present Congress, President LINCOLN stated that if there was any good reason why the independence of Hayti and Liberia should not be recognized by the United States, he was not aware of it. On the contrary, there are many very good reasons why it should be recognized, and hence we are very glad that the Chairman of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations has brought in a bill for the appointment of diplomatic representatives to these republics. Congress is, we think, in a disposition promptly to legalize the measure, without any protracted debate; and the more so, as both justice, civility and self-interest urge the recognition of Liberian and Haytian Independence.
headline: {'main': 'Recognition of Haytian and Liberian Independence A Step in Advance.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Recognition of Haytian and Liberian Independence A Step in Advance.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, a petition from the manufacturers of steam machinery in Boston, against reducing the grade of engineers on ships, was presented. Resolutions passed by the Michigan Legislature, asking the passage of a law to punish frauds on the Treasury; a resolution from the same body in favor of a direct tax according to property owned, and another, against the sale...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, a petition from the manufacturers of steam machinery in Boston, against reducing the grade of engineers on ships, was presented. Resolutions passed by the Michigan Legislature, asking the passage of a law to punish frauds on the Treasury; a resolution from the same body in favor of a direct tax according to property owned, and another, against the sale of intoxicating liquors to army officers, were presented and referred. A bill from the Committee on Foreign Affairs, authorizing the appointment of diplomatic representatives to the Republics of Liberia and Hayti, was introduced by Mr. SUMNER. The resolution offered by Mr. POMEROY, of Kansas, asking information of the Secretary of War relative to the Lane Expedition, and the recent order of Gen. HUNTER assuming the command, was called up and passed after an explanation from Mr. POMEROY, that the resolution was introduced at the request of the Secretary of War himself. The bill providing for the construction of iron-clad steamers was called up, and after some debate was referred back to the Naval Committee. The objection urged against their construction was the length of time it would take. The report of the Naval Committee on the answer of the Secretary of the Navy to the inquiry relative to the Morgan contracts, was made the special order for Friday. A substitute for the bill to define the pay aad emoluments of officers of the Army, was reported from the Military Committee. A Pacific Railroad and Telegraph bill was presented by Mr. POMEROY, of Kansas, and referred. Mr. BRIGHT's case was then further considered, until the Senate went into Executive Session, at the conclusion of which an adjournment was carried. It is expected that Mr. BRIGHT's case will be disposed of to-day.

abstract: One traveller has favored us, in the pages of Blackwood, with an account of the South, as he saw it in last September and October, and we have the authority of the Times than he is impartial; moreover, he (or a companion) claims to add to his narrative,...
lead_paragraph: Some Account of both Sides of the American War,in which he speaks of both sides, but for one, and thatwith great fact, sufficient to satisfy those who knowlittle on the subject that he looks at both. We wouldwarn our readers against supposing us to be impartial,as the writer professes to be. We are not; for across bias against slavers and slavery runs throughour very marrow; and every statement of ours musthe sifted as from those who take a side, and would beashamed not to do so. Stealthily apologizing forSlavery; alleging, against Mr. LINCOLN and the North,multifarious and, in several cases inconsistent, accusations;bringing into view all the virtues of theSouth, and not one of its vices; showing, as a sampleof Slavery, negroes laboring with gold watches intheir pockets; and, as a specimen of opinion, thatthe Southerns earnestly desired (what they hadgot before his paper appeared) a descenton the coast of South Carolina or Florida;and, as one of information, that two counties in Virginiacontained sufficient supplies or animal food forthe Southern army for two years -- this writer is, nevertheless,useful in several respects. He first shows,as slaveowners always boast, how soon men, whenwell treated by them, and familiar with their mode ofgaining their livelihood, warm to it as being a gentlemanlycalling. He does, indeed, admit that there arethings about Slavery to be abhorred by all Englishmen;but he keeps them far out of view, and paintssuch as are of an opposite character. He condemnsthe North, because, during a state of revolution, restraintis put on speaking and writing treason; butnot a syllable has he to say on the fact that, in ordinarytimes, no editor dared to write, no minister topreach, no orator to declaim, in the South, against thedark cause of all the commotion he saw; that eventhe benevolent might not emancipate, nor the enlightenedinstruct the victims of his fair and his gallantclients, without bringing upon themselves far andfeathers, or mayhap dignified legal punishment; andthat every year some peaceful friends of freedommeet with some violent death for their opinions.

abstract: Some misunderstanding seems to have prevailed as to what time the Senate adjourned to on Satur day. abstract: A painful accident occurred in the Camp of the First Massachusetts Volunteers, to-day, resulting in the death of a soldier in that regiment. Two soldiers, named SWALLOW and BARLOW, were indulging in a little innocent badinage, when SWALLOW caught up a musket standing near him, and leveling it at the breast of BARLOW, exclaimed, "Now I will have a good pop at you," and immediately pulled the trigger.

abstract: The discussion of the Treasury Note Bill thus far in the House of Representatives, has produced nothing to upset or weaken the able and lucid explanations of the Bill, at the outset, by Mr. SPAULDING of New-York. On the contrary, it has brought to his support an eminently just and merchant-like exposition of the bearings of the measure upon the exigencies of the Treasury and the Currency of the...
lead_paragraph: The discussion of the Treasury Note Bill thus far in the House of Representatives, has produced nothing to upset or weaken the able and lucid explanations of the Bill, at the outset, by Mr. SPAULDING of New-York. On the contrary, it has brought to his support an eminently just and merchant-like exposition of the bearings of the measure upon the exigencies of the Treasury and the Currency of the country from Mr. Hooper, of Massachusetts - a Boston merchant and manufacturer of large experience, and a political economist, who has devoted much time and written much upon the question of banking. His speech of Mon day excites the warmest commendation. It not only grasps the whole emergency of the Treasury, but points out the sufficient reasons why the United States Notes and Funded Loans of the Government should not be left unguarded by the authority of a legal tender, or unprotected by the most ample taxation. The distinction between the use of plain Treasury paper for the prosecution of a foreign war and a struggle against domestic rebellion, is forcibly drawn, and the presence among us of an indifferent or disloyal feeling to defeat the healthy and vigorous exercise of the public credit, more than hinted at. In this he is backed by the declaration of the Secretary of the Treasury, that but for the already developed inclination of some of our bank people to discredit the United States Notes, now in use, without the stamp of legal tender, thereby creating an unjust and most damaging discrimination against others who give this currency a generous and public-spirited support, the authority of the Government need not have been exercised to give the additional issue of $100,000,000 a uniform validity.

abstract: which the rebels trade between Nassau and Charleston must have attracted the notice of the Navy Department. Vessels laden with arms, army stores and supplies for the southern market arrive in the harbor of Nassau constantly, and with equal frequency steamers...
lead_paragraph: which the rebels trade between Nassau and Charleston must have attracted the notice of the Navy Department. Vessels laden with arms, army stores and supplies for the southern market arrive in the harbor of Nassau constantly, and with equal frequency steamers appear from Charleston to exchange cotton for such commodities. If it be desirable to satisfy Europe what a sham is the stone blockade, the practice may have its uses. But if we are earnest in the purpose to cut off the rebel supplies, the Secretary of the Navy will have to take some steps to intercept this intercourse. And to this end the dispatch to the Bahamas of a cruiser commanded by a loyal officer would be a happy thought. We are aware that the Flambeau, commanded by Capt. TEMPLE, is already detailed to that station; but the certainty with which that vessel gets out of the way when a rebel steamer is to sail, or is looked for, has suggested serious doubts with regard to the capacity, if not to the loyalty, of its commander. He should be replaced by one who is familiar with the locality, and who will be certain to do his duty.

abstract: COMMISSIONERS OF HEALTH SALTING THE STREETS. The Commissioners of Health held a special meeting yesterday at the Mayor's Office, called at the instance of several of the railroad and stage proprietors, with reference to the salting of the streets. Affidavits were presented by those opposed to the measure, tending to show its disastrous consequences to horses, in one stable alone, one hundred...
lead_paragraph: COMMISSIONERS OF HEALTH SALTING THE STREETS. The Commissioners of Health held a special meeting yesterday at the Mayor's Office, called at the instance of several of the railroad and stage proprietors, with reference to the salting of the streets. Affidavits were presented by those opposed to the measure, tending to show its disastrous consequences to horses, in one stable alone, one hundred and twenty-three horses having been laid up from frozen feet in consequence of sprinkling salt on the snow. On the other hand, one party (Mr. T. BAILEY MYERS) claimed, that if permitted, he could prove that the salting of the streets to dissolve the snow, was absolutely beneficial to horses. After considerable discussion, the original mandate, prohibiting absolutely, and under heavy penalty, the use of salt on the streets, was so modified, on motion of Dr. SAYRE, Resident Physician, as to permit its use by the railroad companies on their switches and turn-outs, and an official proclamation to that effect will be at once issued.

abstract: editorial on use of notes as form of currency; editorial on use of notes as form of currency; editorial anticipates discussion of blockade in British and French Parliaments
snippet: editorial on use of notes as form of currency; editorial on use of notes as form of currency; editorial anticipates discussion of blockade in British and French Parliaments
lead_paragraph: It is understood that the opening of the British Parliament and the French Corps Legislatif, was to be the signal for a hot discussion on our blockade of the Southern coast. The rebel agents have elaborate documents drawn up, demonstrating its utter inefficiency, of course; and under cover of this battery of fictitious facts, poured simultaneously from the French and English Parliaments, it is hoped the two Powers -- NAPOLEON leading -- will be able decently to intervene and declare the blockade futile, and therefore illegal. It will be well, however, for the rebel agents and their Parliamentary friends to hurry up matters somewhat, for the opening of Spring will probably find no blockade to talk about. There are many hundred miles of Southern coast along which we have already superseded the blockade by the actual possession of its land side. And, as it is the design of the Government to push on and complete this bold and original plan of dealing with the rebel coast, it will not be long ere the very term blockade will become obsolete and inappropriate. As it is probable we are not left entirely without friends in the French and English legislative bodies, we beg leave to call their attention, anent the coming discussion, to this new Yankee style of blockade, and the extent to which it has already been carried out. The facts in the case are of a kind that in all likelihood the rebel memorialists have forgotten to mention.

abstract: Our advices from Western Kentucky render it probable that we may have news of another battle today. The expedition which left Cairo a day or two ago under Gen. GRANT, it appears, is des-...
lead_paragraph: Our advices from Western Kentucky render it probable that we may have news of another battle today. The expedition which left Cairo a day or two ago under Gen. GRANT, it appears, is destined for operations against Fort Henry, on the Cumberland, not far from the Tennessee line, said to be defended by a large body of rebel troops. At last accounts, Gen. GRANT was reported to have arrived with his command within four miles of the fort, while the gunboats Essex and St. Louis had made a reconnoissance and exchanged shots with the enemy, with a view to ascertain the range of their guns.

abstract: vote yesterday, expelled JESSE D. BRIGHT from the Senate of the United States. The case is well known to the public. A great deal of forensic fog and legal mystification have been thrown around it by both the advocates and the opponents of the resolution. Thus it was attempted to show that the Senator was on trial before a body clothed with a judicial character, and that the evidence for his conviction was insufficient. This poor legal figment, it seems, had sufficient power over certain honest but intensely technical minds to induce a negative vote. The loyal public, meanwhile, impatient with this faltering, had but one question -- Is JESSE D. BRIGHT, after writing the letter he did to DAVIS, a fit person to be intrusted with Senatorial functions? There was but one conclusion, and any other would have been but to impugn the profoundest instincts of the patriotic mind. The Senate has taken the same view, and recorded it in an emphatic vote. The expulsion of the traitor, while no more than an act of duty it owed itself, cannot fail to have an elevating and inspiring effect both on Congress and the country.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The music of sleigh bells, accompanied by weird floatings of fish-horns, and plaintive murmurs on the subject of the defunct JOHN BROWN, has so usurped public taste during the past week of snow carnival, that the desire for opera seems to be in complete abeyance, notwithstanding the worthy efforts of Mr. GRAU. Thus the house last night, although good in appearance, was not we fear a remunerative one; and this is the more to be regretted, inasmuch as the performance was unusually spirited and excellent. We have nothing to add to this general commendation, for the extraordinary success of VERDI's "Ballo in Maschera" has drawn forth all the criticism that the work can bear, and the particular artists who participated last night in its representation, have been noticed already in their various roles. The season will end on Friday, when we trust Mr. GRAU will meet with better luck.

abstract: In the Senate, Mr. CARLILE, of Virginia, called up his resolutions, offered some time ago, regarding the finances of the country. He did so, he explained, in order to call the attention of the Senate to the condition of the finances, which he considered as remarkably bad. The resolutions were referred to the Finance Committee. The bill making an appropriation for the support of the West Point Academy was reported from the Finance Committee without amendment, andpassed. A resolution, offered by Mr. SUMNER, calling upon the President for the recent correspondence relative to the presentation of American citizens at the Court of France, was passed. The amendments of the Military Committee to the bill defining the pay and emoluments of army officers were agreed to. The bill, however, was not passed. The case of Mr. BRIGHT, of Indiana, was then considered, and finally disposed of -- the Senate, at the conclusion of a long debate, in which Mr. BRIGHT himself took part, voting to expel him. The following is the vote:

abstract: Digest of report by House (Van Wyck) committee probing Government military contracts reveals frauds in all branches of service
snippet: Digest of report by House (Van Wyck) committee probing Government military contracts reveals frauds in all branches of service
lead_paragraph: An Immense volume, consisting of over 1,100 octavo pages, has just been sent us from Washington, containing the report of the Select Committee of the House of Representatives to inquire into the contracts of the Government Mr. VAN WYCK, of this State, Chairman. Fragments of the report and of the testimony have already been given to the public; but as these were evidently published so as to expose the crimes of some men and to conceal those of others, and as, because they were but fragments of the evidence given they were necessarily unjust, we have refrained from giving any of it publicity until the whole of the report and the testimony was before us. In this volume we have all the evidence so far as it has yet been taken. The Committee, however, announce that they have a large amount of material still on hand, which will be made the subject of a further report; and as the work of the Committee in investigating contracts is still going on, and is likely to be kept up as long as the war lasts, or until contractors and agents become indisputably honest, it is likely that we will be furnished with a library of corrupt reading, which, next to the history of this bloody rebellion itself, will strike posterity with horror at the awful wickedness of the present generation. The document, and the exposures contained in it might have a certain kind of speculative and anatomical interest if the rebellion were crushed out and victory had perched upon our banner; but at the present crisis of the Republic, such disclosures are painful and dreadful, and produce a feeling of public indignation which would justify the most summary measures against the knaves whose villany is here dragged into daylight.

abstract: The West Indian, a vessel belonging to a Southern planter merchant, has arrived at Liverpool direct from Charleston, having, successfully run the blockade.
lead_paragraph: The West Indian, a vessel belonging to a Southern planter merchant, has arrived at Liverpool direct from Charleston, having, successfully run the blockade. The owner of the West Indian and her cargo, (who came from Charleston with the vessel,) and Capt. FOOTE, informed our Liverpool correspondent that the blockade of the port of Charleston is anything but effectual, and that the "granite blockade," so far from stopping the entrance to the port, will eventually deepen the shallow channels. On this point the Charlestonians are confident, and therefore the sinking of the granite fleet gives them but little uneasiness. The West Indian is 241 tons burthen, and has a full cargo of spirits of turpentine. She left Charleston in the evening of the 24th December. It was a fine starlight night, and with a favorable wind, the blockade was run, without meeting with any of the blockading squadron. The West Indian left Charleston after the stone fleet had been sunk, and ran down to the sea through one of the channels left open by the Federals. Mr. PHINIZEY, the owner of the vessel and freight, is a resident of Savannah; and as he frequently traveled between that port and Charleston, states that he himself saw the plantations on fire. It is the fixed determination, he says, of the planters to burn their cotton sooner than it should fall into the hands of the Yankees. All the plantations about Port Royal have been destroyed; and with the exception of a few hundred bales of cotton which have been gathered by the Unionists, and which is uncleaned, there is scarcely a bale of good cotton about the place. Charleston was well defended, and the number of troops between that city and Savannah was about forty thousand men, under the command of Gen. LEE. Reinforcements also continued to arrive at the different points of defence. Savannah is in the best possible state of defence. The blockade of Mobile is said to be a regular farce. Vessels run regularly between that port and Havana. From Mobile the vessels engaged in the trade carry Southern produce, and on their arrival at Havana their cargoes are transhipped on board neutral vessels, and forwarded to England. The Southern vessels then take on board arms, ammunition, and other necessaries for the Southern army, and run back to Mobile. This trade is carried on with impunity, and one commercial house in Havana, which is also connected with a well-known Liverpool firm, has three vessels engaged in this trade. Coffee, tea, sugar, salt, boots, and shoes, &c. -- indeed all the common luxuries of life -- are exceedingly scarce and dear in nearly all the Southern cities.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, the bill in relation to the punishment of crime in certain cases was reported favorably by the Prison Committee, which also recommended an alteration in the terms for sending criminals to the State Prisons, and in the law relative to the commutation of sentences. The report of the Select Committee, appointed at the last session, to investigate charges of malfeasance brought against certain Harbor-masters, was presented and ordered to be printed.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, the bill in relation to the punishment of crime in certain cases was reported favorably by the Prison Committee, which also recommended an alteration in the terms for sending criminals to the State Prisons, and in the law relative to the commutation of sentences. The report of the Select Committee, appointed at the last session, to investigate charges of malfeasance brought against certain Harbor-masters, was presented and ordered to be printed. Notice was given of a bill to secure compensation to passengers for personal injuries received on railroads, and to provide for the establishment of surgical stations with hospital accommodations on railroad lines; also of a bill to raise a fund for building the New-York County Court-House. A bill was introduced to amend the act for the formation of gas companies; another concerning the public health of New-York, (the Health bill,) and another to amend the act to regulate the sale of poisons. The Governor was called upon to communicate to the Senate in Executive session some facts connected with the complaints made against Harbor-master J.W. TAYLOR.

abstract: The steamships City of Baltimore and Hansa arrived at this port, last night, and the Nova Scotian at Portland yesterday morning. The Nova Scotian's dates are five days later than our last advices. A brig laden with turpentine had arrived at Liverpool from Charleston, and her Captain thinks that the stone blockade will greatly improve the harbor of Charleston. A London let-letter, in the Patrie, asserts that England will protest against our closure of the Southern ports, while in England it is reported that Fiance will take the initiative in breaking our blockade. The French dispatch boat Forfort had received orders to be ready to sail for this station. A letter (probably from some rebel) has been published in London, calling on the British Government no longer to tolerate our gunboat Tuscarora (watching the pirate Nashville) in her disregard of neutral rights. The London Times opposes England's interference in the American war at present, though Mr. MASSEY, M.P., had advocated the interference of the European Powers to close the struggle. A letter of Earl RUSSELL had been published, which said that, even as a scheme of embittered and sanguinary war, our stone blockade could not be justified; and Lord LYONS was instructed to make representations to Mr. SEWARD, with a view to prevent similar acts of destruction at other ports. The French Minister would join Lord LYONS in protesting against the act. The newspapers -- French and English -- continue to take sides, some with the rebels, and others with our Government. The pirate Sumter reached Gibraltar on the 19th ult., and on her passage from Cadiz she burnt one American bark and captured another, but the latter she subsequently released. A rumor comes from Algiers that the Sumter was there, and had probably sunk another American ship.

abstract: Editorial on Southern blockade effects on France
snippet: Editorial on Southern blockade effects on France
lead_paragraph: The settlement of the little account opened by Capt. WILKES unhappily left an unadjusted balance. The blockade is an international question. It is regulated by principles of maritime law, which, vague and unsatisfactory as they are, constitute the only code to which nations are at liberty to appeal, and which, if administered by a combination of the leading Powers of the world, must control the will and action of any individual State. There is no doubt that the blockade of the Southern ports has been a cause of serious damage to the two leading commercial nations of Europe. What evils it has really inflicted upon them they estimate at the full value; but the real source of complaint and indignation springs from an absurd exaggeration of the value of the rebel States as a market for their commodities; and this, in turn, arises from the mistake of supposing that all the demand for the products of French and English workshops, which the war has suspended, came from Southern customers; whereas nothing is better understood here than that it is to Northern economy, not to the Southern blockade, this diminution of traffic is attributable. In France, and especially in provincial France, there is an imperfect understanding of the American question; and an erroneous impression that the idleness and prostration of French industry is due to the perseverance of the American Government in a policy which cannot and ought not to succeed, and which only threatens to block the wheels of the world's progress for an indefinite period. We have alluded now and again to the representations of this character addressed to the Imperial Government by the various local Chambers of Commerce. They all invoke the interference of the Emperor to stop the conflict, dwelling pathetically upon the sufferings of the population heretofore dependent upon their several centres of industry, owing to the blockade. To such addresses the Emperor cannot be insensible. These are the most influential bodies in the Empire. They speak the sentiments of millions. They guide the opinions of the Legislative Chamber. They typify that middle class, which in France holds the balance of power between Legitimacy and Red Republicanism. It would be most impolitic for NAPOLEON III. to treat the wishes of these people with disregard; and we cannot doubt that in permitting the Corps Legislatif to discuss the question at the opening of their annual session, the Emperor has shrewdly yielded to a current of public feeling which it would be dangerous to encounter.
headline: {'main': 'Foreign Intervention France and the Blockade.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Foreign Intervention France and the Blockade.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Editorial says 1st year of war shows permanent separation of North and South would not be feasible
snippet: Editorial says 1st year of war shows permanent separation of North and South would not be feasible
lead_paragraph: A year ago, Tuesday, the Convention to organize a provisional government for the rebels met at Montgomery. HOWELL COBB was selected to preside over its sessions. A year ago, and after the experiment of a twelvemonth, we have a report of HOWELL COBB, in conjunction with ROBERT TOOMBS, THOMAS COBB and MARTIN CRAWFORD, as to the progress made by the rebellion, and the degree of encouragement these leaders of Georgian sentiment are enabled to hold out as to the prospects of final success. The document belongs to the category of spasmodic literature. There is a dogged iteration of confidence in the eventual result of the conflict to which they invite the people; but this generalization is marred by the sturdy irreconcilability of the particulars. The financial prostration of the South is confessed; the success of the North in converting a mob of volunteers into a regular army, is admitted; the certainty that, in the Spring, the cordon already placed about the rebel States will be drawn irresistibly closer and closer, until the struggle for existence will be mortal, is recognized; and the people is exhorted to the use of those frightful alternatives, which are only considered by a race obstinately resolved to prefer extermination to submission. The slight probability of foreign assistance is also dwelt upon with a candor, that exhibits the writers as only anxious to excite the courage of desperation.
headline: {'main': 'A Year of Rebellion.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Year of Rebellion.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Banks having now paid up their installments in full for the Government loan subscribed for by them, much uneasiness is felt as to the course which they will adopt in future as to the taking United States demand notes on deposit.
lead_paragraph: The Banks having now paid up their installments in full for the Government loan subscribed for by them, much uneasiness is felt as to the course which they will adopt in future as to the taking United States demand notes on deposit. At present the rule is both to receive and pay them out, though exceptions are sufficiently numerous to seriously embarrass both the public and the Banks who adopt the more accommodating course, and it is greatly to be desired that some arrangement should be entered into that will lead to a uniform system.

abstract: editorial on report Sumter was put out of Cadiz and is now at Gibraltar
snippet: editorial on report Sumter was put out of Cadiz and is now at Gibraltar
lead_paragraph: The parable of the two sons, of whom the one made loud professions of filial obedience and yet disobeyed in act, while the other atoned for an unfilial refusal, by doing the thing commanded, never found completer realization than in the conduct of Spain and England respectively with regard to the rebel privateers that have lately sought refuge in their ports. The Sumter, as we learned with a thrill of indignation some weeks ago, has transferred the scene of her piratical exploits to the European shores of the Atlantic, and was known to have sought asylum, after burning three American vessels, in the Spanish port of Cadiz. We expressed our fears at the time, that we had little guarantee in the public morality or good faith of Spain against her affording every hospitality to the buccaneer, but it is now due to say that her conduct in the case has been entirely just -- we may even say, generous; for an act of justice conspicuously done in the face of repeated wrongs, becomes something more than bare justice. It appears that the Spanish authorities, on learning the character of the Sumter, forthwith ordered her to leave Cadiz. The representations of the United States Consul at the port were cheerfully and faithfully followed -- no supplies for the furtherance of her piratical designs being granted, and the right of asylum being rigorously limited to the legal period of twenty-four hours. We are further told, in a London letter, that at Cadiz the officers of the Sumter were looked upon as buccaneers by the inhabitants of the town, and there were none so mean as to do them reverence save the correspondent of a leading London journal, who accompanied them to the play.
headline: {'main': 'The Sumter at Cadiz and at Gibraltar.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Sumter at Cadiz and at Gibraltar.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, favorable reports were made on the bills to enforce the liability of Bank stockholders, and imposing a tax on dogs. Among the bills introduced was the one to secure compensation to passengers injured by railroad accidents, and to establish surgical stations along the lines. The bill to authorize the Banks of the State to take and hold State or United States stocks was passed. An amendment was proposed to include Treasury Notes, but it failed.

abstract: Editorial on Confederacy reported intention to exhibit at 1862 World's Fair, London; Editorial on report Confederate States of America intend to exhibit at 1862 World's Fair
snippet: Editorial on Confederacy reported intention to exhibit at 1862 World's Fair, London; Editorial on report Confederate States of America intend to exhibit at 1862 World's Fair
lead_paragraph: -- A portio of the grounds selected for the Grand Industrial Exhibition of 1862 have been appropriated to the so-called Confederate States. Even if the latter should have the means of transportation, it puts the imagination on the stretch to conceive what specimens of Southern industry would be sent to these rebel acres. As to agricultural products, we have no doubt the people of Liverpool and Manchester would be glad to see some specimens of Southern cotton, and a few model "niggers" of the real gingerbread color," might prove attractive to some, provided they were free. But in none of the mechanic arts have the rebels anything to show. In military matters, Necessity has been a kind mother to them, and they might make a formidable display of masked batteries, submarine torpedoes, and other enginery of destruction.

abstract: editorial on Union movements up Tennessee River
snippet: editorial on Union movements up Tennessee River
lead_paragraph: Active though quiet preparations have been going on for some time at Cairo and Paducah, for a pretty strong military and naval expedition against some point which its planners had the good sense to conceal both from us and from the rebels. The expedition was not strong enough to make the grand assault on Columbus, much less to descend the Mississippi on the long projected tour to Memphis and New-Orleans; so it has been generally conjectured that it was bound to operate against some of the rebel works or camps on the Tennessee or Cumberland Rivers. It was necessary that the detached rebel forces in Western Kentucky should be dispersed, as those in the Eastern part of the State have just been dispersed, before any general forward movement be attempted. It seems now that the conjecture was correct A force declared by the telegraph to consist of ten thousand men and eleven gunboats, have entered the Tennessee River, and, at latest accounts, had got up in the vicinity of the rebel fort Henry, some fifty miles above the river's mouth. The only works or camps known to exist in this vicinity, are two -- one on each of the rivers, the Tennessee and the Cumberland, which here flow not far apart, in a parallel direction northward. Fort Henry, on the Tennessee, is an earthwork thrown up along the river, and constructed mainly to prevent our advance in the rear of Columbus, while both this and Fort Donelson, on the Cumberland, were intended, also, to prevent our operating so as to turn the left flank of the main rebel body at Bowling Green. Fort Hay, which, according to the telegraph, is to be at once assailed by the very respectable force we have mentioned, has an armament of some ten or twelve guns, of heavy calibre, and has been manned by a garrison of three thousand men. It is very probable, however, as this same point was threatened in the reconnoissance in force, made from Cairo a fortnight ago, that the rebels have sent additional forces up from Tennessee for its defence. On the opposide (or western) side of the river, the rebels have a battery placed on rising ground, which commands the fort, so that it will be necessary for our forces to operate on both sides of the river. The gunboats, however, which are those strong iron-plated craft built for service in the Mississippi Expedition, can, if their qualities are anything like what is supposed, ascend within striking distance of the rebel guns, and bombard the position, while the troops, acting from a direction north-easterly of the fort, will meet the rebels in case they evacuate the fort. But if any action has taken place, or is intended at this point, we will at once have news of its result, and speculation thereon is unnecessary.
headline: {'main': 'Movement up the Tennessee River An Important Expedition.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Movement up the Tennessee River An Important Expedition.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Editorial on military strategy of flank movements
snippet: Editorial on military strategy of flank movements
lead_paragraph: The importance of flank movements is likely to receive more attention and deserves more in connection with the present, than with any previous struggle on record. The reason is that, besides being of greater necessity strategically, these movements are extraordinarily facilitated by the open frontier separating the loyal from the rebellious States, and still more by the easy accessibility of every point on the Southern coast. Plainly, too, these facilities are wholly to the advantage of the North. Our power to outflank the enemy through naval expeditions is overwhelming; and by land, given an unfortified frontier, the same power evidently rests with the side that can muster the greatest force and confine its enemy to a defensive attitude, securing its own territory from invasion and keeping intact its vast systems of communication, while it reserves to itself alone the power to menace and to strike. It may seem that time, giving the rebels opportunity for fortification, has, in some degrees neutralized our advantage; but on the contrary, it has increased our relative superiority, as it has matured our strength of attack.
headline: {'main': 'FLANK MOVEMENTS.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'FLANK MOVEMENTS.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: It is reported that the orders under which those companies of the Ninth Infantry (regulars) now in California had prepared to come East, and, indeed, were on their way to San Francisco, have been countermanded, and that the Ninth will remain where they are. Several non-commissioned officers belonging to the company which passed through here a short time ago, en route to Washington, will leave for California by the next steamer hence.
lead_paragraph: It is reported that the orders under which those companies of the Ninth Infantry (regulars) now in California had prepared to come East, and, indeed, were on their way to San Francisco, have been countermanded, and that the Ninth will remain where they are. Several non-commissioned officers belonging to the company which passed through here a short time ago, en route to Washington, will leave for California by the next steamer hence. They go to recruit for their company, which is understood to have been broken up, and the privates assigned to other regiments. If this is correct, it shows that the authorities do not think it advisable to withdraw all the regulars from the Golden State, as they intended to do.

abstract: Sporting men, pugilists and small politicians were much excited yesterday, by a report that PAT. MATHEWS, one of the most widely known of their class, had been murdered. The report was not wholly correct. MATHEWS is not dead, but he lies at the City Hospital in a condition which precludes the hope that he will recover, and an investigation by the Coroner must first be held, before the wounds of which he is suffering, can be characterized as having been inflicted by a murderer. It is quite as likely that they were given in self-defence. There is now but one side of the story to tell, and that comes from the friends of MATHEWS. To-day Coroner RAMSEY will hold an anlemortem inquest in the case, and a different version of the matter may be given.

abstract: VIA BALTIMORE, Thursday, Feb. 6. The United States transport Constitution, which sailed yesterday forenoon for Ship Island, spoke the gunboat Miami about forty miles north of Hatteras last night, in a sinking condition, and unable to make steam enough to take her into port. The Constitution arrived here at 1 o'clock this afternoon with her in tow.

abstract: It appears from the text of the President's respite in the case of the condemned slaver GORDON, that there is no hope of pardon. Marshal MURRAY received the official documents yesterday morning and about 9 o'clock proceeded to the Tombs to read them to the unfortunate man. GORDON heard them read calmly.
lead_paragraph: It appears from the text of the President's respite in the case of the condemned slaver GORDON, that there is no hope of pardon. Marshal MURRAY received the official documents yesterday morning and about 9 o'clock proceeded to the Tombs to read them to the unfortunate man. GORDON heard them read calmly. He said he felt more for his wife and children than for himself; and, indeed, since his conviction, his wife has seemed the greater sufferer of the two. Marshal MURRAY intimated, that in case of necessity, he could and would willingly procure a subscription to aid Mrs. GORDON and her family.

abstract: The Honorable Commissioners to rebeldom Bishop AMES and Gov. FISK, arrived here this morning, on their way to execute their mission. Capt. MILLWARD was dispatched with a flag of truce at once to communicate with the rebel authorities, and learn if the Commissioners are to be received, and when. If I were to express an opinion, I should say they would not be received; in any event, it cannot be...

abstract: in his vehement appeals to his Republican countrymen, had frequently to reprove them for their idle curiosity to learn the intentions of PHILIP, the foreign potentate whose insidious designs they suspected, feared, and yet were inert in preventing. A similar reproof is well deserved by those among us who while burning with anxiety to know whether foreign Powers will interfere in our domestic troubles, neglect to do all that in them lies to strengthen the hands of the Government. Now, more than at any period of our history, is the true that to be respected abroad, our Government must be strong at home. Victories by land and sea are, no doubt, at hand, and they will do much to deter European intervention. But victories are not all out bleeding country needs. Patriotism is equally necessary. We want a patriotism in our contractors, in our capitalists, in our Government officials, strong enough to prevent future Van Wyck Reports, Morgan revelations, and bullionist combinations to "shave" the Government credit. We have two armies to fight against -- an army of traitors in Secessia and an army of hungry parasites at home. Let us deal vigorously with both these hostile forces, and in proportion as we show our courage, and paralyze the foes of our national life, shall we inspire with salutary caution any foreign Power who might be meditating mischief.

abstract: WALDO EMERSON lectures to-night, in Brooklyn, on "American Civilization." This, we believe, is the discourse which Mr. EMERSON delivered the other night in Washington, and which so astonished the officeholders and other patriots of that town with its sublime wisdom and morality. All those who ever heard the "Concord Philosopher," (with understanding ears,) will assuredly go to hear him again to-night; and all who are so fortunate as to be listeners, will learn that there is a vitality and character to American civilization capable of carrying it and us safely through even these distracting times.
