abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, among other petitions and memorials presented, was one asking a reduction of the salaries, fees and perquisites of the Naval officer and Surveyor of this port. A petition was also presented from citizens of Boston, praying Congress to let the Slavery question alone, and attend to the business of the country. Another petition for the repeal of the Reciprocity Treaty with Canada, was also presented. A bill to allow the Corporation of Washington to issue small notes, was referred. The bill to define the pay and emoluments of the officers of the army, was then taken up, and occupied attention until the adjournment. Mr. SHERMAN, of Ohio, reviewed the financial condition of the country in a lengthy speech, at the close of which he offered an amendment providing for the reduction of all Government salaries. He accepted a suggestion of Mr. DOOLITTE, of Wisconsin, that all mileages of members of Congress be reduced fifty per cent. and that they be computed by the most direct routes. After a long debate, this was modified so as to except members from beyond the Rocky Mountains; and pending a motion to recommit the whole bill to the Military Committee, the Senate went into executive session, and subsequently adjourned.

abstract: Our advices from Kentucky still leave the National forces within four miles of Fort Henry on the Tennessee River, while Gen. GRANT had returned to Paducah for SMITH's Brigade of seven thousand men, which together with the eight thousand under Gen. MCCLERNAND, would make a sufficient force to insure success. Reconnoissances have established the fact that the rebel forces behind the Fort have recently been heavily reinforced, and a rumor puts BEAUREGARD himself in command. Our land force will be assisted by seven gunboats.

abstract: editorial on reported battle
snippet: editorial on reported battle
lead_paragraph: News as gratifying as that we receive from Mexico may be pardoned for taking a roundabout way. Through San Francisco, we learn that the army of Spain has met with its first serious reverse. Leaving Vera Cruz, seven thousand strong, it had advanced thirty miles on the road to the capital, to a point of much strategic importance, known as the National Bridge, where the Rio Antigua is crossed, and where the Mexicans seem to have posted themselves to dispute the passage. No point is more disputable. The bridge is surrounded by a throng of hills, and the westward road, upon leaving it, ascends gradually over ground exposed for some distance to the fire of an opposing force, who may shelter themselves behind intrenchments, and pour death upon the advancing enemy. It would require only a small body of troops to withstand at this place an army of thrice its strength. Gen. URAGA, the Mexican commander, has doubtless availed himself of these advantages. The arrogant and confident Castilians despising their foe, and eager to forestall their allies in the harvest of glory, rushed upon this danger, and have been defeated. It may be long before we learn how signal this reverse has been. The neglect of Government to provide means of communication with Mexico, leaves us at the mercy of the Havana Press for news of the allied army; and the Spanish Press is not likely to report Spanish disasters otherwise than as victories.
headline: {'main': 'The Reported Battle in Mexico.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Reported Battle in Mexico.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The House of Representatives last evening passed the Loan and National Currency Bill by an unexpectedly large majority. The contest was on the policy of United States Treasury Notes as a uniform National circulation, made a legal tender, absolute, as the best substitute for Gold and Silver, through the War, and to be redeemed in Gold and Silver after it shall be concluded, and on the general resumption of payments by the Banks of the country. The motion to strike out this important clause failed by a vote of 53 to 93, and the bill was then passed by a vote of 93 to 55. The imperious necessity for immediate action was appreciated by all parties and the opposition appears to have ceased with the rejection of the substitute offered by Mr. MORRILL, of Vermont. The matter is thus disposed of by the House in season to have the Senate take at least preliminary, if not final action, before adjourning over Sunday. As in the case of most other money hills originating in the House, the Senate will no doubt substantially concur.

The imperious necessity for immediate action was appreciated by all parties and the opposition appears to have ceased with the rejection of the substitute offered by Mr. MORRILL, of Vermont. The matter is thus disposed of by the House in season to have the Senate take at least preliminary, if not final action, before adjourning over Sunday. As in the case of most other money hills originating in the House, the Senate will no doubt substantially concur.

abstract: The soft, white carpet which February ordered of the clerk of the weather, upon which to make his entree in the drama of 1862, in New-York, has had the effect of bringing every variety of conveyance down upon runners.
lead_paragraph: The soft, white carpet which February ordered of the clerk of the weather, upon which to make his entree in the drama of 1862, in New-York, has had the effect of bringing every variety of conveyance down upon runners. Little girls on neat little sleds are drawn swiftly through streets or parks by equally little fellows; newsboys and boot-blacks, who may be able to "raise" three pieces of stick and a rope, gather in squads in the lower parts of town at night, after the last edition is all sold off, and the last pair of "boots blacked, Sir," and furiously drag each other around on the improvised sleigh, shouting and laughing at the upsettings received by the unhappy loon who has been so happy as to get the ride, just as though there were no more editions ever to come, or as though boot-blacking were henceforth to be enrolled among the lost arts. Children of a larger growth, too, of both sexes, have made the most of the snow and the frost. Sleighs of every conceivable fashion and style, have been gotten up, and nags of every possible degree of sleekness or boniness, have been hitched to them, and male and female parties -- generally mixed -- of every conceivable size, have crowded themselves into them, and have dashed forth for a sleigh-ride. The omnibus lines, too, have followed suit of private parties, and the unfortunates who have no sleighs of their own, for the small sum of sixpence get a ride of one, two or three miles, and are as happy as anybody. These sleighing parties have run deep into the nights of late, and as the gay parties glide over the smooth street at 11 or 12 o'clock, singing some gay snatch of a song, or repeating some brisk chorus, it sounds wondrously romantic and fine. A dozen of each sex, well packed in an old sixpenny omnibus on runners dashing down Printing House-square under the stars, and their clear voices ringing through the air the Hallelujah Chorus -- nothing can seem or sound more cheery. Some of the gay hosts seem to be spiritually inclined, if one may judge from the burden of the choruses:

abstract: ARREST OF PICKPOCKETS. A young woman of respectable appearance, went into STEWART'S, on Wednesday afternoon, and conducted herself in such a manner, that suspicions against her honesty were aroused. When she left the establishment, a policeman of the Broadway Squad was called, and told to ...
lead_paragraph: ARREST OF PICKPOCKETS. A young woman of respectable appearance, went into STEWART'S, on Wednesday afternoon, and conducted herself in such a manner, that suspicions against her honesty were aroused. When she left the establishment, a policeman of the Broadway Squad was called, and told to follow and arrest her as a pickpocket. He did so, and as soon as he took hold of her, she threw away a porte-monnais, which was afterwards identified as belonging to one of the ladies who had been shopping when the prisoner was in the store. Two bank bills were also found in her possession, both of which had been stolen from Mr. STEWART's customers. Yesterday, the accused was committed to answer. She says her name is ELIZABETH MARSHALL.... On Wednesday evening, Detective DUSENBERRY saw a lad, named MICHARL KENNY, pick a lady's pocket in Parkrow. He caught hold of the rogue, who twisted from his grasp, and ran through Ann-street, first throwing away the pocket-book which he had just stolen. The fugitive could not run fast, because of the tattered condition of his garments, and when he reached Nassau-street, he sought refuge in a printing office. The officer found him there attempting to make his way to the roof. He was caught, and taken to headquarters, where he will be detained for the present.

abstract: We have telegraphic advices from San Francisco to the 4th inst., embodying important intelligence from Mexico. A dispatch, conveyed overland, had been received by way of Acapulco, announcing that the Spanish army, attempting an advance into the interior from Vera Cruz, had been defeated at the National Bridge by the Mexican forces under URAGA, after a desperate battle of five hours' duration. If the Spanish forces, numbering only seven thousand men, have attempted an advance, we can very well believe they have suffered a defeat at the point indicated. The position of the National Bridge, which spans the Rio Antigua on the Jalapa road, is one of the strongest for defence. The assailants, if they attempted to force the pass, must have suffered great slaughter.

abstract: whose affecting farewell to the rebel army we published such a heart-rending account a week or two ago, has withdrawn his resignation, and proposes again to take the field, this time under Gen. JOHNSTON, and in the command of BEAUREGARD. From the formal document which announces his return to military duty, we have confirmation of the rumor current at the time of his resignation, that he resigned because of the "incompatibility of his temper" and ambition with the temper and ambition of Rev. Gen. POLK, "Gen. PILLOW," says the document, "being advised of a change of circumstances at Columbus, Ky., has withdrawn," etc. Now, the only change of circumstances at that point has been the appointment of BEAUREGARD to the chief command, and the consequent subordination of the Right Reverend General. PILLOW was unhappy from the moment of POLK's appointment; he felt that his great services in the field at Camargo and elsewhere had been overlooked, and he himself overslaughed for the sake of a man whose only conflicts had been with the powers of darkness -- if happily he had ever fought even them. But now that the hero of Manassas has taken command, Gen. PILLOW resumes his shovel, that he may teach the world anew his old lesson of military engineering. It is questionable, however, if PILLOW is willing to endure BEAUREGARD, whether BEAUREGARD will be willing long to endure PILLOW.

lead_paragraph: We have cheering news this morning from Tennessee. The United States soldiers and sailors have at last attained a foothold in that State, after a brilliant naval engagement a foothold at a point, too, most important for operations, which will now very soon be begun, against Nashville, Memphis, and the whole of the rebel region of the Southwest. As Gen. HALLECK says in his brief bulletin of victory: "The flag of the Union is reestablished on the soil of Tennessee. It will never be removed." It must henceforth be borne steadily southward to the Gulf of Mexico.

abstract: The negotiation between the Government and the Merchants' Exchange Company has been brought to a successful issue. The premises, as heretofore described, are hired for a Custom-house at $65,000 per annum, on a lease for three years, with the privilege of two renewals of three years each at the same rate, and of purchase at any time during either term for $4,000,000, which is one-half of its original cost, and $50,000 less than it cost the present Company. The Government resumes the present leases to the American Bank Note Company, and other tenants, some of which leases will continue for some time. The Collector of the Port will take possession on the 1st of May, when the Treasury will be removed to the present Custom-house.

I can hardly believe that the writer ...
lead_paragraph: SIR: My attention has been called to an edi- torial in the World, of this date, in which I am particularized as one of four gentlemen who support the financial scheme of the Secretary of the Treasury, and am called upon to answer certain questions therein propounded. I can hardly believe that the writer the money necessary to carry on the war, to pay a reasonable price for its use, and to repay it in twenty years. The $150,000,000 of currency will be practically a loan of that amount by the people to the Government. Until it is funded, it will be a loan without interest. As soon as the people find that they cannot use it in the market in such a manner as to realize six per cent. for it, they will convert it into Government stock, and it will then bear interest. To my mind, it makes but little difference whether the interest is paid in coin or paper, as, in my opinion, by the time the first installment of interest is due, the issue now proposed will have given place to the new bank currency, which will be convertible into specie at the banks, unless a general suspension, such as now exists, should then take place, in which case the interest could not be paid in specie, for the very obvious reason that the country would not have the specie to pay it.

abstract: meteor was seen in the Heavens above a great exten of Northern Germany, in the evening of Jan. 3. It has been described by Prof. HEIS, in his "Weekly Papers on Astronomy." It was simultaneously visible at Berlin, Dresden, Munster, Dessan and other widely distant places. At Dessan, its appearance was preceded by a sound resembling thunder. It was of a fiery red color, and equal to the full moon in apparent size, with a radiance so extreme as to resemble the dawn of day. Its computed height from the earth's surface during its protracted flight, was 29 miles. It must have been witnessed by millions in the North of Europe, and everywhere awakened feelings of wonder and awe.

abstract: The United States sloop-of-war Savannah, Commander JOHN S. MISSROON, arrived at this port last night from Port Royal, S.C., making the passage in eight days. The Savannah went into commission in June last, and since has been engaged in arduous blockade; her crew are suffering from its effects, on which account she has been ordered home. The holding of Tybee Island by the seamen of the Savannah and gunboats in the Savannah River, until relieved by the New-York Volunteers, was a signal service. She brings no news of importance from Fort Royal, except the sailing of the Expedition for the South on the 26th, including all the light-draft steamers, several gunboats and several thousand troops. Everything remained quiet at Port Royal. The following is a list of officers of the Savannah:

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, resolutions passed by the Legislature of Rhode Island, asking the permanent location of the Naval Academy at Newport, were presented. Memorials from merchants of New-York, against any interference with the present warehousing system, were presented.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, resolutions passed by the Legislature of Rhode Island, asking the permanent location of the Naval Academy at Newport, were presented. Memorials from merchants of New-York, against any interference with the present warehousing system, were presented. Emancipation and homoeopathic petitions were also presented. The Judiciary Committee made a report in the case of Mr. STARKE, of Oregon, recommending that he be allowed to take the oath, without expressing any opinion as to the merits of the case. The papers were ordered to be printed. A bill to reduce the expenses in making surveys and sales of the public lands, was introduced from the Committee on Public Lands. A joint resolution, giving thanks to Capt. DUPONT and his officers for the capture of Port Royal, was passed. The bill providing for iron-clad steam gunboats was reported back from the Naval Committee by Mr. HALE, who proceeded to make a speech advocating its passage. It was amended so as to limit the number of boats to twenty, and then passed. Mr. HALE also explained at considerable length the investigations of the Naval Committee regarding the Morgan and other contracts. He was followed by Mr. DIXON, of Connecticut, who contended that Secretary WELLES had done the very best he could under the circumstances. Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, offered a substitute for the Committee's resolution of censure, somewhat modifying its tone, when the matter was postponed until Monday. The Civil Appropriation bill was passed, after some amendments. The bill authorizing an additional issue of ten millions of demand notes was passed. The bill to define the pay and emoluments of officers of the army was taken up, and pending its consideration the Senate adjourned until Monday.

abstract: Mt. [???] WALDO EMERSON repeated last evening, at Brooklyn, his Washington lecture on "American Civilization." It has been wittily said of EMERSON that his almanac notes the seasons by such indications as "Now is the time to lay in your Fall stock of Vedas;" and one might readily surmise, in Emersonian phrase, that that fine spiritual soul, with an ear hearkening solely to the croonings of Nature's mystic shell, had little heed for the jar and clamor of our war times: but his new lecture -- which, by request we do not report -- is stated to be a most vivid, practical and inspiring word for the hour "American civilization." South and North, receives an unsparing anatomy from his trenchant scalpel. The Southern institution is to him the Southern destitution. He does not think the present convulsions without their excellent compensations, however. Our spread eagle will hereafter be less of a peacock. He finds the altered tone of England and France, and the sudden courage of Spain, all instructive to us. What, however, though England does sympathize with the South? So much the worse for England. As for the slowness of the Government and its seeming unwillingness to strike blows, he is patient -- having no fear that half-way measures will answer. If our rulers are timid, things are bold. Mr. EMERSON's sentiments as to Slavery have long been known, and in his present lecture he is reported to declare for emancipation; but it is with the wise moderation and practical good sense that characterize his mind.

abstract: The turf, the ring, and kindred institutions, which, in the aggregate compose the "sporting world," each had its representatives yesterday at Jefferson Market Police Court.
lead_paragraph: The turf, the ring, and kindred institutions, which, in the aggregate compose the "sporting world," each had its representatives yesterday at Jefferson Market Police Court. This dazzling outburst of the major and minor lights, from what might be termed the subterranean universe, was caused by an announcement in the TIMES that the case of PAT. MATHEWS, who is a star of the first magnitude, would be investigated by Coroner RANNEY. MATHEWS was stabbed on Thursday morning, and so severly, that it is not probable he will live. His acquaintance demonstrated their interest in his misfortune by assembling to learn the circumstances by which it was attended. For the most part, they were gratified. Shortly-cropped hair, a nose retrousse, and garments of the swell pattern, were sufficient to pass all of whom they were characteristic into the private room where the Coroner held sway. For others, and especially for the representatives of the Press, there was no admittance. No questions were put until the Coroner was assured, by a careful glance around the apartment, that persons were not surreptitiously taking notes. He afterward explained his reasons for this unprecedented privacy. The proceedings, he said, were simply to ascertain whether JOHN REYNOLDS, WILLIAM WHISTON and JAMES SKEILY, the persons accused of assaulting MATHEWS, might be admitted to bail, and at this stage of the case, justice would be injured by a publication of the facts. In his opinion, the evidence taken in Coroners' cases, of a criminal character, should not be made public. This opinion was of course concurred in by Mr. MATHEWS' friends, especially by Mr. HENRY FELTER, who was present during the affray.

abstract: Many years since, Dr. COLTON gave a series of well-managed and amusing exhibitions of the nitrous oxide, or "laughing gas" in the old Broadway Tabernacle, which attracted large numbers of ladies and gentlemen. Subsequently he repeated the same in Hartford, Conn., where Dr. HORACE WELLS, by injuring himself while under the influence of the gas, was led to the discovery of anaesthesia, or the agent by which a sense of pain is destroyed in surgical operations. The evidence is very conclusive, that the honor of this great discovery is due to Dr. WELLS. By the advertisement in another column, it will be seen that Dr. COLTON will give an exhibition of the "Laughing Gas" at the Cooper Institute on Monday evening. Twelve gentlemen have volunteered to inhale the gas. To add to the attractions, the full National Band of the Seventh Regiment have been engaged to perform for thirty or forty minutes, to commence the evening's entertainment -- for which Dr. COLTON pays the band at the rate of two dollars per minute! The entertainment will be well worth attending.

abstract: In calling attention to the speech delivered yesterday in the House of Representatives by Hon. CHARLES VAN WYCK, and reported at length in other columns of this paper, we are conscious of not recommending a course of cheerful and soul-animating reading.
lead_paragraph: In calling attention to the speech delivered yesterday in the House of Representatives by Hon. CHARLES VAN WYCK, and reported at length in other columns of this paper, we are conscious of not recommending a course of cheerful and soul-animating reading. Mr. VAN WYCK lectures on the morbid anatomy of our body politic. At each phrase his knife turus over some revelation of disease and putridity at which the soul grows sick, nay, well-nigh hopeless of the National restoration; and even realizes something like resignation at the possibility of National dissolution. Why should so loathsome a mass of corruption persist in living?

abstract: During previous administrations, and when the business transacted at this branch of the Treasury, although large, was relatively insignificant, when compared to what, it is at present, I have repeatedly urged upon your predecessors in office the propriety of furnishing a fire-proof and, burglar-proof building, properly adapted and adequate to the requirements then existing. My representations were listened to, their reasonableness admitted, and the desired change promised. Year after year, however, has passed, and nothing has been done. It is no longer a matter of propriety or of reasonableness only, but as I commenced by stating, it has become of imperative necessity.

abstract: editorial on French and British intervention
snippet: editorial on French and British intervention
lead_paragraph: It is with feelings far from indifferent that the progress of European intervention in Mexico is watched by the people of the United States. The avowed purpose of two out of the three nations engaged in the business was to refute the Monroe doctrine, by extending to the New World the idea of a balance of power, and placing some barrier to that march of manifest destiny, which would otherwise be resumed by an elastic and restless people at the close of our civil war. To Europeanize Mexico, to write its laws in Paris and London, and surround it with a military force strong enough to resist the encroachments of fillibusterism, and that form of colonization which wrested Texas from New-Spain -- these were the objects which lay immediately behind the pretence of debts unpaid, and European residents endangered. Further back there was reason to apprehend the existence of other motives still more nearly concerning the welfare of this country. The right to interfere in the internal affairs of Mexico at the moment when faction had for the first time in the life of a generation been quieted, implies, with stronger reason, a right to interfere in the United States, where the presence of a war which Europe has resolved to regard as needless, malignant, barbarous, apparently robs France and England of industrial prosperity, and threatens the former with the hazards of revolution. Nor has such apprehensions been simply a matter of inference. It has been more than hinted that the demonstration against Mexico was really directed against this country. The disproportioned squadron, and armament apparently in excess of any occasion Mexico was likely to give for their employment, have been regarded, not only in the United States but in Europe, as the supplement of preparations for interventions in our own troubles; preparations otherwise partially completed by the large body of British troops thrown into Canada; by the powerful reinforcements added to the squadron of Admiral MILNE, and by the numerous French men-of-war haunting at this moment the waters of America. The friends of the American cause in Europe have repeatedly warned us of the danger to be feared in this quarter. We have been bidden to watch the Mexican campaign with more than the jealousy that its remoter reference to our future might seem to authorize. And had the task undertaken by the allies been as trifling as they reckoned it; had they landed at Vera Cruz to be hailed by the great body of the Mexican people as deliverers, and to march, as at a triumph, to the capital, there to prescribe laws, erect a Government, and from the pinnacle of success proceed to the next act of the preconcerted drama, it is quite possible that intervention in the United States would have followed hard upon the [???] of intervention in Mexico.

abstract: -- The Secretary of the Treasury, indisposed to let the community suffer the slightest inconvenience from the financial measure now passing through Congress, has authorized Mr. CISCO to submit to the Banks a proposition, to the effect that the Sub-Treasury take of them their surplus demand notes upon ten days' notice, giving for them a certificate of deposit, bearing five per cent. interest. The proposition has, we learn, proved acceptable to all of the Banks with whom the Assistant Treasurer has communicated; and will no doubt be generally adopted. As meeting, to some extent, an objection raised as to the ability of the Treasury to issue the new emission of notes as rapidly as demanded, the fact is of importance; and is even more important as indicating the restoration of more harmonious relations between our great moneyed institutions and the Government.

abstract: left unacquainted this morning with the developments in the Mathews case made at the ante-mortem inquest yesterday, they have to thank the Coroner, Dr. RANNEY. That person discovers that the revelations in criminal cases at Coroners' inquests are prejudicial, and hence establishes the precedent that they shall not be allowed to appear in the public Press. Such tender solicitude for the ends of justice is highly commendable -- but its beauty is somewhat damaged by the fact that while representatives of public journals are to be ruled out with the intent that the proceedings shall be shrouded in secrecy, scores of miscellaneous persons are, as they were yesterday, to be admitted to a full cognizance of the whole matter. Whether their freely circulated gossip, with the accompanying glosses and exaggerations, are calculated to be less prejudicial than an authentic published report, is a consideration that one would suppose the Coroner had well weighed before establishing this strange, unprecedented principle. It is foolish, and Dr. RANNEY will find it is impracticable.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, favorable reports were made on the bills to close part of Partitionstreet, Brooklyn; to organize an Asylum for insane convicts, and to amend the laws for incorporating Life and Health Insurance Companies.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, favorable reports were made on the bills to close part of Partitionstreet, Brooklyn; to organize an Asylum for insane convicts, and to amend the laws for incorporating Life and Health Insurance Companies. Notice was given of a bill to amend the Excise law of 1857; to divide the crime of murder into degrees, and to define the punishment of arson, and to amend the Revised Statutes relative to bankers and brokers. A great number of bills were introduced -- among them, one providing for the examination of the books of the Treasurer of the Canal Department, and of the Secretary of the Bank Department; one incorporating the Spring-street Railroad Company; one amending the Charter of this City; one relating to taking private property for public uses in this City; one to authorize the construction of a railroad in Broadway; two relative to the Courts in this City; and others of less importance. The Amended Charter for this City, presented by Mr. MCLEOD, we print in full elsewhere.

abstract: Mary Jane Robbins, Administratrix, , VS. Henry Walls et al., representing the American Express Company. This action was brought to recover $1,087, the alleged value of certain goods and jewelry found.
lead_paragraph: Mary Jane Robbins, Administratrix, , VS. Henry Walls et al., representing the American Express Company. This action was brought to recover $1,087, the alleged value of certain goods and jewelry found missing upon opening a trunk sent by the American Express Company from this City to Iowa City, Iowa, on the 18th of September, 1854, but which was not delivered, as alleged, until the 20th of April, 1855. It was claimed by the plaintiff that the trunk was shipped to C.A. Robbins, (of whose estate she is administratrix,) and that when delivered to the Express Company, it contained property worth $1,850.

abstract: The Senate had only a very short session this morning, and then adjourned until Monday evening. They intended to have taken a recess until Monday evening last week, but through the too speedy arrival of the hour of adjournment, and the earnest discussion of the Bright resolutions, they missed it, and have taken it this week with additions to recompense for their disappointment.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY, Friday, Feb. 7, 1862.

abstract: rebels have suddenly discovered that they have shamefully neglected their friend Spain, in not sending representatives to her Court. "Spain," says the Richmond Dispatch, "is the natural ally of the South. If the South has had a friend from the beginning of her troubles, it has been Spain." What inducement Spain has to be the "natural ally" of the South, when filibusterism is an indigenous product of Southern soil, and when she knows it is the proclaimed purpose of the Slave Empire, if successful, to absorb the Spanish American possessions, it is not easy to see. But let that pass. If Spain shows the rebel Government no more "friendship" than she has lately done in the case of the Sumter, they will be welcome to all the comforts they can get from their "natural ally." The Sumter, remember, according to the rebel theory, does not figure as a privateer, but us a public armed vessel of the C.S.A. -- and consequently entitled to every possible respect. Nevertheless the Spanish Government indignantly dismissed her from Cadiz -- justly regarding her in her true character as a pirate, after her wanton destruction of peaceable merchantmen. If the South can find any encouragement in this, she will easily succeed in extracting sunbeams from cucumbers.
lead_paragraph: rebels have suddenly discovered that they have shamefully neglected their friend Spain, in not sending representatives to her Court. "Spain," says the Richmond Dispatch, "is the natural ally of the South. If the South has had a friend from the beginning of her troubles, it has been Spain." What inducement Spain has to be the "natural ally" of the South, when filibusterism is an indigenous product of Southern soil, and when she knows it is the proclaimed purpose of the Slave Empire, if successful, to absorb the Spanish American possessions, it is not easy to see. But let that pass. If Spain shows the rebel Government no more "friendship" than she has lately done in the case of the Sumter, they will be welcome to all the comforts they can get from their "natural ally." The Sumter, remember, according to the rebel theory, does not figure as a privateer, but us a public armed vessel of the C.S.A. -- and consequently entitled to every possible respect. Nevertheless the Spanish Government indignantly dismissed her from Cadiz -- justly regarding her in her true character as a pirate, after her wanton destruction of peaceable merchantmen. If the South can find any encouragement in this, she will easily succeed in extracting sunbeams from cucumbers.

abstract: terday witnessed the departure of more vessels of the "Mortar Fleet" from our port. Day by day they quietly slip their anchors and depart for their mysterious rendezvous, no body knows where. Their mission is equally shrouded in mystery. But the most likely suggestion is that the mortar fleet is to go to Charleston harbor, where it will be the indispensable complement of the stone blockade.

abstract: Our gallant sailors under Commodore Foot have achieved a handsome victory and gained possession of a most important point in Ten- nessee. The whole country congratulates them on the spirit and pluck exhibited in the action.
lead_paragraph: Our gallant sailors under Commodore Foot have achieved a handsome victory and gained possession of a most important point in Ten- nessee. The whole country congratulates them on the spirit and pluck exhibited in the action. Wherever our navy [???] battle, upon the sea, the lake, or the river, it sustains its glorious prestige, and adds to the record of its ancient renown. Upon the Tennessee, the great Mississippi, and its affluents in the far South, there is now opened up a new field for naval daring and glory; and the first action on that field is an argury of victory which will have a splendid effect upon the spirits of our river blue-jackets in their future exploits. From the [???] telegram and the brief and [???] official report of Commodore [???], we gather that it [???] a most [???] and handsome little engagement -- the Fort having all the advantages which belong in guns [???] over [???] on shipboard, and the gunboats showing the value of their [???] and the power of their rifled cannon.

abstract: We have glorious news this morning from Tennessee. The rebels at Fort Henry, on the Tennessee River, were, at noon on Thursday last, assaulted by our gunboats in command of Commodore FOOTE, and, after an hour and twenty minutes hard fighting, the secession troops surrenderod' leaving all the artillerymen in the fort to be taken ...
lead_paragraph: We have glorious news this morning from Tennessee. The rebels at Fort Henry, on the Tennessee River, were, at noon on Thursday last, assaulted by our gunboats in command of Commodore FOOTE, and, after an hour and twenty minutes hard fighting, the secession troops surrenderod' leaving all the artillerymen in the fort to be taken prisoners. The rebel infantry, some four thousand strong, cut and fled, says the dispatch. Our troops, at latest advices, were in pursuit. The effect of this victory is to prepare our way for the general movement southward. Very full accounts will be found in other columns.

abstract: The annual Anti-Slavery State Convention, met at Association Hall to-day. The call for the meeting was at 10 o'clock, but at 11 o'clock the meeting was organized, which time thirteen white men, six white women, and three negro men were present. OLIVER JOHNSON, editor of the Anti-Slavery Standard, was chosen President. The meeting holds sessions two days.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY, Friday, Feb. 7.

abstract: the new Charter for the City, reported on Thursday in the State Senate, is given elsewhere in this paper. It is understood to reflect imperfectly the views of any party, and in the aggregate of its provisions, to be acceptable to no one of the Charter-mongers, whose lives have been sacrificed to that special line of study. But in its recognition of the necessity of altering the constituency of the Board of Aldermen so as to introduce a greater degree of intelligence and conservatism into municipal legislation, and in its attribution of large powers to the Mayor, with larger attendant responsibilities, it sanctions principles which must enter in some form into whatever scheme of reconstruction. There is little doubt that after the objectionable traits of this bill have been eliminated, the remainder will constitute a very much better organic law for this City, than any beneath which it has heretofore suffered.

abstract: The victories of Mill Spring and Fort Henry, followed as they have doubtless been by the reduction of Fort Donelson, have cleared both flanks of Gen. BUELL'S army of opposing enemies.
lead_paragraph: The victories of Mill Spring and Fort Henry, followed as they have doubtless been by the reduction of Fort Donelson, have cleared both flanks of Gen. BUELL'S army of opposing enemies. The former success, preceded by the dissolution of Humphrey Marshall's corps, compelled the rebels to evacuate Eastern Kentucky, leaving all the approaches into Eastern Tennessee open to the Unionists. The capture of Fort Henry, if supplemented by the capture of Fort Donelson, exposes both Nashville and Memphis to attack; and will doubtless compel the retirement of JOHNSTON, and the evacuation of Columbus. Indeed, the movements of Gen. GRANT and [???] FOOTE are so very energetic, that at any moment we may receive, without astonishment, news that the capital of Tennessce has fallen into their hands. A gunboat squadron is known to have entered the Cumberland, where the water is at the high stage of the Winter months. There is nothing to interrupt its voyage to Nashville. If the land forces could move with equal celerity, the movement would be the work of a day.

abstract: The roads at present are in such a wretched state that the greatest difficulty is experienced in teaming stores from the landing at Rum Point to the regiments composing this division. The embarrassment occasioned is so great that it is found necessary to bring up many supplies from Liverpool Point, by water, and this is only accomplished by running the rebel batteries, which is attended, of course, with great risk and peril.

abstract: papers of this City, in alluding to the return of CARL SCHURZ, in the Bavaria, from Europe, says that he has come merely on leave of absence, and not as an Ex-Ambassador. He had, indeed, sent in his resignation repeatedly, but the President declining to receive it, had merely accorded a leave of absence, which Mr. SCHURZ will employ to the best of his ability in endeavoring to bring about a modification of the internal policy of the country which, it is declared, is gaining for it the contempt not only of foreign Governments, but of their subjects universally. The same article goes on to declare that nearly all the American Envoys abroad are longing to return home. Mr. JUDD, our Minister at Berlin, who paid Mr. SCHURZ a visit at Hamburg, where his family, unwilling to accompany him to Madrid, have been for the last six months, is one of those. Mr. DAYTON, at Paris, is also said to be painfully impressed with the universal hostility manifested by the French people to the American Northern Stales.

lead_paragraph: The two leading British reviews each devote an article of their January issue to the consideration of the late difficulty with England; and, though they both take, as might be expected, a view of the matter antagonistic to the American Union, there is much in both that may be read with interest and advantage by the statesmen and politicians of this country. The writer in the now exceedingly Toryfied-Whig Edinburgh, argues strongly for the abolition of the right of search altogether, and of course is highly indignant at the stoppage of the Trent, more especially as, being a mail steamer, and proceeding toward a neutral port, he holds her to have been exempt from search, according to modern usage. He points out that in all recent maritime wars, even in the blockades of Buenos Ayres, Mexico, and Dalmatia, packets have been treated as privileged vessels; and that it is essential to the constitution of a contraband character that the vessel stopped should be proceeding toward the enemy's coast. England, we are told, carried this principle so far, even in the beginning of the present century, as to liberate a Dutch vessel bound to the Cape of Good Hope, on the ground that, during the period between her departure and the seizure, the colony had become a British possession. Cases illustrative of maritime belligerent rights have, however, been cited so profusely of late, that we are glad to turn from them to the views of the writer in the Edinburgh, on the expediency and utility of the right of visitation and search. The effect of the Declaration of Paris has been to limit the maritime rights of belligerents to blockade, and the seizure of articles contraband of war, including dispatches and persons in the naval or military service of the enemy; and the writer asks:

abstract: gives series of lectures at Brooklyn Academy of Music; Reports from around country
snippet: gives series of lectures at Brooklyn Academy of Music; Reports from around country
lead_paragraph: The third lecture of the series was delivered at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, on Sunday evening, Feb, 2. The house was full to overflowing. Mr. TAYLOR, President of the Brooklyn Institute, stated to the audience that he had been asked why these lectures were given on Sunday. His answer was, that the will of Mr. GRAHAM so required, and in addition to that, he deemed the subject a very appropriate one for consideration on that day.

abstract: Reports from Confederate States
snippet: Reports from Confederate States
lead_paragraph: The enemy have announced four grand objects as the aim of their strategy and of their vast system of preparation. First in importance among them is the advance upon Richmond from the banks of the Potomac. Next is the descent of the Mississippi, with a view to the capture of New-Orleans, and the opening of that great channel of navigation to the pent-up West. Next is the penetration of the interior from the direction of the Kanawha Valley, or from Eastern Kentucky, for the double purpose of breaking up our railroad communication from Lynchburg to Nashville, and of giving support to the disaffected population of East Tennessee. Lastly, is the invasion of North Carolina from the seaboard, and the capture of the great Southern line of railroad between Weldon and Wilmington. When these grand objects are stated, their whole programme is disclosed, for all other operations undertaken or carried on, are either auxiliary to these, or intended for mere local objects, such as opening a cotton port, or to subserve mere secondary and subordinate purposes.

abstract: Francis Morris, Appellant, vs. Margaret Astor Ward, Respondent.- The question in this case is whether Mr. Samuel Ward took by descent from his son, Wm. Samuel Ward, an estate in fee simple in certain lots at the foot of Fourteenth-street in this City, or only an estate for life. The property was settled by John Jacob Astor upon his grand-daughter Emily Astor, (daughter of Wm. B. Astor,) a few days after her marriage with Samuel Ward. The deed of settlement declares the consideration to be one dollar and natural love and affection. The lots in question were settled upon Mr. Ward for his life with remainder to his issue in fee. Mrs. Ward died in 1841, leaving two children - Margaret Astor Ward and Wm. Saml. Ward. The latter died shortly after his mother, and the question is what estate did his father take in the son's moiety of the lands. It appeared that Saml. Ward, upon the death of his son, assumed to take only an estate for life in said lots. During his absence in California, his daughter brought an action against him, and caused the estate to be sold to pay her father's share of taxes and other expenses incident to the lots. She was a minor at the time, and her grandfather, "Wm. B. Astor, who was her guardian, conducted the suit on her behalf. The title of Mr. Ward appeared to have been vested nominally in Mrs. Mary Griffin, who was also made a defendant in this suit. Morris became the purchaser under the judgment, and afterward, for the benefit of Ward, procured a conveyance from Mrs. Griffin of whatever estate she might hold in addition to an estate for the life of Samuel Ward, which was sold under the judicial proceedings. Being thus invested with the full claim, he now asks for a decree that he is entitled in fee simple, and not merely for the life of Ward.

abstract: We have received information from the officers of the United States sloop-of-war Savannah, to the effect that the expedition spoken of as having departed for the Savannah River has been wonderfully magnified, and, in fact, could scarcely be called an expedition, as it consisted only of a few small gunboats and one brigade, "or 2,000 men," which sailed...
lead_paragraph: We have received information from the officers of the United States sloop-of-war Savannah, to the effect that the expedition spoken of as having departed for the Savannah River has been wonderfully magnified, and, in fact, could scarcely be called an expedition, as it consisted only of a few small gunboats and one brigade, "or 2,000 men," which sailed from Port Royal for the purpose of reconnoitering the Savannah River and to keep the men in exercise. A portion of these boats entered the Savannah River by a creek on the north, and the others by a creek on the south, and upon reaching the river they found the channel obstructed, and could not proceed. They, however, discovered three or four of the enemy's fleet, on their way from Fort Pulaski to Savannah, who were obliged to run the gauntlet, and run by singly, when the Federal gunboats opened fire upon them, but could not ascertain the amount of damage done; hence the heavy firing heard in that direction. The main part of the expedition had returned to Port Royal, and when the Savannah left, a number of cannon were being sent through the creeks, but for what purpose it has not been ascertained.

abstract: We receive by way of Cincinnati some additional items of interest concerning the recent great victory at Fort Henry. At the time of the attack, the rebel infantry were in their camp disposing of their dinner, and when the firing commenced they abandoned everything, leaving...
lead_paragraph: We receive by way of Cincinnati some additional items of interest concerning the recent great victory at Fort Henry. At the time of the attack, the rebel infantry were in their camp disposing of their dinner, and when the firing commenced they abandoned everything, leaving thousands of shot-guns and all their camp equip-age and clothing. In the pursuit, bodies of our cavalry captured fourteen guns and thirty-three prisoners. Dispatches from Gen. HALLECK received in Washington state that our forces immediately pushed up the river in the direction of the rail-road bridge, sixteen miles distant, reducing on their way the batteries on the other side of the river. The bridge over the Tennessee River is undoubtedly now in our possession, and communication between Memphis and Bowling Green cut off. Fort Donelson, on the Cumberland River, has also doubtless been reduced ere this.

abstract: Harrisburgh Telegraph feels called upon to print the correspondence connected with the retirement of Mr. CAMERON from the Cabinet. It is marked "private," but there is no such thing in these days as epistolary privacy, and indeed we cannot discover a reason why these letters, which might be expected to throw light on a transaction not as perspicuous as it might be, should not have been published earlier. The reader will be the judge of the measure of light they really afford. We have every reason to believe that Secretary CAMERON was removed for incapacity, or something very much worse. Nothing of this sort appears in the correspondence - how could it? It is not the way of the political world to tell one's friend in so many words he is a thief, or an idiot; that he is unfitted for a position in which one has placed him, and must even take one of minor responsibility where knavery has no chance. We give him courtly phrases; consult his wishes; lavish upon him our God-speed, and look after him tenderly as he goes his way. Thus has the President dismissed CAMERON. But there is an abruptness in the business, which detracts from the effect of the courtesy. The letter of the President, dated on January 11, is evidently the first announcement the Secretary received of his discharge. In his reply dated the same day, the Secretary alludes to his wish to be relieved, formerly expressed, as a recollection the President had "revived," and pays a panegyric to his successor, whose name was not referred to by Mr. LINCOLN, and whose intended appointment must have been brought to his ear by rumor. Mr. CAMERON was, in truth, taken by surprise. He withdrew as gracefully as he might, the President endeavoring generously to cover his retreat; but the most desirable moral of his official story would be wanting, did we not go behind official phrase, and learn how well he had earned a less gentle dismission.

abstract: The Journal des Debals, a French journal so well known here for its liberal tone and its friendly sentiments towards America, has been discussing recently from an economical point of view, the effects of a war between the European Powers and this country.
lead_paragraph: The Journal des Debals, a French journal so well known here for its liberal tone and its friendly sentiments towards America, has been discussing recently from an economical point of view, the effects of a war between the European Powers and this country. It takes for its text a careful and well-considered circular of a leading cotton house of this City, published in the London Times. This firm, the NEILL BROTHERS, discuss for their English correspondents the probable effects of war on cotton oxport, and arrive at a quite different conclusion from that in vogue in Europe. The popular idea in England and France - shown recently by the very considerable fall in cotton during the Trent imbroglio - is that as soon as war was declared with the United States, and a French and English squadron had opened the Southern ports, a fleet of merchantmen would at once enter those harbors, bringing cargoes of manufactured goods, and then having laden themselves in return with vast quantities of cotton, they would sail quietly back over the ocean and supply the hungry manufacturers of England and the ouvriers of France, and prosperity and plenty would again return to those unfortunate classes.
headline: {'main': 'The Profits of a War for Cotton.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Profits of a War for Cotton.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- The rebel iron-sheathed annihilator, the Merrimac, is reported a total failure. We might suppose that this was given out as a rebel ruse, with the design to throw our naval force on the Potomac off its guard, had not various facts come out in the course of its construction that made it pretty evident it would be a failure. Months ago, on trying the iron-sheathing with columbiads it proved to be almost worthless. It now appears that an enormous error in the calculation of displacement, amounting to two hundred tons, was discovered when the ship was floated off lately, and that she " hogs" and "logs" and is a botch generally. The Norfolk Day Book, while censuring certain Richmond journals for letting out the fact of the Merrimac's failure, declares it is "an abortion." Horrors -- an abortion! But it is very much such "an abortion" as the rebellion, of which it is a very good type, is beginning to prove. Both have been put forth with the most blustering claims of what they would do -- both have been gigantic blunders in construction -- and the fizzle of the one is a sure harbinger of the failure of the other.

abstract: The steamer Eastern State arrived here this morning, having left Hatteras yesterday. She brings the important news that Gen. BURNSIDE' fleet left its anchorage at the Inlet, on Wednesday morning, for the North. The gunboats started at sunrise, and the troops and ships followed soon after. abstract: A SCENE AT TIFFANY'S. Yestesday, an honest countryman, who had traveled from home in a very dilapidated one-horse carl, left his team in front of TIFFANY'S marble palace while he went in to attend to some financial operation with the cashier and junior partner, Mr. ALFRED BEDFORD.
lead_paragraph: A SCENE AT TIFFANY'S. Yestesday, an honest countryman, who had traveled from home in a very dilapidated one-horse carl, left his team in front of TIFFANY'S marble palace while he went in to attend to some financial operation with the cashier and junior partner, Mr. ALFRED BEDFORD. He had but begun his story when his [???] was attracted by the sudden disappearance of his vehicle, which, besides being drawn by a $20 horse, contained his only son and heir, aged about ten years. Dropping instantly the matter in hand, he plunged violently through the crowd of astonished customers, shouting "Whoa, Bill, stop I tell you," at the top of his voice. On he went till he reached the doors, which are made of a single pane of plate glass. Never dreaming that any thing less solid than air was before him, he made one final dive, went head foremost against the glass, and landed, cut in forty places, on the pavement. He uttered an exclamation of astonishment, and then remembering "his lost child," ran swiftly up Broadway, until he was stopped by Officer DEVOE, who, imagining him to be a run away thief, arrested and returned him, cut and bleeding, to the store. The poor fellow finally comprehended the matter, but vowed he was never so astonished in the course of his life, which astonishment was somewhat increased when he learned that the cost of the door, which he smashed into a thousand fragments, was $100. His horse, wagon and boy were soon brought safely back, and he went home very much "mixed" in his mental mind as "to them Yorkers and their denied doors with glass in 'em."

abstract: Now the President and Mrs. LINCOLN gave a ball, and the World, the Flesh and the Devil went to it. For what kind of a ball would that be to which the World, the Flesh and the Devil did not go? Each of these great personages has given us, through his own particular...
lead_paragraph: Now the President and Mrs. LINCOLN gave a ball, and the World, the Flesh and the Devil went to it. For what kind of a ball would that be to which the World, the Flesh and the Devil did not go? Each of these great personages has given us, through his own particular Jenkins, an account of the affair. The World sent his, of course, to the paper which has assumed his name, and which, alas! has backslidden into the vanities appropriate thereunto; the Flesh sent his to the paper dearest to the inmost recesses of his stomach - the Tribune; and where the Devil sent his, no man who knows how well the Satanic Press has earned its name by serving him, need be told.

abstract: LES ENFANS PERDUS (LOST CHILDREN) -- A CONCERT TO BE GIVEN IN AID OF THE REGIMENT. -- Col. CONFORT, the commander of the above regiment, has recruited a fine body of men for this corps, nearly all of whom having seen active service in Europe. The name "Les Enfans Perdus," which was given to a celebrated French Regiment during the Crimean war, is on account of the regiment always being employed in the most hazardous and desperate undertakings. The "Lost Children" are under the especial patronage of Gen. MCCLELLAN, and will leave for the seat of war on the 21st of this month. Col. CONFORT intends giving, for the benefit of his regiment, two grand entertainments at the Academy of Music, on the evenings of the 17th and 16th inst. The programme will be a varied one, and will consist of evolutions by the men, dramatic performances, and a grand ball -- further particulars of which will be found in the advertising columns. Col. CONFORT is a French officer of distinction, having served with credit in Algeria and the Crimea.

abstract: It will be well for the public to recollect that all notices of skating or other matches, or other exhibitions on the Park, unless promulgated by the authorities of the Park, are the invention of persons having especial objects to serve. The Park Commissioners intend to maintain the Park an orderly place of amusement and recreation, and will see to it that none of these unauthorized matches or prize operations take place, to the prejudice of perfect order and decorum, or to the inconvenience of  the general public. When any entertainment of special interest to the public is contemplated, due notice will be given by the proper authorities.

lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the steamship America at Har fax we have intelligence from Europe two days later. She left Liverpool on the 25th, and Queenstown on the 26th ult. There were somewhat vague rumors in circulation, which find utterance through the London Shipping Gazette, to the effect that a semi-official note had been addressed to the British Government by France, respecting the Southern blockade, declaring that the Emperor cannot longer allow French commerce to be injured by respecting it, and that he will shortly make an official demand to the British Government to join him in raising it. The rumors further state, that in case the British Government should decline to do so, he will proceed alone. The Corps L�gislatif was to meet on the 27th, and the Emperor's speech on the occasion was expected to touch upon American affairs. The London Times had published another editorial deprecating interference, and urging the British people to wait, as they can afford to do so as long as the North and South can afford to look at each other across the Potomac at a cost of two millions sterling per week to each. The London Globe is in favor of opening the Southern ports immediately.

abstract: The Southern journals have an ingenious way of consoling themselves for the losses sustained by the rebel cause. It is to pooh-pooh every success gained by the National arms. Thus the Richmond papers are now busily proving that the capture of Fort Henry was "a foregone conclusion, whenever the enemy should think proper to bring a large force of men and artillery to bear upon it." These professions are in curious contrast with the loud boasts of impregnability invariably put forth for each position. But bluster and back down has been the rebel tactics throughout. It is like human nature to seek to be little what one has been forced unwillingly to give up. But Southern nature seems to intensify this peculiarity to a degree that is really a study.
lead_paragraph: The Southern journals have an ingenious way of consoling themselves for the losses sustained by the rebel cause. It is to pooh-pooh every success gained by the National arms. abstract: Editorial on British press views on US finances
snippet: Editorial on British press views on US finances
lead_paragraph: We have had sauce enough from England of late; but of that particular kind of sauce which is suited both to the goose and the gander, we have received none at all. This sort of unevenhanded justice is flagrantly manifested in regard to our recent financial measures consequent upon the insurrection. The suspension of specie payments is pronounced "very like an act of national bankruptcy." "When," adds the Morning Herald, "a private individual or public company does this,we say that they are bankrupt." But in that case very often "we" say what the event proves to be untrue. For in how many instances in this country and in some, as we know, in England, is suspension of payment followed by relief to all parties concerned and prosperity to one, and in case of a winding up of a concern with a payment in full and a handsome surplus, when an opposite course would have insured a loss to all parties, and the ruin of one. But our Secretary of the Treasury is said, by his English censor, to have only followed "truly national example." The old Confederation, it is said, "contracted debts and refused to pay them. Pennsylvania contracted debts, and in a like fashton swindled her creditors." Notice here the ignoring of the absolute impossibility of the payment of its debts by the old Confederation; but chiefly the untruthful statement with regard to Pennsylvania, all of whose bonds were finally paid in full, and the studious neglect to bring to mind the absolute repudiation of the State, Mississippi, which has furnished the insurrection with a leader, a leader who is the very apostle and archpriest of repudiation. Not more religiously or distinctly does the sponsor in baptism renounce the devil and all his works, on behalf of his god-child, than Mr. DAVIS renounced her debts and all her liabilities in behalf of Mississippi, adding thereunto a denunciation of her creditors. But, although Pennsylvania, who assumed her debt, is held up to the scorn of the British nation, the flagrant sins of the faith-breaking Slave States are passed over in utter silence.

abstract: Our Special WashingtonCorrespondent telegraphs that the Treasury bill will be reported by the Finance Committee of the Senate, as it came from the House, including the legal tender clause, but with the important amendment to make the interest on the Public Debt payable in coin, and pledging the Customs Revenue to this object. Another amendment is made to authorize Treasury deposits at five per cent. interest, to the extent of $25,000,000. Our Correspondent adds that the legal tender clause will be adopted by a large majority of the Senate.

Another amendment is made to authorize Treasury deposits at five per cent. interest, to the extent of $25,000,000. Our Correspondent adds that the legal tender clause will be adopted by a large majority of the Senate.

abstract: We have advices from Havana to the 25th ult., and from Vera Cruz to the 21st. The Allied force in Mexico numbered at that time some sixteen thousand men, while the Mexicans had collected between Vera Cruz and Mexico, according to all accounts, some fifty thousand. For sanitary considerations, a portion of the Allied forces, with the consent of Gen. UPAGA, had occupied two or three small villages adjacent to the city.
lead_paragraph: We have advices from Havana to the 25th ult., and from Vera Cruz to the 21st. The Allied force in Mexico numbered at that time some sixteen thousand men, while the Mexicans had collected between Vera Cruz and Mexico, according to all accounts, some fifty thousand. For sanitary considerations, a portion of the Allied forces, with the consent of Gen. UPAGA, had occupied two or three small villages adjacent to the city. A manifesto, taking the shape of an ultimatum, had been issued to the Mexicans, setting forth the ostensible designs of the Allies, and closing with a dispatch from each of the Plenipotentiaries stating their claims. The very latest advices state that an advance had been made, the Mexicans retiring as the Allies advanced. This intelligence is not quite so late, apparently, as that received by way of San Francisco, announcing a battle at the National Bridge.

abstract: "A courier arrived at this place on Tuesday evening last. from Pound Gap, bringing information of a battle having been fought near Prestonburgh, Ky., on Friday last, the 10th inst., between the Confederate forces under Gen. MARSHALL, and the Federal forces under a Gen. MOORE. Gen. MARSHALL's forces engaged did not exceed fifteen hundred, (Col. TRIGG's regiment being held in reserve,) while that of the enemy is reported at from six to ten thousand. Our forces repulsed the enemy three times with a reported loss on their side of four hundred killed. Our loss is some fifteen or twenty killed and wounded. Col. A.C. MOORE, of the Twenty-ninth Regiment Virginia Volunteers is reported to have deported himself very gallantly, as did also his men. He lost some five or six of his men killed and several wounded.

abstract: been quartered at Port Richmond, Staten Island, for some time past, embarked on board the steamer John Potts for Amboy, in route for Washington. This regiment has been enlisted especially for garrison duty in or near Washington. It is understood that one batallion will be assigned to Fort Greene, and the other to Fort Corcoran, both of which are in Virginia. In the list of officers published a few days ago in the TIMES, there were a few vacancies which have been filled as follows In Company F, Edward A. Tudor has been appointed Captain; in Company K, Wm. Waterbury and D.K. Smith Jones have been chosen Second Lieutenants; in Company H. George Bliss has been appointed Captain, J. Henry Thorp, First Lieutenant, and Edward C. Knower, Second Lieutenant.

abstract: Mr. STANTON promptly followed up the victory over ZOLLICOFFER with a bulletin, which stirred the nation with its terse eloquence. His ringing words will doubtless be remembered by our brave soldiers on every battle-field, and by them they will be urged to nobler deeds, in the hope of receiving still more emphatic commendations. But why has not Secretary WELLES followed the example thus happily see him? Commodore FOOTE and the sailors who poured such a terrible fire into the rebel stronghold, never flinching for an instant under that which they received in return, certainly deserve the warmest words of praise. Gen. MCCLELLAN and Mr. STANTON have briefly and informally approved their acts and Gen. HALLECK's energy. Please speak out, Mr. WELLES.

abstract: Gen. STONE, recently removed, as will be seen by our Washington dispatches, from the command of his division on the Potomac, and put under arrest for treason, arrived, in custody of United States Marshal BANT, at Jersey City, yesterday, en route for Port Lafayette. His arrival was not known to the employe[???] at the d\'e9p\'f4t. He was conveyed quietly across the river, thence down the bay to the fort. On the passage from Philadelphia, the fact of Gen. STONE being on board the cars was not known to hardly any of the passengers. And those who did know were requested to keep the matter a secret. The charges upon which the General was arrested, as will be seen elsewhere, refer to his loyalty or want of loyalty, but of this fact no one was, at that time, cognizant.

abstract: The patriotism of Mr. GEORGE D. MORGAN has been repeatedly vouched for by his sympathizing sponsor, Mr. Secretary WELLES. What notion these two trusted servants of the Republic have of the sacred quality which as NAPOLEON used to say is "the chief of human virtues, the noblest form of disinterested duty," may be seen from the correspondence on the purchase of the Mercedita which we published yesterday. The story there recorded is by no means the most flagrant of those the particulars of which have been laidbefore us. The vessel in question is a screw steamer, till lately engaged in the Southern trade. The owners having no use for her when their commercial arrangements were broken up by the rebellion, were waited on by an agent commissioned by Mr. WELLES, who opened negotiations for the purchase of the ship. Anxious to be rid of the importunity, and to resist the extortions of this person, the owners wrote direct to the Government, offering to sell the vessel at any price which might be fixed by the Department. This offer was promptly refused, and the preceding negotiations were as promptly renewed by Mr. WELLES's satellite, who made ineffectual attempts to exact a bribe of $5,000, to be given, as he said, to men of influence in the Department to induce them to acquiesce in the purchase. The shipowners very properly refused to be parties to any such disgraceful proceedings, and thought they had succeeded in " keeping their record clear."
lead_paragraph: The patriotism of Mr. GEORGE D. MORGAN has been repeatedly vouched for by his sympathizing sponsor, Mr. Secretary WELLES. What notion these two trusted servants of the Republic have of the sacred quality which as NAPOLEON used to say is "the chief of human virtues, the noblest form of disinterested duty," may be seen from the correspondence on the purchase of the Mercedita which we published yesterday. The story there recorded is by no means the most flagrant of those the particulars of which have been laidbefore us. The vessel in question is a screw steamer, till lately engaged in the Southern trade. The owners having no use for her when their commercial arrangements were broken up by the rebellion, were waited on by an agent commissioned by Mr. WELLES, who opened negotiations for the purchase of the ship. Anxious to be rid of the importunity, and to resist the extortions of this person, the owners wrote direct to the Government, offering to sell the vessel at any price which might be fixed by the Department. This offer was promptly refused, and the preceding negotiations were as promptly renewed by Mr. WELLES's satellite, who made ineffectual attempts to exact a bribe of $5,000, to be given, as he said, to men of influence in the Department to induce them to acquiesce in the purchase. The shipowners very properly refused to be parties to any such disgraceful proceedings, and thought they had succeeded in " keeping their record clear."

abstract: Winter has its own delights -- many, indeed' which, in the estimation of the wholesome Northern temperament, Summer, with all her splendors, cannot rival. It is not the fireside spell alone which Winter wields. To those who love him, and fear him not, he is beneficent as well as kindly. From the caves of Aurora he gathers the bloom he scatters on the lips and cheeks of his votaries; and the sparkle of the Polar star is not brighter than the light he freshens in their eyes. Health and jovial pleasure attend the coming of the Icy King when hailed aright. So seemed to think the gay and fair of Brooklyn yesterday, and the occasion offered them by the Washington Skating Club to hold a carnival in costume on the Fifth avenue pond, in the southern suburb of the city. The pond, which was beautifully hardened by the sharp cold of Sunday night and Monday morning, was, notwithstanding the full sunshine of the forenoon, in fine condition yesterday at 3 P.M., the hour fixed for the commencement of the festival. Unfortunately, some misunderstanding had arisen in respect to the admission of guests, the advertisement fixing the admission fee, for any and all, at twenty-five cents per head, while many members of the Club vehemently contended that the price stated was merely an extra contribution to be levied upon the members of the Club, who, only, could be admitted, with their families, according to the bye laws of the organization. This disagreement led to an uncertainty, which prevented the attendance from being, at an early hour, what had been expected. DODWORTH's Band, of twenty-five pieces, was, however, promptly present and in fine tune. The bright sky, the exhilarating atmosphere, and the excellent condition of the ice, which covers a superficies of some acres in extent, proved temptations too strong for even discontent to resist, and by sundown the up-cars were, thronged with eager crowds of both sexes, and nearly all ages from the toddling "3-year-old" to venerable age. On the way along Fifth-avenue, too, there wore processions of pedestrians hurrying toward he same point, and every here and there were large ponds covered with the overplus of the skating fraternity, who had not the patience, inclination or cash to visit the Washington ice-field. By dusk, the Club house on the edge of the grand pond was uncomfortably filled with ladies and their escort and many hundred pairs of skates were ringing a merry chorus on the ice. The frigid rule of the Club was abandoned, and all well-behaved persons paying the needful "quarter," were at once admitted within the gateway. From 7 o'clock, the throng rapidly increased until at 8, a fair estimate could be formed of the success of the festival Passing from the Clubhouse with its dense mass of occupants struggling every inmate with his or her neighbor, for even standing room, the coup d'aeil was very fine. The ice, unfortunately, was not well illuminated; only a few reflector-lamps on eight-foot posts here and there, contending with the shades of evening; but the moon was unusually fair for the season, and the sky pure as a crystal dome. The pond rests in a cavity of the soil surrounded and overlooked on three sides by high embankments, upon and beyond which run the streetways which inclose those portions of the square. These banks were lined with multitudes of spectators, standing compactly and silently together like regiments seen at night drawn up in line of battle, an illusion which, from time to time, the flash of the irons flung over the arm of some departing skater who yet lingered for another glimpse at the scene, helped to convey. The broad plateau of ice, powdered with the snowy scurf tossed up by a thousand steel runners, presented an ever-changing, ever brilliant scene of kaleidoscopic oddity and picturesqueness, the ring of merry voices and the rush of iron-shod feet, chiming in quaintly with the beat of dancing music But let us not be carried too far from the recollection of individual features in the survey of the general scene, gay as it was. The costumes were not very numerous, but were in many instances good, and the characters assumed by those who wore them well sustained.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a memorial from the Hatteras citizens of North Carolina, insisting upon the right of Mr. FOSTER to represent them in Congress, was presented. The resolutions passed by the New-York Legislative, in favor of each State being allowed to assess and collect its share of the National tax, were presented. A petition of Citizens of Maine, asking Congress to drop the "negro question," and attend to the business of the country, was also presented. The Committee on Military Affairs was requested to inquire into the expediency of completing the military road from Point Douglas in Minnesota toSuperior City in Wisconsin. Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, gave notice of a bill to establish a National foundry. A bill concerning contracts and orders for Government supplies was referred. The bill to incorporate the Georgetown and Washington Railroad Company was taken up, and passed after some debate, after being amended so as to secure three per cent. of the gross receipts of the Company for the support of the Washington schools. The report of the Commit tee on Conference on the bill establishing Home Guards in Missouri and Maryland, was taken up, and agreed to after explanations from Mr. HENDERSON, of Missouri. Mr. SUMNER's resolution, that the Finance Committee be directed to inquire into the expediency of establishing a National institution for savings, and the fiscal agency of the Government, was taken up, and Mr. SUMNER proceeded to explain the objects of the proposed measure, but gave way to a motion for an Executive Session, after which the Senate adjourned.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- Mr. GRAU's brief season of opera came to an end last evening, when BELLINI's "Somnambula" was played to a fashionable but not over-crowded house. Miss KELLOGG appeared as Amina for the first time, and succeeded in adding another branch to that cluster of laurels which she has gathered so worthily during the past and present seasons. The music of the unfortunate village maiden lays easily within the range of Miss KELLOGG's voice, and the many touches of pathos with which it is filled are admirably adapted to the lady's earnest and tender style. In the first and last acts she was heard to the best advantage, the overwhelming scene of the second act (the finale) being rather too physical in its character for a vocalist of delicately intellectual resources.

abstract: The Advertiser states that volunteering is going on in Mobile with a rush, and adds: "In two weeks' time our volunteer army will make a show with glittering pikes, streaming pennons, double-barreled guns and bowie-knife cleavers. So every good and loyal citizen will be able to feel the comfortable assurance that, if the negro refrain, 'Picayune Butler's come to town,' should be realized by the march of that Massachusetts hero upon our fair city, every man will be in arms to welcome him with 'bloody hands to hospitable graves' -- that we have not gone to sleep, depending solely for the safety of our homes upon Confederate troops and neighbors who may rush to our defence."

abstract: The intelligence that a General in the service of the Union has been arrested at the head of his Division, and consigned to State Prison as a traitor, will profoundly shock the public mind. Gen. STONE is an inmate of Fort Lafayette. Arrested on Saturday night at his Headquarters, he was yesterday brought to this City, and placed in the custody of Col. BURKE.
lead_paragraph: The intelligence that a General in the service of the Union has been arrested at the head of his Division, and consigned to State Prison as a traitor, will profoundly shock the public mind. Gen. STONE is an inmate of Fort Lafayette. Arrested on Saturday night at his Headquarters, he was yesterday brought to this City, and placed in the custody of Col. BURKE. From our Washington correspondent we receive a resume of the charges upon which this action is founded. Government, we learn, has reason to believe the slaughter at Ball's Bluff to have been less the result of military incompetency than of a preconcerted plan to deliver our troops into the hands of the enemy. Of the character and strength of the evidence relied upon to sustain this fearful inculpation, we are, of course, unapprised. It must indeed, be cogent: for, to fix upon an officer the guilt of deliberately exposing his troops to be slaughtered pitilessly and helplessly by traitors, only less culpable than himself, no testimony that is not entirely conclusive should be received. Other charges -- one of holding treasonable communication with the enemy, and two of recent treachery -- are also made. They are probably more easily capable of proof than the first-mentioned; but they are none the less infamous and shocking than it though, fortunately, they have not been permitted to go on to as fatal an issue.
