abstract: A fresh report from Norfolk brings further confirmation of the tidings that BURNSIDE has really got to work, and that hostilities against Roanoke Island have begun. As we had news direct from the fleet that the Expedition sailed from Hatteras Inlet for that point on Wednesday last, there is no doubt the report is perfectly authentic. There is also very good ground for surmising that the movement has been quite successful; for it has become established as a principle, which we have come to count on with all the confidence of an astronomical law, that when our Norfolk neighbors keep back intelligence, it is because it is of such a character that we would like exceedingly to hear it.
lead_paragraph: A fresh report from Norfolk brings further confirmation of the tidings that BURNSIDE has really got to work, and that hostilities against Roanoke Island have begun. By dusk, the Club house on the edge of the grand pond was uncomfortably filled with ladies and their escort and many hundred pairs of skates were ringing a merry chorus of the ice. The frigid rule of the Club was abandoned, and all well behaved persons paying the needful "quarter," were at once admitted within the gateway. From 7 o'clock, the throng rapidly increased until at 8, a fair estimate could be formed of the success of the festival. Passing from the Club house with its dense mass of occupants struggling every inmate with his or her neighbor, for even standing room, the coup d'ail was very fine. The ice, unfortunately, was not well illuminated, only a few reflector-lamps on eight fool posts here and there, contending with the shades of evening; but the moon was unusually fair for the season, and the sky pure as a crystal dome. The pond rests in a cavity of the soil surrounded and overlooked on three sides by high embankments, upon and beyond which run the streetways which inclose those portions of the square. These banks were lined with multitudes of spectators, standing compactly and silently together like regiments seen at night drawn up in line of battle, an Illusion which, from time to time, the flash of the irons flung over the arm of some departing skater who yet lingered for another glimpse at the scene, helped to convey. The broad plateau of ice, powdered with the snowy scarf tossed up by a thousand steel runners, presented an ever-changing, ever brilliant scene of kaleidoscopic oddity and picturesqueness, the ring of merry voices and the rush of [???] feet, chiming in quaintly with the beat of dancing music But let us not be carried too far from the recollection of individual features in the survey of the general scene, gay as it was. The costumes were not very numerous, but were in many instances good, and the characters assumed by those who wore them well sustained.

abstract: It is verygratifying to note the spirit of Christian resignation displayed by the rebel journals in their discussions of the recent defeats suffered by the Confederate arms. That impetuous paper, the Memphis Avalanche, quotes with serene satisfaction the Shakesperean apothegin, "Sweet are the uses of adversity," and proceeds to discourse of ZOLLICOFFER's [???] in a tone which would impel one not acquainted with the antecedents of the paper, to the conclusion that its editors were regularly ordained ministers of the Gospel. So, too, theRichmond Dispatch declares that the loss of Fort Henry is not at all a surprise, and that the interruption of railroad communication between Bowling Green and Columbus is merely a trifling inconvenience.

abstract: The transport fleet, as it rendezvoused at An napolis, consisted, aside from the naval forces of 59 vessels of all sizes, ranging from the steam-tug, to the big side wheel steamship, and from the schooner to the largest ship. In tonnage, they range from one to twelve hundred tons, and in draft from three to...
lead_paragraph: The transport fleet, as it rendezvoused at An napolis, consisted, aside from the naval forces of 59 vessels of all sizes, ranging from the steam-tug, to the big side wheel steamship, and from the schooner to the largest ship. In tonnage, they range from one to twelve hundred tons, and in draft from three to eleven feet. The class of vessels employed, naval and transport, and the whole character of the force, are adapted only to such operations as could be conducted in inland waters, and it was evident from the first that the North Carolina waters were to be the scene of action, as there are no other accessible south of Fortress Monroe. There has been great dissatisfaction at the character of some of the vessels, but the great bulk of them, as the event has shown, are staunch and seaworthy.

abstract: John M. Caballos vs. Augustus Schell -- This was an action against the defendant, as Collector, to recover back certain amounts paid by the plaintiff for half-storage on goods imported by him. The ware-housing act of 1854, having empowered the Secretary of the Treasury to make necessary regulations for carrying out the act, he made one, among others, to the effect that if the parties desired, after they had completed the entry of their goods for warehousing, to sell them directly from their vessel, they might be allowed to do so on the payment of half a month's storage. This proceeding enabled the parties to save the expense and risk of carting the goods to and from the warehouse, and the month's storage which would be due on them, though they remained less than a month in store. The plaintiff having paid various amounts for this half-month's storage on goods imported by him at various times, brought this suit to recover back the amount, claiming that the amounts were illegally exacted, and that he was compelled to pay them to get possession of his goods. No objection or protest against the payments was proved, and the defence took the ground that whether the charge were a proper one or not, yet that the plaintiff had paid the amounts voluntarily, and could not, therefore, recover them back. The Judge-directed the jury to find a verdict for the defendant.
lead_paragraph: John M. Caballos vs. Augustus Schell -- This was an action against the defendant, as Collector, to recover back certain amounts paid by the plaintiff for half-storage on goods imported by him. The ware-housing act of 1854, having empowered the Secretary of the Treasury to make necessary regulations for carrying out the act, he made one, among others, to the effect that if the parties desired, after they had completed the entry of their goods for warehousing, to sell them directly from their vessel, they might be allowed to do so on the payment of half a month's storage. This proceeding enabled the parties to save the expense and risk of carting the goods to and from the warehouse, and the month's storage which would be due on them, though they remained less than a month in store. The plaintiff having paid various amounts for this half-month's storage on goods imported by him at various times, brought this suit to recover back the amount, claiming that the amounts were illegally exacted, and that he was compelled to pay them to get possession of his goods. No objection or protest against the payments was proved, and the defence took the ground that whether the charge were a proper one or not, yet that the plaintiff had paid the amounts voluntarily, and could not, therefore, recover them back. The Judge-directed the jury to find a verdict for the defendant.

abstract: The steamer Ellen S. Terry has been chartered by Quartermaster BIGGS, to convey ordnance and supplies to the Burnside Expedition, and probably will be dispatched to day. She will also take out Assistant Quartermaster LOREING, and forty men of the Marine Artillery, and a mail. It is understood that Quartermaster BIGGS will deposit $50,000 with the United States Assistant Treasurer in this City, which amount will be placed to the credit of Capt. CUTTING, of the Quartermaster's Department, and disbursed by him, in the form of checks, to the soldiers and seamen serving in the Expedition. By his method the checks can be returned to families here, who, upon presenting them at the proper place, will receive their equivalent in money.

abstract: Editorial on outlook for French and British intervention
snippet: Editorial on outlook for French and British intervention
lead_paragraph: The Emperor NAPOLEON has a reputation for disappointing expectations. Those who expected he would use the occasion of opening the Legislative Chamber to announce his resolution to acknowledge the Southern Confederacy, and declare the blockade invalid have now had their disappointment; for his speech, taking a contrary direction, sustains the propriety of preserving neutrality, until neutral rights shall be infringed by the belligerents. The blockade, therefore, is not at present a violation of neutral rights. Some fresh accident or incident, or a maintenance of the blockade until its existence threatens to be interminable, must furnish the groundwork of that policy of intervention, which is just now wanting. A London paper, the Morning Advertiser, attributes this extreme moderation of tone to a remonstrance of Lord RUSSEL, who is said to have begged a longer probation for our Government. But the Advertiser is of no authority, and its explanation may go for nothing.

abstract: There were two sentences in the dispatch announcing the capture of Fort Henry which were by no means the least interesting or important. GRANT will attack Fort Donelson tomorrow."

abstract: Our readers will remember the case of MATTHEWS, who was stabbed by a party of roughs on Thursday last. Owing to his well-known sporting character, his condition has excited the liveliest interest among the peculiar class of which he was a prominent member. The fact that as yet he is not dead, induced the counsel for the prisoners charged with his assault, to endeavor by the appliance of a writ of habeas corpus to remove from the immediate attention of the law their clients.

abstract: Senate Finance committee amends bill; editorial; Dispatches from Washington; Senate Finance committee amends bill; editorial
snippet: Senate Finance committee amends bill; editorial; Dispatches from Washington; Senate Finance committee amends bill; editorial
lead_paragraph: The Senate's Finance Committee has agreed upon sundry amendments to the House United States Note bill. Among them are: To strike out the declaration that the authorization to issue $150,000,000 is to meet the necessities of the Treasury, and to provide a currency receivable for the public dues; and to insert that the Notes shall be receivable in payment of all public dues and demands of every description, and of all claims and demands against the United States of every kind whatsoever, except for interest upon Bonds and Notes which shall be paid in coin, and shall also be lawful money and a legal tender in payment of all debts, public and private within the United States, except interest as aforesaid.

abstract: The conclusion arrived at by the Congressional Committee in regard to Gen. STONE and his services, correspond with a very current popular impression. Among those who had occasion to note the career of the man, much surprise was felt at his promotion to a position...
lead_paragraph: The conclusion arrived at by the Congressional Committee in regard to Gen. STONE and his services, correspond with a very current popular impression. Among those who had occasion to note the career of the man, much surprise was felt at his promotion to a position so vital to the success of the Union cause, especially as his sympathies and associations had openly inclined to the cause of secession, and nothing could be easier than at the post to which he was assigned, to maintain communication with the enemy. There is, perhaps, no doubt, that such intercourse has been maintained by the prisoner. But whether or not the correspondence was treasonable; whether it was he who transmited passwords and admonitions of proposed movements, to the enemy, thereby defeating or crippling the few demonstrations of energy the army has made, is still undetermined, and of the doubt the prisoner is entitled to the benefit.

abstract: more data on capture
snippet: more data on capture
lead_paragraph: North Carolina has no very populous towns. Raleigh, the capital of the State, has a population of 5,000; Newbern, formerly the capital, 5,000; Wilmington, (on the extreme southern point of the State, and its largest town,) 9,000; Fayetteville, 5,000; Beaufort, 2,000; Goldsboro', 1,000; Weldon, 1,000; and there are many other small towns scattered throughout the State, ranging from 1,000 to 3,000 inhabitants. By the last census, the population of the State was 661,586 freemen, and 331,081 slaves. These, free and slave, are nearly all native-born, only two or three thousand Europeans having taken up their residence there.

abstract: In this Court yesterday, before Recorder HOFFMAN, the trial of Frederick Lenor for the murder of Thomas Ryan, at a dance-house kept by the prisoner, on New-Year's Eve, was continued, and occupied the day. The case was summed up for the prisoner by James T. Brady, Esq., who claimed that there was no proof that the pistol which killed the deceased was discharged by the prisoner, but every reason to believe that it was the act of some one of the parties who had been creating the disturbance in the saloon. The District-Attorney will sum up the case for the Government at the opening of the Court this morning.

abstract: -- An address, entitled Mistakes of Educated Men, delivered at the Commencement of Pennsylvania College, in 1861, by JOHN S. HART' LL. D., is published by D.C. GARRIQUES, of Philadelphia. We are glad to see the second edition of this address before the public in so inviting a form. It abounds with sensible advice to students, and inculcates maxims, which, if practiced by young men in the walk of life, would save them from committing the mistakes into which so many educated men have fallen. Moreover, the address is entirely free from that pedantry and dictatory spirit which mar the usefulness of so many works of this kind. Dr. HART talks to his parish of young men as a father might -- a good, sensible father, who didn't whine any.

abstract: It was announced in yesterday morning's dispatches from Washington, that the Secretary of War had sent one of the special employes of the Herald to Fort McHenry. The grounds of arrest are of a two-fold nature; first, suspicion of treason and alleged complicity with the enemy; and secondly, offensive, intrusive...
lead_paragraph: It was announced in yesterday morning's dispatches from Washington, that the Secretary of War had sent one of the special employes of the Herald to Fort McHenry. The grounds of arrest are of a two-fold nature; first, suspicion of treason and alleged complicity with the enemy; and secondly, offensive, intrusive and gross impertinence in the War office, where threats were made of the vengeance of the Herald upon all officials who should deny this letter-writer information of a confidential or exclusive tenor, which, from prudential considerations, had been withheld from the Press generally.

abstract: Mr. ARNOLD, from the Special Committee on Lake and River Defences, will make his report to-morrow. He will report in favor of a National Foundry, and a depot for arms at Chicago, a naval depot on Lake Michigan, a naval depot on, Lake Erie and a naval depot on Lake Ontario. Also for fortifications on the Northern frontier, as recommended in the report of Gen. TOTTEN, and appropriating $1,400,000 to carry out the works, which includes appropriations for Mackinaw, Ports Brady, Gratico, Wayne, Buffalo, Niagara, mouth of the Genesee River, and Oswego, beside shore defences.

abstract: We have now news enough from Southern sources to infer that BURNSIDE has achieved a complete success, and that the rebels have suffered a severe defeat by land and by water. With Norfolk in a panic, as is reported from Fortress Monroe, we can hardly expect...
lead_paragraph: We have now news enough from Southern sources to infer that BURNSIDE has achieved a complete success, and that the rebels have suffered a severe defeat by land and by water. With Norfolk in a panic, as is reported from Fortress Monroe, we can hardly expect to receive a composed or consistent account of the affair, even if there were the disposition to give it, and we shall probably have to await a dispatch-boat by was of Hatteras for detailed intelligence. For the information that we have, we, in common with other journals, are indebted to the enterprise of the Fortress Monroe correspondent of the Philadelphia Inquirer, and it establishes, beyond a doubt, that Roanoke Island is in the possession of our forces, after a three days' combat, naval and military, which brilliantly illustrated the resources, the pluck and the valor of both arms of the Nation a service. For, in this victory, the cooperation of the land and sea forces seems to have attained a completeness not reached in any of our former expeditions. Port Royal and Hatteras were exclusively naval victories, but Roanoke called forth and combined the effective qualities of both arms of the service. We have as yet no details of the work done on the island after landing, and only know it was triumphantly done, and that the National Standard was planted over the enemy's fortifications. But the naval bulletin is certainly as brilliant as one could well desire. Of the rebel fleet, under command of Commodore LYNCH, three gunboats were sunk, two were captured, and the rest dispersed in every direction!

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, a resolution from the New-York Chamber of Commerce, urging the immediate passage of the Treasury Note bill, was presented. A petition, signed by 25,315 persons, in favor of homoeopathic practice in the army, was also presented, with several others of lesser importance. A petition from citizens of Philadelphia, similar to that presented by Mr. GRITTENDEN in the House, praying for the...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, a resolution from the New-York Chamber of Commerce, urging the immediate passage of the Treasury Note bill, was presented. A petition, signed by 25,315 persons, in favor of homoeopathic practice in the army, was also presented, with several others of lesser importance. A petition from citizens of Philadelphia, similar to that presented by Mr. GRITTENDEN in the House, praying for the observance of WASHINGTON's Birthday, was presented by Mr. JOHNSON, of Tennessee, and a resolution to carry out the suggestions of the petition was passed. Mr. SUMNER, of Massachusetts, offered a series of resolutions declaratory of the relations of the Government with certain States, which were laid on the table, 21 to 15. They advocated emancipation as a war measure. A bill to authorize the banks of the District of Columbia to issue small notes, was referred. The Fortification bill was taken up and debated until the Senate found itself without a quorum, when it adjourned. During the proceedings, Mr. FESSENDEN, of Maine, gave notice that he should call up the Treasury Note bill to-day, and press it to a speedy passage.

abstract: To the Editor of the New-York Times: Every loyal citizen of the United States must feel gratified at the recent arrest of the traitor, Gen' STONE, and the impudent correspondent of the NewYork Herald. For my part, I regard it as a decided ...
lead_paragraph: To the Editor of the New-York Times: Every loyal citizen of the United States must feel gratified at the recent arrest of the traitor, Gen' STONE, and the impudent correspondent of the NewYork Herald. For my part, I regard it as a decided step in the right direction. It shows that new energy and spirit have been infused into the War Department by the present Secretary, which is very commendable, and has heretofore been wanting.

abstract: Accounts from Washington show that vengeance is pursuing like fate the agents and representatives of the Herald. No sooner is IVES fairly lodged in Fort McHenry, than a colleague, that saucy adventurer WIKOFF, receives a touch of Governmental discipline, the House of Representatives having voted to place him in confinement until he answers ...
lead_paragraph: Accounts from Washington show that vengeance is pursuing like fate the agents and representatives of the Herald. No sooner is IVES fairly lodged in Fort McHenry, than a colleague, that saucy adventurer WIKOFF, receives a touch of Governmental discipline, the House of Representatives having voted to place him in confinement until he answers a question propounded him by a Committee of that body. A portion of the annual message at the opening of the extra session appeared, it may be remembered, in the Herald prior to its submission to Congress. This bit of enterprise has been traced to WIKOFF, who, strange to say, had admission at the Executive mansion, and when a question was put by the Committee as to the source from which he received the manuscript, the fellow declined to answer on the ground that he was pledged to secrecy. His contumacy has been properly noticed by the House.

abstract: the absorption of the public mind, in the immediate practical business of putting down the rebellion, will rather interfere with our giving the attention its importance demands to the diplomatic correspondence in the sequel of the Trent affair. It has been regarded on the Continent of Europe as a sufficient compensation for the distressing aspects of the great international difficulty, that the adjustment of the case would lead to a clear definition of many hitherto unsettled points of the public code with reference to neutral and belligerent rights. This has also been our own feeling. And hence it is gratifying to see the British Government respond so promptly to the hope of Mr. SEWARD, expressed in his dispatch on the Trent case, and which, it will be remembered, was seconded by the note of M. THOUVENEL -- that the occasion of the correspondence would be so improved as to secure a mutual understanding between all the maritime Powers. We have the first fruits of the international conference in the dispatch of Earl RUSSELL, which we published yesterday. This elaborate paper is wholly occupied with the question as to whether "persons" and "dispatches" can be considered contraband of war. Earl RUSSELL announces definitively that England cannot so consider them. The result is good and satisfactory, and the United States gladly accepts the doctrine. But it is somewhat amusing that the Foreign Secretary, in his elaborate process of reasoning, seems to think he is demolishing a position held by Mr. SEWARD! Mr. SEWARD did, indeed, in the first part of his dispatch, argue, hypothetically, the quasi contraband character of persons and dispatches. But it was only as a deduction from the dicta of English jurists -- not the declaration of an American principle. On the contrary, the American principle is quite the other way, and is precisely what Earl RUSSELL now announces with so much zeal as the British doctrine. Both sides may well be satisfied accordingly.

Mr. SEWARD did, indeed, in the first part of his dispatch, argue, hypothetically, the quasi contraband character of persons and dispatches. But it was only as a deduction from the dicta of English jurists -- not the declaration of an American principle. On the contrary, the American principle is quite the other way, and is precisely what Earl RUSSELL now announces with so much zeal as the British doctrine. Both sides may well be satisfied accordingly.

abstract: An article in the Opinion Nationale of Paris, from the pen of one of its ablest and shrewdest col laborateurs, M. ADOLPHE GUEROULT, very adroitly reviews the results of the late MASON and SLIDELL im- ...
lead_paragraph: An article in the Opinion Nationale of Paris, from the pen of one of its ablest and shrewdest col laborateurs, M. ADOLPHE GUEROULT, very adroitly reviews the results of the late MASON and SLIDELL imbroglio, and throws considerable light upon the efforts made by secessionist agents in France to array that Power on the side of the Southern Confederacy. It assumes, in the outset, that England has been, for some time past, seeking a pretext of quarrel with the Northern States, and that, intensely disappointed at the surrender of the Rebel Commissioners, she is now endeavoring to found her casus belli upon the stone blockade of Charleston harbor. In this connection, it reverts to the recent Sikh revolt in India, and after briefly sketching the military rigors inflicted by British armies upon the insurgents, pertinently asks how England would have liked an American recognition of NENA SAHIB. An article in the Morning Post, urging an intervention to stop the American struggle, is made the theme of satire and rebuke, and the journal in question is, with its compeers of the same opinions, exhorted to lay aside the transparent mask of hypocrisy, beneath which they declaim about the rights or humanity, barbarous proceedings, et cetera, and honestly avow the true secret of their wrath, viz.: the need of cotton.

abstract: -- The very concise, clearly-written and modest report of Commodore FOOTE, respecting his reduction of Fort Henry, is published this morning. It adds no facts to the story which was told the readers of the TIMES yesterday by our Special correspondent, who was present at the engagement. It confirms, however, the accuracy of all his statements; and gives proof that not only is Capt. FOOTE a gallant and successful sailor, but a writer as skilled with the pen as with the sword. The first victories in Mexico were made memorable by the model dispatches written for Gen. TAYLOR. Our officers in this contest are evidently able to be their own amanuenses.

abstract: The oracle that sits in the Tuileries has given forth a voice, yet no man is sure of the meaning thereof. The Emperor declares that, "so long as the rights of neutrals are respected, we must confine ourselves to the utterance of wishes that these dissensions may soon be ...
lead_paragraph: The oracle that sits in the Tuileries has given forth a voice, yet no man is sure of the meaning thereof. The Emperor declares that, "so long as the rights of neutrals are respected, we must confine ourselves to the utterance of wishes that these dissensions may soon be terminated." These are fair words, certainly, yet the London interpreters tell us they are a "threat." "It is Jacob's voice," say they, "but the hands are the hands of Esau." There is, perhaps, a little spite in this. The journals that now exert themselves to give a menacing interpretation to the words of the French Emperor are precisely those that have persistently predicted that NAPOLEON would signalize the opening of the Legislative Body by a declaration of his purpose either to intervene in the war or to recognize the Southern Confederacy. And we may well place over against the sinister constructions of the hostile British Press, the fact that the Imperial declaration is unanimously accepted by French journals of every complexion, as a frank reiteration of a strictly neutral policy in American affairs.

abstract: Editorial on boundary lines that determine North and South
snippet: Editorial on boundary lines that determine North and South
lead_paragraph: Those dear friends of the people of the United States who weep and wail and gnash their teeth because we have plunged into "a fratricidal war", merely from "the lust of territory" which is the name they give to the slight objection we make to the violent disruption and utter destruction of the Republic -- exclaim from time to time that the North is wanton and wicked in its persistence in the war, because "it is in no danger, and can make peace to-morrow by simply withdrawing its troops within its own frontiers." Passing by the fact that the North was in imminent danger from this insurrection, which if not put down would result in the transfer of Washington to the possession of the insurgents, and in attacks upon the soil as well upon the rights of the Free States, we look round for these Northern frontiers behind which we are so earnestly counseled to retire. What determines them? for North and South are mere relative terms, and South Carolina is north of Georgia. Is it parallels of latitude? Missouri, the local Government of which is, or was, under disloyal rule, is far north of Kentucky, which is and ever has been under loyal rule, and which furnishes troops by the thousand to the National armies. Does Slavery determine these frontiers, and are the "Northern" boundaries coterminous with Freedom? Maryland and Kentucky, whom no threats have been able to force, no intrigue to juggle from their loyalty, are both Slave States. Do State lines and State rights mark out these lines? Where then are the homes of the loyal East Tennesseeans, who furnish regiments to the armies of the Union, and take batteries at the point of the bayonet? Where those of the loyal and courageous Western Virginians -- within or without this Northern frontier?

abstract: The British Admiralty illustrate curiously the national addiction to the rites of hospitality. The Nashville, after committing an outrage upon a peaceful vessel, far less justifiable under the laws of war than a stone blockade entered the dock at Southampton more than three months ago, and demanded repairs and supplies. After some affectation of hesitancy both were granted, and the vessel might have put to sea in November, but for fear of that punishment the crime, of which her commander was guilty, justly merited. The James Adger was for a time understood to be awaiting her appearance outside of neutral waters, and the Nashville lingered. Then came the Tuscarora, and again, the Nashville delayed, Capt. PEGRAM -- a true scion of chivalry that he is -- having no stomach for a contest with any but defenceless shiping. And as the Tuscarora persisted, in awaiting his time, there was no apparent extrication from the necessity of putting to sea boldly, and taking the chances of honorable warfare. At this moment the British Government interposed. Had it acted with any affectation of partiality, even upon the assumption it had unwarrantably adopted, that the Nashville was a national vessel, and not a privateer -- an assumption refuted by the very fact from which the vessel came red-handed into British waters -- it would have determined, that as being the latest comer, the Tuscarora was entitled to remain, and that the Nashville, if either, must receive notice to leave. But impartiality, hospitality and justice had nothing to do with it. Satisfied of the present helplessness of the American Government, and of the impunity with which insult might be inflicted, the British Cabinet determined to screen the piratical destroyers of the Harvey Birch from vengeance; and the Tuscarora was ordered away. It is a satisfaction to know even this defiant intervention will not save the rebel craft, unless it remain in port permanently. The Tuscarora is instructed not to lose sight of her, and will follow her motions like a bloodhound, around the world, if the pursuit be so long, and sooner or later it will compel the cowards to fight. But it is no satisfaction to add this fresh wrong and contumely to the catalogue England is completing against the time when we shall be ready to vindicate our honor and rights against such dastardly assailants. We are learning as a people patience; but we are not unlearning self-respect, or courage.

abstract: The managers of the Brooklyn Industrial School Association and Home for Destitute Children, after three years' constant application, have at last succeeded in completing the object of their mission, by constructing a Home for Destitute Children. The ...
lead_paragraph: The managers of the Brooklyn Industrial School Association and Home for Destitute Children, after three years' constant application, have at last succeeded in completing the object of their mission, by constructing a Home for Destitute Children. The new building was taken possession of and thrown open to the inspection of the public for the first time, yesterday, and will be open for the same purpose throughout to-day, and up to 10 o'clock in the evening. The building is eligibly located in Butler-street, near Flatbush-avenue, on a plot of land containing about eight city lots, of the usual size, with a frontage on Butler-street of 75 feet, and extending back to Baltic-street. The building fronts on Butler-street, and is of the Domestic Gothic style of architecture, constructed of brick, with stone facings, five stories high, with an extreme depth of 80 feet, and extreme width of 50 feet. Rising from the roof is a tower 40 feet high. The basement story is divided into dining-room, laundry, kitchen, lavatory, matron's dining-room and school-room. On the second floor there is a reception room, teachers' bed-room, family parlor, matron's room, two large wardrobe closets, committee room and library. Third floor -- the whole of this floor is arranged as a chapel. The fourth floor has two large domitories for the inmates of the "Home," extending the whole length of the building, and opening from these are several rooms set apart as nurseries. The fifth floor is set apart as a play-room for the children in unpleasant weather. The building is heated by means of hot air; there are abundant accommodations for bathing, and the entire building is thoroughly ventilated. The ground upon which the Home stands cost $4,800; building, $16,000; fixtures, $1,400; total, $22,200. There is a mortgage upon the property of $5,000, and a floating debt of $1,000 -- the latter amount the managers hope to receive from visitors during the opening exercises.

abstract: The long suspense in regard to the destination, and the tremulous fears concerning the fate of the Coast Expedition under Gen. BURNSIDE, are at last happily relieved by the news which we receive from rebel sources. The first work of our forces was to be the seizure ...
lead_paragraph: The long suspense in regard to the destination, and the tremulous fears concerning the fate of the Coast Expedition under Gen. BURNSIDE, are at last happily relieved by the news which we receive from rebel sources. The first work of our forces was to be the seizure of Roanoke Island, the key of the North Carolina Sounds, and the attainment of a basis on the mainland from which operations might be undertaken against more vital points. That Island has been captured after a sharp conflict, in which the killed and wounded count up to many hundreds, and the prisoners in our hands to thousands; the armed rebel vessels cruising in the Sounds have all been captured or destroyed; Elizabeth City, some forty miles north of Roanoke, and on the inland water-route to Norfolk, has been captured; and, at latest advices, our gallant troops were pushing on to Edenton, on the Chowan River, apparently with the object of ascending that stream, and seizing the Seaboard and Roanoke Railroad, connecting Norfolk with the South, or, perhaps, pushing inland even as far as Weldon, and obtaining possession of the Wilmington and Weldon, and the Raleigh and Gaston roads, the most important lines of railway communication in the Southern States. It hardly seems possible, however, that after leaving a force sufficient to guard his prisoners on the island and hold the position, and leaving another body to hold and defend Elizabeth City against approaches from Norfolk, BURNSIDE would have dared to venture thus far into the enemy's country with his remaining troops. But, on the other hand, it may be remembered that the fleet under his command, as might be seen by the list and armament of his vessels which we published yesterday, was a very large and imposing one; that one or two armed steamers could without difficulty guard thousands of beaten and disarmed prisoners; that a single gunboat could guard the Pasquotank River, on which is Elizabeth City; and that thus there would still be at least forty gunboats, of various kinds, and -- putting our loss of men at the highest figure given by the rebels -- twelve or fifteen thousand troopst, flushed with victory, ready for operations in any other quarter. And from all we know of Gen. BURNSIDE, he is just the man, of all men now in the field, likely to illustrate by some daring act a war into which he has thrown all the energies of his chivalric soul. The truth, however, both in regard to the first battle and the prospect of further operations, will undoubtedly be in our possession immediately.

abstract: To the Editor of the New-York Times: It is long since anything transpired here which has caused such wide-spread astonishment and grief, as has the arrest of Brig.-Gen. CHARLES P. STONE on charges of treason. During last Winter and Spring, when the Capital was in imminent danger at the hands ...
lead_paragraph: To the Editor of the New-York Times: It is long since anything transpired here which has caused such wide-spread astonishment and grief, as has the arrest of Brig.-Gen. CHARLES P. STONE on charges of treason. During last Winter and Spring, when the Capital was in imminent danger at the hands of the conspirators against the Government, and the hero, SCOTT, was laboring with wise and patriotic zea[???] to unravel and counteract the machinations of the secret plotters, the Lieutenant-General called STONE to his aid. STONE was not then in the service, having resigned years ago, and been engaged in civil engineering. Happening to be in Washington however, when it was discovered that plots were rife to prevent the counting of the Electoral vote, and failing in that, to defeat the Inauguration of Presides LINCOLN and seize the Government, he promptly re sponded to the call of his old commander, and, with out asking or waiting for rank or pay, devoted his days and nights to the service of his country, with an assiduity, skill, prudence and self-sacrificing disinter estedness that would be expected of few men. Such I knew was the view of Gen. SCOTT, and such is the testimony of all who, like your correspondent, happened then to be brought in contact with him in the course of mutual effort to contribute something toward the vigilance that alone saved this Capita from the hands of the traitors.

abstract: further reports on Roanoke Island victory; diagram showing island position
snippet: further reports on Roanoke Island victory; diagram showing island position
lead_paragraph: The above diagram will show more clearly than the large map we gave yesterday the position and some of the relations of Roanoke Island, of whose capture we have now definite intelligence. We have already described the island, and need not now recapitulate. It may be said, however, that it is seven miles long and three broad, and has good natural means of defence, which had been well improved by the rebels. The rebel earthworks, which were strong, were thrown up about the centre of the island, and our troops had to debark on its southern end, and march up a distance of between two and three miles, to the rebel position. On the mainland opposite, there were also defences; and on the narrow strip of beach to the east, at the point marked as Nag's Head, there was lately a rebel force stationed; but as we have no account of fighting there, it may have been that the whole of the rebel forces were concentrated on the island. The waters between the island and the outer beach, designated Roanoke Sound, are not navigable by large vessels so that the movements of our gunboats were mainly in Croatan Sound. It will be seen how perfectly Roanoke Island here forms the key of the inland navigation at this point.

abstract: Judging from the reports which reach us from the rebels, the success of the Burnside Expedition has thus far been greater than its most sanguine friends have dared to hope for. Not only has Roanoke Island, with its formidable batteries, been captured; not only has the rebel gunboat ...
lead_paragraph: Judging from the reports which reach us from the rebels, the success of the Burnside Expedition has thus far been greater than its most sanguine friends have dared to hope for. Not only has Roanoke Island, with its formidable batteries, been captured; not only has the rebel gunboat fleet, under "Commodore" LYNCH, been almost totally destroyed; but our forces, not satisfied with these important advantages, have pushed on to Elizabeth City and captured it, and at last accounts were approaching Edenton, with a view, probably, of ascending the Chowan River to cut off communication with Norfolk by railroad. The Chowan River is navigable for large vessels as high up as Murfreesboro, near the Virginia State line, and at this season, when the waters are high, our light-draught gunboats would probably find little difficulty in ascending still higher. The first news of the rebel defeat at Roanoke Island reached Norfolk on Sunday, and was soon followed by the announcement that Elizabeth City had fallen into our hands. The city was fired, but whether by our shells or by the inhabitants, is not yet certain -- the rebels say the latter. There was a rebel force of three thousand effective fighting-men on the Island, and of these, the Norfolk papers say, not more than seventy escaped; the rest being killed, wounded and taken prisoners. Their estimated loss in killed and wounded is three hundred of the former and one thousand of the latter. Among the wounded is O. JENNINGS WISE, son of the Ex-Governor and now General. The General himself, it appears, found it convenient to be sick about the time the fighting was to commence, and remained at Nag's Head, on the sand-spit opposite the island, until the rebels began to get the worst of it, when he started for Norfolk; but, as he had not arrived there at last accounts, there is a possibility that he has been captured. The rebels are very disheartened at their defeat, and admit it to be a very serious one.

abstract: A detachment of about 140 men will leave Governor's Island at 12 o'clock to-day. These men have been recruited for the battalion of five companies of the First and Third Infantry, which has been in course of formation on the Island for some months
lead_paragraph: A detachment of about 140 men will leave Governor's Island at 12 o'clock to-day. These men have been recruited for the battalion of five companies of the First and Third Infantry, which has been in course of formation on the Island for some months past, but in consequence of recruits coming in very slowly the men have been transferred to Companies F and I, Third Infantry, commanded respectively by Capts. CLINTON and WALKER. These companies will join the battalion of the Third and Tenth Infantry, stationed at Camp Anderson, Franklin-square, Washton, under the command of Maj. LOVELL, Tenth Infantry. The officers and non-commissioned officers belonging to the two companies of the First Infantry above referred to will remain here on recruiting service.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a petition for the entire confiscation of the property of rebels, and emancipation of the slaves, was presented by Mr. KING, of New-York, who also presented a memorial from mer- ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a petition for the entire confiscation of the property of rebels, and emancipation of the slaves, was presented by Mr. KING, of New-York, who also presented a memorial from merchants and underwriters against alteration of the Pilot laws. Homoeopathic petitions were also presented. The bill prohibiting the sale of spirituous liquors to the Indians was passed. The Fortification bill was again debated, and finally passed. A bill for the establishment of a National Foundry and Furnace, was introduced by Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts. Mr. WILSON also introduced a bill providing for the appointment of a Warden of the. Jail in the District of Columbia -- the object, as explained by Mr. WILSON, being to get the Jail out of the control of Marshal LAMON, under whom the greatest outrages are perpetrated upon colored persons. The bill was referred. The Treasury Note bill was then taken up, and Mr. FESSENDEN, of Maine, proceeded to address the Senate. He was disposed to vote for the measure, though he would prefer it without the legal tender clause. He was followed by Mr. COLLAMER, of Vermont, who opposed making the notes a legal tender. Mr. SHERMAN, of Ohio, proposed an amendment, which was adopted, that the notes authorized in July also be received in payment of public dues, The amendment of the Finance Committee, with regard to the payment of interest in coin, was adopted; also, the amendment striking out the provision that the notes may be exchanged for bonds bearing 7 per cent, interest; also, the amendment setting aside the proceeds of the public lands, confiscated property and duties on imports, as a special fund for the payment of interest. Some other verbal amendments were agreed to, and the Senate adjourned.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, favorable reports were made on the bills to legalize the acts of the NewYork Common Council relative to providing for the families of volunteers; to enable the United States to take land at Fort Hamilton and other ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, favorable reports were made on the bills to legalize the acts of the NewYork Common Council relative to providing for the families of volunteers; to enable the United States to take land at Fort Hamilton and other places for purposes of defence, and to require security from receivers of Mutual Insurance Companies in actions. Notice was given of bills to levy tolls upon certain railroads competing with the lands, and to amend the General Railroad law. A bill was introduced in relation to assessments for improvements in this City. The concurrent resolutions for the appointment of a Commission to revise the Assessment laws were called up, but were again laid on the table after a brief debate. A resolution to adjourn over from the 20th until the evening of the 26th inst., was laid over.

abstract: BLOCKADE. -- The note of Lord LYONS to Earl RUSSELL, reporting, in a tone evidently friendly to the United States, a conversation he had with Secretary SEWARD touching the stone blockade, puts that act in its true fight. It must be confessed that the stone blockade was not ill-calculated for dramatic effects, and the rebel agents and rebel sympathizers in Europe, by working its capabilities to the utmost, succeeded in making a good deal of capital out of it. Mr. SEWARD clearly shows that it was altogether a mistake to suppose that this plan had been devised to injure the harbors permanently. It is, as we ourselves said some time ago, simply a temporary military expedient, adopted to aid the blockade. And the Secretary of State announces that the Government of the United States will consider it its duty to remove all these obstructions as soon as the Union is restored, just as Great Britain had done in the case of a vessel it had ordered to be sunk in the harbor of Savannah during the Revolutionary War. Are the "guardians of civilization" satisfied?

abstract: At a meeting of the Central Republican Committee, held last evening at the headquarters, corner of Twenty-third-street and Broadway, resolutions were passed indorsing the conduct of Hon C.H. VAN WYCK, one of the Congressional Inves
lead_paragraph: At a meeting of the Central Republican Committee, held last evening at the headquarters, corner of Twenty-third-street and Broadway, resolutions were passed indorsing the conduct of Hon C.H. VAN WYCK, one of the Congressional Investigating Committee, in exposing the frauds that have been practiced upon the Government, and censuring Hon. IRA HARRIS, for voting in favor of JESSE D. BRIGHT, Senator from Indiana, retaining his seat in the Senate after having been proved a traitor.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. The comedy of the "Serious Family" has been revived at this theatre, to houses full to overflowing. As Mr. CLARKE seems, by universal consent, to have occupied the comic chair made vacant by the death of Mr. BURTON, and the pub- ...
lead_paragraph: WINTER GARDEN. The comedy of the "Serious Family" has been revived at this theatre, to houses full to overflowing. As Mr. CLARKE seems, by universal consent, to have occupied the comic chair made vacant by the death of Mr. BURTON, and the public look naturally for his appearance in those parts with which the fame of that great artist was associated, we presume that the "Serious Family" was produced mainly with the object of presenting Mr. CLARKE in the character of Aminadab Sleck, which, as the companion picture to Toodles, stirred fur so many seasons the galety of the town, and under the most lachrymose ribs awoke laughter. It could hardly be with other object, for in itself the piece has but few elements of success. In London it was a comparative failure when first produced, though the part of Capt. Mu phy Maguire was filled by Mr. WALLACK, then in the zenith of his vigor, and that of Sleck by Mr. BUCKSTONE. It mainly owes the position of almost unparalleled success it holds on the stage to the combined genius of Mr. BURTON and Mr. BROUGHAM, who almost created these roles, or, at all events, covered them wiih such a mixture of merriment as to virtually make of them new parts. As in the case of Toodles, Mr. CLARKE does not, even in the smallest details, call up a memory of BURTON. The personation is purely and entirely his own. As might be expected from his individual nature, it lacks the breadth and unctuousness which gave to BURTON's personation so olly a richness; but whatever deficiency it finds in this respect, is more than compensated for by the unique quaintness and fresh, hearty fun he throws into the part. Of the two, perhaps Mr. CLARKE's personation excites the most genuine merriment. Certain it is, the piece never rode to its close on so full a tide of laughter as that which bore it to its termination on Monday night. The piece was produced evidently with much care, and many new effects. Among the latter we may mention a comic dance of hypocrites, in which Mr. DAVIDGE figured most humorously, and which received a most merry encore. The brilliant CUBAS, on whom all the expressions of Terpsichorean admiration seems to be exhausted, followed in two of her exquisite dances, and brought the evening's entertainment to a delightful close.

abstract: extracts from foreign journals, given in another column, will be found sundry translations from the newspaper Press of Madrid. They are drawn impartially from the representatives of every party -- the Administration, the Moderate, the Progressive, the Radical. All speak the same language. The cause of the American Government is approved, that of the rebels is fairly appreciated; the suggestion of intervention, with or without England, is denounced as an insult to the Spanish Crown and people. There is perfect consent in counseling a strict adherence to neutrally, whatever course may be urged upon the Government, or adopted by the Cabinets of Paris and London.

abstract: to the inquiry of a correspondent in regard to the appointment of the traitor and spy, MALCOLM IVES, to a position in the New-York Custom-House. We do so notwithstanding an assurance that on the first news of his arrest Collector BARNEY caused his name to be stricken from the roll of employes; for if it be true that the original appointment was made with a knowledge of IVES' connection with the Herald, or that he was retained in the face of authenticated evidence of the man's infamous character, and his labors to combat the cause of the Union, and to slander its defenders, it is proper the Collector should gratify the public with the reason why. Ten thousand loyal applicants, supported by evidence of devotion to the Union, and who did not oppose the election of Mr. LINCOLN, have been turned away unsatisfied. Why was this malignant traitor accepted? Was it in submision to the same sort of reckless bullying which Secretary STANTON has so properly punished?

abstract: measures," says NAPOLEON, "should never be adopted except with the maturest deliberation and after the most comprehensive research." Our Committee of Ways and Means are acting wisely in adopting this maxim, notwithstanding the feverish curiosity of a portion of the public Press to learn prematurely the details of their plans, and to induce them to hurry forward and present to Congress a crude and imperfectly-considered bill. Inordinate haste is one of our national failings, which, with others of a more positive character, will perhaps be in part corrected by the privations, reverses and victories and earnest struggles incident to the present war.

abstract: to Lord LYONS' representations of the sympathizing sorrows of the British Government at the destruction of the port of Charleston, was so sufficient, that he probably did not think it worth his while to make it more conclusive. Otherwise he might have added that even if our Government had permanently closed that harbor, it would have only accelerated a little a certain and quickly impending fate. For Charleston, instead of being a flourishing port, has been in its decadence for ten years and more. In spite of the great progress of the whole country in population and in all material prosperity during that period, Charleston fell back. At the census of 1860, its population proved to be 2,400 less than at that of 1850. Its weatth diminished proportionably. No harm would have been done to the State of South Carolina, or, what is of more importance, to the people of the United States, by the utter destruction of the harbor of Charleston. Its little commercial importance has for years been steadily and surely diminishing; and it has small claim upon the attention of our Government, except as the nest in which treason was hatched and brooded. Slavery and such political purposes as those of Charleston, kill commerce and destroy harbors far more surely than stone fleets.

abstract: The steamship Columbia, Capt. ADAMS, from Havana, arrived yesterday morning, bringing dates to 8th inst. She stopped at Port Royal Light-ship on the 10th inst., at 3 P.M., for the mails, and there ascere tained that the Baltic had left about an hour previous with them. The Columbia passed the Baltic the same evening at 7 o'clock having in tow a steamer, probably disabled.

abstract: The United States steam transport Baltic, JOSEPH J. COMSTOCK, commander, arrived at this port, yesterday, from Port Royal. She left New-York Jan. 13, at 6 o'clock A.M., with three companies of the First Massachusetts Cavalry, for Port Royal, S.C., where she arrived on the 17th, at 10 A.M.
lead_paragraph: The United States steam transport Baltic, JOSEPH J. COMSTOCK, commander, arrived at this port, yesterday, from Port Royal. She left New-York Jan. 13, at 6 o'clock A.M., with three companies of the First Massachusetts Cavalry, for Port Royal, S.C., where she arrived on the 17th, at 10 A.M. Having landed her men and horses, she sailed for Annapolis on Monday, Jan. 21, arriving there on Sunday, Jan. 26. She sailed on her return voyage to Port Royal, with another detachment of the First Massachusetts Cavalry, on Jan. 31, arrived there on Feb. 4, and, having landed her men and horses, received on board six hundred and thirty bales of cotton. She sailed for New-York on Feb. 10, with the steamer Vixen in tow, for the capes of Virginia.

abstract: Company P, Capt. WILKINS, (net CLINTON, as previously reported,) and Company 1, Capt WALKER, Third lafantry, left Governor's Island yesterday for Washington. These companies are almost perfect in all the branches of light infantry drill, and appear more like veterans than young soldiers, thanks to ....
lead_paragraph: Company P, Capt. WILKINS, (net CLINTON, as previously reported,) and Company 1, Capt WALKER, Third lafantry, left Governor's Island yesterday for Washington. These companies are almost perfect in all the branches of light infantry drill, and appear more like veterans than young soldiers, thanks to Capt. NEILL, Fifth Infantry, under whose superintendence they were formed, and Capt. WALKER, by whom they were chiefly instructed. Most of the non-commissioned officers are old soldiers, who have seen active service on the frontiers. Capt. WILKINS has been recruiting for his company in Albany for some months, and was called in specially to take command of his company, and go into active service. No laundresses were allowed to go with these companies, and all the wives of regulars now in the field have been quietly withdrawn to Washington or elsewhere, and have received certificates entitling them to draw rations from the Commissary. This looks as if the regulars have their work cut out for them.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, a communication from the Union Defence Committee of New-York was read, urging the immediate passage of the Treasury Note bill, retaining the legal tender clause. The bill to appoint a Warden for the Washington jail was reported back from the District Committee.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, a communication from the Union Defence Committee of New-York was read, urging the immediate passage of the Treasury Note bill, retaining the legal tender clause. The bill to appoint a Warden for the Washington jail was reported back from the District Committee but was not acted upon. A series of resolutions, declaratory of the policy of the Government, was presented by Mr. DAVIS, of Kentucky, and laid over. Notice was given of a bill providing for the confiscation of cotton on the lands now in possession of the United States. The bill fixing the number of Representatives in the House at two hundred and thirty-nine was debated, but not finally acted upon. The Senate's amendments to the Civil and Miscellaneous Appropriation bill having been disagreed to by the House, a Committee of Conference was appointed. The Treasury Note bill was then taken up, and after a long debate, which continued until 7 1/2 o'clock in the evening, was passed, by a vote of 30 to 7. A motion to strike out the legal tender clause was defeated, 22 to 17. The bill now goes back to the House for action on the Senate amendments.

abstract: The Superior Court has had its attention occupied somewhat of late with a divorce suit in which the public will have an interest when the facts become known, as the defendant is a celergyman who not long since occupied a position of some note as pastor of the Universalist Church in this city.
lead_paragraph: The Superior Court has had its attention occupied somewhat of late with a divorce suit in which the public will have an interest when the facts become known, as the defendant is a celergyman who not long since occupied a position of some note as pastor of the Universalist Church in this city. Rev. Mr. KING is summoned to answer the charges made against him by his wife, MARY M. KING, and to show cause why a decree of divorce should not be issued in her favor, annulling the marriage tie that exists between them. As a divine of considerable pretension, and a claimant of high moral virtues, which were admitted, we believe, until he practically disproved them, he stands in a bad light before the charges of the wife who shared his home and knew his private life for ten years.

abstract: A leisure was delivered, Wednesday evening, in Calvary Baptist Church, in Twenty-third-street, by Mr. JAMES GILLETTE, of the Rev. Dr. GILLETTE, a member of the Seventy-first Regiment N.Y.S.M., who was taken prisoner at Bull Run, and returned only in January last. The church was well filled. The speaker occupied the attention of the audience for over an hour, with a long, well-written, and well-read narrative of the incidents connected with the Battle of Bull Run: his capture, and his treatment at Manassas, and the journey to Richmond, with their subsequent incarceration. As Mr. GILLETTE was not permitted to bring away any of his notes or diary, the whole narrative was written from memory. Of the treatment of the prisoners, especially the wounded at Manassas, he spoke, as all others have spoken, condemning the inhumanity of the rebels, and paying a merited tribute of gratification on behalf of all to Surgeon STUART, of the First Minnesota Volunteers; PEUGNET, of the Seventy-first N.Y.S.M.; SWIFT, DEGRAW and WINSTON, of the Eighth New-York, who not only were unremitting in their attentions, but freely expended their own money to purchase little comforts for the wounded. They arrived at Richmond on the 4th of August, and were quartered (1,466 in number) in four tobacco houses, two of which were used as hospitals. And after the arrival of 600 prisoners from Leesburgh, three more warehouses were filled, one being occupied as a hospital. Of their treatment there he gave detailed and interesting statements, not forgetting the tyrannical and traitorous conduct of Lieut. TODD, who seemed to be possessed of the spirit of a fiend in his treatment of them. He used to go through the prisons sword in hand, and twice he cut down two men for the most trivial causes, Sergeant WHITCOMB and T.D. SMITH, of the First Michigan Volunteers. Three prisoners were shot at the windows, for looking out, viz.: N.C. BUCK, of the New-York Seventy-ninth; C.W. TIBBETTS, of the New-York Twenty-seventh, and R. GLEASON, of the New-York Eleventh. Capt. GEO. C. GIBBS, who took charge after the removal of Lieut. TODD, was a humane man, and allowed the prisoners every privilege, and did all he could to contribute to their comfort, consistently with his orders. A "United States Prisoners' Court for the District of Richmond" was established in November for the trial of offenders, which resulted in checking many petty larcenies -- Hon. H.B. HALL, of the Eighteenth New-York, being elected Chief-Justice. They also organized a company of "Prison Invincibles," and drilled daily, thus whiling away time. They also established the "Prisoners of War Olio," and, with the aid of blankets, flannels, tin foil, &c., got up quite a theatrical wardrobe. The lecturer read "the Prison Bill of Fare," a humorous narrative in rhyme, by JAMES BANKS, of Massachusetts, which caused much laughter. In December, the prisoners, who had suffered very much for want of proper clothing, received some warm clothes from the States of Massachusetts, Rhode Island and Indiana; but nothing from the State of New-York, except two boxes of clothing from the "Ladies' Aid Society," of this church, the largest of which was sent to their friends at Tuscaloosa, and the other distributed among the hospitals at Richmond.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, favorable reports were made on the bills proving for the examination of the accounts of the Canal Department and the State Treasurer, and to amend the Revised Stateutes relative to lawkers and peddlers.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, favorable reports were made on the bills proving for the examination of the accounts of the Canal Department and the State Treasurer, and to amend the Revised Stateutes relative to lawkers and peddlers. The bill to levy tolls upon railroads competing with the canals was introduced. The bill relative to the Court of General Sessions in this City was read a third time and passed. The resolution to appoint a Commission to revise the Assessment and Tax laws was amended so as to require a report to be made by the 25th of March next, and adopted. The resolution to adjourn over from the 29th to the 26th inst. was lost. A bill relative to the public health in the Metropolitan Police District was introduced.

abstract: -- In a detailed description of the Burnside Expedition, which was given in the TIMES on Wednesday, a reference was made to the great practical value of the code of signals in use by the army, and the invention was credited to Capt. MYERS, of a Pennsylvania regiment of volunteers. This attribution we have since found reason to believe incorrect. It was Mr. FREDERICK P. BARNARD, formerly of Albany, who, after years of painful study, elaborated this very ingenious method by which intercourse, literal in accuracy, can be carried on at great distances, not only by signs visible day and night, but by sounds where the communicating parties are separated by intervening objects, or a fog. Mr. BARNARD bears with him vouchers and affidavits of leading citizens of the State, attesting the merit and originality of the invention. It is due to him not only that he should have the praise his ingenuity deserves, but that a more substantial return should be made for his services.

abstract: The Senate in Committee of the Whole yesterday, perfected the Loan and Treasury bill, and at 7 o'clock. It was reported to the Senate and finally passed by a vote of 30 to 7.
lead_paragraph: The Senate in Committee of the Whole yesterday, perfected the Loan and Treasury bill, and at 7 o'clock. It was reported to the Senate and finally passed by a vote of 30 to 7. The bill returns to the House to-day for concurrence in the amendments, of which there is little or no doubt, and will then be signed by the President.

abstract: our Hilton Head correspondence this morning which we sincerly trust will turn out to be correct. It is to the effect that the rebel steamer Isabel, laden with cotton, had been captured.
lead_paragraph: There is an intimation in our Hilton Head correspondence this morning which we sincerly trust will turn out to be correct. It is to the effect that the rebel steamer Isabel, laden with cotton, had been captured. The announcement stands bare of all relations of time, place or circumstance, so that we feel no absolute assurance in the good news. This is, undoubtedly, owing to the fact that the tidings were brought to Port Royal by the Pocahontas, from off blockading duty at Charleston harbor, which arrived just as the steamer was on the point of leaving.

abstract: Editorial on favorable sentiments toward Union in parts of South
snippet: Editorial on favorable sentiments toward Union in parts of South
lead_paragraph: That there has always been among the people of the revolted States an abundant latent Union sentiment latent and yet real requiring special conditions for its revelation perhaps, as tracings in sympathetic ink are revealed by fire, but sure to show itself under the right conditions -- has all along been an article of faith with loyal men. True, like many other of the grandest convictions, it has for months been little more than an article of faith -- and as we have hitherto been able to point to few manifestations of its existence, it has not been difficult for the rebel agents in Europe to make it a matter of general European belief that there is absolute unanimity in the rebellion cause at the South. There is a fictitious sense in which they are, perhaps, right in the assertion; and as the certificates of Southern loyalty which we in the North have are of an incommunicable nature, springing from deep-rooted instincts and long affiliations, and not to be conveyed to those abroad, it is not in the least wonderful that the Secessionists and their journalistic friends in England and France have been successful in their endeavors to mold public opinion in this respect. It has not been enough to point to the practical demonstrations of Unionism that have attended the presence of the liberating National army in the shore counties of Eastern Virginia, at Hatteras, and in the Western Border States; the vast interior spaces of the revolted States have been confidently pointed to as permeated with but one sentiment, and that unanimous hostility to the National Government.

abstract: whether any one of the rebel regiments from the far South, which fled from Fort Henry the other day on the approach of our troops, was the regiment which marched from Louisiana into that part of Tennessee not long ago, bearing...
lead_paragraph: whether any one of the rebel regiments from the far South, which fled from Fort Henry the other day on the approach of our troops, was the regiment which marched from Louisiana into that part of Tennessee not long ago, bearing before it a black flag, adorned with fearful imagery and cross-bones, and, underneath, the words, "No quarter." It may have been, and it may not; it is as likely to be one way as the other. We certainly know that the black-flag gentry of South Carolina were not slow in fleeing from the Hilton Head forts when DUPONT's guns began to play about their ears; and, according to a Charleston paper we quoted from the other day, a good many of them did not stop running (possibly trailing a black flag behind them) till they "reached the mountains," some two hundred miles north. According to that journal, they are only now venturing down to Charleston again. The commander at Roanoke Island, again, according to one of the deserters from there who came into our lines, had given his soldiers two orders: First, that the Yankees should be shown no quarter; and, second, (a genuine Hibernianism,) that, if it should be necessary to retreat, they should destroy all property by fire. The event proves, however, that two or three thousand of these heroes were, like their brethren at Fort Henry, quite willing to accept quarter or anything else. The fact is that this whole thing of rebel black flags, cross-bones and no quarter, is an exploded humbug.

abstract: According to the rebels, there were sixty-one battles fought between the middle of last Februay (when Sumter fell) and the close of the calendar year. Of these, fifty-three were rebel successes, and but eight National successes.
lead_paragraph: According to the rebels, there were sixty-one battles fought between the middle of last Februay (when Sumter fell) and the close of the calendar year. Of these, fifty-three were rebel successes, and but eight National successes. We published,the other day, a curious table given by a Richmond paper, and collected from official (rebel) sources, showing the dates and localities of all these battles, with a list of the killed, wounded and captured on both sides. Some of the battles we had never heard of before, and others it was odd enough to see designated as rebel triumphs. To make the list longer, apparently, there were scattered through it a number of names of battles and rebel victories in which the subsequent column showed that there had been neither killed, wounded nor prisoners on either side! What kind of victories these could be, it were hard enough to say. Possibly they belonged to the grand category of moral victories (rebel morals) of which philosophers love so much to discourse. In other cases they had picket fights entered in the list of battles, which undoubtedly they were, in one sense, though hardly reaching that dignity in a national point of view. The losses on our side, too, were fearful, while on theirs the whole loss amounted to a mere bagatelle. It is thus that the rebels flatter themselves, and whistle to keep their courage up. We who know the facts in each of the cases mentioned -- and they, also, who, in some cases, knew the facts as well as we -- of course regard the whole thing as a bit of harmless bluster; but we expect that as soon as the tabular statement gets across the sea, it will be published in the London Times and Galignani, and the former journal will doubtless have a solemn and very heavy leader upon it, showing the miserable imbecility of the North and the unconquerable herolism of the rebels. A correspondent has taken the trouble to collate for us a somewhat more accurate list of the warlike encounters of last year, and this year so far, which gives quite a different aspect to the case. He says:

abstract: The accounts from Vera Cruz, published today, contain no reference to a defeat sustained by the Spaniards. The Spaniards had not advanced to the national Bridge, the pretended theatre of the conflict; the furthest....
lead_paragraph: The accounts from Vera Cruz, published today, contain no reference to a defeat sustained by the Spaniards. The Spaniards had not advanced to the national Bridge, the pretended theatre of the conflict; the furthest point in that direction reached by any portion of the allied force being Tejeria, the terminus of a short installment of railroad leading from Vera Cruz toward the capital. This point and Medellin, on the lower road, were in possession of the European troops. No movement upon the City of Mexico had yet been arranged. Even the small strip of territory occupied by the allies outside the walls of Vera Cruz, they had obtained by application made to Gen. URAGA, the Mexican leader, who had given his consent. And there was no sound reason for withholding it. The region about Vera Cruz is already pestiferous, the vomito having already appeared in the camps of the Europeans, where it was doing the work of an army. Transports were leaving for Cuba, carrying away large numbers of the sick. Against this enemy the allies are unarmed. It must presently drive them to their ships, or to the highlands of the interior.

abstract: Benedict Barnard and Alfred Rosenthall vs Louis Kersten. -- This is a motion to set aside certain orders of arrest obtained against the defendant, on the ground, chiefly, that an order requiring the Sheriff to hold the defendant to bail in an additional sum of $60,000, was irregular, in being another, distinct and further order of arrest, granted without legal warrant, in the same action, against the same defendant. The plaintiffs allege that the defendant has fled from justice, and the motion is merely to relieve his bail. The case grew out of the fact that the plaintiffs being large dealers in London, consigned goods to the extent of $160,000 to the defendant, to be sold by him in this City. They allege that the defendant sold the goods, but failed to pay over the proceeds, in consequence of which they failed in business. Case still on.

abstract: editorial on conditions
snippet: editorial on conditions
lead_paragraph: By the arrival at this port of the steamship Columbia, from Havana, we have news from Vera Cruz to Jan. 29. The advices are intersting and important. Gen. MIRAMON, who left Havana for Vera Cruz on board the English mail steamer, arrived at that place on Jan. 24. By order of Commodore DUNLOP he was at once arrested and taken on board H.B.M. frig te Challenger, for having violated his pledge not to leave Havana. It was rumored that he was subsequently transferred to the Jason for attempting to effect his escape to the mainland. The affair had created much excitement among MIRAMON's partisans, who had been anxiously anticipating his arrival. The Commissioners representing the allied Powers, who left Vera Cruz for the City of Mexico on Jan. 14, returned on the 19th. Senor ZAMACONA, a Plenipotentiary commissioned by JUAREZ, accompanied them. The Allied Commission represent that they were everywhere received with cordiality. JUAREZ treated them with great consideration. He attempted to exact as a condition of future negotiations, that all of the allied forces which had been landed at Vera Cruz, with the exception of a guard of 2,000 men, should be reembarked. This preliminary was at once declined, but as the Plenipotentiary of JUAREZ returned with the Commission, it was taken for granted that negotiations would proceed. Where the conferences would take place was uncertain, although it was generally believed that Jalapa would be agreed upon. JUAREZ, it is said, had acknowledged that his Government had not fulfilled its obligations to foreigners, and expressed his willingness to extend any additional guarantees. The allied forces at Tejeria had advanced three leagues toward Santa Fe, in order to be removed from the unhealthy localities where they had at first encamped, and measures were in progress to advance immediately upon the capital, should a disposition be manifested to resist the demands of the allies. All reports of conflicts between the opposing forces are contradicted. On the contrary, it is alleged that the pickets of the Mexican and allied armies maintained the most friendly relations, and that the price of provisions in Vera Cruz had fallen materially, H.B.M. gunboat Plover had gone ashore near the bar of Alvarado, and it was thought would prove a total less.

abstract: Editorial on views of British Saturday Review on war
snippet: Editorial on views of British Saturday Review on war
lead_paragraph: The Saturday Review is at last driven to apologize for or attempt to justify its course in regard to American affairs since the breaking out of the slaveholders' insurrection. It does this plainly because it feels unpleasantly the pressure of adverse opinion, even among Englishmnen, whom it admits to be "worthy of respect." The plea which it puts in is simply a denial of bad feeling and hostile purpose, and the assertion that it merely comments in a fair and just spirit upon American affairs as they reveal themselves to the world. Nay, it goes even further, and speaks for the nation, uttering these astounding words: "In England we cannot see that there is any disposition to criticise the Americans unfairly, or to taunt and exasperate them!" We did not expect the Saturday Review to stickle at small matters in the way of misstatement; but after this enormity can we be surprised at anything. In the very same number which contains this stunning assertion, is the following paragraph:

abstract: The Loan and Treasury bill finally passed the Senate yesterday evening Yeas 30, Nays 7. The main discussion turned upon a motion by Mr. GOLLAMER, of Vermont, to strike out the legal tender of United States Notes ...
lead_paragraph: The Loan and Treasury bill finally passed the Senate yesterday evening Yeas 30, Nays 7. The main discussion turned upon a motion by Mr. GOLLAMER, of Vermont, to strike out the legal tender of United States Notes which was negatived,17 to 22. The proposition of the Finance Committee, to allow temporary deposits with the Treasury at an interest of five per cent., was disagreed to. The more important amendment, to make all payments of interest on all the Public Stocks and Treasury Bonds of the United States in specie, was adopted. For all other payments and debts, public and private, the United States Notes are created lawful money and made a legal tender, as in the original bill. In lieu of the alternative privilege of converting the United States Notes into a five-year 7 per cent. stock, in place of twenty-year 6 per cent. stock, when preferred, the Senate substituted the alternative of 7:30 per cent. two-year Treasury Bonds. A specific pledge of the Customs and Land revenues is added to the House bill for the further security of the interest and the support of a sinking fund for the Public Debt. The sinking fund to receive an annual contribution from the Treasury, out of these revenues, equal to one per cent. of the whole principal of the debt. Some other verbal amendments were made to the bill. None of the amendments are likely to be seriously opposed on the return of the bill to the House, where it will probably have final action to-day, and then approved by the President.
