abstract: The United States store-ship Supply, Capt. COLVO CORESSIS commanding, from Ship Island, on Jan. 24th, arrived at this port yesterday.
lead_paragraph: The United States store-ship Supply, Capt. COLVO CORESSIS commanding, from Ship Island, on Jan. 24th, arrived at this port yesterday. She has on board as prisoners, Capt. FRANCIS LEE and nine others, officers and crew of the prize schooner Lizzie Weston; also, JAQUES ERNEST SANAGIN, Captain of the rebel steamer Anna; J. WINTERS. Captain of the rebel steamer Henry Lewis, and WM. BLAKLLEY, Captain of the rebel schooner A.J. Vien. The prisoners were delivered over to United States Marshal MURRAY, who committed them to the House of Detention.

abstract: With profound regret the country has read the telegrams of the past two days, announcing the indisposition of Secretary STANTON, which, we grieve to see, still continues. Brief as is the time during which Mr. STANTON has filled his high office, we have already learned that he is the man for the place, and that there is much bound up in him. His indisposition, which is stated as an attack of vertigo, is, doubtless, simply, the effect of an overtasked brain. His labors, since assuming the duties of the War Department, have been enormous, and, after all, the cerebral functions, in the strongest head, will only endure a certain strain. The whole country will unite in the heartfelt wish that a few days of rest may completely restore the Secretary to health, and that he may soon again assume his post, to prepare victories and issue inspiring bulletins for the Union.

His labors, since assuming the duties of the War Department, have been enormous, and, after all, the cerebral functions, in the strongest head, will only endure a certain strain. The whole country will unite in the heartfelt wish that a few days of rest may completely restore the Secretary to health, and that he may soon again assume his post, to prepare victories and issue inspiring bulletins for the Union.

abstract: By way of San Francisco, from which city we have telegraphic advices to the 12th inst., we receive news from China to the 4th ult., a vessel having arrived from Hong Kong in 37 days.
lead_paragraph: By way of San Francisco, from which city we have telegraphic advices to the 12th inst., we receive news from China to the 4th ult., a vessel having arrived from Hong Kong in 37 days. American vessels in China were being put under the protection of the British flag, to prevent interference on the part of privateers. Purchases of tea for the United States were being made at improved rates, and freights had advanced to $20@ $24 per ton. The rebels captured the city of Ning Po on the 9th of December, and the Hong Kong papers were filled with accounts of atrocities committed by them.

abstract: By the arrival of the steamship Columbia at this port, and the Baltimore at Baltimore, we have advices from Havana to the 8th inst. The British steamer Gladiator is reported to be still at Nassau, N.P., where she was being changed into a privateer for the rebel service. Among the passengers by the Columbia is Capt. PALMER, late of the steam-gunboat Iroquois, relieved of his command on account of the escape of the privateer Sumter from Martinique while under his surveillance. Capt. PALMER will proceed immediately to Washington, and make answer to the charge of conniving at the escape of the pirate, which his friends contend he will be able to do satisfactorily. There is no news of importance from Havana.

abstract: SERIOUS BURNING ACCIDENTS. A woman, whose name could not be ascertained, residing on the corner of North Seventh and Seventh streets, yesterday, afternoon, while intoxicated, set her clothes on fire, and was fatally injured. She was taken to the City Hospital for treatment. A little girl named SARAH FEUNY,whose parents reside on Hoyt, near Butler-street, was so badly burned by her clothes taking fire on Wednesday evening, that her life is despaired of.

abstract: A NOVEL TEA-DRINKING. The Superintendent of the Five Points' House of Industry gave a teaparty last evening to the parents of the children of the schools of the institution.
lead_paragraph: A NOVEL TEA-DRINKING. The Superintendent of the Five Points' House of Industry gave a teaparty last evening to the parents of the children of the schools of the institution. There were gathered about one hundred men and women, to whom a bountiful and elegant repast was given, greatly to their enjoyment. There were three hundred children present, and their delight in seeing their parents enjoy the good things was real and irrepressible. After supper, the old people listened, well pleased, to the beautiful music of their own sons and daughters. The parents seemed astonished and delighted with the proficiency of their children. Messrs. HART, THORNE, PHELPS and MESSER made short addresses, and the whole was a decided success. They are to be continued from time to time. The following is the work of the year 1861: 285,305 meals furnished gratuitously; 1,076 children enrolled in day-school; 326 average daily attendance in day-school; 12,000 articles of clothing given; 1,200 pairs of shoes given away; 975 have been inmates during the year; 150 is the average daily inmates; school children get three meals daily; annual expense from $12,010 to $16,000. Voluntary contributions are depended upon. We need money, clothing, food.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, favorable reports were made on the bill authorizing the construction of railroads on certain streets in Brooklyn; for the relief of owners of lands under water in front of the cities of New-York and Brooklyn, and appropriating a portion of the State tax to the support of schools.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, favorable reports were made on the bill authorizing the construction of railroads on certain streets in Brooklyn; for the relief of owners of lands under water in front of the cities of New-York and Brooklyn, and appropriating a portion of the State tax to the support of schools. A bill was introduced to create a New-York County Court-house stock by loan. The Committee on Banks were discharged from further consideration of the bill to modify the Usury laws, and the bill was referred to the Judiciary Committee. The bill to prohibit County Treasurers from loaning and investing the public funds for their own benefit was ordered to a third reading. The concurrent resolution to adjourn over from the 19th to the 25th inst., was adopted. It was rejected by the Assembly on Wednesday.

abstract: Gen. DRAYTON'S Official report of the battle at Port Royal, on Nov. 7, is given elsewhere in this number of the TIMES. Gen. DRAYTON, it will be remembered, was sent down from Charleston to look after the defence of Beaufort, in the third week of October.
lead_paragraph: Gen. DRAYTON'S Official report of the battle at Port Royal, on Nov. 7, is given elsewhere in this number of the TIMES. Gen. DRAYTON, it will be remembered, was sent down from Charleston to look after the defence of Beaufort, in the third week of October. His report throws the entire responsibility of the disaster upon the indolence of those previously intrusted with the preparations. Troops were not detailed, intrenchments were not digged, guns were not mounted, wharves were not built, avenues of escape were not provided. To these deficiencies Gen. DRAYTON devoted himself, with especial attention, however, to the latter. Some Georgian and. South Carolinian regiments were procured, the labor on the defences was hastened, more of the guns were placed in position; and flats and boats were hurried from Savannah and Charleston to bear away the chivalry, in the event of their valor proving ineffectual. Of these labors the arrangements for escape Were alone fruitful. With the exception of the artillerymen in the two forts, the troops who marched down so gallantly to repel the Yankees, marched away again without testing their power of repulsion, or waiting the coming of the enemy. There is much of compliment in Gen. DRAYTON's report to the determined bravery of his men, but he admits they did not fight.

abstract: -- The Chevalier WIKOFF has told his secret and gained his liberty. The dispatch which yields this important announcement adds that during his imprisonment no one was admitted to his quarters except Gen. SICKLES, "his counsel." There is a mystery about this SICKLES, which it would be pleasant to read. He obviously resides at Washington, frequents the Executive mansion in company with WIKOFF, and makes himself generally conspicuous, very much in the manner of an Ex-Member of Congress of the same name. But that Ex-Member is now a Brigadier, with a command on the Lower Potomac, and we know there is no rule, exceedingly proper in itself, more rigidly enforced than that officers who absent themselves from their posts and haunt Washington, expose themselves to a forfeiture of their commissions. What the public palpitates to know, then, is whether this SICKLES, the friend and counselor of WIKOFF, is the nominal commander of that costly body, the Excelsior Brigade; and, if so, whether the country is in any danger of losing his inestimable services, through his unfortunate devotion to WIKOFF and other attractions of Washington society.
lead_paragraph: -- The Chevalier WIKOFF has told his secret and gained his liberty. The dispatch which yields this important announcement adds that during his imprisonment no one was admitted to his quarters except Gen. SICKLES, "his counsel." But that Ex-Member is now a Brigadier, with a command on the Lower Potomac, and we know there is no rule, exceedingly proper in itself, more rigidly enforced than that officers who absent themselves from their posts and haunt Washington, expose themselves to a forfeiture of their commissions. What the public palpitates to know, then, is whether this SICKLES, the friend and counselor of WIKOFF, is the nominal commander of that costly body, the Excelsior Brigade; and, if so, whether the country is in any danger of losing his inestimable services, through his unfortunate devotion to WIKOFF and other attractions of Washington society.

abstract: HEWS, who was stabbed, in Broadway, near Fifty-first-street, about ten days since, died, at the City Hospital, last evening at 5 o'clock. It was known from the first that the deceased was mortally wounded and his lingering so long was altogether unexpected'.He was attended in his last moments by his mother, his sister and brother, as well as a number of sympathizers of the class to which he belonged. An inquest will probably be held in the case to-day. MATHEWS made a will a few days since, leaving $1,000 to one of his brothers now in California, and the remainder of his estate to his mother.

abstract: Fort Donelson is invested by our troops. Our lines are formed from right to left and from north to south, nearly surrounding the fort. A heavy cannonading and skirmishing have been going on since 7 o'clock this morning, but, owing to the extent of our line of action, but little can be learned of the result.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Friday, Feb. 14.

abstract: Editorial on decisive signs of progress in war as McClellan promised; editorial speculates on retreat route
snippet: Editorial on decisive signs of progress in war as McClellan promised; editorial speculates on retreat route
lead_paragraph: It is just one month ago since we gave place in the TIMES to a letter from the "highest possible authority" in regard to the plans of Gen. McCLELLAN. It was there stated that the details of the campaign were thoroughly arranged, and on the eve of realization; or to employ the overtasked metaphor of the writer, "the folds of, the constrictor were tightening around the rebellion, and the coming month (of February,) would see it crushed out completely and forever." February is just half gone, and this engagement is more than half verified. The rout of HUMPHREY MARSHALL and the defeat and death of ZOLLICOFFER at Mill Spring have cleared Eastern Kentucky of rebels. In Western Kentucky the reduction of Fort Henry, and the seizure of the Memphis and Ohio Railroad, have struck a fatal blow at the insurrection in that quarter, followed as it will be by the capture of Fort Donelson, and the advance of Gens. BUELL and THOMAS into the heart of Tennessee, where the reinspirited loyalists await their coming impatiently. It is safe to predict that the month will not close until, the back of rebellion has been broken by the National army gaining possession of Tennessee and its all-important lines of railroad communication. In Missouri, PRICE has commenced another of those retreats for which he must always be memorable, the pursuers, in this instance, being CURTIS and SIGEL, directed by Gen. HALLECK, whose strong hand grasps surely all he regains from the rebels. Who can doubt that Missouri will be cleared of armed rebels before March? Gen. HUNTER, at the far West, is already moving the expedition which is to proceed from Kansas upon Memphis. He will hardly need more than a fortnight to reach his destination. Memphis threatened at once from the West, the North and the East, Columbus must be evacuated.

abstract: We have the satisfaction, this morning, to publish the first complete and direct account of the battle of Roanoke Island, from our special correspondent, whose praiseworthy energy, fidelity, and tact, enable us to accompany...
lead_paragraph: We have the satisfaction, this morning, to publish the first complete and direct account of the battle of Roanoke Island, from our special correspondent, whose praiseworthy energy, fidelity, and tact, enable us to accompany the official reports with this detailed and accurate recital. Appended to it will be found a list of the killed and wounded, to which the thousands who have friends or relatives in the Expedition will anxiously turn. The list of wounded is official and complete, and numbers 158. No official list of killed had been made out at the date of our correspondent's departure, but he was able to ascertain the names of nineteen, which is two-thirds of the total killed -- the whole number being estimated at not over 30. This is certainly a different story from the sanguinary bulletin of a thousand killed, which the panic-stricken people of Norfolk sent to us as an offset to the corresponding reports of fearful slaughter on their own side. The rebel loss is probably even smaller than our own, as might be expected from the circumstance that they were protected by their earthworks; but the fact that the whole force, numbering close on three thousand men, surrendered themselves prisoners, make the battle of Roanoke the most illustrious victory, of the war, and, perhaps the severest blow the rebel cause has yet received.

abstract: The United States gunboat Massachusetts, Com- mander MELANOTON SMITH, arrived at this port last night, at 9:30 P.M., from Ship Island.
lead_paragraph: The United States gunboat Massachusetts, Com- mander MELANOTON SMITH, arrived at this port last night, at 9:30 P.M., from Ship Island. The Massachusetts has on board the cargo of prize schooner J.W. Wilder, captured by steamer R.R. Cuyler, consisting of coffee, lead, leather, &c.; and likewise cargo of schooner Gipsy, captured by steamer New-London, consisting of 103 bales of cotton. Before leaving Ship Island, Commander SMITH turned over to the army eleven contrabands, and a number of prize vessels that were captured in Mississippi Sound.

abstract: At the meeting of the Board of Aldermen last evening, Alderman DAYTON submitted an extraordinary report of the Special Committee appointed to consider the Mayor's Message.
lead_paragraph: At the meeting of the Board of Aldermen last evening, Alderman DAYTON submitted an extraordinary report of the Special Committee appointed to consider the Mayor's Message. The document was quite discursive, alluding to City, State and National affairs at length, and winding up by proposing a Joint Special Committee to examine and report what steps are necessary for retrenchment and reform in the City Government. The report was adopted, and ordered extensively printed. The Board appropriated $3,000 for the celebration of WASHINGTON's birthday.

abstract: report of the conflict on Roanoke Island, the names of two officers are mentioned with distinguished praise. One, Col. EDWARD FERRERO, of the Fifty-first New-York, who, at the head of his men, sprang with daring intrepidity upon the principal rebel battery, and planted there, the America flag; the other, Lieut.-Col. VIGUIER DE MONTEIL, of the Fifty-third New York Regiment, who participated in the fight as a volunteer, and at once amazed and animated all by the spectacle of his gallantry. The latter unhappily fell a sacrifice to his courage; the former survives to enjoy the honors he has well earned; and both will be long counted to the credit of that roll of officers of foreign birth who have offered their swords for the defence of their adopted country.

abstract: THE SOUTH. -- The mission of Ex-Gov. FISH and Bishop AMES has been crowned, with unexpected and most splendid success. Our Washington correspondent informs us, that after refusing to admit them to visit the National prisoners, the insurgent Government made them the vehicle of a proposition for a general exchange. At the time this offer came, the Wise Legion had not been captured, and the balance of numbers was by some three hundred in favor of the South. This advantage the rebels offered to forego, by releasing at once all the captives in their hands; the excess of National prisoners to go upon parole. The proposition was promptly accepted, and it will not be many days before all those brave fellows, for whom families and friends have been pining hopelessly, will once more be at home. At the reception of some of the number, the brave CORCORAN and COGSWELL, for instance, there will doubtless be something more than private demonstrations of joy.
lead_paragraph: THE SOUTH. -- The mission of Ex-Gov. FISH and Bishop AMES has been crowned, with unexpected and most splendid success. The proposition was promptly accepted, and it will not be many days before all those brave fellows, for whom families and friends have been pining hopelessly, will once more be at home. abstract: A new propeller has commenced running be- tween the Government barge landing, Castle Garden, and Governor's Island, for the convenience of soldiers and their friends, and anyone else wishing to visit the Island. It has been named the General McClellan, and has taken the place of the small propeller General Winfield Scott, which run last summer, and was sold to Government at, it is said, a pretty good price.

abstract: Col. RUSSELL, of the Connecticut Tenth, who was killed at the head of his regiment, while gallantly leading in the assault upon the rebel works at Roanoke Island, was born at Northfield, Connecticut, in 1828, and consequently was but 33 years of age at the time of his death. The greater part of his life was passed in New-Haven County, where he was engaged as a master mechanic. He was fond of military pursuits, and served for fourteen years in the militia service of his native State. He served in the three months' troops in the Second Regiment Connecticut Militia as Adjutant. He was present at the battle of Manassas, where the regiment was attached to the brigade commanded by Col. KEYES, now Brigadier-General of Volunteers. Col. RUSSELL is honorably mentioned in the report of the battle made by his commanding officer. When the Connecticut Tenth was organized last Summer he was appointed Colonel. His regiment passed through this City in November on its way to the seat of war, and consisted of a fine, athletic-looking set of fellows. For its excellent qualities it was detailed to serve on the Burnside Expedition, and in the first battle its gallant Colonel has fallen -- where so many of our bravest officers fall -- at the head of his regiment.
lead_paragraph: Col. RUSSELL, of the Connecticut Tenth, who was killed at the head of his regiment, while gallantly leading in the assault upon the rebel works at Roanoke Island, was born at Northfield, Connecticut, in 1828, and consequently was but 33 years of age at the time of his death. The greater part of his life was passed in New-Haven County, where he was engaged as a master mechanic. He was fond of military pursuits, and served for fourteen years in the militia service of his native State. He served in the three months' troops in the Second Regiment Connecticut Militia as Adjutant. He was present at the battle of Manassas, where the regiment was attached to the brigade commanded by Col. KEYES, now Brigadier-General of Volunteers. Col. RUSSELL is honorably mentioned in the report of the battle made by his commanding officer. When the Connecticut Tenth was organized last Summer he was appointed Colonel. His regiment passed through this City in November on its way to the seat of war, and consisted of a fine, athletic-looking set of fellows. For its excellent qualities it was detailed to serve on the Burnside Expedition, and in the first battle its gallant Colonel has fallen -- where so many of our bravest officers fall -- at the head of his regiment.

abstract: fort being attacked by Union forces
snippet: fort being attacked by Union forces
lead_paragraph: The news from Western Tennessee this morning is highly exciting. Fort Donelson was invested, and the attack upon it begun, on the morning of Thursday, at 7 A.M. The cannonade was kept up with great fury on both sides for the whole day. Gen. MCCLERNAND's Division operated on the right wing and Gen. SMITH's on the left. There was but one gunboat -- the Carondelet -- to play on the Fort, but the others were said to be coming up. It is believed that the left redoubt had fallen into our hands. Three of the rebel guns were dismounted, and our sharpshooters were picking off the cannoniers as fast as they appeared. A considerable number had been killed and wounded on both sides. There were said to be 15,000 rebels within the works, commanded by PILLOW, FLOYD, JOHNSTON and BUCKNER. No rebel reinforcements could arrive. Gen. GRANT and all his men were acting with the greatest gallantry. The fort will he stormed to-day or to-morrow.

abstract: It is hard to say whether the intelligence of Gen. PRICE having again evacuated Springfield, and retreated southward, is to be regarded as good or bad news.
lead_paragraph: It is hard to say whether the intelligence of Gen. PRICE having again evacuated Springfield, and retreated southward, is to be regarded as good or bad news. That rebel chieftain has such a facility, on being pursued, of retreating to where pursuit is said to be impossible, and such a fatal facility of advancing again as soon as our forces have given up the chase and retired to their base of operations, that we have come now to look upon a retreat of PRICE and his army as only the prelude to their subsequent advance. It would certainly have been much better for us if he could now have been induced to make a stand, and at once try the issue, and, if possible, settle it for Missouri, upon the battlefield. We were in hope that our troops were moving upon him in such a way, or ways, as to force a decisive fight upon him at or near Springfield. It may indeed be that that will yet take place before he gets out of the State. There are two roads leading south from Springfield -- one in a southeasterly direction, by Ozark, and the other in a southwesterly direction. Of the two accounts publish, one says that he retreated by the former route, and the other by the latter. If he has taken the southeasterly route, it is possible that he may make a stand at the scene of his old triumph, at the strongly fortified position of Wilson's Creek, or, if he does not, that he may be overtaken by our pursuing columns before he reaches the crossing of the White River. If he has taken the road toward Fayetteville, in Arkansas, it is not likely he will pause in his retreat until he reaches the wild and desolate region of the Boston Mountains, in the Indian Territory, when his forces, if pursued, will scatter, and every man seek safety as best he may. As, however, one of the columns of our army was moving southwardly on a road some distance west of where the Fayetteville road leaves Springfield, it is to be hoped it may come up in time to intercept his fleeing troops. In case he does not make a stand anywhere in Missouri, and our troops do not succeed in intercepting him at any point, there is little doubt, whichever road he may have started upon, that he will pass through Southwestern Missouri, and the northwestern corner of Arkansas into the Indian Territory, where he will join his forces and his fortunes with those of the red rebels. What, in that case, our troops will then do, so far away from their supplies, and from any practicable basis for operations, remains to be seen.
headline: {'main': 'The Rebel Retreat from Missouri.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Rebel Retreat from Missouri.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a bill was reported from the Military Committee to reorganize the cavalry. A resolution for the relief of loyal Indians, driven from their homes by the rebels, was adopted. A bill to provide for the safe-keeping and...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a bill was reported from the Military Committee to reorganize the cavalry. A resolution for the relief of loyal Indians, driven from their homes by the rebels, was adopted. A bill to provide for the safe-keeping and maintenance of United States prisoners was referred; also a bill to provide for Provisional Governments in certain cases. The bill to provide a Warden for the jail in the District of Columbia was passed. The report and resolution from the Naval Committee, relative to the Secretary of the Navy, was debated, but was not disposed of. The case of Senator STARKE, of Oregon, was postponed until Tuesday. The bill in regard to the pay and emoluments of the officers of the army was taken up and debated until the Senate went into Executive session, at the close of which it adjourned until Monday.

abstract: The schooner Glide was seen going out at 2 A.M. to-day, and a blank cartridge was fired at her to heave to, but she kept on, when a signal was made to the officer on duty at Fort Hamilton, who fired a shot at her, and struck her. This had the effect to bring her, and several others who were in company, back to the cutter. Five shots in all were fired from Forts Hamilton and Lafayette.

abstract: Another battery of artillery from Rhode Island, the Ninth, reached this City yesterday morning in the steamer Vanderbilt, of the Stonington line, en route to Port Royal. This battery consists of 156 active, intelligent young men -- real Rhode Island stock -- and are under the command of Lieut. WIGHTMAN. Two companies of recruits for the Rhode Island Third accompany the battery. These troops will probably sail to-day in a transport. The following officers are attached to the companies: Capt. EDDY, and Lieuts. Wightman, Potter, Rossander, Brown and Dockray. Men and officers are in fine spirits, and are eager to reach Port Royal to take part in the military operations there.

abstract: The TIMES, in advance of all other leading journals, yesterday gave to the public a most important order of the Secretary of War. It was an announcement that the crisis in our national distemper is passed; that the extraordinary measures and rigors exacted by the dangers of last year are no longer necessary; and that the military prisons are to be cleared of their inmates. Hereafter, we are told, no...
lead_paragraph: The TIMES, in advance of all other leading journals, yesterday gave to the public a most important order of the Secretary of War. It was an announcement that the crisis in our national distemper is passed; that the extraordinary measures and rigors exacted by the dangers of last year are no longer necessary; and that the military prisons are to be cleared of their inmates. Hereafter, we are told, no prisoners will be consigned to Forts Lafayette, McHenry and Warren, except for military offences, under a warrant of the Secretary of War.

abstract: Gen. BURNSIDE and Commodore GOLDSBOROUGH are not disposed to slumber upon their laurels. Their advance into the interior is steady, one point after another falling into their hands without resistance. Hertford, on the north side of Albemarle Sound, and Plymouth on the south, are in possession of the National troops. The Chowan river is open to the ascent of the gunboats and transports. The railroads at Welden and Suffolk may at any moment be severed; in fact, all the expedition was designed to accomplish is on the verge of completion. The rear of the principal rebel army in Virginia, with its lines of communication, indispensable for supplies, reinforcements and retreat, are about to fall into our hands, leaving to its leaders the choice of fight or flight. They must decide promptly. The advance of Gen. LANDER to Blooming Gap, and his success at that point, are but the first step of the movement, which must precipitate a decision.

abstract: There are three things in which the rebels have shown themselves proficient, viz.: stealing, lying and vituperation and it is difficult to say which has played the most important part in the rebellion. But for the stolen arms with...
lead_paragraph: There are three things in which the rebels have shown themselves proficient, viz.: stealing, lying and vituperation and it is difficult to say which has played the most important part in the rebellion. But for the stolen arms with which FLOYD filled the Southern arsenals, thus arming the South "in spite of herself," as the Richmond Enquirer says, the lack of arms would have almost of itself been enough to have prevented the rebellion; and but for the amounts due their Northern creditors, which they evinced such an alacrity in first refusing to pay and then in confiscating, the sinews of war would have been unstrung. And the truism, that "He who steals will lie," was never more thoroughly illustrated. One would almost think that they had carried into all departments of morals, the same startling boldness and independence of thought, as they would call it -- the same lack of sense and incapacity to reason, as it seems to us, which led them to assume, as the fundamental principle of government, that Slavery is the true foundation of freedom, and that they had thus arrived, also, at the belief of two other similar paradoxes, viz.: That stealing is the best foundation for honesty, and that ying is the corner-stone of truth.

lead_paragraph: This regiment, which has been quartered for some time past on Governor's Island, embarked on board the steamer Ericsson on Friday evening, in order to be conveyed to Port Royal. Owing to some unforeseen delay, the vessel did not sail till yesterday. The regiment numbers nearly a thousand men, who are thoroughly equipped, and armed with the Enfield rifle. abstract: The screw gunboats Kennebec, Commander RUSSELL, and Kineo, Commander RANSOM, sailed from Boston on Thursday to join the Gulf Squadron. The Penobscot, Marblehead, Aroostook, and Chocura, will be ready for commission the beginning of this week, and will no doubt all sail within eight days, and the Wachusett soon after. Capt. MISROON, late of the Savannah, has been appointed to the command of the latter vessel. This officer has seen service, and is one of those whom the South Carolina Legislature honored, by denouncing as traitors and false to their State. He is known to be a brave and skillful officer.

abstract: The Star learns from a gentleman who came direct from Roanoke Island that Col. RUSSELL, of the Tenth Connecticut Regiment, fell dead from his horse, at the head of his regiment, while marching against the enemy. Strange as it may appear, not a scratch was found upon his body when examined, and his death must have come from the wind of a cannonball, or from excitement.

abstract: Henry, and printed in the report of our special correspondent, yesterday, embraced a ludicrous mixture of blunt confession, and cheap and empty gasconade. They possibly amused our readers, while incidentally conveying some idea of how, and of what material, the legions of the enemy down South are improvised. But the following additional scrap of familiar correspondence, found in the same fort, after the Mississippi and other volunteers had "cut and run," is of a different order. It was written by a father in Mississisippi to his two married sons in the volunteer service, and there is in it that, which, if not truly pathetic in style, ought, at least, to excite our sympathies, for the substance of its honest acknowledgment of the material and mental sufferings which follow political wrongdoing. A great crime has been committed by the wicked conspirators against a beneficent Government, and this plain and almost heart-broken planter in Mississippi confesses to his boys in the Confederate service, how the Lord of Hosts has forsaken the land and people upon whom is made to rest this heavy sin:

abstract: As the army and navy of the Union pierce the interior of the Southern Border States, we are afforded an insight into the real condition of suffering and smothered sentiment among the masses of these misguided people.
lead_paragraph: As the army and navy of the Union pierce the interior of the Southern Border States, we are afforded an insight into the real condition of suffering and smothered sentiment among the masses of these misguided people. The official and informal reports of the gunboat expedition up the Tennessee River, after the capture of Fort Henry, have already been published. They are too significant and well authenticated for reasonable doubt as to the state of popular feeling through the Western District of Tennessee and the contiguous counties of North Alabama. The people are heartily tired of a rebellion into which they were precipitated last Spring by mad and unprincipled politicians. They long to welcome back the good old flag under which their fathers established a Constitutional Government, and bequeathed to their sons a prosperous and happy independence. They were more than reluctant to have their State even attempt to sever its connection with the Federal Union. They protested against it, voted against, refusing to commit to a Convention of delegates of their own choosing the discussion of the sacrilegious proposition. But the year before they had elected a Legislature for other and more legitimate duties, and this body, under the false guidance of the traitorous Governor HARRIS, who made himself the pliant and miserable tool of the Montgomery usurpation, passed the ordinance of separation, and entered into the so-called compact of confederation with the Gulf States. A majority of the people, frensied by the grossest misrepresentations, and in numerous counties literally threatened and overborne by the military which had been called into the field against the Union, without waiting the popular consent of the ballot-box, had no choice left to them but to go with their rulers. It was a bitter pill to reverse in June, what they had declared to be their honest and untrammeled sentiment in February. Thousands and tens of thousands of their more independent fellow-citizens refused to the end to vote with them. In some of the Western counties through which the Tennessee River runs, after passing from East Tennessee, through North Alabama, to the Western District, the majority continued against separation. It is these good people who welcomed our River Navy and the glorious old flag which it bore in triumph from Fort Henry, last week, and the same demonstrations were made at Eastport and Florence, in Northern Alabama, where the friends of Mr. DOUGLAS, in 1860, were in the ascendant over Southern radicalism.

lead_paragraph: A prisoner of war is a disarmed soldier in the power of his enemy, wounded or not. We have spoken of the wounded enemy in our power, and here let me say that LOUIS XIV, was present at the battle of Fontenoy, where his Marshal, SAXE, was victorious over the Duke of Cumberland, and was asked how the wounded were to be treated, when he answered: "Like ourselves; they have ceased to be enemies." Would to God that this was so with every one in our own war with a certain side.

abstract: -- The spectre of European intermeddling in the American quarrel is laid. The advices received by the Asia show that both France and England decline to interfere, without the development of new causes; and they, if events continue to move with their present velocity, are not likely to occur. The change of French sentiment in this particular is marked not only by the applause attending the allusion by the Emperor, in his address to the Legislative body, to the policy of non-interference, but by the signal change in the tone of the semi-official Press, previously clamorous for intervention. The project seems to be generally abandoned. In England not only has the Government signified its resolution to persevere in its neutrality, but popular demonstrations at Manchester and York, and the counsels of the leading journals, strongly support the Government policy. The last court card of the rebels has thus been played, and is trumped.
lead_paragraph: -- The spectre of European intermeddling in the American quarrel is laid. abstract: gives series of lectures at Brooklyn Academy of Music
snippet: gives series of lectures at Brooklyn Academy of Music
lead_paragraph: The fourth lecture of the Graham course was delivered at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Sunday evening, Feb. 9. Prof. A. briefly adverted to the evidence of the great length of the present geological period, as shown by the manner in which the Niagara River had worn a channel below the Falls; also, by the accumulations at the mouths of great rivers. The Delta of the Nile, which has been solid land since the dawn of human history, and which is the work of that river, shows that it has been flowing when there were no men on earth. Our own Mississippi tells the same story. We have no tradition which accounts for the accumulation around the prominent forks below New-Orleans; and yet what is that space compared with the whole distance from St. Louis to the Gulf of Mexico, all of which has become dry land by the deposit of mud brought down by that river? For there is evidence that the Gulf of Mexico once extended even to the upper bend of the Missouri. In those accumulations of mud we find the remains of the same plants which grow on the adjacent hills, the same shells, and the bones of the same fishes that now exist, just as we find the same corals in the reefs inside of the Florida coast and those outside. But there is one feature in regard to corals that I beg leave here to advert to. There is a gradation in these animals; those that are more compact in form are inferior to those which radiate in elegant branches, and that same gradation is observable in the various levels at which they grow. Those that are found deepest are lowest in structure; while those that grow at the surface of the water are highest in structure. Thus the thought of gradation in the mind of the Creator is manifested even in the coral walls of the depths of the sea. Prof. AGASSIZ here gave a brief account of the physical history of the earth. He explained the theory of the formation of the solar system, from experiments of PLATEAU with a revolving globule of oil in a liquid of the same specific gravity. By means of a rod, the globule was made to rotate with accelerated velocity, until the extreme equatorial portions were thrown off in the form of a ring like Salturus; and as this ring lost its rotation, the tendency was to flow to-gether in a spherical form, constituting a body revolving around the central mass. Thus was exemplified, no doubt, the way in which our solar system was formed, assuming the nebular hypothesis to be true, which was generally conceded. But there is no means of ascertaining what lapse of time it has required for this process; and yet we have to take this part of the history into account in the chronology of the world. The earth being once set off from its primary has thenceforth a history of its own, and here is a field of investigation to be explored. The history, as presented by the astronomer, is not yet taken up by the geologist and followed up. There is a middle ground that requires both astronomical and geological knowledge, which we must wait for another generation of scientific men, educated for that purpose, to explore. When geologists take up the subject it is with our earth as a distinct body, already solidified at its surface, and presenting two kinds of rocks -- of different origin -- the unstratified and the stratified. The first are of igneous origin, and the second are produced by the agency of water. The lavas which flow from volcanoes, when cold, present a structure similar to the unstratified rocks. The stratified rocks must have been deposited in horizontal layers. Our proof of this is the fact that the remains of animals and plants, which form an integral part of these rocks, are found in a position which shows that they must have been deposited horizontally. The bivalve shells, for instance, are always found lying parallel to the surface of stratification -- just as we would find an oyster shell in the mud at the bottom of a river, lying on its flat surface. And yet we find stratified rocks in slanting positions, but the conclusion is inevitable that they were originally formed horizontally, and were subsequently tilted by upheaval. We frequently find stratified rocks sloping in opposite directions on the two sides of a mountain, the interior of the mountain being of granite. Though the granite rises higher at the summit than the stratified rocks, it is evident that the mass of granite is inferior, for these stratified beds can be easily ascertained to correspondent to one another, the lowest stratus on one side corresponding to the lowest on the other, and so on through the successive layers to the highest. In some cases these strata are found to close over the top of the granite mountain. It is a matter of demonstration that the want of continuity of the stratified rocks is the result of breaks which have taken place in these beds when they were removed from their primitive horizontal position into that which they now occupy, in consequence of an upheaval causing the masses beneath to protrude through the strata. Thus we have mountain chains, the center of which consists of masses upheaved from below, flanke by superficial strata thus displaced. And when we consider the fact that in these beds on the opposite sides of the mountain remains of animals and plants are found in the same slanting position assumed by the beds themselves, and in the same relative position and order on the two sides, the evidence is overwhelming that those beds must have been originally formed in a horizontal position, where they remained till they hardened into rock. Now, whatever be the age of these beds, we find everywhere below them unstratified masses, showing that rocks of igneous origin are the foundation crust of our earth. Taking now into consideration another fact, that the stratified beds must have been deposited one after the other, the lowest first and the uppermost last, we must conclude that there was a time when there was nothing above the unstratified masses, and that they alone constituted the solid portion of the earth. That these unstratified rocks are of igneous origin is further proved by the fact that most of the great mountain chains there are found cavities where the unstratified masses have flowed in, soldering the sides of those cavities together. These unstratified rocks contain no remains either of animals or plants, and therefore furnish evidence that at the time of their formation the earth was uninhabited, for there are hardly any animals so soft that none of their parts could not be preserved. The solid parts of animals when once deposited in sand or mud and covered, are there preserved and treasured up for all future time in the solid rock that is formed out of the deposit. In exploring the strata of the earth and examining their contents it is ascertained from the immense number and variety of animals and plants, there found, that at all times since the stratified rocks have been forming, the earth has teemed with inhabitants as numerous and diversified as they are now. Within the limits of this State there are beds of rock so full of remains of animals and plants that the mass of strata consists of almost nothing else. And yet these limestone rocks are among the oldest of the stratified beds on the surface of the earth. Here then we may begin to trace through the successive stata the history of the development and progress of life. We may consider these beds or layers as the leaves of a great book in which is recorded the history of all the various plants and animals that have existed since creation, and the order of their succession. In order to read this book, it is only necessary to study living animals and plants to such an extent as to be able to recognize them when they are not quite perfect. It is not difficult to be able to recognize each tooth of any common animal, and not only to tell to what species it belonged, but to assign it its proper place in the mouth. And this study may be extended so as to be able to distinguish any separate bone, and even a single scale of a fish; and not only tell to what particular animal it belonged, but assign it to its proper place. Having acquired that knowledge, it may be applied to remains of animals which have existed only in former ages, as they are found in the rocks, so that even when fragments of those animals are discovered, a comparison between them and animals now living will be sufficient to ascertain how far they are related to one another, and whether they belong to the same or a different species. In this way geologists are able to refer these remains at once to their different groups, and the result of their investigation is this, that all animals which live now upon the earth, to whatever class they belong, differ from all the animals which have existed before, and that those which have existed in the earlier periods are not the same at different depths of the earth's crust, but each successive bed contains remains entirely different from those above it. So that we may consider the whole stratified crust of our earth as an immense cemetery made up of large leaves and sheets of rocks, within which are buried all the inhabitants that have lived on the globe, and to such an extent preserved that their true character can be identified. And naturalists have already proceeded so far in their explorations, that it is no exaggeration to say that the remains of some of these ancient animals are better known than some that now exist, as for instance, in the interior of Australia, Africa and America. Fossil remains are everywhere found in such quantities that we may make collections of them as complete as of butterflies in Summer. Knowing now the order of stratification and of succession, we find evidences of certain breaks and interruptions of that order, indicating great commotions on the globe. At the beginning of the Christian era Mount Nueva, in the Bay of Naples, rose above the level of the sea some 400 feet, causing the destruction of immense quantities of fishes and marine animals for a great distance around. Before that event everything was going on quietly, animals were dying in the course of nature, and sinking in the mud in regular order. But those beds were disturbed in the same manner, probably, as in former ages, on a grander scale, immense portions of the earth's strata were upheaved and erected into mountain chains. It is these gigantic upheavals, no doubt, which have changed the configuration of the earth's surface, and produced those interruptions in the regular order of succession which we observe in the strata of rocks. Prof. A. here named, and illustrated on the black-board, the various systems or divisions of rocks which marked the successive epochs. Each of these is characterized by peculiar animal and vegetable remains. Thus, Geology furnishes the most direct evidence against the favorite theory of some, that there has been no gradual transformation of animals, but that each successive epoch has been characterized by the same diversity that we now observe, and that the animals of one epoch are not identical with those of another, and we find that all the different types of animals existed in the most ancient times. Radiates, molluses, articulates and vertebrates have always existed side by side. These, therefore, could not have been derived from one another -- for cotemporaries cannot be each other's descendants. On the lowest layer we find various kinds of radiates, mulluses and articulates: and though we do not there find mammals, birds or reptiles, yet we find fishes, so that at least the type of the vertebrates, is represented, indicating the intention of introducing man as the highest representative of that class. So these principal divisions of the animal kingdom have had a common start. But there is evidence that animals have at certain periods ceased to exist, and have been replaced by the representatives of another period. Let me give you the nature of that evidence, derived from the fact that there have been successive upheavals of stratified rocks. In the Jura Mountains, for instance, we find the lowest beds having a certain slant; upon these are deposited other beds that slant at a different angle; and upon [???] we have still other beds which are horizontal. It is evident that here there have been two successive upheavals, for each bed must have been deposited horizontally. And now if we ascertain that the first set of beds is jurassic, the second cretaceous, and the third miocene, we know that that mountain chain was raised earlier than the cretaceous period, and that before the miocene period it underwent a second elevation. It is by such facts that we ascertain the relative ages of all the mountain chains on the globe, and the result of the investigation is, that the higher mountains are the younger, and the lower the older -- all of course prior to the present epoch. It is found, for instance, that the Alps were upheaved subsequent to the cretaceous period, and therefore that the Alps are younger than the Jura. The lofty mountains were once considered as the back-bone of the earth, around which the waves of the ocean had been heaping up loose materials. But if the internal structures had been known as it now is, it would have at once appeared that when the earth's crust was thinner the resistance would be less, and, consequently, only small hills would be found. It is only where the resistance is great that the result is gigantic. The Rocky Mountains are higher than the Apalachians on the sea-board of the Atlantic, and are therefore younger. And this is in accordance with other facts. We find the sand stone of the Connecticut valley standing everywhere, and the cretaceous, and other more recent deposits forming the low lands along the shore horizontal; whereas, in the region or the Rocky Mountains the most recent deposits found on this continent follow the mountain slopes. Thus it will also appear that the oldest chain on this continent is that which follows the great Canada lakes, where we find the very oldest beds slightly raised and following the undulations of the land, while even the oldest fossil-bearing rocks are at the foot of the hills, and do not rise to the summit. Now these interruptions mark the limits of these great successive geological periods. During the intervals between those great commotions the earth has remained quiet as it is now; animals and plants have gone on multiplying, and their remains became buried in the strata, until another commotion produces another change, another configuration, another disturbance of land and sea, and all the concomitant results. And in each of these sets of beds, as I have stated, we find peculiar combinations of animals, but through all ages consisting of representatives of all the great divisions of the animal kingdom -- at first polyps, acalephs and echinoderms, associated with bivalves, univalves and chambered shells, also with worms, crustacea and fishes; then very soon with insects, reptiles, birds and mammals, and at last with man. And now the order of succession in detail I shall present in my next lecture.

abstract: announcing it, those who have yet failed to understand the real merits of the cause for which the Government is contending, will find the case so clearly and succinctly stated as to put controversy out of the question. Mr. STANTON has infinite skill in the framing of State papers. His orders are at once direct and eloquent, convincing and animating. The document we have just referred to is a fine specimen of his terse and exhaustive logic; while the congratulatory dispatches addressed to the heroes of Roanoke Island and Fort Heary, exhibit a tact in such matters resembling that of NAPOLEON.

abstract: Map and description of points of military operations on Albermarie Sound, NC
snippet: Map and description of points of military operations on Albermarie Sound, NC
lead_paragraph: We repeat the accompanying small, but exceedingly full, clear, and accurate map of the scene of our operations in Eastern North Carolina, to accompany our diagrams of the plan of the action of Roanoke Island, which will be found on the Eighth Page. These diagrams were made by our correspondent on the island, while the military movements and the battle were still going on. We have already described, in detail, for the benefit of those who had forgotten the lessons of the school-room, the geographical and topographical character of this part of the State, and of the seacoast, and it is not now necessary to rehearse. From the rebel news we publish this morning, it would appear that our troops had taken possession of several other towns since the date of our advices direct from BURNSIDE. Hertford and Plymouth, as well as Edenton and Elizabeth City, heretofore reported captured, all on or near Albermarle Sound, are said to be in our hands, and our gunboats had penetrated the Chowan River as far up as the town of Winton. The position of all these places will be seen on the map, as also their relation to Norfolk and the railroad running south from that point. Hertford is the capital town of Perquimans County, and is situated on the south side of Perquimans River, near its entrance into Perquimans Bay, a branch of Albemarle Sound. It is a small place of some five hundred inhabitants. It is only 50 miles south by west from Norfolk, and there is a road leading from there to the railroad connecting with that great rebel stronghold. Plymouth is the capital of Washington County, and is a small town of 1,000 inhabitants. It is situated on the south side of Roanoke River, eight miles from its entrance into Albemarle Sound. Edenton, the citizens of which raised the white flag on the approach of our troops, is the capital of Chowan County, and contains about 2,000 inhabitants. It contains a fine court-house, a jail, two churches, an academy, and a printing-office, and is a place of some shipping -- inland navigation. Elizabeth City, heretofore reported as in our possession, after being burned by the rebels, is the capital of Pasquotank County, and and has 1,000 inhabitants. It is situated on Pasquotank River, 20 miles from its mouth. Vessels requiring seven feet of water come up to the place. It has a water communication with Norfolk, 20 miles up the Pasquotank River, thence 22 miles by the Dismal Swamp Canal, and thence nine miles to Norfolk.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the bill to amend the charter of the Long Island Railroad Company was reported favorably; also, the bill respecting the act to open Union-street, Brooklyn; also, the bill to amend the act altering the map of the City of Brooklyn. Mr. ROBERTSON'S bill, regulating concert saloons in this City, was then debated in Committee of the Whole until the adjournment, which was made until Monday evening.

abstract: A glorious day we have had at the National Capital. An atmosphere bright as youth, and inspiring as the presence of beauty, has enwrapped the earth; while an air, sweet as ever breathed over a bed of violets, sweeps from the warm South, as if to remind us of the love that once reached us from that land of flowers. This is the first utterance of Spring.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Thursday, Feb. 13, 1862.

abstract: Bowling Green, the rebel stronghold of the West, has been evacuated, and the place is now occupied by the National forces. This gratifying news way telegraphed to Gen. McCLELLAN by Gen. BUELL, Gen. MITCHELL'S Division, by a...
lead_paragraph: Bowling Green, the rebel stronghold of the West, has been evacuated, and the place is now occupied by the National forces. This gratifying news way telegraphed to Gen. McCLELLAN by Gen. BUELL, Gen. MITCHELL'S Division, by a forced march, reached the Big Barren River at Bowling Green yesterday morning, but could not cross immediately, as the rebels, at 1 o'clock in the morning, had burnt the railroad bridge, and our troops were forced to build a bridge for their passage. The rebels were evacuating the place when Gen. MITCHELL arrived.

abstract: --It was the fervent wish of an eminent patriarch that his enemy might write a book. Some commentators have gathered from this that Job was a reviewer by profession, and rejoiced in the pleasurable anticipation of paying particular attention to that particular book, in the literary columns of some antediluvian daily or hebdomadal.
lead_paragraph: --It was the fervent wish of an eminent patriarch that his enemy might write a book. Some commentators have gathered from this that Job was a reviewer by profession, and rejoiced in the pleasurable anticipation of paying particular attention to that particular book, in the literary columns of some antediluvian daily or hebdomadal. But the only ground for assuming that he was troubled with books as well as with boils, and obliged, in the faithful performance of his duty, to read all that was printed -- there were fools before the flood -- is found in the record which hands him down to us as a man of many sorrows and much patience. It is more to be supposed that Job desired his enemy to become an author, because he knew how fatal it is in the majority of cases, for a man to commit himself to print. An evidence of folly is thus put upon record which will continue until the edition is bought up, and the stereotype plates destroyed. If Mr. BENJAMIN WOOD, a gentleman who has the honor of representing one of the patriotic districts of this City, in Congress, has any enemies -- we trust he has not -- they have now cause for joy, he has written a book and published it.

abstract: Editorial on US flag flying in NYC in honor of Union victories of week
snippet: Editorial on US flag flying in NYC in honor of Union victories of week
lead_paragraph: -- It recalled the old day after Sumter to see, as we did in New-York on Saturday, the City resplendent with thousands of flags. In accordance with the suggestion of Mayor OPDYKE, the Stars and Stripes were, in commemoration of the glorious Union victories of the week, raised over all the public buildings of the City; and the newspaper offices, libraries, hotels, shipping in the harbor, and tens of thousands of private dwellings followed the example. The emblem of our nationality did not float more proudly in the pulsing air than our hopes beat high at the successes of the cause. And the flag seemed to have a meaning different from that it conveyed during the uprising after Sumter. Then it marked a prophecy, a resolve; now it signalizes triumphant fulfillment. During the "winter of our discontent," too, the flag all but disappeared from view; but now it bursts forth like the buds and blossoms of Spring. Let it not cease its inspiring presence; for if last week was glorious in its victories, this week promises to be still more so -- opening as it does with the illuminated initial of the downfall of Fort Donelson -- the Sebastopol of the rebellion in the West. Keep the Stars and Stripes flying!

abstract: The excitement of the past week in fashionable, musical, and journalistic circles was the return of the eminent planist, Mr. GOTTSCHALK. Every one with an...
lead_paragraph: The excitement of the past week in fashionable, musical, and journalistic circles was the return of the eminent planist, Mr. GOTTSCHALK. Every one with an opinion to utter has been careful to deliver it, and hence -- as the opinions were all of one character -- the Metropolis has resounded with a loud chorus of praise. The young American artist may well feel proud of his triumph. Such singular unanimity does not often fall to the lot of the most praiseworthy. Mr. GOTTSCHALK gave three concerts in New-York and one in Brooklyn -- the latter being the least successful of the number, as is usually the case. To-night Mr. GOTTSCHALK will give his fourth grand concert at Niblo's Saloon, being assisted on the occasion by Mr. HARRY SANDERSON, and the principal vocal artists of the Academy of Music.

abstract: A brief dispatch received in this City last evening made the gratifying announcement that Fort Donelson had fallen before our troops, and that the Old Flag was waving over it. From subsequent dispatches, giving details, we learn that the battle commenced on Thursday, and continued...
lead_paragraph: A brief dispatch received in this City last evening made the gratifying announcement that Fort Donelson had fallen before our troops, and that the Old Flag was waving over it. From subsequent dispatches, giving details, we learn that the battle commenced on Thursday, and continued through Friday, Saturday and Sunday -- the fighting on the three last days being very desperate. The upper fort, or redoubt, was captured by our troops at 4 o'clock on Saturday afternoon, and the Stars and Stripes were immediately hoisted upon it. One of our field batteries, commanded by Col. SWARTZ, was at one time captured by the rebels, but was retaken in the most gallant manner by our troops. Commodore FOOT went into the action on Friday afternoon, with the gunboats St. Louis, Louisville, Pittsburgh, Carondelete, Tyler and Conestoga, and after an hour and a quarter's fighting at close quarters, was forced to withdraw, his boats having been disabled, with fifty-four men killed and wounded, himself among the latter, though not dangerously. Some idea of the strength of the rebel batteries may be formed when it is stated that the St. Louis alone was struck fifty-nine times. The enemy's firing was very accurate, special pains having been taken to collect in the fort all the best cannoneers in the rebel service. Three batteries were playing upon the gunboats -- one near the water, one fifty feet above this, and the third fifty feet above the second, mounting four 18-pounders, the fire of which was reserved until the gunboats arrived within four hundred yards of the fort. Several of the gunboats in this encounter were more or less disabled. Among the land forces, the Illinois Eighteenth and the Iowa Seventh Regiments are mentioned as having suffered severely. The possession of the upper fort, however, gave our forces a great advantage, as it commands the main work, and Gen. GRANT on Saturday evening telegraphed to Gen. HALLECK that he had no doubt of finishing the work yesterday. Commodore FOOTE states in his official report, that had his boats not been rendered unmanageable by the shooting away of the steering apparatus, in fifteen minutes more he would have had possession of the fort, as the rebels were already running away from their guns. A dispatch from Chicago, giving news from the Fort to Friday, asserts that the rebels were flying the black flag.

abstract: The United States transport Matanzals, Capt. LIESOANG, from Port Royal, arrived here last night, after a passage of five days. She bad in tow for some...
lead_paragraph: The United States transport Matanzals, Capt. LIESOANG, from Port Royal, arrived here last night, after a passage of five days. She bad in tow for some distance the steamer Primero, which had been ordered to New-York for repairs to her machinery. During the first two days out the weather was remarkably fine, with light winds from the southwest, but when passing Cape Hatteras it became very stormy, the wind blowing from the northwest, and changing to northeast, which caused a heavy sea. On the night of the 14th, the Primero was nearly towed under several times. Her bulwarks were stove in by the waves striking violently beneath the guards, and she shipped large quantities of water, and it was only by constant pumping that she could be kept afloat.

abstract: The news of the capture of Fort Donelson--or at least its virtual capture by the taking of the redoubt commanding the rebel positions that still held out on Saturday--which is announced by telegraph this morning, and the still more important news of the rebel evacuation of Bowling Green, will attract un-...
lead_paragraph: The news of the capture of Fort Donelson -- or at least its virtual capture by the taking of the redoubt commanding the rebel positions that still held out on Saturday -- which is announced by telegraph this morning, and the still more important news of the rebel evacuation of Bowling Green, will attract undivided attention to the great military operations now being carried out in the Southwest. To render more clear to everybody the value of these victories, we give the above map, showing not only the important positions which have of late been the scenes of Union triumphs, such as Fort Henry on the Tennessee, Fort Donelson on the Cumberland, Bowling Green on the Big Barren, Mill Springs on the Eastern waters of the Cumberland, and other strategic localities, but showing also the bearing of these points on Columbus and Memphis, on Clarksville and Nashville, on Cumberland Gap and Knoxville, still in rebel hands; and exhibiting, too, the relation of the several places captured, and of those on which our army is now rapidly advancing, to the rebel States immediately south and east of Tennessee, to the Gulf States of Mississippi and Alabama, and to Georgia, North and South Carolina. If the reader will give a few minutes' study to this little reference-map, to its topography, railroads, rivers and mountains, he will gain a more accurate knowledge of our present military situation in the Southwest, and of the directions and places whence our banners will next be borne, than could possibly be given by verbal descriptions. As the scene of our main operations for some time to come is likely to be within the territory included in this map, those who wish to follow them up intelligently will find it convenient to clip out and preserve for reference.

abstract: We have reason to believe, if not the certainty, that Fort Donelson has fallen. After a struggle, desperate on both sides, and, as far as may be judged from the imperfect details which have reached us, creditable to the fighting qualities of both, the post capitalated, and the National colors took the place,...
lead_paragraph: We have reason to believe, if not the certainty, that Fort Donelson has fallen. After a struggle, desperate on both sides, and, as far as may be judged from the imperfect details which have reached us, creditable to the fighting qualities of both, the post capitalated, and the National colors took the place, on the ramparts, of the rebel rag. The destruction of life and the lists of wounded are probably largely in excess of those of any previous contest of the war. It could hardly be otherwise. The opposing forces were strong in numbers; but while the assailants were the more perilously exposed, the defenders, from their very numbers, cooped up as they were in lines where they were helpless to fight, and simply in the way of each other must have suffered frightfully from the storm of shell and shot hurled upon them from that circumvallation of fire. It was doubtless the terrible sacrifice of life to which they were subjected within the fort that prompted these daring sorties which the besiegers so gallantly repulsed.

abstract: I feel that I violate no confidence in stating, as I now do, that the highest military authorities of our Government believe the Confederate rebellion to be hopelessly overthrown. Gen. McCLELLAN is expecting to hear, any hour, that the rebel army is in full retreat from Manassas, and when it breaks away from Manassas, it is doubtful if even Richmond will be a point in the next line of defence.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, D.C., Saturday night, Feb. 15, 1862.

abstract: The United States transport Matanzas, Capt. LIESGANG, from Port Royal, arrived here last night, after a passage of five days. She had in tow for some...
lead_paragraph: The United States transport Matanzas, Capt. LIESGANG, from Port Royal, arrived here last night, after a passage of five days. She had in tow for some distance the steamer Primero, which had been ordered to New-York for repairs to her machinery. During the first two days out the weather was remarkably fine, with light winds from the southwest, but when passing Cape Hatteras it became very stormy, the wind blowing from the northwest, and changing to northeast, which caused a heavy sea. On the night of the 14th, the Primero was nearly towed under several times. Her bulwarks were stove in by the waves striking violently beneath the guards, and she shipped large quantities of water, and it was only by constant pumping that she could be kept afloat.

abstract: One of the Herald's agents is scarcely placed in close confinement, for stealing news, than another is brought to light. IVES is comfortably lodged in Fort McHenry.
lead_paragraph: One of the Herald's agents is scarcely placed in close confinement, for stealing news, than another is brought to light. IVES is comfortably lodged in Fort MCHenry. WIKOFF, upon a special charge of having purloined or otherwise dishonestly obtained portions of the President's Message for publication, is imprisoned, but finally regains his liberty by confessing fully and freely the entire truth. Of this particular delinquency he is not guilty. The agent was another employee of the Herald, one JOHN WATT, formerly a servant at the White House, and now an officer of the army. WATT's his name, who -- probably, under pretence of some menial duty -- stole into the private room of the President, when none else was there, and as he relates, glanced hastily over the manuscript message, but with memory so tenacious as to recall and record literally whole passages for his masters in New-York.

abstract: On the 22d of February -- Saturday of the present week -- JEFFERSON DAVIS, traitor, President, is to be inaugurated at Richmond. On that day the rebel Government shuffles off its "provisional," and assumes its "permanent" form. In the meantime from the West our victorious columns are swooping down on it; from the South BURNSIDE has carried panic to Norfolk; and ere long the words of SHAKESPEARE will find a new reading, in a confused cry and the tremblings of war--

abstract: On motion of Mr. STETSON, the bill to provide for the public defence reported by the Committee on Militia and Public Defence was taken from its place on "general orders," and referred to the first Committee of the Whole for discussion.
lead_paragraph: On motion of Mr. STETSON, the bill to provide for the public defence reported by the Committee on Militia and Public Defence was taken from its place on "general orders," and referred to the first Committee of the Whole for discussion. Section first constitutes the Governor, Lieut.-Governor, and Comptroller a Commission, entitled "The Commission of Public Defence." Section second provides that the Engineer-in-Chief, the State Engineer, and Surveyor, with three engineers of good professional reputation be designated by the above Commissioners, and constituted a board to consider and report plans for the defence and protection of the harbors and frontiers, said Commission to receive a suitable compensation, fixed by the first Commission named, and their actual expenses. Section third authorizes the Commissioners of Public Defence to procure such heavy ordnance and all its appurtenances and ammunition and projectiles therefor. Section fourth authorizes them to turn over such part or parts of the ordnance, and so forth, as they deem proper, to the United States Government, to become a charge against the United States. Section fifth makes the same provision in regard to small arms, accoutrements and ammunition, as section third, in regard to heavy ordnance. Section sixth authorizes surveys and plans to be made for public defences, and the incurring of the necessary expenses therefor. Section seventh provides for the raising, arming and equipping of a volunteer force not to exceed 100,000 men, to serve for one year, unless sooner dismissed, on the same pay and under the same regulations as prevail in the United States service. Section eighth provides for the erection of the temporary fortifications, recommended in the Board of Engineers, under an impending necessity therefor. Section ninth gives a general authorization of all needful measures for affording security to persons and property in the State, in case of war, invasion, insurrection, or imminent danger thereof. Section tenth appropriates $2,000,000 to defray expenses authorized in third, fourth and fifth sections. Section eleventh appropriates $3,000,000 for the expenses contemplated in the sixth, seventh and eighth sections, providing that no portion shall be expended unless in the opinion of the Commissioners there shall be a necessity, actual or impending, for the use of the same, or a portion thereof, before the next session of the Legislature. Section twelve declares that the act shall take effect immediately. The resolutions introduced early in the session, in regard to the exchange of prisoners, were called up, and upon motion of Mr. STETSON again laid upon the table. The moving spirit to this result was a desire to do nothing which can embarrass a Government whose actions are beginning to show its energy and power so gloriously. The people have confidence in a Government that can strike so vigorously, and will have prudence to abide its course of action. In this connection I may add that the order for the release of State prisoners is here regarded as a masterly State paper, and not only that, but a good stroke of policy, as evincing to those who have been carping at what they called unconstitutional actions, that the Administration is anxious to confine itself to the exercise of its ordinary powers, when it safely can dispense with the use of extraordinary powers. It effectually crushes out all cries of centralization, a growing despotism, and all that sort of thing, which quasi-loyalists have been sounding during the whole progress of the war. Mr. REDDINGTON called for the consideration upon his resolutions upon the liquor-prohibition clause of the Constitution, which were pending at the adjournment yesterday. The question pending was the motion to reconsider the vote rejecting Mr. MCMULLEN's substitute. The motion to reconsider was lost, and the question was then taken upon the original resolutions, which were carried by a good majority. Mr. PRYNE called up his resolutions of congratulation upon our recent victories, and made a very patriotic speech in support of them. They were, however, laid upon the table, in order that, when finally passed, they may include other victories, whose announcement is hourly expected. Mr. MCLEOD introduced a resolution refusing the petition of W.R. JACQUES and other citizens of New-York City, in regard to frauds in the street cleaning contracts, to a Select Committee, with power to send for persons and papers, and to act during the recess of the Legislature, if necessary. Being a concurrent resolution, it lies upon the table. A resolution was passed providing for the holding of evening sessions, after the 18th instant, on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday evenings of each week, for the consideration of bills in Committee of the Whole. This begins to look like work, and there is a chance that important bills will now receive their long delayed and needed attention. Mr. TRACEY, of Tioga, called up the resolutions in reference to the expulsion of JESSE D. BRIGHT. Mr. PRINGLE moved as an amendment, seeing that the original resolution was not new pertinent, to strike it out, and insert therefor a resolution expressive of the satisfaction of the Legislature with the action of the Senate. Mr. MCLEOD, of New-York, moved to amend by adding "and extend their thanks to Hon. PRESTON KING for his vote upon that occasion." After an expression of opinion upon the question of passing an implied censure upon Senator HARRIS, the gentlemen withdrew his amendment in order to allow members to vote directly upon the original resolution, but Mr. ALVORD again renewed the amendment. Hereupon, a long and animated discussion arose, in which gentlemen pitched into each other promiscuously. The House finally dodged the question by adjourning until Monday morning. The anxiety of some gentlemen to avoid any vote upon this question is not so indicative of a fierce adherence to the Government, as their loud-mouthed professions of fealty and patriotism. But the majority are determined to have a vote, and the resolution, unamended by Mr. MCLEOD's addition will pass. Mr. MCLEOD's amendment, or a resolution embodying it, cannot pass, I think. Many who would be glad to vote thanks to Senator KING, will vote against anything which implies a censure of Senator HARRIS. Just about the close of the debate, Mr. SCHOLEFIELD announced the receipt of a dispatch that two batteries at Fort Donelson had been taken by our troops, and that by that time, the Fort itself was probably in our hands. The announcement was received with loud applause. The victories awaited have now come, and let us hope that the resolution of approbation of our brave soldiers will not be upon the table any longer than Monday. They deserve all the praise that they can receive at the hands of a grateful people.
