abstract: MILITARY MATTERS IN BROOKLYN.--The Police, a few days since, received a list of no less than 180 deserters from the Fourteenth Regiment N.Y.S.M., Col. A.M. WOOD. The men have all deserted since the battle of Bull Run, several having reached home only within the last few days.
lead_paragraph: MILITARY MATTERS IN BROOKLYN. -- The Police, a few days since, received a list of no less than 180 deserters from the Fourteenth Regiment N.Y.S.M., Col. A.M. WOOD. The men have all deserted since the battle of Bull Run, several having reached home only within the last few days. The most of these men are still lounging about Brooklyn and New-York and vicinity. The Police have at different times made arrests and delivered the parties over to the military authorities at Governor's Island. During the last week nine members of the regiment were arrested, and they will be taken on to Virginia to-day, together with about 175 recruits for the same regiment. The Police make serious complaints of the attempts of a certain class of lawyers to prevent the deserters from being forwarded when arrested, by taking out writs of habeas corpus under the Baby act. Other subterfuges have been resorted to for the purpose of depriving the Government of the services of these men, but thus far without any degree of success commensurate with the efforts put forth in their behalf. One of the local Judges seems to took upon it as an outrage that deserters should be arrested by the police at so much a head, and has intimated a determination to communicate with the Secretary of War upon the subject. The Police, as yet, have not presented any claim for the $5 allowed by the Government for the arrest of deserters. Not withstanding all the difficulties encountered, the Police are determined to obey orders, and arrest every deserter they can find within their jurisdiction. There is considerable dissatisfaction among the members of the Fourteenth, owing to the changing of their numerical designation to the Eighty-fourth, and also growing out of the extended absence of Col. WOOD, who has been a prisoner in the hands of the rebels since the battle of Bull Run. Under the recent change of affairs it is confidently expected that Col. WOOD will soon be permitted to rejoin his regiment, and that he will be able to bring order out of chaos, Officer COYLE, of the First Precint Police, on Saturday night arrested JOHN LYNCH, a member of the regiment, for desertion. LYNCH is something of a desperate character, and avowed a determination never to be taken alive. A severe fight ensued, during which LYNCE seized Officer COYLES chin in his mouth and was shaking him in true terrier fashion, when fortunately assistance arrived, and the pugnacious LYNCH was safely lodged on Governor's Island. WM. THATFORD, another deserter from the Fourteenth, was also arrested Saturday night, by Officer UTTER, of the Fourth Precinct.

abstract: -- The response of Mr. SEWARD to the request for the United States to join the pacification of Mexico will be read with fresh interest, now that the real purpose of the Allies is found to be subjugation, not pacification. It is most fortunate that the action of our Government was thus wisely reserved. We are thus left to a policy which in due time will restore Mexico to her independence, and extinguish the hope of disfiguring the New World with an Olo World crown.

abstract: Editorial on usefulness of iron gunboats in Mississippi River battles
snippet: Editorial on usefulness of iron gunboats in Mississippi River battles
lead_paragraph: It is not becoming in us, as yet, to be too confident, but we think it may now be fairly said that the iron gunboats have settled the question where the Mississippi River shall belong. Whatever fortune betide the Virginia army, or the rebel States on the Atlantic, the Valley of the Mississippi has now passed over to the control of those to whom, in the natural course, it must belong -- the ingenious and hardy population of the West and Northwest. The iron gunboats are merely an exponent of those qualities which have gained the victory -- the ingenuity, mechanical skill, perseverance and calm courage of a Northern free people over the ardor and impulse, and want of thoroughness, of a Southern and slaveholding population.
headline: {'main': 'The Meaning of the Iron Gunboats.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Meaning of the Iron Gunboats.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Diagrams of the battle-scenes on Roanoke Island, drawn by our correspondent on the spot, were inserted only in our edition of Sunday morning, and as being the only correct view of the field and the movements yet given to the public there have been ...
lead_paragraph: The Diagrams of the battle-scenes on Roanoke Island, drawn by our correspondent on the spot, were inserted only in our edition of Sunday morning, and as -- being the only correct view of the field and the movements yet given to the public -- there have been a large number of Inquiries for them, we herewith reproduce them. The contour of the island, and the location of the rebel fortifications and batteries, will at once be seen and understood. At the left, on the mainland, a long, low point puts out, which marks the entrance to Croatan Sound, (Croatan Sound is the sheet of water to the left of Roanoke Island, as seen in the Diagram.) The entrance for ships lies between this marshy point and two small, low islands, between which, on piles, is set a lighthouse. The passage is not not over 200 yards wide, and could easily have been obstructed by sinking wrecks or driving piles. It was not capable of being defended, however, the mainland at the left being an extensive marsh, cut up in all directions by deep sloughs.

abstract: It is re ported that Mr. LINDSAY, whose thirst for notoriety has already led him to an absurd and intemperate zeal in the service of the rebel cause, intends to present the House of Commons a list of same five hundred ships which ...
lead_paragraph: -- It is reported that Mr. LINDSAY, whose thirst for notoriety has already led him to an absurd and intemperate zeal in the service of the rebel cause, intends to present the House of Commons a list of same five hundred ships which have run the blockade. From present appearances, however, it is probable that Mr. Bull will be in no humor to listen to such representations. For English newspapers are inquiring how it is that cotton cannot be exported, if the blockade is really so imperfect; and journals formerly hostile to our National cause, argue that the blockade is proved to be generally efficient by the "excessive prices of sugar, salt, leather, woolen goods, and other articles of prime necessity;" and especially by the fact, that "at Richmond, during the prevalence of ague-fever among the troops, it was impossible in November last to obtain quinino at any price." The real facts of the case are at length, it seems, becoming known; and, if so, Mr. LINDSAY's little plot to pervert the truth and aid his Confederate friends is prematurely exploded.

abstract: Many were the anxious hearts carried to business yesterday. Over the matutinal muffin was read the fact that the right wing of the intreachments at Fort Donelson had been carried, and that the Stars ...
lead_paragraph: Many were the anxious hearts carried to business yesterday. Over the matutinal muffin was read the fact that the right wing of the intreachments at Fort Donelson had been carried, and that the Stars and Stripes waved over those works. In ferry-boats' omnibuses and cars men earnestly discussed the position of our troops, and confidently asserted that it was only a question of time with regard to the beleaguered fort. Yet, notwithstanding this confidence in the success of our troops, anxiety was depicted on many faces, and further news was looked for with the deepest interest.

abstract: A regular meeting of the Board of Aldermen Was held last evening, Ald. P.G. TAYLOR in the Chair. Under the special order, the Railroad Committee reported that it was inexpedlent the present season to prohibit the use of salt by the Railroad ...
lead_paragraph: A regular meeting of the Board of Aldermen Was held last evening, Ald. P.G. TAYLOR in the Chair. Under the special order, the Railroad Committee reported that it was inexpedlent the present season to prohibit the use of salt by the Railroad Companies on their tracks. The Committee also recommend the passage of an ordinance to prohibit smoking in the cars, and also forbidding the Conductors from eating their meals on the cars. The last two matters were finally withdrawn, and the report was then laid on the table.

abstract: By reference to our Fortress Monroe dispatch, it will be seen that this city is to be soon placed on rapport with the headquarters of Gen. WOOL.
lead_paragraph: By reference to our Fortress Monroe dispatch, it will be seen that this city is to be soon placed on rapport with the headquarters of Gen. WOOL. The cable will be speedily laid, and we shall soon have the pleasure of laying before the public important news from that quarter as soon as received there from various Southern localities, which we have heretofore, in common with the public, had anxiously to await twenty-four, and in some, instances thirty-six hours. As the Burnside and other important expeditions progress on their conquering marches, the value of this new line will soon be evident. The line has been built by Mr. HEISS, formerly connected with the Southern Magnetic line, but now one of the staff of Capt. A. STAGER, Chief of the Army Electric Corps. The cable was manufactured by Mr. BISHOP, of this City, and is a very superior one. As our forces move onward, connections will be made with this line further South, and be of infinite service to the military authorities, the Press and the public.

abstract: Editorials on British observations on war; highlights of bill
snippet: Editorials on British observations on war; highlights of bill
lead_paragraph: Tuscarora seems to have created a rather strong sensation on the English Channel shore, and, indeed, throughout the country, all her movements being immediately telegraphed to the London journals. The February number of the united Service Magazine, the monthly organ of the naval and military professions, contains a short article concerning her and the rebel vessel Nashville, from the pen of an officer who says that "like many others," he was "induced to pay a visit to these vessels, and ascertain the nature of their equipment, general appearance and discipline, if for no other reason than a desire to know the sort of vessels this country would be likely to have to contend with in the event of war with America." With respect to the rebel steamer he has has but little to say, and prefaces that little by observing that "she is not worthy to be called a vessel-of-war." This may account for the contemptuous brevity of his description, which is as follows: "She was improvised by the Southerners by taking her from commercial pursuits, and armed with a couple of useless guns, manned and sent to sea as a privateer. Her hull is well formed for speed, but her deck being encumbered with an elaborate series of wooden erections, looking like so many gigantic hencoops, but called hurricane houses, very materially diminishes her utility as a vessel-of-war."

abstract: George P. Naylor et al. vs. Francis A. Hoffman et al, The plaintiffs, a mercantile firm in this city, commenced an action against the defendants, who were bankders in the City of Chicago, by issuing...
lead_paragraph: George P. Naylor et al. vs. Francis A. Hoffman et al, The plaintiffs, a mercantile firm in this city, commenced an action against the defendants, who were bankders in the City of Chicago, by issuing a summons and filing a complaint for money collected by them as agents of the plaintiffs, and not paid over. The defendants being non-residents, an attachment was issued against their property here. One of the defendants, being found within the jurisdiction of the Court, was served with the summons and complaint. No attempt was made to serve the defendant Hoffman, or to compel his appearance.

abstract: LAUGHING GAS EXHIBITION IN AID OF THE FIVE POINTS HOUSE OF INDUSTRY, Nothing daunted by Boreas with his terrific aids of sleet and snow, the tried friends of the Five Points Mission proved themselves other than fair-weather friends, and crowded ...
lead_paragraph: LAUGHING GAS EXHIBITION IN AID OF THE FIVE POINTS HOUSE OF INDUSTRY. -- Nothing daunted by Boreas with his terrific aids of sleet and snow, the tried friends of the Five Points Mission proved themselves other than fair-weather friends, and crowded Cooper Union main hall last night, to witness the scientific as well as ludicrous developments, produced by the action of laughing or nitrous oxide gas upon the human brain. One hundred and twenty-five children occupied the platform, or rather each side of it, while the centre was fenced about and left vacant for the inhalers of the gas. First the children sang sacred and patriotic songs, then Dr. COLTON came forward and stated that, as we all were aware, there was a time appointed to be serious, also one to laugh and dance; this was the moment for the latter, and although he had prepared the gas, he scarcely thought its agency would be required to make people laugh to-night, after the joyous news of the day. Great applause hailed this allusion, which was joined in by the youthful denizens of the Five Points to such a hilarious extent as to call for demonstrations of rebuke from their guardians, although they themselves could scarcely keep their faces straight long enough to scold. The exhibition was a perfect success, and netted a handsome sum which, after the deduction of the necessary expenses, will be appropriated as above stated. So popular have these innocent exhibitions become that Dr. COLTON is in demand among our amusement-lovers, who desire not alone their own satisfaction, but the advancement of some good cause, and he has consented to the proposition of one such for next Wednesday week, in the same hall. The proceeds are to go to the increase of the fund established for sending children to homes in the West. Due notice of it will appear in the City Press. It will also be seen that Dr. COLTON will give one of these agreeable entertainments to-morrow afternoon for ladies only.

abstract: editorial on rumor
snippet: editorial on rumor
lead_paragraph: These principles,"says NAPOLEON, "He at the basis of the science of War to keep our forces united, to leave no weak point unguarded, and to seize with rapidity on important points." These fundamental maxims, which gave victory to such great Generals as ALEXANDER, HANNIBAL and CAESAR in ancient Europe, and GUSTAVUS ADOLPHUS, TURENNE and FREDERIC the Great, in a less remote age, are receiving new illustrations in the glorious achievements with which Gen. MCCLELLAN's campaign is so auspiciously opening. Here lies one great difference between our strategy and that of the insurgents. The latter have never exhibited any masterly combinations, followed up a single victory, or reaped the smallest advantage from success, but our reverses have served only to develop our strength, reveal our defects, and improve our discipline, while our triumphs have invariably led to others more decisive and commanding. In view of these facts it is only simple justice to our military and naval forces, with their gallant leaders, to say that their bravery has won from their grateful country an admiration near akin to that accorded to the genius of WASHINGTON and to the exploits of his companions in arms.

abstract: Pennington, William; former NJ Gov. and US Congressman
snippet: Pennington, William; former NJ Gov. and US Congressman
lead_paragraph: Hon. WM. PENNINGTON, of New Jersey, died at his residence, in Newark, on Saturday evening last. Mr. PENNINGTON was in the 66th year of his age. In 1837 he was elected Governor of New-Jersey, and for seven successive terms of one year each he was reelected. President TAYLOR appointed him Governor of Minnesota, and the Senate confirmed him, but Mr. PENNINGTON declined the position, and subsequently was appointed by President FILLMORE one of the Judges to settle claims under the Mexican treaty. A union of the Republicans and Conservatives elected him to Congress in 1858, from a District which had previously been largely Democratic, and on Feb. 1, 1800, he was chosen Speaker of the House, after one of the bitterest contests on record. In 1861, Mr. PENNINGTON was renominated for Congress, but local causes contributed to his defeat, after a very close canvas, in which he ran largely ahead of his ticket.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, various petitions were presented among them one asking that the full gank of Major-General be conferred upon Gen. WOOL, Mr. LATHAM reported his bill authorizing.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, various petitions were presented -- among them one asking that the full gank of Major-General be conferred upon Gen. WOOL, Mr. LATHAM reported his bill authorizing a survey with a view to constructing a telegraph line across Behring's Straits. The joint resolution relative to the payment of the Oregon and Washington war debt, settling the method of paying the awards, was passed. A dispatch received by Gen. MCCLELLAN announcing the surrender of Fort Donelson, was read, and caused the greatest excitement and rejoicing -- the floor and galleries joining indiscriminately and unchecked in the applause. The bill to change and regulate the Circuit and District Courts in the Northern District of New-York, was passed. The bill to provide for the better organization of the cavalry forces of the United States was taken up, and debated until the Senate went into Executive Session. During the debate, Mr. JOHNSON, of Tennessee, obtained leave to offer a joint resolution thanking the army and navy for their heroic gallantry, as exhibited in recent battles, which was passed.

abstract: Gen. JOHNSTON, who was captured at the fall of Fort Donelson, and is now in our hands as a prisoner of war, is one of the five "Generals" of the rebel ...
lead_paragraph: Gen. JOHNSTON, who was captured at the fall of Fort Donelson, and is now in our hands as a prisoner of war, is one of the five "Generals" of the rebel army. The other four being BEAUREGARD, LEE, COOPER and J.G. JOHNSTON. He was in chief command of the rebel Department of Kentucky, to which he was appointed as the successor of BUCKNER, four months ago. He is considered by military men the ablest General in the rebel service.

abstract: The indefinite news in the morning papers of yesterday, as to the operations of our troops at Fort Donelson, caused great anxiety among all classes, they had not forgotten the ever-to-be-remembered 21st of July; but when the semi-official announcement was made about in on that the Union troops had really gained a great victory over the rebels, it [???] the whole people. The good news seemed to have been communicated simultaneously throughout the city, and great was the rejoicing thereat. The Stars and Stripes were displayed upon private and public buildings, and on the shipping at the docks, and the ferry-boats traversing the East River.

abstract: Gen. GRANT was right in his announcement, made to Gen. HALLECK on Saturday evening, that he would have possession of Fort Donelson on Sunday. At 9 o'clock on the morning of that day the fort surrendered, and thus came into our possession fifteen thousand prisoners, including Gens.
lead_paragraph: Gen. GRANT was right in his announcement, made to Gen. HALLECK on Saturday evening, that he would have possession of Fort Donelson on Sunday. At 9 o'clock on the morning of that day the fort surrendered, and thus came into our possession fifteen thousand prisoners, including Gens. JOHNSTON and BUCKNER -- and some reports say also Gen. PILLOW -- together with an immense amount of war material and trophies. FLOYD, the Thief, true to his instincts' succeeded in stealing away on Saturday night, taking with him some five thousand men. The entire rebel force in the position is stated as high as thirty thousand, but this is, perhaps, an exaggeration. The loss of life is necessarily very heavy on both sides, but on ours it is especially so. The news of this great success of the Union arms was received everywhere in the North with the most enthusiastic demonstrations of rejoicing. In St. Louis, Gen. HALLECK's headquarters was visited by a joyous crowd, who, by repeated cheers, called him to a window, when he made them the following brief but significant speech:

abstract: The patient and confiding endurance of the people through those long, dark months, when victories were planned, but not won, is gen- ...
lead_paragraph: The patient and confiding endurance of the people through those long, dark months, when victories were planned, but not won, is generously rewarded. After the calamity at Bull Run, the imputation of incapacity and cowardice which the world was ready to fling upon the loyalists of the North, was so insufferable, as to excite a popular craving, amounting to a passion, to rush upon the enemy and disprove the charge of paltroonery by achievements of reckless hardihood. The leaders of the army wisely declined to yield to this insane pressure. They saw the necessity of adding to bravery discipline, unity, steadiness; of preparing the entire long line of the projected advance, so that its movement might be nearly as possible simultaneous; of familiarizing the men in some degree to the smaller encounters of the field, so that when the pitched battle or the assault might require an exhibition of nerve and resolution, there should be less danger of panic, terrors and reckless flights. The military authorities simply realized the want of an army, but understood that the material out of which a victorious army might be made was in their hands, if time were only given for manipulation and education.

abstract: Gen. BUCKNER, the second prisoner in rank captured at Fort Donelson, is a Brigadier-General in the rebel army, and for some months was in chief command in the rebel Western Department.
lead_paragraph: Gen. BUCKNER, the second prisoner in rank captured at Fort Donelson, is a Brigadier-General in the rebel army, and for some months was in chief command in the rebel Western Department. He is a native of Kentucky, a graduate of West Point and is now 38 years of age. In 1841, he was appointed, by brevet, Second Lieutenant in the Second Infantry, and next year he was Acting Assistant-Professor of Ethics at West Point. In 1846, he was transferred to the Sixth Infantry, in which he went to Mexico, and was breveted Fast Lieutenant for gallant conduct at Contreras and Cherubusco, at which latter battle he was wounded. He was subsequently breveted Captain for gallant conduct at Molino del Rey. In 1847 he was Regimental Quartermaster, subsequently Assistant Instructor in Infantry Tactics, and in 1852, Commissary of Subsistence, with the rank of captain. When the secession movement began, he too's an active but secret part with them, and as commander of the Kentucky State Guard, be exercised a powerful influence on the fighting element of his native State. Last Summer he visited Washington, represented himself there as loyal, ingratiated himself into Gen. SCOTT's confidence, obtained permission to inspect all the fortifications in that vicinity, made Hon. ROBERT MALLORY and others believe that he wished to take active service in the army of the United States, returned to Louisville, and remained for a brief period, without giving public indication that he contemplated any disloyal movement, but all this time was holding conference with JEFF. DAVIS and the conspirators. Subsequently he managed to seduce a large part of the State Guard into the rebel service, and for this was appointed to command at Bowling Green. He is an adroit, skillful, bad man. The days of his active treason, however, are now ended.

abstract: It is well for us that the tidings respecting the capture of Savannah are confined to the brief announcement of the fact; for such an accumulation of victorious bulletins as we daily publish exercises a ...
lead_paragraph: It is well for us that the tidings respecting the capture of Savannah are confined to the brief announcement of the fact; for such an accumulation of victorious bulletins as we daily publish exercises a bewildering effect on the mind. While the imagination is to-day to take in the full import of the Western successes, that have driven a wedge through the heart of the rebellion, the announcement comes of a simultaneous blow struck at it from the flank, resulting in the probable capture of one of the chief cities of the Southern coast. The report of the attack on Savannah comes to us through a rebel source, and this circumstance, joined to the fact that the movement has been wholly unheralded, may excite doubts of its authenticity. We have, however, confirmations from private sources that quite bear out the rumor; and, indeed, it has been very evident from the recent stir down at Port Royal, and the silence imposed on all correspondents there, that Gens. DUPONT and SHERMAN were meditating a blow that meant something. It now appears to have meant nothing less than Savannah. Further details of this most important movement will, of course, be awaited with an intense interest.

abstract: The glorious news of the capture of Fort Donelson caused the greatest enthusiasm with the employes at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, yesterday, and was the theme of conversation during the whole of the day.
lead_paragraph: The glorious news of the capture of Fort Donelson caused the greatest enthusiasm with the employes at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, yesterday, and was the theme of conversation during the whole of the day. The troops on Governor's Island also expressed their delight at the surrender of the fort, but more especially at the capture of the rebel Generals. They are looking forward to the arrival of the Roanoke prisoners, some of whom are expected to be quartered in Castle William, though nothing positive is known as to their disposition.

abstract: The croakers were in their element when the first news from BURNSIDE'S expedition reached us. The difficulties and disasters which delayed its progress were to their minds sure tokens that nothing but failure ...
lead_paragraph: The croakers were in their element when the first news from BURNSIDE'S expedition reached us. The difficulties and disasters which delayed its progress were to their minds sure tokens that nothing but failure was to await it. The rebels, having had time to prepare for its coming, would be in such force everywhere that there could be no success for us, except by some lucky accident. It is well for the country that such was not the tone of Gen. BURNSIDE's mind. Our correspondent has spoken of the hopeful, trustful tone of his conversation, and his whole manner of carrying himself. There can be no doubt that such a disposition, determined to do everything which lies in one's power to be done, and then relying upon Divine Providence for the rest, is just the one to accomplish the greatest results.

abstract: nouncing the fugitive FLOYD in that elegant and forcible language for which slaveholders have made the country famous, as "a black-hearted coward and traitor." They are unreasonable and hard to please. FLOYD only acted after his kind. He was bound to steal something, and so he stole himself away. They should remember Dogberry's advice in the promises and practice on it. "The most peaceble way for you, if you do take a thief, is to let him show himself what he is, and steal out of your company." But though this may be the most peaceable way for rebels, it is not counsel for loyal officers. They must remember that they are to comprehend all vagrum men, particularly FLOYD.

abstract: NIBLO'S SALOON.--Mr. GOTTSCHALK'S fourth concert was attended on Monday night, by one of the most crowded audiences the American pianist has yet attracted to his entertainments. Mr. GOTTSCHALK introduced a few novelties;--a Grand Polka de Concert, by HARRY SANDERSON, played by the composer, and embroidered by Mr. GOTTSCHALK.
lead_paragraph: NIBLO's SALOON. -- Mr. GOTTSCHALK's fourth concert was attended on Monday night, by one of the most crowded audiences the American pianist has yet attracted to his entertainments. Mr. GOTTSCHALK introduced a few novelties; -- a Grand Polka de Concert, by HARRY SANDERSON, played by the composer, and embroidered by Mr. GOTTSCHALK. It is a lively and graceful morceau. Subsequently Mr. GOTTSCHALK played a quatuor of pieces, all in his best style, and filled with sentiment and clear poetic purpose. They were "Reflets du Passe;" "Jeunesse;" (a Mazurka played frequently by SATTER,) "Murmures AEoliene," and "Pastorella e Cavalliere."

abstract: The resolution of France to place an Austrian Archduke upon a Mexican throne appears to be earnest, and, so far as the consent of the favored candidate is concerned, is likely to be successful. Our latest advices from Europe attest the willingness of the Court of Vienna to see MAXIMILIAN promoted...
lead_paragraph: The resolution of France to place an Austrian Archduke upon a Mexican throne appears to be earnest, and, so far as the consent of the favored candidate is concerned, is likely to be successful. Our latest advices from Europe attest the willingness of the Court of Vienna to see MAXIMILIAN promoted from the Venetian vice-royalty to the imperial purple and succession longo intervallo of ITURBIDE. There was attached, however, to the bargain, a condition which Austria is less eager to accept. In exchange for a trans-atlantic crown poised upon cis-atlantic bayonets, Venice was to be given up to Italy. The German frontier was to retreat to the Alps. The menace of an Austrian army on the Po was to be removed, in order that a French army on the Tiber might go home. But these arrangements are not in harmony with the Viennese policy; and if the Archduke MAX can on no other terms reign in the halls of the Montezumas, he must, it is popularly supposed, be satisfied with a coronet and forego the crown.

abstract: To accept offer of throne of Mexico; Austrian Archduke Maximilian to accept offer of throne of Mexico
snippet: To accept offer of throne of Mexico; Austrian Archduke Maximilian to accept offer of throne of Mexico
lead_paragraph: The idea of creating a royal throne in favor of the Archduke MAXIMILIAN is of less recent date than may be generally supposed. Even before making preparations for the Mexican Expedition, the Cabinet of the Tuileries sounded the intentions of the Court of Vienna as to the eventual reception which the offer of the throne of Mexico to an Austrian Prince might be likely to meet with. The Cabinet of Vienna did not show itself very eager to close with the offer, although great care was taken at first to say nothing about equivalents. is only within the last few weeks that it has been shadowed forth in a very delicate manner. The idea of a connexity between the trans-oceanic extension of the Austrian power and the excision of some of its possessions in Europe. It will be readily understood that this confirmation of suspicions previously entertained was ill calculated to remove the objections at Vienna, and the offer made to the Archduke MAXIMILIAN continued to be looked upon very coldly. The idea then arose of finding some further compensation for Austria in Europe. It was believed, on good grounds, that Turkey would not be altogether intractable, if a good pecuniary indemnity and other advantages were offered against the cession of Herzegovine, as a measure conducive to the peace of Europe. There was certainly a chance at one time that this combination would have had a chance of success at Vienna. But the latest news loads to the supposition that great difficulties are in the way. The Cabinet of St. Petersburgh, which so seriously took to heart the little affair of Suttorina, would never consent to such important territorial changes on the Lower Danube; and it does not appear that Paris and Vienna have made up their minds to go against Russia. We may add, as latest news, that, according to a dispatch just received from Vienna, the Archduke Maximilian's Privy Councilor, M. Scherzenlechner, has just started for Mexico.

lead_paragraph: By the arrival at this port of the screw-steamship Edinburgh, we have advices from Europe two days later than were received by the Asia. The rebel steamer Nashville left Southampton on the 3d inst. She passed the gunboat Tuscarora off Cowes, where the latter was anchored. The Tuscarora steamed up to start in chase of the Nashville, but the frigate Shannon was alongside to prevent her departure for twenty-four hours. The last seen of the Nashville was that she was steaming down the channel with all speed.

abstract: Editorial holds majority of Southern people not guilty of rebellion; editorial queries rumor
snippet: Editorial holds majority of Southern people not guilty of rebellion; editorial queries rumor
lead_paragraph: We do not now confound in thought, and we shall not hereafter confound in action, the mass of the people of the South, who have formed the body of the rebellion, with the rebel chiefs, civil and military, who have been its brain and hand. Not that the former have not been weak, and wicked, and guilty. Weak, in becoming the victims of specious political sophisms; wicked, in allowing those sophisms to be carried into effect in secession; and guilty -- trebly guilty -- in madly lifting up their hands in parricidal war against the best and most beneficent Government man ever formed.

abstract: -- Somepainful and distorted rumors having gained currency -- to the effect that Gov. PENNINGTON's death was caused by poison -- it is proper to explain what was at first intended not to mention. During his last moments, sulphate of quinine was prescribed in frequent doses. It was sent for, but the effect was so contrary to what was intended, that inquiries were immediately made at the druggist's (BADGER's,) resulting in a frank confession by the clerk, that he had, through mistake, substituted morphine for quinine! Of course efforts were made to counteract the effect, but they were all unavailing; and the careless misfortune is deemed only to have hastened but not produced the fatal result, which the physicians believe would have speedily occurred at any rate. It was to this cause that the profound and insensible stupor into which he was thrown was due, and the incident should serve as a fearful warning to druggists in their delicate duty of preparing prescriptions. It is needless to add that the clerk is greatly distressed by his thoughtless blunder, and is probably at this moment suffering as severe a punishment from his own conscience, as any one could wish him to endure. -- Newark Advertiser, Feb. 18.

abstract: There is reason to believe that attempts will shortly be made to connect England and America once more by the electric telegraph, and this time with greater increased prospects of permanent success. Recent occurrences have impressed the Governments of England and of the United States with the enormous importance of such a means of communication, and the President and Government of the...
lead_paragraph: There is reason to believe that attempts will shortly be made to connect England and America once more by the electric telegraph, and this time with greater increased prospects of permanent success. Recent occurrences have impressed the Governments of England and of the United States with the enormous importance of such a means of communication, and the President and Government of the United States have decided on giving every support in their power to any well-considered project of that kind. The Government of the United States have in a liberal manner offered to subscribe one-half of the sum which would be required for making the cable, and give the use of vessels of their navy in assisting to lay it, provided the British Government will grant the remaining portion of the sum. Mr. CYRUS FIELD, who took so active a part in reference to the former, Atlantic telegraph, has, we are informed, undertaken a mission to this country, for the purpose of inducing the British Government to act in a spirit of equal liberality, and cooperating with this friendly offer on the part of the United States. As further evidence of the friendly spirit which has actuated this offer, the Government of the United States are perfectly content that the telegraph should have its terminus on British territory, as that will afford the nearest point of communication with England or Ireland. Any arrangements that would be entered into between the two Governments would of course provide for the efficient working and use of the line, and would guarantee its protection by both countries in the event of hostilities. We are at a loss to see upon what grounds our Government can refuse to respond favorably to the offer, which, if not already made, will shortly be submitted to its consideration. The cost of the cable, calculated with the greatest amount of care, and with every improvement, would not be greater than that which was expended on the line from Malta to Alexandria, and which was wholly defrayed by the Government. Our interests with the American continent are not less important than those with India, and even if greater importance were to be attached to our Eastern possessions, it would only render still more necessary a line across the Atlantic, seeing that with the telegraphs which already exist on the American continent, and which now extend to the Pacific coast, it would afford a means of rapid and valuable communication, from the West, with China and our Indian Empire.

abstract: The later and more full dispatches relative to the capture of Fort Donelson, which we publish this morning, add to rather than detract from the immense importance of the victory, especially in a strategic point of view, and considering the great moral force which such a success must necessarily carry with it.
lead_paragraph: The later and more full dispatches relative to the capture of Fort Donelson, which we publish this morning, add to rather than detract from the immense importance of the victory, especially in a strategic point of view, and considering the great moral force which such a success must necessarily carry with it. Our men fought with a bravery which cannot be too highly extolled, and at a disadvantage in point of position which more than overbalanced their superiority of numbers. The nature of the ground, where the most severe fighting took place, was such that hardly more than one regiment could engage the enemy at the same time, and regiment after regiment in turn stood up before the concentrated fire of thousands of the enemy, and only fell back with the expenditure of all their ammunition. SCHWARTZ's battery was captured by the enemy only after all the horses attached to it had been shot, and all the officers in charge of the guns had been killed. It was recaptured again, however, in the most gallant manner, by a bold dash, in which also a portion of the rebel intrenchments were secured. The rebels, on Saturday, fought in one particular direction with the utmost pertinacity, evidently with the purpose to cut their way through the beleaguering forces and escape, but they were happily foiled in their intentions. On Sunday morning, previous to the surrender, an exchange of brief notes took place between Gen. BUCKNER, commanding the rebel forces, and Gen. GRANT. The former proposed a Commission, to fix upon terms of capitulation. Gen. GRANT replied that he could allow no terms but an immediate and unconditional surrender; and BUCKNER, making a virtue of necessity, yielded with bad grace. It is believed that the five thousand rebels who escaped with FLOYD and PILLOW went to Nashville or to Clarksville, intending to make another stand, in conjunction with the forces already there. Commodore FOOTE has, doubtless, ere this, paid his respects to them once more. There is yet no definite announcement of the number of our killed and wounded. The lowest estimate we have seen places the former at three hundred, and the latter at four hundred. Some of the names are given in our dispatches this morning.

abstract: LOSS OF BR. BRIG CHARLES. -- The Br. brig Charles, of Westport, N.S., Capt. Wyman, from Gonaives, St. Domingo, Jan. 20, with a cargo of 200 bags coffee and 150 tons logwood, went ashore on the night of Jan. 24, on French Cay, Bahamas, near the Caicos, and became a total loss. Cargo saved in good order. The first officer and 4 seamen arrived this morning in bark Bonita. The captain remained to take care of the cargo. The vessel was built at Cornwallis in 1854, 128 tons, rated A 2, and was owned by Eaton, of the above place. Cargo insured in New-York.

abstract: Small impertinences often vex us more than great misfortunes, and these miserable Yankee ships that have come into our ports, and go steaming about, have become a nuisance which it is absolutely necessary to abate. There is nothing of the dignity of power about any of them. It is as if two potboys insisted upon fighting out their quarrel in the Royal...
lead_paragraph: Small impertinences often vex us more than great misfortunes, and these miserable Yankee ships that have come into our ports, and go steaming about, have become a nuisance which it is absolutely necessary to abate. There is nothing of the dignity of power about any of them. It is as if two potboys insisted upon fighting out their quarrel in the Royal Exchange, to the derangement of the business of the city. Any one of the quiet British frigates lying about could knock all these quarrelsome craft into splinters, just as any policeman could carry off the two potboys, one under each arm. It is the Tuscarora ant the Nashville to-day -- it may be the Sumter and some other rickety craft with combustibles on board to-morrow. To see the Tuscarora with her fires banked, or her steam up, and her guns run out, lying among the peaceful merchant vessels at Southampton or running in and running out, and making demonstrations of zeal to devour a wretched river steamer, it might be supposed that there were no international police regulations in the world, and that we were not strong enough to protect our own peace and quietness in our own harbors. What the Tuscarora has been doing at Southampton the Sumter has been doing, although less offensively, at Gibraltar, and probably the same game would be played among all our merchant shipping in all our ports, scattered all over the world, if it were not stopped. Earl RUSSELL has issued a letter of instructions to the British Admiralty to put an end to this inconvenience. We printed the letter on Saturday, but it is as well to draw attention to its chief provisions. Now, we cannot drive any ship to sea which comes to us in a dismasted state, nor can we refuse any ship water, or provisions, or coal sufficient to carry her home. These are acts of common hospitality, which must be rendered to every floating thing which is not absolutely a pirate. We must give them what our workhouses give to a tramp -- shelter for the night and food to carry them on. But encouragement or harbor, or license to carry on their cockboat battles in our ports, or to interrupt our business with their little fights, is out of the question. We do not allow our own little boys to disturb the thoroughfares with squibs and crackers on the 5th of November, and why should we submit to be annoyed with the two guns of the Nashville or the "columbiads" of the Tuscarora, eager as these mighty men-of-war may be to make themselves noisy and disagreeable in the neighborhood of Osborne? The rule of International law is plain enough. Every nation has the right, if she likes, of giving hospitality to the ships of war of either or both belligerent Powers, and she may suffer them, or either of them, to bring in their prizes and submit them to her Admiralty Courts. But every nation has also the right to exclude them altogether, unless where such exclusion would be contrary to the general dictates of humanity. Our Government has made its choice, as we think, very wisely, and has excluded both parties. Earl RUSSELL in this State paper measures out equal measure to ships of war and privateers. He excludes both from all British ports for all warlike purposes. If they come into our waters, except in distress, they are to be warned away, and to depart in 24 hours. If they be in distress, they are to go as soon as they have obtained the repairs and supplies necessary to enable them to sail homeward. If any hostile ships or merchantmen that might be made their prey are in the same harbor, they cannot follow them out until 24 hours' "law" has been allowed to the fugitives. All this is old law, which has been already enforced within the French ports without any public declaration such as this now made by our Foreign-office. The comparatively recent appliance of steam to war-ships has made the question of coals a novelty in our international law of neutrals. The obvious idea of supplying a ship of war with only coals sufficient to take her to her nearest home port would not meet the present case, for she would spend these coals in a cruise and come back for more, being again in distress. Earl RUSSELL meets this difficulty by a provision that a ship of war or a privateer shall not obtain coal within the British dominions, even to take her home, more than once in three months.

lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA COLLEGE -- STUDENT's SEMI-ANNUAL. -- The "Student's Semi-Annual" of this venerable institution was held yesterday morning, at Wallack's Theatre. Although the weather appeared quite unsettled, yet long before the hour appointed for the commencement of the exercise -- 11 A.M. -- the building was well filled. At the hour named the Grand Marshal of the day, W.G. LATHROP, Jr., with his eight Aids, made their appearance upon the stage, followed by the Presiding Officer, C. SIGOURNEY KNOX with many of the College's Alumni. Prayer was offered by Rev. Geo. C. PENNELL, after which Mr. KNOX, in a few words, explained the peculiar circumstances under which the present Semi-Annual was held, there being a wrong impression as regards the matter before the public. The trustees, owing to the state of the country and to the almost universal financial condition of our institutions, saw fit to abolish the Semi-Annual. By so doing they deprived the students of an enjoyment looked forward to with emulation and interest. Hence the latter were not willing to relinquish the time-honored custom, and determined to hold a Semi-Annual upon one of the holidays immediately preceding the new term -- with what success, the gay assemblage and the excellent arrangements told.

abstract: Gen. LANE made a short speech in Leavenworth last Wednesday, in relation to matters pertaining to the proposed expedition, in which it is now settled that he will have a part. He intended to go with the expedition; paid a high compliment to the soldierly abilities of Gen. HUNTER, and his qualities as a gentleman. He (LANE) had been elected to the United States Senate for four years, but he would resign that seat. He spoke of the rumors of a quarrel between HUNTER and himself; said there was no quarrel -- there had been none. Outside parties had interfered, and attempted to create a difficulty between them, but had not succeeded.

abstract: The Moniteur, of Feb. 1, publishes a letter from Vera Cruz, stating that the excitement of the Mexicans was beginning to subside. The idea of an arrangement was no longer rejected a priori as treason against the nation. There were serious indications that a party was forming which was disposed to repudiate a Government which has been so fatal to the country. The enlightened inhabitants did not look for war, and the sound-thinking portion of the population demanded the unity of the country under an independent constitutional monarchy. A foreign prince would doubtless rally all sympathies. The allies should take care not to put forth any pretensions on their own account, which, as they would give rise to ideas of conquest, could not fail to wound the national self-respect.

abstract: Petition of the Trustees of the New-York Protestant Episcopal Public School.--In 1786 Dr. John Boker, by his will, left a valuable estate in the Nine teenth Ward of this City, in trust to Trinity Church for the purpose of establishing a "Charity School," at which it was proposed to educate, support and maintain such children as should be admitted...
lead_paragraph: Petition of the Trustees of the New-York Protestant Episcopal Public School. -- In 1786 Dr. John Boker, by his will, left a valuable estate in the Nine teenth Ward of this City, in trust to Trinity Church for the purpose of establishing a "Charity School," at which it was proposed to educate, support and maintain such children as should be admitted as pupils. At the expiration of the life estates in the property, the Governor of the State was authorized by the will of the testator to collect the rents, &c., of such property, and apply such collections to the uses mentioned.

McCLELLAN, with the ex offico rank of Colonel. lead_paragraph: An artillery reserve, numbering about 650 men, has been formed at Camp Duncan, Capitol Hill, Washington, under the command of Major HUNT, of the Sixth Cavalry, Aid-de-Camp to Gen. McCLELLAN, with the ex offico rank of Colonel. The companies forming this reserve are the following: First Artillery, Companies E and G; Second Artillery, B and L; Third Artillery, F and K; Fourth Artillery, G. There are several vacancies in these companies, and any old soldier has a fine chance of being made a noncommissioned officer at once. Company G, of the First Artillery, is a light company, 115 strong at present, with room for 40 more recruits. The battery of this company is six 24-pound brass howitzers.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, Mr. HARRIS, of NewYork, introduced his bill, given in our Washington dispatches a few days ago, declaring the forfeiture of the rights and privileges of certain persons under the Constitution of the United States. It was referred, and ordered to be printed.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, Mr. HARRIS, of NewYork, introduced his bill, given in our Washington dispatches a few days ago, declaring the forfeiture of the rights and privileges of certain persons under the Constitution of the United States. It was referred, and ordered to be printed. The joint resolution relative to compensating certain railroads in Missouri, was returned to the House, at its request. The Committee on the District of Columbia was directed to inquire into the judicial management of the jail in the City of Washington. The joint resolution from the House, directing the Commissioners of Public Buildings to illuminate them all on the 22d of February, in honor of the recent victories, was passed. The case of Mr. STARKE, of Oregon, was then taken up, and debated at considerable length, the question being on referring the matter back to the Judiciary Committee. Pending the question, the Senate adjourned.

abstract: JOSEPH ANTONIE VIGNIER DE MONTEIL, late Lieutenant-Colonel of the Fifty-third Regiment NewYork State Volunteers, was born at Toulon, Department of the Var, (France,) in 1818. His father was a distinguished officer of artillery. The son entered the French army at the age of sixteen. By his industry and good conduct he rose from the ranks to a First...
lead_paragraph: JOSEPH ANTONIE VIGNIER DE MONTEIL, late Lieutenant-Colonel of the Fifty-third Regiment NewYork State Volunteers, was born at Toulon, Department of the Var, (France,) in 1818. His father was a distinguished officer of artillery. The son entered the French army at the age of sixteen. By his industry and good conduct he rose from the ranks to a First Lieutenancy in the artillery. An ardent Republican, he was thrown into prison after the coup d'tat, but made his escape and went to England, where he remained a short time. In 1853 he came to this country, and, until the breaking out of the rebellion, supported himself by teaching mathematics and the French language. For three years, in one of the largest private schools in this City, he did his duty in the most thorough and conscientious manner. He took the most lively interest in the advancement of his pupils, shrinking from no labor or drudgery which might in any way contribute to their improvement. He has been known repeatedly to sit up half the night, correcting and recorrecting, with his own hand, their exercises -- paying equal attention to the work of the boy of eight and the youth of eighteen years. His guiding principle was the faithful performance of his duty, and all his conduct showed him to be a most honorable and reliable gentleman. When the rebellion broke out, his old military enthusiasm was rekindled, and he immediately offered his services to the Government. He received the Lieutenant-Colonelcy of the Fifty-third New-York State Volunteers, commonly known as the D'Epineul Zouaves.

abstract: The husband and wife who were found dead on Monday at their house in One Hundred and Nineteenth-street, Harlem, proved to have died from excessive drinking. His name was PATRICK MCCARTY, and the name of the woman was MARY. They were both natives of Ireland, each about 50 years of age. From the testimony elicited by Coroner COLLIN, at an inquest held upon the bodies, it appeared that a son of the deceased is in the army. A week since, he sent them $10, which they spent in drink, and since that time neither of them had seen a sober moment. The neighbors found them on Monday, dead in their room. The woman was in bed and the man was lying upon the floor, with a stone jug containing some bad whisky beside him. Dr. ROBINSON, Coroner COLLIN's deputy, made a post-mortem examination of the bodies, and found that in each case death had resulted from suffocation. The deceased had drunk themselves into such a state of physical exhaustion that when they fell down upon their faces they literally had not strength enough to turn over and breathe.

abstract: Our citizens were startled this morning by the announcement that Col. SAMUEL PRUYN was dead. The announcement came with paralyzing suddenness to those who met him, in his usual robust health and spirits, last evening--rejoicing with his fellow-citizens over the good news brought to us from the seat of war. No man was happier, or seemed more likely to pass on healthfully into a green old age.

abstract: We print, in another column, a very clear and interesting letter of Hon. GEORGE BANCROFT, to the President of the New-York Historical Society, on the subject of the exchange of prisoners during the Revolution. It comes a little late, as we have some time ago reached the conclusion at which Mr. BANCROFT...
lead_paragraph: We print, in another column, a very clear and interesting letter of Hon. GEORGE BANCROFT, to the President of the New-York Historical Society, on the subject of the exchange of prisoners during the Revolution. It comes a little late, as we have some time ago reached the conclusion at which Mr. BANCROFT arrives; but there has been no statement of the historical aspects of the question so compact and so conclusive as that here presented by the distinguished historian of the United States. The dispatch of Lord GERMAIN to Gen. HOWE, especially, is of extreme importance, as having been the basis on which all the exchanges of prisoners during the Revolution were effected. It is also an interesting parallel to the decision recently adopted by our Government, with reference to the rebel privateersmen, that the sailors taken on board of American privateers during the Revolution were, as is shown by this dispatch, put on precisely the same footing as soldiers. The fact will probably be new even to our learned and laborious Secretary of State.

abstract: In this Court yesterday, before Recorder HOFFMAN, Jas. J. Wall was placed on trial for the murder of Owen Phelan, at Harlem on the 31st of December last. At the time of the homicide the prisoner was a clerk on the steamboat Sylvan Shore, and on the night in question he met the deceased at a drinking saloon called the Alhambra, when a quarrel ensued between them, and after they left the saloon Phelan knocked the prisoner down, who immediately drew a pistol and shot the deceased, inflicting a wound from which he died three days after. There was no evidence as to the cause of the quarrel, but the facts above stated were corroborated by the dying declarations of the deceased. The testimony for the prosecution was closed, and the Court adjourned to this morning. The defence admit the killing, but claim that it was justifiable homicide.
lead_paragraph: In this Court yesterday, before Recorder HOFFMAN, Jas. J. Wall was placed on trial for the murder of Owen Phelan, at Harlem on the 31st of December last. At the time of the homicide the prisoner was a clerk on the steamboat Sylvan Shore, and on the night in question he met the deceased at a drinking saloon called the Alhambra, when a quarrel ensued between them, and after they left the saloon Phelan knocked the prisoner down, who immediately drew a pistol and shot the deceased, inflicting a wound from which he died three days after. There was no evidence as to the cause of the quarrel, but the facts above stated were corroborated by the dying declarations of the deceased. The testimony for the prosecution was closed, and the Court adjourned to this morning. The defence admit the killing, but claim that it was justifiable homicide.

abstract: Observations on Civil War and on settlement of Trent Affair; J S Mill observations on war
snippet: Observations on Civil War and on settlement of Trent Affair; J S Mill observations on war
lead_paragraph: The cloud which for the space of a month hung gloomily over the civilized world, black with far worse evils than those of simple war, has passed from over our heads without bursting, The fear has not been realized, that the only two first-rate Powers who are also free nations would take to tearing each other in pieces, both the one and the other, in a bad and odious cause. For while, on the American side the war would have been one of reckless persistency in wrong, on ours it would have been a war in alliance, and, to practical purposes, in defence and propagation of Slavery. We had, indeed, been wronged. We had suffered an indignity, and something more than an indignity, which, not to have resented, would have been to invite a constant succession of insults and injuries from the same and from every other quarters. We could have acted no otherwise than we have done; yet it is impossible to think, without something like a shudder, from what we have escaped. We, the emancipators of the slave -- who have wearied every Court and Government in Europe and America with our protests and remonstrances, until we goaded them into at least ostensibly cooperating with us to prevent the enslaving of the negro -- we, who for the last half century have spent annual sums equal to the revenue of a small Kingdom, in blockading the African coast, for a cause in which we not only had no interest, but which was contrary to our pecuniary interest, and which many believed would ruin, as many among us still, though erroneously, believe that it has ruined, our colonies -- we should have lent a hand to setting up, in one of the most commanding positions of the world, a powerful Republic, devoted not only to Slavery, but to Pro-Slavery propagandism -- should have helped to give a place in the community of nations to a conspiracy of slave-owners, who have broken their connection with the American Federation on the sole ground, ostentatiously proclaimed, that they thought an attempt would be made to restrain, not Slavery itself, but their purpose of spreading Slavery wherever migration or force could carry it.

abstract: There is palpable confusion about the rumored taking of Savannah. The original announcement came from rebel sources, through Norfolk, and was generally credited, though the indorsement of some loyal testimony was felt to be desirable. This testimony was yesterday furnished by a Philadelphia cotemporary,...
lead_paragraph: There is palpable confusion about the rumored taking of Savannah. The original announcement came from rebel sources, through Norfolk, and was generally credited, though the indorsement of some loyal testimony was felt to be desirable. This testimony was yesterday furnished by a Philadelphia cotemporary, noted for great enterprises and therefore notably exposed to error, who asserted that dispatches from Commodore DUPONT, giving the tidings, had reached the Navy Department. No such dispatches have, however, been received. The statement rests solely on Southern rumor, and its inherent probability.

abstract: editorial on bill changes made by House and Senate; editorial on bill changes made by House and Senate
snippet: editorial on bill changes made by House and Senate; editorial on bill changes made by House and Senate
lead_paragraph: The probable disagreement of the House to one or two of the Senate amendments to this bill is said to have been seized upon by the original opponents of the whole measure as the means of finally defeating it altogether between the two Houses. No such result is probable, but as the favorable turn in the war is used as a pretext to induce the opinion that the Secretary can get along with plain United States notes without the legal tender, it is well enough to say that the bank opposition to these notes, as a currency, would be infinitely greater, because it could be made more effective in this shape than as a legal tender. To strike out the latter, therefore, if a proceeding so irregular, after the clause has been contested and passed upon by both Houses, be admissible, would be simply to destroy the vitality of the bill.

abstract: when told by Gen. GRANT that no terms but absolute and immediate surrender would be accepted, replied that, "notwithstanding the brilliant success of the Confederate arms," he was obliged to " accept the ungenerous and...
lead_paragraph: when told by Gen. GRANT that no terms but absolute and immediate surrender would be accepted, replied that, "notwithstanding the brilliant success of the Confederate arms," he was obliged to " accept the ungenerous and unchivalrous terms" which were proposed. We are ready to make all reasonable allowance for a man who two days before had boasted of the impregnability of his position, and who found himself suffering severe punishment and disastrous defeat; but we must say that this reply of Gen. BUCKNER's was one of the silliest sentences ever written. Why, the absolute and immediate surrender of that post, and the punishment of those who held it, was the very object of the expedition under Gen. GRANT's command. It was to attain that end that he planned, and that the brave fellows with him fought, and bled, and died. And when by skill, courage, endurance, suffering and death their prize was within their grasp, what absurdity to expect that they would forego one jot or tittle of it!

abstract: The latest number of Fraser's Magazine contains a very able and carefully considered article of Mr. JOHN STUART MILL on affairs in the United States. The writer is an uncompromising logician, and, by long intellectual training, has cleared his mind of many prejudices, national...
lead_paragraph: -- The latest number of Fraser's Magazine contains a very able and carefully considered article of Mr. JOHN STUART MILL on affairs in the United States. The writer is an uncompromising logician, and, by long intellectual training, has cleared his mind of many prejudices, national and social, which almost uniformly warp the judgment of Englishmen. An aversion for our universal suffrage and the ballot are the only peculiarities to which we can take exception. Our whole situation, as well in its domestic as in its foreign relations, is treated by Mr. MILL fairly and sensibly; and his conclusions are not such as can please the London Times or the Saturday Review. His verdict is for the cause of the North. He appreciates the necessity of the struggle in which we are involved. He recognizes the spirit of humanity, justice, and moderation which have characterized the conduct of our Government. So much of this admirable paper as refers to the impolicy of intervention, and the creditable attitude of Mr. SEWARD and the American people in regard to the Trent affair, we extract in another column, where it will be read with interest.

abstract: The early telegraphic dispatches of Monday in regard to the noted prisoners captured in Fort Donelson were at fault. JOHNSTON, PILLOW, BUCKNER and FLOYD were all named among the Generals who surrendered. Of these BUCKNER only was actually present to give up his sword to Gen. GRANT.
lead_paragraph: The early telegraphic dispatches of Monday in regard to the noted prisoners captured in Fort Donelson were at fault. JOHNSTON, PILLOW, BUCKNER and FLOYD were all named among the Generals who surrendered. Of these BUCKNER only was actually present to give up his sword to Gen. GRANT. The lateness of the hour at which the correspondence between this officer and the National commander was received by telegraph prevented a correction of the mistake as to Gen. ALBERT SYDNEY JOHNSTON. Had he been present, he would have ranked BUCKNER, and, of course, conducted the negotiation for surrender. But the fact seems to be that he was, at no time during the investment of the rebel army, in or very near Fort Donelson. Gen. PILLOW would also have ranked BUCKNER, but he took himself off during the night of Saturday, and with his staff and certain favorites accompanied FLOYD in the direction of Clarksville and Nashville. The demoralized force that under these two valiant leaders, made their escape on that night, is reckoned at five thousand. There is scarcely a doubt that the number would have been doubled, nay, that the whole army would have precipitately evacuated under cover of the night, had the means of transportation been at hand to justify the attempt, without the hazard of early pursuit and inglorious capture. But the number and capacity of the steamboats immediately above Dover were limited, and the railroad four or five miles in the rear, with uncertain means of transportation at command. Hence the sudden change of Senior Commander, to which BUCKNER alludes in one of his notes to GRANT, from PILLOW to himself.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a favorable report was made on the bill to create the New-York County Court-house Stock. A report was made in favor of the repeal of the Church Property bill, passed by the last Legislature, in consequence of a controversy between the Catholic Clergy and the congregation of the St. Louis Church, in Buffalo.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a favorable report was made on the bill to create the New-York County Court-house Stock. A report was made in favor of the repeal of the Church Property bill, passed by the last Legislature, in consequence of a controversy between the Catholic Clergy and the congregation of the St. Louis Church, in Buffalo. A bill to incorporate the Permanent Library Association of New-York for Masonic and kindred works, was introduced. A bill was also introduced to authorize the selection of a site for another State Prison, to be located in Broome, Tioga, Chemung, Steuben, Alleghany or Livingston County. The bill to amend the Revised Statutes relative to judgments in actions for ejectments was passed. The bill to abolish the Concert Saloons was ordered to a third reading. The bill appropriating $250,000 to aid the Albany and Susquehanna Railroad was debated.

abstract: Two recruiting parties were sent out from Governor's Island, on Tuesday afternoon, to recruit for the two companies of the First Infantry and one of the Third which are being reorganized there. One of the parties, under Lieut. MARSTON, First Infantry, has gone to Portland, Me., where the Seventeenth Infantry had two offices open for several months, but had to close them on account of the paucity of recruits.

abstract: The steamship kangaroo, with European advices to the 6th, arrived here yesterday. It brings intelligence of the opening of the British Parliament, and also the Queen's speech on that occasion. The document, as usual, is brief.
lead_paragraph: The steamship kangaroo, with European advices to the 6th, arrived here yesterday. It brings intelligence of the opening of the British Parliament, and also the Queen's speech on that occasion. The document, as usual, is brief. It alludes to the death of Prince ALBERT; declares that Her Majesty's relations with all the European Powers is satisfactory; refers to the difficulties lately threatened with this country, and declares that the friendly relations between Her Majesty and the President are unimpaired; alludes to the Mexican difficulty; speaks of Her Majesty's relations with the Emperor of China and the Sultan of Morocco; and concludes by saying that though there is considerable pressure and privation, the condition of the country is satisfactory.

abstract: The rebellion, as a military fact, is extinet throughout the whole of the great State of Missouri. Gen. PRICE'S army has again fled from before our pursuing columns; and, according to Gen. HALLECK'S dispatch, published this morning, the elder PRICE himself and his ...
lead_paragraph: The rebellion, as a military fact, is extinet throughout the whole of the great State of Missouri. Gen. PRICE's army has again fled from before our pursuing columns; and, according to Gen. HALLECK's dispatch, published this morning, the elder PRICE himself and his Staff, as well as the younger PRICE, his son, have been captured; while other, and later dispatches, announce that the entire Missouri rebel army had been cut up, routed, or taken prisoners. Gen. CURTIS set out from Sedalia, about twenty days ago, to do this work; and, after a Winter march of extraordinary severity and celerity, down through the wild regions of Southwestern Missouri, he has succeeded in achieving the splendid success we chronicle. This capture of the man who organized the rebel army in Missouri, who has led it and upheld it through all its varying fortunes, and to whom it was attached with the greatest devotion, destroys all hope of the rebels achieving any future successes, or making any future forward marches in that State. There are still bands of marauders, each a few hundred strong, scattered here and there, who subsist by plunder, and amuse themselves every now and then by capturing some city of half a dozen log huts; these, in a vast, sparsely populated State like Missouri, may be able to carry on their ravages for some time yet; but the martial-law which now rules the State, is rapidly curtailing their range and reducing their numbers. There is yet much virulent disloyalty in some of the heavy slave counties bordering on the Missouri River, and, indeed, throughout the State; but that is now brought under a rigid moral discipline, before which it is speedily disappearing. With the defeat of all hopes of rebel success, disloyalty, both active and passive, will soon become utterly extinct. A small military force maintained at Springfield, will now uphold the National supremacy in the State, while the bulk of the heavy force under Gen. CURTIS, will at once be set free for operations in Arkansas, or to cooperate, after a march across the latter State, with the forces preparing for action in Southwestern Tennessee. This success also clears the way for the forward march of Gen. HUNTER's frontier column, which will soon now be on the move.

abstract: Observations from Great Britain
snippet: Observations from Great Britain
lead_paragraph: The publication of the "The orders and directions for the observance of neutrality" has not only called forth, as was to be expected, great indignation on the part of Mr. ADAMS, but some difference of opinion among home critics as to the policy and propriety of the course taken by the Foreign Office, for which I was less prepared. There is among us an active and intelligent party of strong sympathizers with the North, who have all along complained that the tone of our Government to the Washington Cabinet has been studiously cold and unfriendly, even if there has been a formal observance of neutrality. This party might be expected to find in Lord RUSSELL's notification a new instance of unfriendliness to the North. But I hear not a few intelligent and well-informed persons, not connected with this party, disposed to doubt the policy, as well as the necessity, of promulgating orders and directions of which the effect will be to close all European ports against both Federal and Confederate ships-of-war. These objectors say that the notification is an innovation; that it introduces new restrictions on the rights to shelter and hospitality of ships-of-war belonging to belligerent Powers with which we are peace. They anticipate that similar orders and directions will be promulgated by France; indeed, one of the most stringent parts of the order -- that which prohibits vessels-of-war from more than twenty-four hours' stay in port -- has already been acted upon by Spain, at Cadiz, in the case of the Sumter. They say that not only are the orders harsh and unfriendly -- which is to be regretted -- but that they would be followed by serious and practically inconvenient consequences if the Federal Government should, as may be expected, issue a similar notification as to our ships-of-war seeking Federal ports.

abstract: Archbishop HUGHES has at last denied the slander of the Herald in regard to a notorious article in the Metropolitan Record. The article, it will be remembered, misrepresented foully the origin and nature of the conflict in which the nation is engaged -- so foully, indeed, that in a cause so defined no honorable man, however patriotic, could strike a blow. It represented the loyal North as ultimately prompted by motives which the Archbishop well knew had no existence. And when to this mischievously meant logic was added a tirade of vulgar falsehood and ridicule, aimed al those who were most loyally aiding the Government, it became obvious that the trash could not emanate from the source to which the Herald with the sanction of the print from which the stuff was taken, persistently ascribed it. The TIMES had no hesitation at the time in branding the imputation as an impudent falsehood. As will be seen in another column, the falsehood now receives a similar brand from Archbishop HUGHES himself.

abstract: The President has satisfied a genuine longing of the heart of the country by selling apart the 22d of February, Saturday next, as a day of jubilee, in commemoration of the late Union victories. The enthusiasm of the people has already sought vent in rejoicings, illuminations, flag displays, firing of cannon, &c., but we needed an opportunity for a united, unanimous celebration. And of all days, that appointed is the fittest -- the birthday of WASHINGTON. Last year the 22d of February was observed as a day of fasting and prayer. Well it might, for we were in a condition sadly needing both. This year it will be consecrated to National rejoicing. Nor is there any appearance that the edge of our joy will have been taken off, for new victories, such as we chronicle to-day, keep it fresh and full. The immortal Shade could not ask a worthier commemoration of the occasion.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, a petition was presented from the Underwriters of this City, against any change in the Pilot laws. The bill for a temporary increase of midshipmen in the Naval Academy was indefinitely postponed; also the resolution tendering the thanks of Congress to ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, a petition was presented from the Underwriters of this City, against any change in the Pilot laws. The bill for a temporary increase of midshipmen in the Naval Academy was indefinitely postponed; also the resolution tendering the thanks of Congress to Capt. WILKES. A joint resolution authorizing the Secretary of War to confer the brevet rank of Lieutenant-General for eminent services was reported from the Military Committee. A petition was presented, from citizens of the State of New-York, asking that the name of South Carolina be expunged from the list of States, and that the Territory be divided between North Carolina and Georgia. The bill in relation to the United States Circuit and District Courts in the Northern District of New-York, was passed. A joint resolution, authorizing the President to present prizes and medals to men serving in the army and navy, who may have distinguished themselves, was adopted. The bill for the better organization of the cavalry was passed. The Senate then went into Executive Session.
