abstract: Editorial on British press views; Editorial on British attitude towards harboring US vessels; editorial on impending execution of Gordon
snippet: Editorial on British press views; Editorial on British attitude towards harboring US vessels; editorial on impending execution of Gordon
lead_paragraph: There is no reason to question a statement in our foreign news, that Mr. ADAMS, our minister, and other American residents in England, are greatly incensed at the action of the British Government in regard to the Nashville and Tuscarora. Neutrality, if it be more than a phrase, means impartiality. The Nashville, three months ago, entered an English port, laden with living witnesses of an atrocity which at once defined its piratical character. It had seized and burned a vessel, which was returning to the United States, after fulfilling the peaceful mission of carrying broad to the famishing workmen of England. The act was so clearly in contradiction of every principle of maritime right, that a Government which has since deplored hypocritically the temporary closing of Charleston harbor as an inexcusable barbarity, had no right to withhold from the violator of international law and civilized usage the just punishment of its crime. On the contrary, the Nashville was received with empressement. There was no suggestion to apply the law which limits the stay of a privateer in a neutral harbor to twenty-four hours. Supplies were furnished it in abundance, and for three months the vessel lay in the Southampton docks, while the pirates who commanded her were the recipients of lavish hospitality in London. It was only when the United States steamer Tuscarora, arriving in chase of the malefactors, anchored in the same waters, that the British authorities began to examine their text books for an excuse under which the frigate of a friendly Power might be refused the entertainment which had been freely afforded a rebel adventurer; and finding no plausible ground for discrimination, resorted to an expedient, which, while it permitted the rebel to escape, and prevented successful pursuit, closed every British port in the world to the navy of a Power with which the Queen has just been made to say, "the friendly relations of her Government are unimpaired." A proclamation was issued, denying the rites of hospitality to all war vessels coming from the United States, in any British harbor. The Nashville, by this ruling, would be obliged to leave her snug quarters, and take the chance at sea of a fight with the Tuscarora; but to save the craft from this encounter, which its officers, had they not been cowards as well as pirates, would not have declined, a British frigate of far superior metal was placed alongside the National steamer, in order to restrain her for a day from following the fugitive. The Nashville is thus dispatched to sea scathless, under British auspices, to resume its work of reckless destruction against the peaceful commerce upon which the people of England and France are dependent for their existence.

abstract: The opinion has often been expressed in these columns, that whatever might be the sentiment of the aristocracy of England, or the dubious policy of its Government, a friendly feeling toward this country is now, as ever, cherished by a large section of its industrial, wealth-producing population. The latest files of English papers confirm this view, and show that prior to the opening of Parliament, numerous public meetings were held, at which resolutions in favor of our Government found enthusiastic and unanimous support in various parts of the kingdom, but especially in the cotton manufacturing counties of the North, where the suffering from the war is the most intense, and the discontent at its continuance has been represented as most bitter and emphatic. Such a wide-spread popular movement cannot but have a wholesome influence on the deliberations of the British Legislature. It is also, on many accounts, gratifying to ourselves. For the progress of enlightened opinion in Europe relative to the prospects, resources and power of our National Government will not only prove a barrier to the policy of intervention, but will infallibly develop a growing sympathy, and cement a closer alliance between this country and the nations identified with us in speech, lineage, religion, laws, and a common civilization. At the same time it will inaugurate more signal triumphs for freedom, commerce and human progress, than could be won by the more brilliant achievements of internecine war. For "a peaceful conquest, our international prejudice and ignorance," it has been well said, is "more real in itself, as well as more beneficent, noble and enduring in its results than the most decisive battle, or the most glorious campaign."
lead_paragraph: The opinion has often been expressed in these columns, that whatever might be the sentiment of the aristocracy of England, or the dubious policy of its Government, a friendly feeling toward this country is now, as ever, cherished by a large section of its industrial, wealth-producing population. abstract: When Italy, inspired by CAVOUR and GARIBALDI, was about to seek liberation from intolerable tyranny and intolerable priestcraft, England declined to aid, because the traditional policy of the Government was adverse to intervention. So, also, in the case of Hungary. But in Mexico, where the people have freed themselves from foreign rule, and have just thrown off the yoke of the priests, England stands ready to intervene, and impose upon the nation a King borrowed from the House of Austria. The London Morning Post announces the concurrence of the British Government in the project of placing the Archduke MAXIMILIAN on a Mexican throne. Why the difference? Because the class which rules England, and proclaims to mankind always noisily, its devotion to "civil and religious" liberty, is in close alliance with Austria, and secretly sympathizes with the intolerance and despotism, of which that monarchy is the traditional type. Hence its contempt and abuse of KOSSUTH; its coldness to the Italians in their struggles for indepence; its readiness to place an offshoot of the HAPSBURGS on a throne, at the cost of a nation's liberties. Such is the prescriptive adherence of England to the doctrine of nonintervention.
lead_paragraph: When Italy, inspired by CAVOUR and GARIBALDI, was about to seek liberation from intolerable tyranny and intolerable priestcraft, England declined to aid, because the traditional policy of the Government was adverse to intervention. abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, bills were introduced to provide for the public defence, and to incorporate the Forty-second-street Railroad Company. Among the bills passed were the ones relative to ceding to the United States jurisdiction over lands
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, bills were introduced to provide for the public defence, and to incorporate the Forty-second-street Railroad Company. Among the bills passed were the ones relative to ceding to the United States jurisdiction over lands for fortification and lighthouse purposes; the one regulating the concert saloons; one to amend the act relative to laying out street and avenues in this City, and one to allow women to insure the lives of their husbands. The bill to stop the sale of swill milk was reported favorably.

abstract: -- NATHANIEL GORDON, the convicted slave-trader, will tomorrow suffer the penalty of the law. The most earnest efforts have been made to avert his fate. The hardship of taking a young man, in the vigor of life, of respectable family, possessing a wife and child, and whose crime may have been the result of circumstances, or of too little reflection, as an example for future criminals in the same walk of guilt, has been pressed upon Mr. LINCOLN, and the utmost eloquence and urgency have been used to obtain a mitigation of the sentence. The highest court of law in the country has been solicited to interpose. But the Executive and Judiciary alike hold that, while compassion is due to the individual, and to those he leaves behind him, there is a debt of long standing due to society, to justice, to public morality, which should at last be paid. The very arguments employed to exculpate GORDON weigh against him. It is that the young, the unreflecting, the well-born and nurtured, and those who have given hostages to fortune, may be warned and terrified from the commission of this infamous crime of man-stealing, that an example is wanted; and with all these conditions the case of GORDON complies. The claims of justice are paramount.

abstract: -- A rumor reaches us, by telegraph from Cairo, that Gov. HARRIS, of Tennessee, has recommended the people to ground their arms as against the National authority. This rumor is perhaps premature, but in substance it is what we may shortly look for, either from HARRIS, or the Legislature, supposed to be now in session at Nashville. It is well known that the rebellion, which HARRIS and his confederates brought about last June, placed the people of the State in a false position toward the Government. It has gone on until it has brought down the strong arm of the National authority upon the very capital of the State. The legions of HALLECK and BUELL are now within striking distance of both Nashville and Clarksville. After the fall of Dover, (Fort Donelson,) there is no competent force left to oppose them.

abstract: To detect and point out a tithe of the malicious misrepresentations and absurb inconsistencies of the leading London newspapers about us and our unhappy war, would be a task equally wearisome and unpleasant.
lead_paragraph: To detect and point out a tithe of the malicious misrepresentations and absurb inconsistencies of the leading London newspapers about us and our unhappy war, would be a task equally wearisome and unpleasant. But when these traits of journalism are striking and significant, it is worth while to note them. So we remark that the London Times, in the course of a compact column of sneers at this country and its eminent men, quotes Mr. LOVEJOY as saying that he "hates England and declares his hate inextinguishable." Mr. LOVEJOY said no such thing. His indecorous ebullition of feeling, which elicited rebuke on all sides, and especially in these columns, was excited by an object very different from England or the English people: it was the "English [i. e. the British] Government" which he said that he hated; and although such a declaration was in the highest degree indecorous on the floor of Congress, yet it did not so outrage the public sense of decency as that one would which the Times has adroitly foisted upon him. The people of this country draw a very wide distinction between England and the English people (ill-natured to them as the latter sometimes are) and the British Government. For the truth is, that the history of the last hundred years and more justifies the conclusion -- and we call the shades of BURKE and FOX to witness it -- that although the English people in their personal intercourse are as honest as any people who are no honester than they, the British Government seeks only to get on -- honestly if it can, and if honestly, to make a great fuss about it; but at any rate, to get on; and that it will reward any man with place, peerage or pension, or all of them, who, by force or fraud extending British dominion and advancing British interests, provides posts of honor and profit for the British governing classes, and open markets for the British merchants and manufacturers. It is this disposition and this policy which has caused the British Government to be regarded with suspicion and defiance by people who still turn their eyes lovingly to Old England, and with a kinsman's feeling toward the English people.
headline: {'main': 'Curiosities of London Journalism.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Curiosities of London Journalism.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We have news this morning hardly second in importance to that of the fall of Fort Donelson before our victorious arms. A brief dispatch from Gen. HALLECK to Gen. McCLELLAN announces that Gen. PRICE, who has given our Generals in Missouri more trouble than any other rebel leader, has at last been captured by Gen. CURTIS, to- ...
lead_paragraph: We have news this morning hardly second in importance to that of the fall of Fort Donelson before our victorious arms. A brief dispatch from Gen. HALLECK to Gen. MCCLELLAN announces that Gen. PRICE, who has given our Generals in Missouri more trouble than any other rebel leader, has at last been captured by Gen. CURTIS, together with several members of his staff. The capture was effected in Arkansas, whither our forces had followed the retreating rebels. Previous to the capture several skirmishes had taken place in the defiles of the mountains through which the rebel army was retreating toward the Indian country, in which several were killed and wounded on both sides, the preponderance being on that of the rebels, and a large number of prisoners were captured by our troops. The National Flag now once more floats in Arkansas -- probably never again to be lowered. Another important capture is reported to have taken place near Warsaw, Mo., on Sunday night -- no less a personage than Brigadier-General PRICE, son of STERLING PRICE, being taken prisoner, with a number of other prominent officers. Missouri is now almost literelly free of rebels.

abstract: The steamship Bohemian arrived at Portland yesterday morning, bringing one day's later news from Europe. The Opposition party had approved of the course of the Government in the Trent affair. Lord PALMERSTON announced that the Government would continue in its neutral course. The last India cotton crop is pouring into Bombay. The iron-clad frigate Warrior had worked badly on her trial trip. The news from the Continent, and indeed the news generally, is unimportant.

abstract: The boat from Old Point has just arrived. She did not leave Old Point until 10 o'clock last night, having waited for the arrival of the steamers George Washington and Express, which went up the James River under a flag of truce, to receive the released prisoners, but owing to a heavy fog on the James River, had not arrived when the steamer left.

abstract: summary of Gordon case and efforts to get his sentence commuted
snippet: summary of Gordon case and efforts to get his sentence commuted
lead_paragraph: The case of NATHANIEL GORDON, the SlaverCaptain, is of no ordinary interest. Like many others who have violated the law of the nation, he was first brought before the bar of our Courts by an Administration in no way disposed to deal harshly with offenders of that class, and like them he would have entirely freed himself from the meshes of the law, had he not been met in the later stages of his legal difficulties by a District-Attorney of a different stamp, whose appointment proceeded from an Administration which is popularly supposed to differ widely from that which preceded it.

abstract: The Secretary of War has met the railroad people and they are his. Much complaint has been made of the charges imposed by various companies upon the transportation of troops and baggage; complaint that finds expression in the report of the Van Wyck Committee of Investigation. So large have been the profits of this class of transportation, that managers have been known to offer a bonus of $3,000 to the commander of a regiment to induce him to prefer the route they controlled. It is also proved that the entire baggage of the troops has been habitually charged as if ordinary freight. These excesses and abuses the Government proposes to reduce and correct; and in the short interchange of views yesterday between Mr. STANTON and the assembled officers at Washington, the latter showed all willingness to second the desires of Government. The omen is gracious. The war against open enemies is prosperous; let there be no pause in that against contractors, jobbers and public plunderers. This last sort of enemy is the more pestilent of the two.

abstract: The latest advices from Fort Donelson confirm the report which reached us late yesterday evening, that the rebels have evacuated Clarksville, and are falling back on Nashville. One of our gunboats proceeded up the Cumberland as far as Clarksville, and found the rebels abandoning the...
lead_paragraph: The latest advices from Fort Donelson confirm the report which reached us late yesterday evening, that the rebels have evacuated Clarksville, and are falling back on Nashville. One of our gunboats proceeded up the Cumberland as far as Clarksville, and found the rebels abandoning the place in a panic. The gunboat captured two large flatboats loaded with war munitions. Every thing at Fort Donelson was progressing favorably. The army was very enthusiastic, and anxious to march to Nashville. The actual number of prisoners surrendered to Gen. GRANT is 13,300, among whom is Gen. WEST, whose name has not before been mentioned. In addition to these, Gen. GRANT has notified Gen. HALLECK that 1,000 more have been captured since the surrender, who came down the river to reinforce the fort, not knowing it had fallen.

abstract: The upshot of the famous effort of the Artisans' Bank to obtain the City Deposits has come to light. The Corporation treasure was, it will be remembered, intrusted to the Shoe and Leather Bank, the Chamberlain at the time being Mr. ANDREW V. STOUT. Under pretence that that trustworthy institution declined to pay interest on balances, Mayor WOOD became suddenly urgent that the deposits should be transferred to the Artisans' Bank, of which Mr. NATHAN PLATT was President -- a plan that required President PLATT to become Chamberlain. Of the means taken to secure this end, the report of the Receiver of the Bank affords information. The sum of $100,000, and perhaps considerably more, was expended in the task of securing indispensable political influence. BEN. WOOD, the Mayor's brother, had something more than ten thousand dollars. Seventy thousand dollars were distributed at the City Hall to procure the confirmation of Mr. PLATT. And, in view of the public outcry at the folly of confiding the City cash to the keeping of a Bank whose capital was not equal to a half of the ordinary sum in deposit, and whose stock was thirty per cent. below par, it was deemed proper to take $70,000 in coin from the vaults of the Bank, with which, by judicious purchases, to inflate the current quotations of the stock on Wall-street. A more extraordinary and daring fraud was never attempted. Corruption, as usual, did its work. PLATT was made Chamberlain; but so exhausting had been the effort to procure the appointment, that the Bank sunk under the load-it had secured. The Park Bank became the City depository and the Artisans' crumbled to pieces.

abstract: Extensive arrangements have been made in this City to duly celebrate WASHINGTON's Birthday to-morrow. A mass meeting of the citizens will be held at Cooper Institute in the evening, at which Gen. SCOTT has accepted an invitation to be present. By order of Collector BARNEY, the Custom-house will be closed after 12 o'clock, in order to afford the persons employed an opportunity to participate in the festivities of the day. Orations will be delivered at the Academy of Music and Niblo's Garden, during the day, and meetings and festivals will be held at various places in the evening. The public buildings will be closed, and business will generally be suspended.

abstract: editorial on allied movements; Editorial on European attitudes toward war
snippet: editorial on allied movements; Editorial on European attitudes toward war
lead_paragraph: The news from Mexico, sent through Havana, is less favorable to the projects of the Allies than preceding advices had authorized us to expect. The advices weallude to are not those supplied by the Paris Moniteur, with a view to proving the Mexicans ripe for a monarchy and MAXIMILIAN. But we had learned that, of eight points presented as the basis of amicable adjustment by the Allies, five had been accepted by the Commissioners of President JUAREZ, and the remaining three were to be made the subject of a fresh Conference, in which the Mexican Envoys, with more extended powers, would participate. And it was hinted, upon good authority, that to get rid of the invaders, it was not unlikely that the outstanding points would be conceded by the Mexican Government.

abstract: - The telegraphic advices this morning again refer to the abandonment of Columbus, Kentucky, by the rebel forces. The certainly of such a movement is not confirmed, but the strong probability that it is immediately contemplated, if not already effected, admits of little dispute. The intrenchments at Columbus have, for months past, been reported as formidable. The calculation was pretty general that a desperate defence would here be made against the progress of the National army, down the Mississippi River. The belief was equally general that the division of Gen. HALLECK would at an early day assault the Columbus intrenchments, or burn them by the cooperation of the gunboat fleet. But, as this expectation proved erroneous, and the Cumberland and Tennessee have first been taken possession of, Gen. POLK appears to have concluded that his position is indefensible against the odds which will be brought against him, and that he has no reasonable prospect of reinforcements from Middle Tennessee after the fall of Dover.

abstract: Editorial criticizes NY Tribune and Evening Post reporting of McClellan and Stanton activities
snippet: Editorial criticizes NY Tribune and Evening Post reporting of McClellan and Stanton activities
lead_paragraph: We have not the slightest disposition to be impertinent, -- but we should like to know what public interest the Tribune and Evening Post hope to serve by stirring up ill feeling and jealousies between the Generals of the National army in the field and the Secretary of War, who stands at their head. There may be some great object of national importance to be attained by their steady attacks upon Gen. MCCLELLAN and their overstrained laudations of Mr. STANTON; but we don't see it. Both these journals insist that Gen. MCCLELLAN had nothing whatever to do with the preliminary arrangement for the combined military movements which were set on foot immediately after the accession of the new Secretary, -- that his removal from the chief command was in fact essential to the vigorous prosecution of the war. It is possible that this may be so, though we have seen nothing whatever in any quarter to render it even probable. And even if it were so, it seems to us a very unfortunate moment for the excitement of the feelings as the discussion of such a topic must of necessity create. Our armies are to move together. The grand assault which has been so splendidly commenced in Tennessee will be followed up, at the proper moment and with all desirable rapidity, on the Mississippi and in front of the Potomac; -- and in our judgment the public Press would be much more usefully employed in arousing the ardor and friendly emulation of our commanding Generals, than in planting among them seeds of discontent and hostile dissension.

abstract: -- The First Battalion Cavalry, Connecticut Valunteers, Maj. JUDSON M. LYON commanding, will arrive in this City this morning from New-Haven. The steamers will land at Pier No. 2, North River. The Cavalry will be transferred to the New-Jersey Central Railroad boats, and proceed to Wheeling, Va., via Harrisburgh. The officers will breakfast at the Astor House, by invitation of the Sons of Connecticut, at 9 1/2 o'clock. Lhose wishing to participate will meet at the Astor House at 9 o'clock. The bodies of Col. RUSSELL, Lieut. STILLMAN, Capt. JOSEPH J. HENRY, and priuate J.F. BRONSON, were received last night by the Sons of Connecticut, J.H. ALMY, Chairman of Committee of Arrangements, and will be forwarded by this morning's Express train to Connecticut.

abstract: THE LIGHT GUARD BALL. The regiment, in full dress uniform, was very largely represented; the attendance of ladies was thronged...
lead_paragraph: THE LIGHT GUARD BALL. -- In spite of the sad prognostications from people worried about war, taxes and the exportation of specie, the ball of the Seventy-first Regiment N.Y.S.M., came off at the Academy of Music, last night, in magnificent style. The regiment, in full dress uniform, was very largely represented; the attendance of ladies was thronged and brilliant to the last degree, and the spacious house was appropriately draped and decorated in an entirely new and unique style. The battle-torn standard of the "Tigers" hung conspicuous amid the blazonry of escutcheons commemorating our National victories and entwined with the friendly colors of the Union and its sister nations, and the song of birds nestled in cages amid the drapery, mingled with the burst of dancing music. From midnight on until the peep of dawn, the throng of three thousand vibrated between the magnificent supper-rooms and the ball.

abstract: The Navy Departmenthas, we understand, introduced an important change in regard to the enlistment of men in the naval service. Men of all rates have hitherto been shipped for three years. It is now optional whether they ship for three years or for the war. This will, without doubt, prove a powerful inducement for sea-faring people thrown out of their regular employments to enter the service. At the end of the war they will find themselves at liberty, and while it does last there is plenty both of pay and of glory to be won.

A Committee of twelve well known citizens was appointed to recive donations and subscriptions, and a substantial cash collection was taken on the spot. The office of the Committee will be at No. 320 Broadway.

abstract: -- The Richmondpapers say that every train from Manassas is crowded with soldiers who are on their return home to visit their friends -- but who have promised to come back and reenlist. Wonder how much, under the circumstances, this promise is worth? The succession of defeats which the rebel cause is encountering at every point must be a lively inducement to return. Once at home, they will, we fancy, come to the conclusion that patriotism imperatively requires them to stay where they are, so as to help drive away the "Hessian invaders" when they go down that way. Besides, if they spend a few weeks at their firesides, it will probably prove so difficult for them to find their old comrades and commanders, unless they seek them among the prisoners in the Union camps, that they will scarcely attempt so desperate an undertaking.
lead_paragraph: -- The Richmondpapers say that every train from Manassas is crowded with soldiers who are on their return home to visit their friends -- but who have promised to come back and reenlist. abstract: The news from Europe is calculated to lessen, if not remove altogether, the fear of a foreign intervention in American affairs. The assurance of Lord PALMERSTON with regard to England, was hardly needed. We have only to look at the present condition of the Old
lead_paragraph: The news from Europe is calculated to lessen, if not remove altogether, the fear of a foreign intervention in American affairs. The assurance of Lord PALMERSTON with regard to England, was hardly needed. We have only to look at the present condition of the Old World, and at the various causes of trouble and disturbance it contains, to rest satisfied that the time is not distant when it will be as busy in the settlement of its peculiar difficulties as we are in the settlement of our own. Without reference to the financial disorders, prevailing in almost every country except England, there is the Italian question, which grows more and more complicated every day, and which cannot fail to engross the attention of European Powers, and perhaps necessitate their intervention. Gen. GARIBALDI has just written a letter to the carabineers of Genoa, in which he tells them that the moment approaches when they will be called to give a new proof of their bravery. It is supposed that the liberator of Naples and Sicily intends to commence operations for the delivery of Venetia early in the Spring, and Austria is taking, in concert with Turkey, active measures of defence, to resist his attack and to protect the frontiers of Dalmatia and Albania.

abstract: The case of Capt. GORDON, who suffers death to-day, came up in a new phase yesterday, in an application for a writ of habeas corpus to bring him before the United States Circuit Court. The ground assumed was alleged irregularity in the sen-...
lead_paragraph: The case of Capt. GORDON, who suffers death to-day, came up in a new phase yesterday, in an application for a writ of habeas corpus to bring him before the United States Circuit Court. The ground assumed was alleged irregularity in the sentence, based mainly upon the act of this State, passed in 1860, in relation to capital punishment. It appears that before GORDON was sentenced, the question of the place of execution was considered by the Judges. They doubtless remembered the unseemly spectacle which took place on the occasion of the execution of the murderer HICKS, on Bedloe's Island, when thousands of people thronged out on the Bay to witness the execution, as if it had been a regatta. And that no such thing should recur, they directed, in their sentence, that the prisoner should be taken back to the City Prison, in which he had been confined, and there executed. This was in accordance with usage. There the murderers from the ship Gen. Parkhill were sentenced to be executed, and there, or in the prison of King's County, were executed the murderers in the case of the bark Glen.

abstract: The Committee of French residents of this City, viz.: Messrs. Dr. GOUDDEN, Dr. A. WOLF, F. AUMERLE, and LACHAUME, who are intrusted with the preparations for the obsequies of Lieut.-Col. VIGUIER DE MONTEUIL of the D'Epineuil Zouaves, who fell so gallantly in the front of battle for the Union, at Roanoke Island, have appealed to their countrymen here for contributions, to be applied to the erection of a monument to commemorate the virtues and the soldierly death of their compatriot. Subscription lists are open at the houses of M. GAUDELET, No. 32 Platt-street, and M. LACHAUME, No. 821 Broadway. So good an object can hardly fail to meet with ready and abundant support.

abstract: The execu tion, yesterday, of the Slave-trader GORDON, for one of the most atrocious and sordid of crimes, was preceded by no evidences of any compunction of conscience or realizing sense of guilt on the part of the culprit. On the contrary, his last hours were passed under the effects of an attempt at self-destruction, and his dying speech bitterly denounces the officer...
lead_paragraph: -- The execution, yesterday, of the Slave-trader GORDON, for one of the most atrocious and sordid of crimes, was preceded by no evidences of any compunction of conscience or realizing sense of guilt on the part of the culprit. On the contrary, his last hours were passed under the effects of an attempt at self-destruction, and his dying speech bitterly denounces the officer by whose courageous and persevering efforts he was brought to justice. He intimated that the United States District-Attorney, in his address to the jury at the trial, had promised to petition the President for a commutation of the death penalty in case of a conviction. The declarations of a criminal in GORDON's state, both of mind and body, can have little weight. But the friends of E. DELAFIELD SMITH, (and these must henceforth number most of our law-abiding citizens,) will be glad to know that the address in question was taken in short-hand by a stenographer, and that it contains no such language. On the contrary, the District-Attorney, (while warning the jury not to permit any individual views of the proper degree of punishment to deter them from answering truthfully on the question of guilt or innocence,) used the following language:

abstract: The execution of NATHANIEL GORDON, the Slaver-Captain, took place yesterday at 12 o'clock. The Captain attempted to evade the punishment of his crime by taking strychnine. This was discovered, however, in season to prevent his death, and by use of stimulants he was kept half alive until the hour appointed, for his execution, at...
lead_paragraph: The execution of NATHANIEL GORDON, the Slaver-Captain, took place yesterday at 12 1/4 o'clock. The Captain attempted to evade the punishment of his crime by taking strychnine. This was discovered, however, in season to prevent his death, and by use of stimulants he was kept half alive until the hour appointed, for his execution, at which time, half stupefied with whisky, he was hanged by the neck until he died. His remains were given to his friends.

abstract: The Presidential proclamation makes today a national festival, and the suggestion so fully responds to a universal desire on the part of the people, that there is every promise the celebration will be a most genuine and cordial one throughout all the loyal States.
lead_paragraph: The Presidential proclamation makes today a national festival, and the suggestion so fully responds to a universal desire on the part of the people, that there is every promise the celebration will be a most genuine and cordial one throughout all the loyal States. The late victories of the Union cause have stirred all hearts with such deep emotions, that there has been a general yearning for an opportunity to give united expression to the new-born hopes and joys. In selecting the anniversary of the birthday of WASHINGTON, the President enables us at once to observe one of our ancient National festivals, and to illustrate it with later glories that do honor to his memory. From all that we hear, the occasion will be celebrated to-day as it never was before. All the cities of the loyal States participate; there will be civic processions, military parades, "sonorous metal blowing martial sounds," orations, closed stores, omnipresent flags, evening illuminations; and every material form that can add pride and circumstance to the festal day will be invoked.
headline: {'main': "A Double Festival--The Birthday of Washington and the Dayspring of the Nation's Triumph.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "A Double Festival--The Birthday of Washington and the Dayspring of the Nation's Triumph.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

lead_paragraph: Of the debate in both Houses of the British Parliament, upon the address in acknowledgment of the Queen's speech, we are able to present this morning a very full and satisfactory report. The address in the House of Peers was moved by Lord DUFFERIN, that brilliant and accomplished descendant of SHERIDAN. In the language of the mover, as well as in that of Lord DERBY, Earl RUSSELL and Earl GRANVILLE, the leaders of the Tory and Whig Parties in the Lords, there was nothing more observable than the gratification at escaping an American war growing out of the Trent business, and the eagerness to counsel nonintervention in our domestic quarrels, whatever the provocation. With the slightly supercilious tone of Lord SHELBOURNE, and the thoroughly English arrogance with which he ascribed the entire merit of the recent pacific settlement to the wisdom and moderation of Her Majesty's Government, we may bear with patience, seeing the traditional experience we have had of the defects in the parental John Bull's personal character and habits. To make war upon the English self-conceit, would be to indefinitely postpone the millennium.

lead_paragraph: Thirty-five years ago, in the City of Portland, a well-to-do couple were gladdened by the birth of a son. The boy, who was delicately made, grew rapidly, and in his earliest years developed unusual vigor of mind, which gave promise of a useful and honorable manhood. At the age of fifteen he manifested suddenly a desire to go to sea. His parents, who had fondly watched his rapid progress at school, demurred, but the boy, already the ruler of the domestic circle, was determined, and to sea he went His father, Capt. GORDON, had been a seafaring man for many years, and soon recovered from the disappointment which, to the mother, has been a life-long grief, and which was the means by which the son,

abstract: Both Houses of Congress adjourned after very short sessions yesterday, out of respect to President LINCOLN and his family, in their recent affliction. The Homestead bill was briefly considered in the House, and Speaker GROW made a speech in favor of its passage. No further action was taken upon it. In consequence of the death of the President's son, it was resolved that the illumination of the public buildings in Washington should not take place to-night, as previously arranged.

abstract: NATHANIEL GORDON, the Captain of the slaver Echo, suffered the penalty of the law yesterday afternoon. A determined, but fruitless attempt was made on his part to escape it by suicide. Every other means had been previously exhausted. Ingenious and able counsel strove energetically to prevent his...
lead_paragraph: NATHANIEL GORDON, the Captain of the slaver Echo, suffered the penalty of the law yesterday afternoon. A determined, but fruitless attempt was made on his part to escape it by suicide. Every other means had been previously exhausted. Ingenious and able counsel strove energetically to prevent his conviction, but the evidence was too clear to be thrust aside -- so clear that no one can doubt that he was guilty of the crime alleged. Nor did their efforts in his behalf cease with his conviction. Every exertion was tried, every argument possible was urged before the Courts to break down the conviction or the sentence. A very powerful effort was made, also, to reach the clemency of the Executive. It is said that petitions for a commutation of his sentence, signed by twenty-five thousand names, were forwarded for presentation to the President, to say nothing of the meeting at the Exchange on Thursday afternoon. But the endeavors were all in vain. The President's duty was clear to him, and though it must have been most painful, he has shown himself to be, what we all know he is, a man to whom the voice of duty is all-powerful. There were interests at stake too mighty to allow him to turn back the mighty power of justice which this unfortunate man had put in motion against himself. And thus the majesty of the law has been vindicated, and the stamp of the gallows has been set upon the crime of slave-trading in so forcible a way that it will not soon be forgotten. And it was time. That crime has been far too lightly thought of among us of late. That it has been so, GORDON himself was a living proof. Born in an intelligent, law-abiding community, of reputable parentage, with means of education within his reach, an American shipmaster for years, why should he four times have put his life in his hand, four times have gone into a traffic to which the law had affixed the penalty of death? Because our commercial communities had become demoralized upon the question. The "cursed greed of gain" had caused them to shut their eyes, had deadened their consciences when the Slave-trade was in question. This City has exerted a terrible influence in that direction. She might well send petitions signed by twenty-five thousand names in GORDON's favor, for his blood lies partly upon her skirts. New-York has been most deeply engaged in the traffic. Her merchants have largely profited by its bloodstained gains; and worse, New-York divines have argued upon the curse of Ham in a way to help on that greed which was urging the merchants and shipmasters into the trade. Religious societies of our City have refused to lend their aid to resist this constantly increasing debauchery of public sentiment, and New-York newspapers have applauded the clerical watchmen that refused to blow the trumpet. And so the navigators and shipping men have lost their sense of the wickedness of the trade, and have come to deride the idea that punishment so terrible should ever be meted out to any one who engaged in it. It has been said, not once or twice only, even since GORDON was convicted: "They dare not hang him." Was it a surprising thing that he should have transgressed the law, when there were so many influences around him to suggest that the crime was not great, and that the punishment would not be awarded? New-York influences might well be exerted to save his forfeited life, for the influences of this City had smoothed his way to that forfeiture, and hereafter his blood may be required of some among us who will cry out in surprise, as did another, "Am I my brother's keeper?" and be met with the same reply.

abstract: The Eighth-avenue Railroad Company, of which Mr. GEORGE LAW is the principal owner, is distinguishing itself by insisting on all its fares being paid in specie. The tender of a banknote is followed by the instant expulsion of the offending passenger, whether male or female, ill or well, from the car. The fact naturally excites great indignation. The public instinctively recurs to the history of the fraud and corruption through which the use of the Eighth-avenue for a railroad was stolen from the people, andplaced in the hands of persons reckless of all obligations to the community; and it becomes important to know whether or not there is any protection against their insolence. Happily there is. The franchise may at any moment be resumed, fair compensation for the material and machinery of the Company being made, or the Common Council may establish such rules as shall forbid the excesses now complained of. The matter has been brought before the Board of Councilmen, who have referred it to the Corporation Counsel. A better plan would have been to have enacted a regulation that upon the presentation to the conductor of a current bank-bill of a denomination of five dollars, or less, with a statement that the passenger is without coin, should, upon the refusal of the conductor to make change, entitle the passenger to his ride. That in the scarcity of silver the rule might diminish the profits of the Company is probable. But there are ample reasons for diminishing them; and in a question between such a monstrous nuisance and the people, the nuisance, we submit, should go to the wall.

abstract: The news from Tennessee this morning is extraordinary and pleasing, beyond anything we have heard since first the rebellion broke out. The Union feeling is manifesting itself in the most remarkable way. Two rebel regiments had come in and given themselves up tired of fighting against the old flag.
lead_paragraph: The news from Tennessee this morning is extraordinary and pleasing, beyond anything we have heard since first the rebellion broke out. The Union feeling is manifesting itself in the most remarkable way. Two rebel regiments had come in and given themselves up tired of fighting against the old flag. The Provost Marshal at Clarksville had sent word to Gen. GRANT to come up and occupy the town at once. The Nashvillians are opposed to the rebels fighting at that place. Gov. HARRIS has called the Legislature together to reconsider, it is said, its late rebellious action. The people of Tennessee say they had been told that the Union army were composed entirely of negroes and Germans -- all Abolitionists. But now that their eyes are opened, they will return to the Union and the flag of their fathers.

abstract: The proceedings in Congress yesterday were very interesting. In the Senate a little routine business was done, when a message was received from the House that the ceremonies incident to the day were about to commence, and the members proceeded in a body to the Hall of Representatives. In the House, the gallaries set apart for the public were densely crowded.
lead_paragraph: The proceedings in Congress yesterday were very interesting. In the Senate a little routine business was done, when a message was received from the House that the ceremonies incident to the day were about to commence, and the members proceeded in a body to the Hall of Representatives. In the House, the gallaries set apart for the public were densely crowded. Many persons were unable even to gain admission to the Capitol. After the House was organized, Mr. CRITTENDEN, of Kentucky, in consideration of the fact that the presentation of flags was not contemplated in the joint resolution providing for the celebration, moved that the ceremony be omitted. This gave rise to a long debate as to the propriety of the proposed presentation, which ended in the adoption of Mr. CRITTENDEN's motion, 70 to 61. At this juncture the members of the Senate, headed by the Vice-President, entered, with the heads of Departments, the Judges of the Supreme Court and the representatives of foreign Governments -- officers of the Army and Navy, including Gen. MCLELLAN, coming last. The ceremonies then commenced with a prayer by Rev. Mr. STOCKTON; after which Col. FORNEY read the Farewell Address, which was listened to with profound attention. The guests then retired, and soon afterward the House adjourned.

abstract: The Trib une loses no chance to attack the skill or character of the officers who lead the Union armies. Its assaults are by no means confined to Gen. McCLELLAN. Some time ago it put in circulation a series of charges affect ing the reputation of Gen. BLENKER, who commands a division of the army beyond the Potomac.
lead_paragraph: -- The Tribune loses no chance to attack the skill or character of the officers who lead the Union armies. Its assaults are by no means confined to Gen. McCLELLAN. Some time ago it put in circulation a series of charges affect ing the reputation of Gen. BLENKER, who commands a division of the army beyond the Potomac. These charges relate principally to transactions in Europe during the revolutionary struggles of 1848. One or two of the most vague and indefinite character relate to the pecuniary affairs of his division, the odium being in this instance equitably divided with the other officers of the command. Because there has been no response to these wholly unauthenticated stories, the Tribune hastens to pass judgment by default, charitably inferring that BLENKER is guilty, or he would turn upon his impugners, and demand inquiry. The judgment, like most of those so freely pronounced in that particular court, must be set aside. Gen. BLENKER does demand an inquiry. He has caused the arrest of Colonel D'UTASSY, who is implicated in the circulation of the charges, and investigation will determine how far the recent conduct of the General authorizes such imputations.

abstract: About 11 o'clock on Thursday morning an accident occurred near Peekskill, on the Hudson River Railroad. Two freight trains left Thirty-first-street for Albany, one a few minutes ahead of the other. When near Peekskill a coupling of one of the cars of the first train broke, and the engine was backed for the purpose of coupling the cars left behind, when the last train coming up, a collision occurred. Three or four cars were instantly broken to pieces, and their contents strewed over the track. The engine was also badly broken; the engineer, fireman, and one of the brakemen injured. The fireman is said to have one of his legs broken. The down express was detained between three and four hours, and the other trains were also delayed some time before the track could be cleared and placed again in running order.
lead_paragraph: About 11 o'clock on Thursday morning an accident occurred near Peekskill, on the Hudson River Railroad. Two freight trains left Thirty-first-street for Albany, one a few minutes ahead of the other. When near Peekskill a coupling of one of the cars of the first train broke, and the engine was backed for the purpose of coupling the cars left behind, when the last train coming up, a collision occurred. Three or four cars were instantly broken to pieces, and their contents strewed over the track. The engine was also badly broken; the engineer, fireman, and one of the brakemen injured. The fireman is said to have one of his legs broken. The down express was detained between three and four hours, and the other trains were also delayed some time before the track could be cleared and placed again in running order.

abstract: The anniversary of WASHINGTON'S birth was observed with a zest and unanimity never perhaps exhibited since the day became a feast in the calendar. Stores were very generally closed, business suspended, the streets filled with throngs abroad, in spite of the unspeakable walking, and splendid regiments tramped...
lead_paragraph: The anniversary of WASHINGTON'S birth was observed with a zest and unanimity never perhaps exhibited since the day became a feast in the calendar. Stores were very generally closed, business suspended, the streets filled with throngs abroad, in spite of the unspeakable walking, and splendid regiments tramped through the slime with a courage worthy of the battle-field. These were outward and visible signs of the popular rejoicing. In doors, where the people assembled to do honor in an intellectual way to the memory of the great dead, and of the more recent dead, who have perished that his work might survive, there was a corresponding show of earnest and enthusiastic feeling. The various speakers who improved the occasion did so with practical reference to the crisis in the National career through which we are passing, bringing history and political philosophy to reinforce the popular heart, and show with what profitable result we may reasonably hope to emerge from the struggle into which misguided men, whose designs are providentially overruled, have plunged a great, prosperous, and happy nation. These political exhortations, attended by the reading of that greatest of all bequests, the Farewell Address, cannot fail to leave a wholesome, and, we trust, durable influence.

abstract: Gentleman In my letter of the 14th, I predicted that Bowling Green would be ours in a very short time and without firing a gun. The prediction has been fully verified, and I am now enabled to give you the particulars of the expedition, which I learned from Capt. COLLISS, of the Second Kentucky Cavalry, who arrived here from Browling Green last night.

abstract: None who have ever lived in our generation ever beheld a more general and imposing display of popular feeling than was witnessed in this vast City yesterday. From the peculiarity of the circumstances surrounding the occasion, such an impressive and universal demonstration may never occur again.
lead_paragraph: None who have ever lived in our generation ever beheld a more general and imposing display of popular feeling than was witnessed in this vast City yesterday. From the peculiarity of the circumstances surrounding the occasion, such an impressive and universal demonstration may never occur again. It comprised within itself an epitome of Northern faith and sentiment as represented by the greatest mart of commerce and centre of population in these States. The aspirations of 23,000,000 of souls for their country were distinctly and emphatically made known in the patriotic fervor of the swarming thousands that filled our thoroughfares from early morning until midnight.

abstract: Editorial on how Union forces have conquered Confederate walls; Editorial on rumor Confederates surrendered Nashville
snippet: Editorial on how Union forces have conquered Confederate walls; Editorial on rumor Confederates surrendered Nashville
lead_paragraph: -- An important rumor, through a rebel source, has been current for a day or two, to the effect that the City of Nashville is to be surrendered to the Union forces without military resistance. Tracing the rumor to its source, we find that it rests upon the authority of Professor EVE, of the Medical School at Nashville, now on a visit to Augusta, Ga. He says that after the fall of Dover, Gen. A. SYDNEY JOHNSTON, Confederate Commander in the West, telegraphed to the National Commander -- probably at Dover, or possibly at Clarksville -- that if he would respect private property, the Capital of Tennessee would be surrendered without a fight.

abstract: gives series of lectures at Brooklyn Academy of Music
snippet: gives series of lectures at Brooklyn Academy of Music
lead_paragraph: The fifth lecture in the series was delivered at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, on Sunday evening, Feb. 16. Prof. AGASSIZ proposed to devote this and the closing lecture to the consideration of the question of the existence of Providence in nature, as demonstrated on purely scientific grounds. The Author of Nature may work by one of two methods, viz.: 1. By established laws, or 2. By direct action. We may recognize intelligence in the constitution of a machine, but the work that the machine does is not intellectual work. Intelligence first devises the machine, and thereafter the machine does the work, and intelligence has nothing to do with it. Now, the question is, are living beings the product of established natural laws, or are they the direct work of the Creator? I have already adverted to a series of facts bearing upon this question. I have shown that there have been interruptions in the sequences of organized beings upon the earth -- that one set of animals, after continuing a certain period, have disappeared, to make room for another, but not in the way in which one generation makes room for another. The earth has again and again been inhabited by successive generations of different kinds of animals. There is a very well-received theory lately propounded by some very learned, but rather fanciful scientific men, that in the beginning animals were few in number, and, as they became more and more numerous, they became more and more different from one another. Let me show, before I take another step, the fallacy of that theory. The lower strata of the earth are, of course, not so accessible as the superficial ones. Now, our information respecting the number and characteristics of the early inhabitants is derived from the remains which we can exhume, and this process is difficult in proportion as they are buried deeper. Then, there is another difficulty which has been entirely overlooked. Living animals exist in profusion everywhere, while fossils are few. We are restricted in our researches for the remains of animals of past ages. Africa, Australia and the greater part of Asia and South America are sealed books so far as regards fossil remains. It is chiefly in certain parts of Europe and North America that we are enabled to compare the remains of past ages with the animals now living on the whole surface of the globe. In order to make a fair comparison we should take the dead and the living species of an equal extent. Let as do so. Near Verona, in Italy, is a celebrated quarry not many miles in extent, from which alone have been taken over one hundred different kinds of fossil fishes, which is more than the whole extent of the Adriatic furnishes of living species. In the neighborhood of Riga, on the Baltic, are found more fossil fishes than the present number of living species in the Baltic and German ocean. So here we have direct evidence that in former periods, within similar areas, there was as great a diversity of animals as now exists. But not to confine the comparison to fishes, let us take shells. In one single region in the neighborhood of Paris, the naturalist LA MARQUE, after ten years' research, described several hundred different kinds of fossil shells, all, of course, different from any that now exist. And yet the number of living species in the Mediterranean, or in any other region of the earth of the extent of 100 miles square, does not exceed 500. And the geological survey of the State of New-York has disclosed in each of the successive strata as great a variety of fossil shells as the sum total of all the living species on the whole Atlantic coast of this Continent. You will bear in mind, that though the number of living species in a particular region is so few, yet the aggregate is very large. The number of living species of fishes on the globe, now known, is nearly 10,000, and the number of shells exceeds 16,000, and yet, taking the fossils of any particular region, they are found to exceed the living species of a very large adjacent area. This is a most powerful blow at the theory that all animals have been derived from a few original beings, which have become diversified and varied in course of time. I will now proceed to enumerate the animals of the different periods, illustrate their character, and show the order of their succession. In the oldest beds we find representatives of the four great divisions viz.: Radiates, Molluses, Articulates and Vertebrates, and not only that, but all the different classes of the first two of those divisions. Of the Radiates we have Polyps, Acalephs, and Echinoderms; and of the Molluses, we have Acephala, Gastropoda and Cephalopoda, from the beginning. Of the Articulates, we have Worms and Crustacea in the lowest strata, but no insects; the first appearance of the latter being in the carboniferous period. Of the Vertebrates, the only representations we have in the lowest strata are Fishes. Reptiles are not found till we reach the carboniferous period. Birds are not earlier than the Triasic, and Mammals at a still later epoch, while no trace of man is found till we reach the present period. So striking are the differences between the various classes of animals at different periods, that the geologist is able to recognize them almost at first sight, and tell to what period they belong. Their characteristics are as distinct as those of the living species. Animals are distributed on the surface of the globe according to definite laws and with remarkable regularity. Each different species has its definite home. Now, in the order of succession there is something quite similar. The idea of an earlier or a later period of existence is associated in the mind of the geologist with the structure of the fossil, just as we associate the palm with a warm climate, and the pine with a cold climate. And not only is there order in the succession of animals, but there is an order which shows, at all times, consecutive thought, which, at the outset, perceives the end. This is something which is never put by mind into machinery; it is something which the architect retains to himself only while he is superintending the work. To present the argument on this subject I will take the class of echinoderms. These are divided into several orders, according to structure. First and lowest are star-fishes, with a stem attached to the ground; second, those which radiate equally in every direction; third, animals with a central disc and radiating arms; fourth, those which have a hemispherical form, with certain anatomical complications, which, without entering into the details, require us to assign them to the fourth position; and, lastly, we have the cylindrically-formed animal which is the highest, being the most complicated of all in structure. As to the frequency of the types of these different animals, we find only one single kind of the description of number one now known to exist; while of the second class there are more, of the third, still more, and so on. Those occupying a higher position are very numerous at the present day, while those occupying the lowest places are exceedingly rare. But let us inquire into their occurrence in past ages. In the lowest beds at Lockport are found innumerable echinoderms all of the [???] of number one -- nothing but echrinoids -- and as many different families of that species as exist of all living species along the whole Atlantic coast. Passing up through the superior beds we find quite as great a variety of echinoderms, but not a single species like those oft he lower strata. Rising a little higher, we find genuine star fishes, and still higher genuine sea urchins, but not a single representative of number five until the present epoch. We find, therefore, that the other in which these animals have been introduced on earth in time presents a similar series to that which we observe in the gradation of the structure of the present living species of the same animals. We have two series which coincide in this result -- one an order of succession in time, and the other an order of gradation of structure. But this is not all. Let us see how echinoderms grow. The little starfish, when it is forming within the egg, and when it is just hatched, is not the same free animal that it is in the adult state. It is a little being attached to a stem or prong, with branches above, forming a kind of cup. It resembles those echinoderms first born on the surface of the earth, the type of which has become extinct, with a single exception. After having lived for some time in that form, it casts off the stem, just as we find in the course of time, a period when starfishes with stems no longer exist, but are succeeded by those that have no stems. So this little animal casts off its stem, becomes free, and assumes the form of its parent. Here, then, we have the order of growth of the young animal coincident with the order of sucession in time and the order of gradation of structure. In other words, we have three different ideas which in their results coincide, viz.: 1. The plan upon which animals vary in their structure in course of time. 2. The order of gradation of structure of living species. 3. The order of growth of the young animal from the egg. What is this but the direct working of an Omnipotent mind? And this result is not confined to one, but to every class, so far as our researches have gone. Unfortunately, we are not sufficiently acquainted with the exact gradation and growth from the egg of every class of animals. But let me take, for further illustration, the class of crustacea. It requires not much insight into their structure to perceivre that of the three groups of this class, shrimps are the lowest, lobsters next, and crabs highest. Now at Trenton, N.Y., in the lowest fossiliferous strata, are found immense quantities of trilobites, the prominent characteristic of which is a body in which the head and tail are hardly distinct from the rest of the body, with uniform transverse divisions of the whole body such as we find in shrimps of the present day. In the middle geological period, especially in the triassic, we find nothing but lobsters like crustacea. They are as numerous in the lithographic quarries of Bavaria as trilobites at Trenton. Then in the more recent sandstone of Switzerland we find scarcely anything but crabs -- fewer lobsters and no trilobites. Now let us see how they grow. The young crab, long before it is hatched, when it first shows signs of distinct parts, presents a shield in front and behind, and transverse ribs just like a trilobite. In fact, it is a diminutive diagram of the trilobite of the earlier ages. But when it is hatched it does not come out a crab, but a long-bodied animal, just like the lobster. So here, again, is the same thought manifested as among echinoderms; the pattern of growth, the order of introduction in time, and the gradation of structure are coincident. Let me now advert to the vertebrates. We have among the vertebrates a similar gradation of structure from the fish to man -- first, fishes, next reptiles, then birds, then mammals, and lastly, man. And this order we can trace through the successive geological formations, showing that the order of succession is coincident with gradation of structure. Let us see if the same coincidence does not exist in their mode of development. Take the egg of a bird. At first it has the features of a fish -- the resemblance being very striking. So here, again, we have the same thought in the mode of development. Is it then, too much to say that when the first vertebrate was called into existence in the shape of a fish, it was part of the plan of that frame-work into which its life was moulded that it should end with man -- the last and highest in the order of succession? We find evidence of this fact in the comparison of the attitude in which he stands with that of the fish, and also in the comparison of the brain. In the fish the brain is only a slight swelling, scarcely raised above the level of the spinal marrow, and the posterior division of the brain is the highest. In the reptile, the posterior, middle and anterior regions are of the same height, and the whole brain is slightly raised above the level of the spine. In the bird the anterior portion is the largest and the posterior region the smallest, and we have a slanting position of the spine. Passing from the quadruped and coming to the man, we find the brain so organized that the anterior portion covers and protects all the rest so completely that nothing is seen outside, and the brain stands vertically poised on the summit of the backbone. Beyond this there is no further progress, showing that man has reached the highest development of the plan upon which his structure was laid. But trace this progress in another aspect. The fish swims horizontally; his body is one cylindrical mass, the head does not rise above the rest of the body, and there is nothing to define the neck. The reptile [???] a slight contraction for a neck; for even in the serpent you can perceive where the body ends and the neck begins, even though there are no limbs to raise the body. But the next step is in the lizard, where rudimentary legs appear, sometimes capable of raising the body slightly; but even yet, like the snake, the animal moves mainly by means of the undulation of the backbone. Then we come to birds, in which the tendency is to an upright position. The bird stands on its hind limbs, but yet it has not reached that position entirely. It requires one further step by which one pair of limbs alone are made to perform the function of locomotion, while the other pair become subservient to the mind. The hand of man is no longer an organ of locomotion, and it is no longer a paw. It is the organ with which we express our deepest feeling; it is the limb with which we grasp our fellow-being in cordial recognition. The brain of man occupies not merely the foremost but the uppermost position. It is not merely forward, but upward -- forward in the direction of all progress in intellectual culture; upward in the direction of all moral excellency; forward and upward towards that Mind according to whose image man is made.

abstract: Yesterday morning, the above regiment arrived in this City, from Albany, by the Hudson River Railroad. On alighting from the cars, the men were marched to the Park Barracks, where they are at present quartered. The Commandant of the regiment, Col. EDWIN ROSE, is a graduate of West Point, and has seen service in the Florida War. At present the men are not armed, but will be shortly, with the Enfield rifle. This week, the men will go into camp, temporarily, on Staten Island. Annexed is a list of the principal officers:

abstract: We have undoubtedly captured the rebel Gen. JOHNSON, at Fort Donelson, and the rebel Gen. PRICE, in Missouri; and now hold both of them as prisoners of war.
lead_paragraph: -- We have undoubtedly captured the rebel Gen. JOHNSON, at Fort Donelson, and the rebel Gen. PRICE, in Missouri; and now hold both of them as prisoners of war. Over the seizure of each of these rebel magnates we have gloried for one day -- only to discover the next morning that while rebels, hearing these respective cognomens and titles have been taken prisoners, those personages whom the public usually identify exclusively with the names and rank, are still at large. It certainly was somewhat of a damper on our spirits, when we were elated at the capture of the most distinguished commander in the rebel service, to learn in a short time that the General we really had captured, was a fellow whose prenomen was Bushrod, instead of Albert Sidney, and that his title to the rank mentioned was exceedingly dubious, while his claims to military genius were unknown outside of the schoolroom where he had taught the young idea how to shoot. So, again, with the General just caught in Missouri. For nine months past, in that State, our armies have been in constant pursuit of a great rebel chief yclept General PRICE, known to the world as the hero of three of the most remarkable foot races recorded in the annals of war. Twenty-five days ago Gen. HALLECK sent out an army twenty thousand strong to pursue, capture, or kill him at all hazards. Daily we chronicled the movements of this pursuing army, hourly and eagerly we looked for news of its catching the old rebel fox; a week ago it reached his den at Springfield, only to find that he had fled; but, tally-ho! and away it started in pursuit down among the hills of Arkansas. Suddenly a message from Missouri was flashed over the wires that "Gen. PRICE has been captured. Signed, H.W. HALLECK, Major-General." And, in truth, PRICE had been captured, and Gen. PRICE too, but alas! as it appeared next morning, not the great old PRICE, but only a cub of the hoary animal, Gen. PRICE, Junior. The old tiger was still at large, his chops red with blood, and his soul plotting further mischief. So, though we have caught JOHNSON and PRICE, PRICE and JOHNSTON still remain the great uncaught.

abstract: The officers and crew of that portion of the gunboat flotilla which were engaged in the capture of Fort Henry on the 6th inst., already have had their brilliant services and gallant conduct favorably noticed by the Commanding General of the Western army and by the Secretary of the Navy, conveying the assurance that the President of the United States, the Congress and the country appreciate their gallant deeds, and proffer to them the profound thanks of the Navy Department for the services rendered.

abstract: The German Hospital, in behalf of which the large and respectable meeting was held last week, has long enjoyed the privileges of a charter, reposed in the hands of a Board of Trustees, consisting of some of the leading Germans of New-York; but these remained, until very lately, without regular permanent organization. They have now, however, remedied this defect in their programme of operations. At a meeting, held in the Prescott House, they called Mr. A. WEISSMANN to the Chair, Mr. HUGE WESENDONCK acting as Secretary pro tem.

abstract: The crew of the British steamer Fingal, which ran the blockade of Savannah, mentioned in yesterday's dispatch, were returned to Craney Island last night. No boat came out, however, to receive them and they were brought back. They were carried over again this morning, and sent back to Norfolk.

abstract: The Emperor is delivered of his speech to the Chambers, and our friends breathe more freely! Our enemies here, and in England, expected the Emperor to lead off in condemnation of our Blockade and of the Charleston Harbor obstruction. So general was the expectation, that the paragraph declaring that our Government had done nothing to which Europe can rightfully object, was received with marked satisfaction throughhout the Chambers.
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Monday, Jan. 27, 1862.

abstract: A reconnoissance was made this morning from the division of Gen. SMITH, consisting of the Cameron Dragoons and three regiments of infantry, all under the command of Col. FRIEDMAN. The infantry separated for several points, namely: Vienna, Flint Hill and Hunter's Mills, to temporarily remain there as a reserve for the cavalry, while the latter proceeded towards Centreville, making a circuit within the lines of the rebel pickets.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Saturday, Feb. 22.

abstract: A writer in the February number of the British United Service Magazine, who dates his communication from Balize, with which place he is evidently well acquainted, deals with the question of colonial military expenditure as it...
lead_paragraph: A writer in the February number of the British United Service Magazine, who dates his communication from Balize, with which place he is evidently well acquainted, deals with the question of colonial military expenditure as itaffects the territory improperly called British Honduras. He regards this settlement as falling in the category of places which Imperial policy demands should be held by a military force, and for the following reasons: "The late troubles with the Indians of Yucatan point out the necessity of a force being kept up for the protection of the frontier. The navy could do little or nothing toward subjugating these unruly tribes. The shallows along the coast prevent a near approach, and would endanger the safety of even ships' boats. The rivers are deep, but difficult of access, and, once entered, oppose an impenetrable barrier of bush to an attempted landing. With safety, therefore, to this part of our dominions, we cannot denude Honduras of troops." But who, he asks, cares for Honduras? Why not abandon it? The question will probably be echoed by a large portion of the British public; but the writer, though his description of the place is very uninviting, believes that it is destined to play a far more important part in the political world than its climate, inhabitants, products, or physical development would seem to intimate, and all on account of its geographical position. Writing as recently as December, 1861, he is of opinion that the proposed line of railway from Port Cortez, on the Atlantic, to the Bay of Fonseca, on the Pacific, would be of incalculable advantage, and "at once raise Honduras in the scale of social advancement." If by Honduras he means Balize, its frightful climate and swampy position render this more than doubtful.

abstract: Again, this morning, we have important and gratifying news from the Southwest. A telegram from Louisville brings intelligence that the Cumberland Gap is in possession of our troops, and also that Russellville, Ky., the seat of the bogus rebel Government of that State, has been occupied by National forces. Cumberland Gap is the key to East Tennessee,...
lead_paragraph: -- Again, this morning, we have important and gratifying news from the Southwest. A telegram from Louisville brings intelligence that the Cumberland Gap is in possession of our troops, and also that Russellville, Ky., the seat of the bogus rebel Government of that State, has been occupied by National forces. Cumberland Gap is the key to East Tennessee and its possession opens the way at once to all that most important section of the country. It is one of the points the seizure of which has been regarded as of the first importance ever since the war broke out, but which the rebels have been able to occupy and hold for three-quarters of a year. Our troops can now at once move on to whatever point in East Tennessee it may be thought most desirable to seize; they can push on to the seizure of the great "backbone" railroad connecting the Southern States of the East with those of the West -- the line of which is but thirty miles from the Gap. Or if they do not at present move any further than the Gap, but simply hold possession of it, they will there furnish a rallying point for the Union patriots of East Tennessee. We shall probably now soon see a general and determined uprising of these long-persecuted, but faithful and gallant men. The troops that have just achieved this most important success are undoubtedly those in the brigade of Gen. CARTER, which left London and Barboursville, shortly after ZOLLICOFFER's defeat, to do this very work. The roads in that section have been shockingly bad; and difficulties and obstructions of every kind have been in the way of the advance; but it seems they have all been overcome, and the magnificent natural gateway to East Tennessee, and the Thermopylae of the West, is ours. As for Russellville, it was there that the recently-erected bogus State Government of Kentucky had established its capital. A body of five thousand rebels have, until lately, been stationed there for its defence. But in the late general flight of rebels from Kentucky, it would seem that these alsohave fled. It is probable that the loyal force now in possession is the division of Gen. MITCHELL, which has reached this point on its way down to Nashville -- before reaching which it will form a conjunction with the immense and victorious column under Maj.-Gen. GRANT. The rebel Government at Russellville has thus been scattered to the winds; that at Richmond will soon follow. Events in the Southwest are marching on with magnificent rapidity.

abstract: The Hospital Fair in aid of certain extended purposes of the "Infirmary for Indigent Women and Children," which is to be held at Dodworth's Rooms on the 26th of the present month, contemplates much of interest in an intellectual point of view. A newspaper (so called) is to be issued, the contents of which will be composed of special contributions from our best American authors, as WHITTIER, LOWELL, BAYARD TAYLOR, Mrs. KIRKLAND, Mrs. PROUTOR, Miss SEDGWICK, ALICE CAREY, and others. The evenings will be enlivened with novel features of entertainment, partaking of an instructive character. First will be tableaux vivants; on the second, classical and other readings, in which Mr. STEPHEN C. MASSETT (Jeems Pipes, of Pipesville,) will assist. The third and last evening will be full of attraction with the blended influence of music and art. Nearly five thousand patients have been successfully treated during the last year, and the Committee, more than satisfied with their endeavors, desire to encourage and assist them for the future. With this intent, the present Fair is to be hold, and one of its objects is to maintain in appropriate character a library, which shall contribute to the comfort and moral elevation of the convalescent patients; also, to inaugurate a course of lectures upon practical medicine and hygiene, the instructive influence of which they have always felt to be a much-needed element of success in their plans.
