abstract: -- We have advices from our correspondents near the Savannah River, up to last Tuesday. At that time, our troops had just completed the erection of a small fortification or battery on a north-western point of Jones' Island, within a distance of eight miles of Savannah. This completely cuts off communication between Fort Pulaski and Savannah, and it was the premature to say that Pulaski had been turned. Operations at other points also were said to be then going on; and a considerable body of troops had started for a destination not made public. The rebels have informed us that Savannah had been captured by our troops. Up to last Tuesday, however, we had not yet taken it, though our forces had got within a very short distance of it from two directions. What may have taken place since then, we shall soon know.
lead_paragraph: -- We have advices from our correspondents near the Savannah River, up to last Tuesday. At that time, our troops had just completed the erection of a small fortification or battery on a north-western point of Jones' Island, within a distance of eight miles of Savannah. This completely cuts off communication between Fort Pulaski and Savannah, and it was the premature to say that Pulaski had been turned. Operations at other points also were said to be then going on; and a considerable body of troops had started for a destination not made public. The rebels have informed us that Savannah had been captured by our troops. Up to last Tuesday, however, we had not yet taken it, though our forces had got within a very short distance of it from two directions. What may have taken place since then, we shall soon know.

abstract: The costly tribute which the country is daily rendering to the National cause, cannot be counted in contributions to the Treasury. Thousands of loyal lives must be added to make up the fearful aggregate. We read of brilliant victories, and the National heart is made glad. Rejoicings pervade the land.
lead_paragraph: The costly tribute which the country is daily rendering to the National cause, cannot be counted in contributions to the Treasury. Thousands of loyal lives must be added to make up the fearful aggregate. We read of brilliant victories, and the National heart is made glad. Rejoicings pervade the land. With our tears we express sympathy in the sad loss of human life, and we place the names of the dead, and dying, and suffering heroes, on the records of the National gratitude. Having done this, we turn our thoughts to new fields, where victory gives an added lustre to the National Flag.

abstract: The arrival of the ship Black Prince at Ship Island, has revealed another of the outrageous acts of the man who conducts the transportation of men, horses, etc., for the Butler Expedition. The Black Prince lost all but six of the horses she took on board in Boston. There can be no excuse for this piece of villainy. If the Black Prince had been an experiment with Col. GEORGE, and had he been without the means to inform himself with regard to the most approved plan of carrying horses by water, we might find a show of excuse in ignorance. But Col. GEORGE is without even this defense. The ships Kingfisher, Geo. Green and Bullion had preceded the Black Prince, and from each of these he had received the Captain's protest as to the manner in which the horses had been put on board. But he took no heed, and the horses were put on board the Black Prince, under Col. George's directions, in pens holding ten each, and the result we have already seen. Col. GEORGE was told repeatedly, by men well calculated to give advice, that his course was wrong. He cannot be defended even upon the ground that he wanted the ships to take all the horses they could as an economical provision; there is no economy in putting two hundred horses on board a ship, in a crowded condition, without ventilation, when, by taking one-half or one-third the horses, with good ventilation, well secured and well tended, every one could be delivered in good order.
lead_paragraph: The arrival of the ship Black Prince at Ship Island, has revealed another of the outrageous acts of the man who conducts the transportation of men, horses, etc., for the Butler Expedition. abstract: The rebels last Summer went to work might and main, building forts and fortifications at all the important strategic points of what they considered as their frontier. They fortified along the sea-coast, along the Potomac, in Eastern, Central and Western Kentucky, in Central and Western Tennessee, in Missouri, and elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: The rebels last Summer went to work might and main, building forts and fortifications at all the important strategic points of what they considered as their frontier. They fortified along the sea-coast, along the Potomac, in Eastern, Central and Western Kentucky, in Central and Western Tennessee, in Missouri, and elsewhere. The white chivalry worked at fort building, the black slaves toiled at it, and Irish laborers were forced to work at it. The rebels finished their forts, mounted their guns upon them, and, sitting down within them, pronounced them impregnable. About that time our sailors and soldiers were preparing to test their impregnability. Commodore STRINGHAM was the first to open the ball. The rebels had constructed two strong forts at Hatteras and Ocracoke Inlets, to guard the gateway to North Carolina, which, if they were held, would effectually protect the whole coastline of that State from the danger of invasion. But Commodore STRINGHAM went down there with a small squadron, with which he performed that celebrated gyratory movement, which so confounded the rebels that they speedily gave up their forts and themselves to his tender mercies. The South Carolinians, too, had constructed their fortifications at Hilton Head, in the latest and most approved style of the art of fortifying -- so far as was known in South Carolina. Commodore DUPONT's naval gyrations soon gave us possession of these forts, and with them a foothold from which to operate upon any part of South Carolina or Georgia. We next went to work on their inland and river forts and strongholds. ZOLLICOFFER's impregnably fortified position near Somerset was possessed -- rather by adroitness than assault, however. JOHNSTON's unassailable position at Bowling Green was evacuated by him, and is now occupied by our troops, owing, again, to the superior strategy and greater force of our Generals. Fort Henry the rebels had built at the northern gateway to Tennessee, to guard against our entrance into that State; but Commodore FOOTE seized, occupied and possessed it, and took captive its garrison. Fort Donelson was altogether impregnable -- so much so that the rebel Generals risked twenty thousand of their best troops behind its battlements; but, excepting the regiments which FLOYD (the thief) stole away, all of these rebel defenders have now taken up their Summer quarters in the tents of ABRAHAM -- and Fort Donelson is ours. On Roanoke Island, again, the rebels had constructed two forts, Bartow and Blanchard not to speak of Pork Point Battery and other batteries; but, strong as were these posts, they have fallen, and the rebel garrison is now boarding al our expense. The rebels are said to have run away from their fortifications at Clarksville; PRICE has fled from his fortifications at Wilson's Creek; and even at Columbus, the Sebastopol of the West, we begin to sec signs of a rebel evacuation. The fortifications at Manassas are still allowed to rear their rebellious front, as it is doubtless well they should be permitted to do so for some time yet. But everywhere else, and at every important point, our navy and army are making brief work with rebel forts.

abstract: Lieut. Col. GEORGE ANDREWS, Sixth Infantry, U.S.A., who has been placed on the retired list in consequence of incapacity resulting from long and faithful service and exposure in the line of duty, is a native of the District of Columbia and a graduate of West Point.
lead_paragraph: Lieut. Col. GEORGE ANDREWS, Sixth Infantry, U.S.A., who has been placed on the retired list in consequence of incapacity resulting from long and faithful service and exposure in the line of duty, is a native of the District of Columbia and a graduate of West Point. He entered the service on the 1st of July, 1823, as Second Lieutenant, and has held the rank of Lieutenant-Colonel since Oct. 18, 1855. By his retirement, Lieut.-Col. ELECTUS BACKUS, Third Infantry, becomes the Senior Lieutenant-Colonel of Infantry, and therefore the first on the list for Colonel. Brevet Lieut.-Col. JAMES V. BOMFORD, Major of the Sixth Infantry, rises to the full Lieutenant-Colonelcy of that regiment; Capt. GEORGE W. WALLACE, First Infantry, becomes Major in the Sixth, vice BOMFORD, and First Lieut. HERMAN BIGGS takes command of Company G, First Infantry, vice WALLACE.

abstract: diagram and description of Confederate positions at Columbus
snippet: diagram and description of Confederate positions at Columbus
lead_paragraph: A month ago the rebels held three strongly-fortified positions in Kentucky, and two near the southern border line of the same State in Tennessee. Of all these they now hold but one -- that at Columbus, on the Mississippi. This, in fact, is the only stronghold which they retain north of Nashville, and the only fortified position of formidable strength from Cairo to the Belize. It was rumored, a day or two ago, that they were about to abandon this place also, in fear of being cut off by the advances of our troops in its rear; but this was yesterday contradicted, on the authority of one of our scouts, though he added the significant information that fourteen steamers, with steam up, were at the Columbus wharf. Whether the enemy is or is not preparing to flee from a stronghold he has always vaunted as impregnable, the above diagram will come none the less opportune at the present juncture of military affairs in the Southwest.

abstract: For a first attempt, the anniversary of WASHINGTON'S Birthday was very creditably observed in this city. The morning was ushered in by the firing of national salutes in different parts of the city, accompanied by a numerous discharge of fire-arms in the hands of the more youthful of the population...
lead_paragraph: For a first attempt, the anniversary of WASHINGTON'S Birthday was very creditably observed in this city. The morning was ushered in by the firing of national salutes in different parts of the city, accompanied by a numerous discharge of fire-arms in the hands of the more youthful of the population -- reminding one more or Fourth of July than any other occasion -- and these demonstrations were soon followed by a general display of the flag of the Union in all parts of the city. Not a block could be seen but at least one flag was displayed, and on many they were to be counted by dozens. Up to midday a majority of the stores were kept open, but after that time business was very generally suspended, and the after part of the day was passed, by the people, in pretty much the same manner as all other holidays. Some went to church, others found amusement in more exciting pastimes, such as skating, playing ball, &c. The most attractive event of the day was, perhaps, a game of ball played on skates at the Nassau Pond, between the Atlantic Base Ball Club on one side and the Charter Oak and Star Base Ball Clubs on the other. This novelty attracted thousands of our citizens to the spot. Although the ice was not in the best condition imaginable, there was nevertheless some splendid manoeuvring by the players. Unfortunately the affair broke up in a row.

abstract: Editorial on prevalent belief that general amnesty is about to be proclaimed
snippet: Editorial on prevalent belief that general amnesty is about to be proclaimed
lead_paragraph: There seems to be prevalent an apprehension that the war against the rebellion is to have a premature close. Some of our neighbors indicate their fears that a general amnesty is about to be proclaimed, which may have the effect of dissolving the rebel army and of releasing the rebels themselves from the penalties they have incurred. These apprehensions, it seems to us, are groundless. It is by no means impossible that the Administration may deem this a fitting time to reassure the great mass of the Southern people who have been deluded into this rebellion by a studied falsification of the motives of the war on the part of the Government, and to give them to understand that they have nothing to apprehend from the mere vengeance of the Government, and that a prompt return to their allegiance to the Constitution is all that is required at their hands. In this sense, and to this extent, the President may very properly proclaim an amnesty, for the humane purpose of preventing the needless slaughter of thousands of our countrymen. If the proffered terms should be rejected, even the most embittered of the rebels could not say a word against the most vigorous and relentless prosecution of the war.

abstract: The enthusiasm of the day seemed to culminate at the mass meeting, held in Cooper Institute, in the evening, under the auspices of the Union Defence Committee.
lead_paragraph: The enthusiasm of the day seemed to culminate at the mass meeting, held in Cooper Institute, in the evening, under the auspices of the Union Defence Committee. The platform was decorated with the Stars and Stripes, festooned around oil paintings of WASHINGTON, JACKSON, JEFFERSON, and LINCOLN. An excellent band enlivened the proceedings. Soon as the doors were opened, the hall became densely crowded. While awaiting the hour named for opening the exercises, Gen. WETMORE announced that he would encourage them by the information that Gen. SCOTT was in the building. This intelligence was received with a storm of applause, which reached the climax of excitement when the brave veteran made his appearance, leaning on the arm of Ex-Gov. FISH.

abstract: A brief dispatch from Louisville announces that Cumberland Gap and Russellville are in possession of the National forces.
lead_paragraph: A brief dispatch from Louisville announces that Cumberland Gap and Russellville are in possession of the National forces. This is highly important intelligence. Cumberland Gap will undoubtedly be held as a rallying point for the loyal East Tennesseeans, and ultimately as a base of operations against Knoxville. Russelville is situated in Southern Kentucky. It is the capital of Logan County, and is a place of about 3,000 inhabitants. It is located between Cumberland and Green Rivers, about 35 miles from each. The place derives its present importance from the fact that when, a few months ago, the rebels established a Provisional Government for Kentucky, it was selected as the State Capital. A bogus State Legislature has already held one session there, and a bogus Governor (JOHNSON) has been installed in power. A rebel force, 5,000 strong, has been stationed there, until recently, for its protection. All of Kentucky, excepting Columbus, is now clear of rebels.

abstract: At a late hour on Saturday night, the Police of the Tenth Precinct made a descent on a disorderly house kept by THOMAS HUTCHINSON and JOHN CASEY, at No. 93 Houston-street. The proprietors and twenty-four others, male and female, were taken into custody. Yesterday, Justice OSBORNE committed CASEY for trial. HUTCHINSON was held to bail in $1,000; the other parties were discharged.

abstract: The Republican Union Festival, in the evening ormed no insignificant portion of the celebration of WASHINGTON'S Birthday.
lead_paragraph: The Republican Union Festival, in the evening ormed no insignificant portion of the celebration of WASHINGTON's Birthday. About 600 guests sat down to a splendid collation, provided in the best style of Mr. L.F. HARRISON, the inimitable proprietor of Irving Hall. The collation was most bountiful, and received full justice at the hands of the guests. At the main table sat SHERIDAN SHOOK, President of the Republican Central Committee, Dr. Tyng, Dr. Bellows, Dr. Hitchcock, Ex-Judge Peabody, James H. Briggs, G.W. Blunt, William Cullen Bryant, Hon. H.J. Raymond, Joseph Hoxie, Col. Frank Howe, Horace Greeley, Hon. Abiah W. Palmer, Elliot C. Cowdin, and others of equal note. The tables were replete with appropriate emblems, comprising national flags, forts, ships, Union mottoes, and candy monuments, of a patriotic nature. At 8 1/2 o'clock Mr. SHOOK called the assemblage to order, and nominated for President Mr. ELLIOT C. COWDIN, who was unanimously chosen to that office.

abstract: The proceedings of Congress on Friday were very interesting. In the Senate a little routine business was done, when a message was received from the House that the ceremonies incident to the day were about to commence, and the members proceeded in a body to the Hall of Representatives.
lead_paragraph: The proceedings of Congress on Friday were very interesting. In the Senate a little routine business was done, when a message was received from the House that the ceremonies incident to the day were about to commence, and the members proceeded in a body to the Hall of Representatives. In the House, the gallaries set apart for the public were densely crowded. Many persons were unable even to gain admission to the Capitol. After the House was organized, Mr. CRITTENDEN, of Kentucky, in consideration of the fact that the presentation of flags was not contemplated in the joint resolution providing for the celebration, moved that the ceremony be omitted. This gave rise to a long debate as to the propriety of the proposed presentation, which ended in the adoption of Mr. CRITTENDEN's motion, 70 to 61. At this juncture the members of the Senate, headed by the Vice-President, entered, with the heads of Departments, the Judges of the Supreme Court and the representatives of foreign Governments -- officers of the Army and Navy, including Gen. MCCLELLAN, coming last. The ceremonies then commenced with a prayer by Rev. Mr. STOCKTON; after which Col. FORNEY read the Farewell Address, which was listened to with profound attention. The guests then retired, and soon afterward the House adjourned.

abstract: editorial on Confederate flight
snippet: editorial on Confederate flight
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the steamship Niagara at Halifax, we have intelligence from Europe two days later, She left Liverpool on the 8th, and Queenstown on the 9th inst. A great number of documents concerning the civil war in America had been laid before the British Parliament -- one of them being an important letter from Earl RUSSELL to the Southern Commissioners, YANCEY and YOST, declaring that England could not acknowledge the Confederate States until the war or further negotiations more clearly determined their position. Not less than forty-five official communications passed about the National gunboat Tuscarora and the rebel steamer Nashville. The blockade had been denounced as a paper one by Mr. GREGORY, in the House of Commons. The Sumter was detained at Gibraltar from a difficulty in obtaining coal.

abstract: None who have lived in our generation ever beheld a more general and imposing display of popular feeling than was witnessed in this vast City on Saturday. From the peculiarity of the circumstan-
lead_paragraph: None who have lived in our generation ever beheld a more general and imposing display of popular feeling than was witnessed in this vast City on Saturday. From the peculiarity of the circumstances surrounding the occasion, such an impressive and universal demonstration may never occur again. It comprised within itself an epitome of Northern faith and sentiment as represented by the greatest mart of commerce and centre of population in these States. The aspirations of 23,000,000 of souls for their country were distinctly and emphatically made known in the patriotic fervor of the swarming thousands that filled our thoroughfares from early morning until midnight.

abstract: -- Would it not be well for our neighbor of the Herald to give a little more attention to its news of the war? It is falling lamentably behind its leading competitors. We have published on several occasions lately most important intelligence received from our special correspondents, not a word of which has appeared in our neighbor's columns. We had, for example, a few weeks since, six or eight columns of correspondence, giving an account of the experiences of the Burnside Expedition up to the time of its arrival at Roanoke Island, while the Herald had not a single letter. Then, too, we published a very full and graphic description of the capture of the island itself, with the destruction of the rebel fleet, and a full list of the killed and wounded, while our neighbor had nothing at all. And no longer ago than Saturday last, again we published from our special correspondent, "Galway," a detailed and most graphic report of the capture of Fort Donelson, while the Herald had nothing on the subject but a few paragraphs picked up from its Western exchanges.
lead_paragraph: -- Would it not be well for our neighbor of the Herald to give a little more attention to its news of the war? It is falling lamentably behind its leading competitors. Then, too, we published a very full and graphic description of the capture of the island itself, with the destruction of the rebel fleet, and a full list of the killed and wounded, while our neighbor had nothing at all. And no longer ago than Saturday last, again we published from our special correspondent, "Galway," a detailed and most graphic report of the capture of Fort Donelson, while the Herald had nothing on the subject but a few paragraphs picked up from its Western exchanges.

abstract: Dispatches from Washington
snippet: Dispatches from Washington
lead_paragraph: -- Among the documents laid before the British Parliament on the American Civil War is the substance of a conversation between Earl RUSSELL and three of the rebel Commissioners now in England -- YANCEY, ROLF and MANN. The interview was at their request, and unofficial. Earl RUSSELL emphatically declared that Her Majesty's Government could not acknowledge nine or eleven of the United States as an independent or Confederate Power, until the progress of the war, or further negotiations, shall more clearly determine their position.

abstract: -- We observe that the Common Council is taking steps to bring its potent influence, moral and municipal, to bear upon the Legislature to prevent amendments of the City Charter. It may not be out of the way for us to offer that body a little advice. Teaching Aldermen and Councilmen how to "lobby" may seem like "teaching one's grandmother to suck eggs;" and yet it is barely possible we may be able to give them a hint or two of some value.
lead_paragraph: -- We observe that the Common Council is taking steps to bring its potent influence, moral and municipal, to bear upon the Legislature to prevent amendments of the City Charter. abstract: Through the Louisville papers we have the particulars of the rebel evacuation of Bowling Green, on the approach of MITCHELL'S column of Gen. BUELL's Division.
lead_paragraph: Through the Louisville papers we have the particulars of the rebel evacuation of Bowling Green, on the approach of MITCHELL's column of Gen. BUELL's Division. These accounts on the authority of an eye-witness, enable us to judge the actual numbers and disposition of the rebel forces at and from that point. Whether or not this will afford a reliable key to the probable force left for the defence of Nashville, should the retreating army make a stand at that city, we are scarcely prepared to say. But there is no difficulty in determining the strength (or rather, we should perhaps say, the weakness,) of the rebel situation, so far as the force recently in Southern Kentucky is concerned.

abstract: Editorial on Congress refusal to receive captured Confederate flags at Washington birthday ceremonies, Capitol
snippet: Editorial on Congress refusal to receive captured Confederate flags at Washington birthday ceremonies, Capitol
lead_paragraph: Among the solemnities set down in the programme for the celebration of WASHINGTON'S Birthday at the Capitol, it was appointed that, after the reading of the Farewell Address, the flags captured from the rebel armies would be presented from the Army and Navy Departments to Congress. On the assembling on the House, however, Mr. CRITTENDEN, the noble old patriot of Kentucky, moved that this part of the ceremonies should be omitted, and after a brief yet interesting discussion, the suggestion was adopted, though by a vote -- seventy assenting against sixty-one dissenting voices -- which strikingly illustrates how easily men arrive at divergent judgments by regarding a subject from opposite points of view. While the presentation of the rebel flags was looked upon simply as a transient formality, designed to lend eclat to the proceedings of the day, and while the insignia themselves were viewed merely as "trophies won by our brave soldiers in hotly contested battle," as a member phrased it, the ceremony was not only unobjectionable, but well fitted to add to the pomp and circumstance of the occasion. It was these considerations, doubtless, that prompted a large number of members to favor the presentation, though the animus apparent in the remarks of Mr. LOVEJOY, would lead one to conclude that the recalcitrant Representative from Illinois was inspired by some more sinister motive.

abstract: A northwest gale of great severity prevailed in this City and over a large extent of country last night, and in some localities did a great deal of damage. Many vessels in the harbor dragged their anchors, and some sustained considerable injuries from chafing, but we have heard of no very serious casualties among them. In Brooklyn the damage was greater than in this City. A portion of the roof of the City Hospital was blown off, andother buildings in exposed situations were more or less injured. In Washington, too, the gale was unusually severe, and several buildings were [???] Telegraphing was much interfered with -- all the direct lines to the West being cut off, and only one line working to the South.

abstract: Confederate press observations on recent defeats and current affairs
snippet: Confederate press observations on recent defeats and current affairs
lead_paragraph: After three days of the most desperate fighting ever witnessed on this continent, (so declares a veteran regular officer,) the most desperate fighting against the most tremendous odds, in which day after day the multitudinous host of invaders were driven back past their own camps, our glorious Spartan band, from sheer exhaustion, has been borne down by a new avalanche of reinforcements piled upon the already enormous weight against which they have hitherto struggled with complete success, and has suffered one of those misfortunes which are common to war, but which entail no dishonor on our cause, and which will only animate to the most stern and undying resistance every true Southern heart.

abstract: We publish this morning the gratifying announcement that Colonels WOOD, LEE, and COGSWELL, together with a number of others lately held as prisoners in the rebel States, have been released, and yesterday arrived in Baltimore from Fortress Monroe. They bring with them important intelligence from the rebels, which is given in our dispatches.
lead_paragraph: We publish this morning the gratifying announcement that Colonels WOOD, LEE, and COGSWELL, together with a number of others lately held as prisoners in the rebel States, have been released, and yesterday arrived in Baltimore from Fortress Monroe. They bring with them important intelligence from the rebels, which is given in our dispatches. Col. LEE states, on the authority of a distinguished officer of the rebel Government, that official dispatches had been received in Richmond announcing the fall of Nashville. There appears to be little doubt that that important City is now in our possession, and that we thus now have command of all the railroad lines communicating with the great Southwest, from which so large a share of the rebel supplies have teen drawn. Col. WOOD was allowed the privilege of witnessing the ceremonies incident to the inauguration of JEFF. DAVIS on Saturday, and according to his representations it must have been a [???] spectacle. No enthusiasm was manifested on the occasion, and hardly a cheer was raised. On Friday, the day preceding the inauguration, the Richmond Whig published a bitter article against the Davis Administration, in which it was denounced as the most lamentable [???] in history, and declared in advance that the inauguration pageant would be a bitter mockery, and miserable compensation for the ruin of a free people.

abstract: By the capture of Nashville, we obtain possession of the largest city in the rebel States which has yet been occupied by our troops. Nashville, the capital of the State of Tennessee, is a city of 30,000 inhabitants. It is situated on the Cumberland River 200 miles (following the windings of the stream) above its junction with the Ohio. The city is built chiefly on the south side of the river'
lead_paragraph: By the capture of Nashville, we obtain possession of the largest city in the rebel States which has yet been occupied by our troops. Nashville, the capital of the State of Tennessee, is a city of 30,000 inhabitants. It is situated on the Cumberland River 200 miles (following the windings of the stream) above its junction with the Ohio. The city is built chiefly on the south side of the river' on the slopes, and at the foot of a hill rising from it It stands upon a solid rock, elevated to the height of from 50 to 175 feet above the level of the stream. It is a place of great trade, and is an important railroad centre. There are five railroads radiating from the city, namely: the Tennessee and Alabama, the Louisville and Nashville, the Edgefield and Kentucky' the Nashville and Chattanooga, and the Nashville and Northwestern. Steamboats and gunboats ascend from the mouth of the Cumberland to Nashville, and the river is navigable by boats of 1,500 tons for 50 miles above the city, and by smaller boats to the Falls, 500 miles.

abstract: A fight occurred on White Oak Creek, in Campbell County, near Boston, on the 22d of January, of which Capt. ROBINSON, who commanded the expedition, gives us the following particulars: The Lincolnites had about 200 men, while we had only about 40 being a part of Capt. ROBINSON'S company and a part of a company of Minute Men under Capt. RICHARDSON.
lead_paragraph: A fight occurred on White Oak Creek, in Campbell County, near Boston, on the 22d of January, of which Capt. ROBINSON, who commanded the expedition, gives us the following particulars: The Lincolnites had about 200 men, while we had only about 40 -- being a part of Capt. ROBINSON'S company and a part of a company of Minute Men under Capt. RICHARDSON. Our little force made three distinct charges on the enemy, and drove them from their position each time. The enemy lost about eight or ten killed, and five or six wounded. One of Capt. RICHARDSON's men was shot through the right hand and left arm, which was the only casualty on our side.

abstract: SALE OF A CONFISCATED CARGO The entire cargo of the prize brig Sarah Starr, consisting of turpentine, resin and beeswax, was sold at auction, yesterday, at the Phenix Yard, Brooklyn, by WHITTEMORE HAZEL, under the orders of the United States Prize Commissioner.
lead_paragraph: SALE OF A CONFISCATED CARGO -- The entire cargo of the prize brig Sarah Starr, consisting of turpentine, resin and beeswax, was sold at auction, yesterday, at the Phenix Yard, Brooklyn, by WHITTEMORE HAZEL, under the orders of the United States Prize Commissioner. The purchasers were mostly from this City and Philadelphia. The following is the result of the sale; 1,128 barrels spirits if turpentine, at an average price of $1 10; 63 barrels colored turpentine, at an average price of $1 11, the entire range for this article having been $1 07@$1 15 per gallon; 140 bbls. Crude Turpentine, at $7 27 1/2 per 280 lbs.; 420 barrels resin, at an average price of $8 per 280 lb., 287 lbs. of beeswax, at an average price of 34 cents per pound; 1 box of assorted hardware for $6 50. Total amount realized by the sale, $22,898 16.

abstract: -- M. HAUTEFEUILLE, the leading French authority on international law, publishes in the present number of the Revue Contemporaine a very remarkable paper on the rights of neutrals, that is noticeable for its hostile tone toward England, which he accuses of arbitrarily taking her own interests as the supreme law. He urges the meeting of a Congress to settle the rights of belligerents at sea, and the formation of a league of armed neutrality, to protect the commerce of neutrals in the event of a maritime war. His plan is to form a coalition of armed neutrality, similar to those of 1669 and 1780, of which France is to be the head. Around her, he urges, will flock all other naval nations, which, thus united, will form an aggregate sufficiently formidable to counterbalance the naval superiority of any belligerents. The maritime equilibrium so important for the repose and freedom of the world, will thus be established. Formed in anticipation of war, it will subsist in time of peace, and become a lasting element in the international relations of civilized peoples. England, he reasons, could not, more than any other nation, take offence at the formation of the league of armed neutrality. If she intends to respect the general law of nations, the union of neutrals cannot, he thinks, give her the slightest umbrage. The association cannot, and will not require anything but the strict fulfillment of the well-known duties of belligerents -- of the rules of international jurisprudence. In the event of meeting with unjust pretensions on the part of any nation, it would be an additional reason for the union of all isolated forces against the common enemy.
lead_paragraph: -- M. abstract: Miss Emma HARDINGE, whose efforts in behalf of the wretched female outcasts that throng the streets of our cities by night, lectured last evening in DODWORTH'S Hall, on Broadway, to a large and respectable audience, comprising some of our most eminent citizens, many of whom were accompanied by the ladies of their families.
lead_paragraph: Miss Emma HARDINGE, whose efforts in behalf of the wretched female outcasts that throng the streets of our cities by night, lectured last evening in DODWORTH'S Hall, on Broadway, to a large and respectable audience, comprising some of our most eminent citizens, many of whom were accompanied by the ladies of their families. With rare pathos and eloquence, she appealed to the benevolent in behalf of the truly great and good work of attempting to reclaim and save some proportion, at least, of the unfortunates who, in consummating their own ruin among us, infect the atmosphere we breathe, and endanger the peace and safety of our own homes.

abstract: A large audience assembled at the Hall of the Historical Society, last evening, for the purpose of listening to a lecture by Rev. C.M. BUTLER, on "The City of Washington during the Rebellion." The lecturer was introduced by the President of the Society, Hon. LUTHER BRADISH, and after some few...
lead_paragraph: A large audience assembled at the Hall of the Historical Society, last evening, for the purpose of listening to a lecture by Rev. C.M. BUTLER, on "The City of Washington during the Rebellion." The lecturer was introduced by the President of the Society, Hon. LUTHER BRADISH, and after some few preliminary remarks, commenced his topic by a general allusion to the traitors of our country. The question had occurred whether the rebellion would have taken place if Washington was situated on the Delaware, instead of the Potomac. A controlling influence at the Capital favored a growth of the conspiracies. Bold and defiant treason was uttered in the Halls of Congress. TOOMBS, WIGFALL, MASON, IVERSON, BENJAMIN, SLIDELL, HUNTER and DAVIS, the master-spirit of them all, made the Senate ring with their treasonable language. The spirit of concession and of moderation exhibited by the Northern members was deemed cowardice and weakness by the traitors. The lecturer often wished while sitting in the Senate Chamber and listening to them, that some master-spirit would rise to rebuke and crush its design. If WEBSTER had been there perhaps this rebellion might have been averted, but Providence had his own ways to perform. "In revolution," says MIRABEAU, "audacity is needed for success." NAPOLEON made rebellion know that it had its master when he charged upon the conspirators before the Tuileries. The lecturer reviewed the last days of the Administration of BUCHANAN, and the traitorous schemes of BENJAMIN. When the brutal TOOMBS closed his last speech in Congress he said he was about to go into the war with a torch in one hand and a sword in the other. Referring to the attempt to destroy the City of Washington, the speaker was positive that before the fall of Sumter, organizations were formed in the very city itself for its total destruction. Mr. HOLT received a glowing encomium in the course of the address, for his fervent patriotism and steadfastness of purpose. Mr. HOLT had thus far proved more than equal for all the demands made upon him. He had stood alone and guided the helm of the old ship. After the fall of Sumter, secession began to take a conspicuous form at the Capital; and why the city was not taken by the traitors at that time could not be easily accounted for. After the proclamation calling for 75,000 men had been issued there was great anxiety for them to appear. As a Massachusetts regiment was marching through the city he was struck with their youthful and almost defenceless appearance. This silent column looked as though they were going into a great white tomb as they passed into the Capitol. It was expected every moment that they would be overwhelmed with myriads of armed traitors, and the city be destroyed. The following day was gloomy enough. Confusion and consternation seized upon the Union men, and confidence was not secured until regiment after regiment had been encamped in their midst. Just before the Seventh New-York Regiment arrived, an anxious suspense pervaded all loyal men. A battery on Arlington Heights then could have easily taken Washington.

abstract: Sylvester Cahill et al. vs. Henry D. Felter. -- This was an action to compel the defendant specifially to perform a contract made as alleged between him and the plaintiffs, to take a lease of the house No. 76 Prince-street, in this City. The contract was made in May, 1859. The defendant had just previously leased No. 560 Broadway from the plaintiffs, for nineteen years, from May 1, 1859. By the contract he was to have a lease of the house in Prince-street upon the same covenants and provisions as the one in Broadway, except the rent in Prince-street, was $2,000 per annum, and the term was to be "from May 1, 1861." The lease was to be executed in duplicates within ten days after the contract was executed. A few days afterwards the plaintiffs, by an arrangement between them and defendant, had a lease prepared and submitted the same to the defendant for his examination, and, if correct, to be executed. The plaintiffs testified on the trial that defendant never executed or returned it. The defendant testified that he returned it, but did not state any objection to it. Two leases at different times were subsequently prepared by the plaintiffs, but defendant refused to execute them.

abstract: Capt. NICHOLS, of the Petersburgh Artillery, arrived here this afternoon from Winton, where he had been stationed with a battery. On yesternay he was shelled out by the Yankees. They had seven steamers, all of which had passed up the river. Capt. NICHOLS had a horse shot from under him. Two of his men were wounded. The town of Winton is in ashes. Our troops retreat to Murfreesborough."

abstract: remarkable letter from the Secretary of War, which we published lately, very properly ascribes the merit of the several victories which have latterly gladdened the popular heart to the generalship of the leaders and the gallantry of the soldiers who won them. This is, of course, just, but a much more prompt and manly dispensation of justice than the public is used to. There were those occupying prominent positions in the Government last Summer, who are reputed to have urged a vote of censure against the brave LYON, because, by his rapidity in advance of orders, he was forestalling a credit and popularity resulting from success which should properly belong to the authorities at Washington. To have exercised this demon of jealousy is a wholesome victory in itself. The Administration can now well afford to recognize and reward merit wherever it is earned.

abstract: Refugees from North Carolina, and even from Norfolk, have been arriving in this city for several days past in considerable numbers. On Sunday, some six or eight wagons, filled with negroes and their effects, belonging to the City of Edenton, who have been compelled to flee for safety from that place, reached Brandford. We presume that there must have been at least fifty negroes with these wagons. We have also seen and conversed with several refugees from Elizabeth City, and other points on the coast of North Carolina.

abstract: editorials on need for improved system
snippet: editorials on need for improved system
lead_paragraph: A bill has just been introduced in Congress, by Hon. JOHN HUTCHINS, of Ohio, to effect some improvements in our postal system. We either have a very inconvenient and imperfect Post-office, or the American public are a difficult people to please, and find fault without just cause. To believe in the latter alternative, is evidently absurd. It may be useless to attempt to look into the causes of our unsatisfactory postal arrangements, but wherever the cause may lie, the facts are not creditable to us as a thrifty, ingenious, enterprising and intelligent people. Once in four years a new Postmaster-General comes into office, and he is usually as ignorant of the details of the Post-office, as a hardware merchant is of the qualities of bottled beer. He usually -- we speak of the past record of several of the late incumbents of that office -- sets up a violent opposition to any postal bill that he did not draft with his own hand. And those bills that have been concocted by the head of the Department have usually been unfortunately conspicuous for their inconvenient, undesirable features. A late Postmaster-General procured the passage of the compulsory prepayment enactment, whereby millions of valuable and important letters have been detained and destroyed, to the great loss, suffering and business inconvenience of innocent citizens. Prepayment is good, and every inducement should be used to persuade and make the public prepay their letters, but when there is forgetfulness of payment, loss of the stamp, or theft of the postage-money by a dishonest servant, to have the letter detained or destroyed in consequence of accidental circumstances, is simply atrocious. Every city Postmaster in office sees daily evidences of the cruelty of this compulsory law, and yet no Postmaster-General has, since its passage, made any comment or recommendation respecting it, except to scold the public for their willful disobedience of the law. Pray, may we ask, must people suffer all the inconvenience of the failure and stoppage of important business letters, without any fault whatever -- where a stamp falls off, a dishonest or careless boy neglects to put one on, or even if the prepayment is forgotten? We have heard of one well-authenticated case, where a witness' testimony failed from this circumstance -- the seizure and stoppage of a letter because it was not prepaid -- and the witness dying soon after, a defendant in a lawsuit lost his cause and an estate worth $30,000, in consequence. Then, too, see the wretched circumlocution, false economy, useless labor and loss of time attendant upon the miserable patching which such a foolish postal law requires. A letter is found in a Post-office box without a stamp -- as several score are every day found in the New-York Post-office -- and forthwith a clerk is set to work to send a letter -- part printed and part written -- to the person to whom such letter is addressed, informing him of the missive held in quarantine, and that if he will write for it, prepay his postage, and send a stamp of the value of three cents, the epistolary prisoner shall be released, and sent along to glad the heart of the recipient. He writes, and his letter is forwarded. Here two letters are prepared and sent, at an expense of time, paper and ink, and three have to be transported, and for this two postages, or six cents, have been received by the Post-office. The full sum of six cents might have been obtained by simply forwarding the letter in the first place, subject to a double charge for postage, and all without any expense of useless correspondence, any transportation or delivery of two useless letters, and with no inconvenience, delay or loss to either party. Really, we are a great people, and have a vast amount of wisdom at Washington, when such a law disgraces our statute books, simply because one man stupid enough to make it happened unfortunately to be in power.
headline: {'main': 'Wanted A Good Postal System', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Wanted A Good Postal System', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Yankee nation, elevated by the recent victories of its hireling armies, is entirely certain of the speedy and thorough subjugation of the South. It laughs to scorn any idea of any other possibility, and exults in delicious day-dreams of the degradation to which its enemy will be reduced. It glories in the consciousness of its brute strength, and intends to exercise it in the spirit of a brute.
lead_paragraph: From the Richmond Dispatch.

abstract: It was reported here last night that a light of a most desperate character was going on at Fort Donelson, about 12,000 on each side engaged; but as yet it is not confirmed. Gen. abstract: The general impression is that Columbus is being evacuated is virtually ours, and will be actually ours by the 22d; that Clarksville, as well as Russellville, is abandoned; that Nashville will in a day or two be taken, without much or any struggle, by Gens. GRANT and BUELL and Commodore FOOTE; and that all Tennessee will, in a fortnight or less, be rescued, without another battle, unless at or near Memphis.

abstract: -- If the solemn farce of inauguration at Richmond, which desecrated the Birthday of WASHINGTON, had been suddenly arrested by the appearance of a National army, we doubt whether the dismay and grief of the chief participants would have been greater than they really were, on the occasion, by the bursting of the storm from another quarter. It seems altogether probable that at the very hour appointed for the "ceremonies," the President-elect was apprised by telegraph or the occupation of the Capital of Tennessee by Gen. BUELL's forced, and the disbanding of the rebel troops throughout that important department of the so-called Confederacy. His game, for a permanent Government, was up before it was fairly entered upon. His control, his power, and all but the empty shadow of authority were struck down the day before they were to throw off their provisional character. Even the Richmond Press could not be kept longer in subjection, for this single day, if only for the eclat of the thing. The affair came off shabbily, after all. The sublimity of the bursting storm was lost upon the scene, because of the indecorous taunts of the Richmond Whig that the whole pageant of the morrow was to be "a bitter mockery and a miserable compensation for the ruin of a free people!" "An old man with a young wife -- a child with a bauble," (adds that disenthralled and disenchanted journal,) "are partial illustrations of the deplorable folly." The funeral baked meats coldly furnished forth the marriage feast, and after this mockery came the impious proclamation of fasting and prayer!

The sublimity of the bursting storm was lost upon the scene, because of the indecorous taunts of the Richmond Whig that the whole pageant of the morrow was to be "a bitter mockery and a miserable compensation for the ruin of a free people!" abstract: -- The Richmond journals, in reporting the capture of Winton last Thursday, by a detachment of BURNSIDE's command, affirm that the "Yankees landed and burnt the town." Everybody at the North will immediately recognize that the statement, in its latter part is a lie on its face. Such falsehoods are manufactured -- the only branch of manufactures that prospers with the Confederates -- by the wholesale at Richmond, under the immediate eye of the rebel authorities.

abstract: A dense fog set in on Sunday night, about 11 o'clock, which continued up to noon yesterday. In the morning a light wind blew from the southwest with frequent showers of rain. Twenty-four sail of square-rigged vessels were at anchor in the North River, outward bound, many of which had been de- tained by the prevailing easterly winds over a week.
lead_paragraph: A dense fog set in on Sunday night, about 11 o'clock, which continued up to noon yesterday. In the morning a light wind blew from the southwest with frequent showers of rain. Twenty-four sail of square-rigged vessels were at anchor in the North River, outward bound, many of which had been de- tained by the prevailing easterly winds over a week. At 3 P.M., the wind shifted, and blew a gale from the northwest, causing all the vessels in the North River to drag their anchors. The United States frigate St. Lawrence drifted down nearly to the Battery enlargement. The British brig Cora Mulgrave, lying at pier No. 14, North River, was badly chafed. A steamtug went to her assistance, but could render none on account of the high sea.

abstract: Our latest information from Nashville this morning comes through Richmond. Col. LEE, of Massachusetts, a returned prisoner, who reached Fortress Monroe on Sunday, reports that a rebel officer of distinction at Richmond told him on Saturday afternoon, as he was about to leave for home, that official...
lead_paragraph: Our latest information from Nashville this morning comes through Richmond. Col. LEE, of Massachusetts, a returned prisoner, who reached Fortress Monroe on Sunday, reports that a rebel officer of distinction at Richmond told him on Saturday afternoon, as he was about to leave for home, that official information had been received of the surrender of the city of Nashville to the National forces. We see no reason to discredit this report, certainly none in the high character of our Fortress Monroe informant. And, independent of his news, we have had for a day information of the movements of the National divisions of BUELL and HALLECK, and of the state of popular sentiment at Clarksville and Nashville, confirmatory of the extreme probability of the peaceable occupation of the city, on the arrival of either or part of both divisions. Gen. MITCHELL's column passed rapidly on from Bowling Green, and was within thirty miles of Nashville as early as Tuesday last. Several of FOOTE's gunboats were at Clarksville on Friday, when the Cumberland was rising fast, and there would be no difficulty in making Nashville in a few hours, the distance by water being but sixty miles. A special dispatch to the Cincinnati Gazette, dated from Cairo on Thursday, states that white flags were flying at Nashville as well as Clarksville, and that Gen. GRANT had been invited to occupy both places. Another account represents that the citizens had protested warmly against the destruction of the railroad, on the north side of the river, or the valuable bridges at Nashville.

abstract: doubt that the great rebel victory in Arkansas of which ALBERT PIKE telegraphs to JEFF. DAVIS, is the affair of the 18th at Sugar Creek, concerning which Gen. HALLECK sent a brief report five days ago. It appears that PRICE, on his last retreat from Springfield, took the Southwestern road, (the United States Mail route,) and fled toward the Ozark Mountains and the Indian Territory. On his way he was reinforced by five thousand of the rebels lately under BEN. MCCULLOCH, and, if ALBERT PIKE was at the fight, probably also by some Indian rebels. He continued in his retreat, however, until he got as far as the Sugar Creek crossing, in Benton County, Arkansas, where he was overtaken by the pursuing column under Gen. CURTIS, and according to Gen. HALLOEK's official dispatch, was defeated, and again started on his flight, away among the mountains. An evidence of the rout is, that many of the rebels were taken prisoners, and many of the arms which they threw away in their flight were taken by our men. PIKE, on the other hand, gives no details of the action, but simply says that in it the Nationals lost seven hundred men and the rebels one hundred; and he closes with the announcement: "We have gained another great victory." Probably they have gained another victory of the kind of which they have been enjoying so many lately -- one of the style of which BUCKNER boasted at Donelson when he surrendered unconditionally all his men, with the remark that the "Confederate arms had achieved a brilliant success." We shall, doubtless, receive the official report of the action from Gen. CURTIS in a day or two. In the meantime, if PRICE and PIKE did triumph so remarkably, it is somewhat singular that they still continue flying southward with all their might.

abstract: The northwesterly gale commenced in this city at about 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, and continued with great violence until a late hour in the night. Some slight damage was done to the shipping along the docks, but it was more serious in its effects upon buildings in exposed situations. At a little before 5 o'clock, one-half of the roof of the northerly wing of the City Hospital was taken up by the wind, carried completely over the chimneys without disturbing a brick, and landed near the Canton-street fence, at the rear of the Hospital, a distance of about 150 feet. It was only by immediate attention that the rest of the roof on that wing was prevented from going in the same direction. The portion of the roof blown off is about 60 by 25 feet. A large number of houses on Flushing, Myrtle and Fulton avenues, were more or less injured, but so far as heard no lives were lost. Trees, chimney tops, awnings and window blinds were blown in every direction.

lead_paragraph: The Tribune indorses Senator SUMNER'S plan for carrying on the Government after the rebellion shall lave been crushed. That plan is simply to abolish every Slaveholding State that las seceded, and to organize the soil of them all as Territories, to be governed by appointment from Washington. The Tribune thinks that "timid, conservative minds" may shrink from a policy which "must strike many readers as very radical," but that a every stage of the struggle "the policy of Senator SUMNER's view is equally clear and decisive."

abstract: The English statesmen, whether Ministerial or Opposition, who have taken ground in Parliament against the recognition of a separate Southern power in this country, will certainly find no reason to regret their well considered prudence in the inaugural of Mr. DAVIS.
lead_paragraph: The English statesmen, whether Ministerial or Opposition, who have taken ground in Parliament against the recognition of a separate Southern power in this country, will certainly find no reason to regret their well considered prudence in the inaugural of Mr. DAVIS. They will rather rejoice that such a shadow of Government as by his own confession he would have the world recognize in a mere league of insurrectionary States, has been denied all present official consideration if not all hope of future place among the acknowledged Powers of this Continent. While speaking of the Union from which he is endeavoring to separate himself, as a voluntary union of sovereign States, instituted by the fathers of the Constitution, the implication is that he would have the new league of the South rest upon the complete sovereignty of the several States, which States shall be left free to come and go at will. To make this implication the plainer, he dwells in a subsequent paragraph upon the voluntary nature of this association of Confederated States, and with a strange perversion or misapplication of terms, speaks of the conservatism of a Constitutional Government. Nor is this all. The very nature of this voluntary association of sovereignties is urged upon the world as the best security against foreign wars and the most infallible guard against civil strife.

abstract: Edward Gould vs. William Mesick. This action was brought to recover the sum of $1,758, for merchandise sold by the firm of Rushmore, Cone Co., of this City, to the defendant. Rushmore Cone Co. assigned their claim to the plaintiff.
lead_paragraph: Edward Gould vs. William Mesick. -- This action was brought to recover the sum of $1,758, for merchandise sold by the firm of Rushmore, Cone & Co., of this City, to the defendant. Rushmore Cone & Co. assigned their claim to the plaintiff. The defence set up is that the goods were warranted by Rushmore, Cone & Co., and that they proved to be of inferior quality, and were subsequently sold by the defendant at a great loss. The defendant claims a set-off for the damage he sustained.

abstract: In this Court, yesterday, before Recorder HOFFMAN, Anne M. Jennings, a German girl, 18 years of age, was tried for a felonious assault upon Gerhart Kieselhaus, and acquitted. It appeared that the complainant, Kieselhans, called at the premises of the prisoner's mother and behaved in a very rude and insulting manner toward the prisoner, whereupon he was ejected from the premises by the mother.
lead_paragraph: In this Court, yesterday, before Recorder HOFFMAN, Anne M. Jennings, a German girl, 18 years of age, was tried for a felonious assault upon Gerhart Kieselhaus, and acquitted. It appeared that the complainant, Kieselhans, called at the premises of the prisoner's mother and behaved in a very rude and insulting manner toward the prisoner, whereupon he was ejected from the premises by the mother. He immediately returned and attacked the mother, whom he threw upon the floor, and as he was in the act of striking her the daughter stabbed him in the back with a dagger. On learning the facts of the case from the witnesses, the District-Attorney immediately abandoned the prosecution, and the jury were directed to bring in a verdict of acquittal.

abstract: The Conference Committee on the Treasury Note bill made a report, on Monday, recommending that both Houses of Congress recede from a portion of their amendments. The report was concurred in by both Houses, and the bill passed. In the Senate, yesterday, however, the vote to agree with the report of the Committee being reconsidered, was disagreed to, and the bill was recommended to the Conference Committee. A petition was presented, asking that J.C. FREMONT be appointed Lieutenant-General. A resolution to carry into effect the Convention with New-Granada and Costa Rica, was passed. A resolution was passed asking the Secretary of War whether any steps had been taken toward the construction of any railroad by the War Department, and the authority for it. The bill for the occupation and cultivation of certain cotton lands was taken up and an amendment limiting the appropriation to $20,000, was adopted. It was then made the special order for to-day. The bill for the confiscation of the property of rebels was considered, the special order -- the case of Mr. STARKE of Oregon -- being postponed to make way for it. Mr. TRUMBULL addressed the Senate in favor of its passage.
lead_paragraph: The Conference Committee on the Treasury Note bill made a report, on Monday, recommending that both Houses of Congress recede from a portion of their amendments. The bill for the occupation and cultivation of certain cotton lands was taken up and an amendment limiting the appropriation to $20,000, was adopted. It was then made the special order for to-day. The bill for the confiscation of the property of rebels was considered, the special order -- the case of Mr. STARKE of Oregon -- being postponed to make way for it. Mr. TRUMBULL addressed the Senate in favor of its passage.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN, A straw tossed in the air shows the direction of the wind, and an incident in so humble a sphere as that of the drama frequently determines the current of public opinion. Some months since Mrs. SROWE'S "uncle Tom's Cabin" was revived in Philadelphia after a long and uneasy slumber. It was an experiment based solely on the presumptive temper of the times; a thing that had to fail utterly or succeed enormously.
lead_paragraph: WINTER GARDEN. -- A straw tossed in the air shows the direction of the wind, and an incident in so humble a sphere as that of the drama frequently determines the current of public opinion. Some months since Mrs. SROWE'S "uncle Tom's Cabin" was revived in Philadelphia after a long and uneasy slumber. It was an experiment based solely on the presumptive temper of the times; a thing that had to fail utterly or succeed enormously. In dramas of the political kind there is no medium; they are either accepted or damned at once. The Philadelphians recorded anew their verdict for the doctrines of Mrs. STOWE, and "Uncle Tom" was a prodigious success. Hence, a Metropolitan hazard in the same direction. The management of the Winter Garden produced the play last night, and we hear already of two or three other establishments in the City that are likely to follow suit.

abstract: The iron-clad war-steamer, built at Mystic Conn., was recently launched, and now lies at Greenpoint, where she will receive her armament and be prepared for sea. She has nearly all her armor, and her engines are finished and partly in. It is expected she will be ready for service in one month from the present time. Her length is 200 feet over all, breadth 37 feet, and depth of hold 12 1/2 feet. Her entire capacity is 1,000 tons.

abstract: On Saturday evening, the anniversary of WASHINGTON's Birthday, DENNIS MCCABE, member of Assembly, was presented with a handsome gold watch and chain valued at $500. Mr. CHARLES SPENCER made the presentation in a neat, effective, and eulogistic address. Mr. MCCABE responded in a brief speech wherein he thanked the donors for their most magnificent gift. After which, all present adjourned to the supper-room, where a superb repast was provided. Jokes were cracked, and so were plenty of bottles of wine, and the whole affair was one of a most social and pleasing nature. At the conclusion of supper speecheswere made by Messrs. DE CAMP, N. BABCOCK, M.D. SWARTS, LUDEZ, HERRICK, MAGUIRE, BANNAM, WAUDS, and others. The Star-Spangled Banner was then sung, in which the whole of the company joined. Previous to supper, letters were received and read from ROBERT T. HAWES, Comptroller, RICHARD DARLING, President of the Harlem Railroad, and other prominent citizens, excusing themselves, and expressing regret at being unable to be present. The festivities were prolonged until a late hour. Messrs. LARRY HARVEY, J.W.F. VAN RIPER, M.H. DE CAMP, JOHN COOPER, Jr., and ROBERT HURNEST formed the Committee of Arrangements.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday evening, the anniversary of WASHINGTON's Birthday, DENNIS MCCABE, member of Assembly, was presented with a handsome gold watch and chain valued at $500. Mr. CHARLES SPENCER made the presentation in a neat, effective, and eulogistic address. Mr. MCCABE responded in a brief speech wherein he thanked the donors for their most magnificent gift. After which, all present adjourned to the supper-room, where a superb repast was provided. Jokes were cracked, and so were plenty of bottles of wine, and the whole affair was one of a most social and pleasing nature. At the conclusion of supper speecheswere made by Messrs. DE CAMP, N. BABCOCK, M.D. SWARTS, LUDEZ, HERRICK, MAGUIRE, BANNAM, WAUDS, and others. The Star-Spangled Banner was then sung, in which the whole of the company joined. Previous to supper, letters were received and read from ROBERT T. HAWES, Comptroller, RICHARD DARLING, President of the Harlem Railroad, and other prominent citizens, excusing themselves, and expressing regret at being unable to be present. The festivities were prolonged until a late hour. Messrs. LARRY HARVEY, J.W.F. VAN RIPER, M.H. DE CAMP, JOHN COOPER, Jr., and ROBERT HURNEST formed the Committee of Arrangements.

abstract: FELLOW-CITIZENS: On this the birthday of the man most identified with the establishment of American independence, and beneath the monument ejected to commemorate his heroic virtues and those of his compatriots, we have assembled to usher into....
lead_paragraph: FELLOW-CITIZENS: On this the birthday of the man most identified with the establishment of American independence, and beneath the monument ejected to commemorate his heroic virtues and those of his compatriots, we have assembled to usher into existence the permanent Government of the Confederate States. Through this instrumentality, under the favor of Divine Providence, we hope to perpetuate the principles of our Revolutionary fathers. The day, the memory and the purpose seem fitly associated.

abstract: The Electoral College has not yet decided the question as to who is to succeed CASTILLA as President of Peru. No doubt exists that Gen. SAN ROMAN has received the majority of votes; but no better evidence is needed that an election in Peru is a farce, than the fact that the people and newspapers are discussing the question as to who ought to be declared President, just as if no choice had been made by ballot. Although the constitution does not allow a President to succeed himself, a movement is making to continue CASTILLA in power; but his friends contend that it is a slander on him to suppose he would violate the organic law by continuing at the head of the country. The new President is not inaugurated till October.

The new President is not inaugurated till October.

abstract: The auspices under which Mr. JEFF. DAVIS delivered his Inaugural on last Saturday, were certainly gloomy enough for him and his socalled Government. His throne, ere it had been well set up, was tottering to its base; the ground was sliding from under his feet; the air was thick with ill omens, and the lightning brought him messages of disaster by every wire.
lead_paragraph: The auspices under which Mr. JEFF. DAVIS delivered his Inaugural on last Saturday, were certainly gloomy enough for him and his socalled Government. His throne, ere it had been well set up, was tottering to its base; the ground was sliding from under his feet; the air was thick with ill omens, and the lightning brought him messages of disaster by every wire. In the West, his armies had just been routed and taken captive; his strongholds had fallen, and one-fifth of his dominion had just been wrested from his clutch. In the South he could almost see the advancing bayonets of his foes. Along the coast line, at twenty points, his enemies were penetrating into his kingdom, and their cannon were at the gateways of every one of his critics. In his front he beheld a host, sufficiently great to annihilate him and every vestige of his power, about to be hurled against him. From across the seas there was no word or sign of hope; those on whom he had relied he now found but mocked at his calamity, and laughed at his fears. Even they of his own household welcomed the flag of his foes, and those whom he had deceived were turning their swords against him. All around him and above him were the evidences of dissolution and destruction. Neither had he within himself the inspiration of a just or noble cause, but only the consciousness that he was going down to destruction, because he had dared to set himself up in opposition to his country's power, to the rights of man, and to the laws of Heaven. It was grotesque enough, that at such a moment, Mr. JEFF. DAVIS should declare his tottering house and his failing power, a "permanent" superstructure.

abstract: The Commander of the Sumter feels aggrieved by our recent comments on his proceedings. We have expressed the opinion that his style of warfare is not that of civilized nations -- that, indeed, it approaches the piratical. We little thought that in expressing this opinion we were wounding the line feelings of a man of sensibility. The practice we remarked on was that of seizing ships engaged in peaceful commerce and burning them to the water's edge, and it did not seem to call for much delicacy and niceness in speaking of it. However, Capt. SEMMES thinks otherwise; he does not covet the charater of a devil-me-care sailor, which has been attributed to him by his English admirers; and as he has stated his case in fair and temperate language, we readily print his letter. Capt. SEMMES, explains that the reason he burns his captures is, that he has no port to take them into. We may venture to say that this was precisely what everybody supposed, and that nobody ever imagined he would destroy ships and their cargoes, if he could get them condemned by a prize court and sold. He appears to think that because he cannot do that, he must go about taking merchant vessels and burning them at sea; and here it is that most people, we think, will disagree with him. We will not, however, again discuss the question, or seek to impair the reasonings of his letter. The British Government has found it necessary to limit the facility which it has hitherto given to our gallant correspondent, and we shall probably hear less of him in future. Capt. SEMMES refers us to a letter which he addressed to the Governor of Cienfuegos, and appeals to our sense of justice to print it. As we have to-day a sense of inconvenient limitation as well as the sense he mentions, we cannot comply with his request, and moreover we do not think it requisite, since the fact Capt. SEMMES wishes to establish by it is not questioned. If, however, any contemporary, feeling more enthusiasm for the cause of secession than we profess, is ready to print it, he is welcome to our copy.

abstract: A meeting of the Sons of Massachusetts was held at the Fifth-avenue Hotel last evening, at 8 o'clock, to take measures to properly receive Col. WILLIAM RAYMOND LEE, and Surgeon REVERE, Captains BOWMAN and ROCKLAND, and other released officers and privates of the Massachusetts Fifteenth and Twentieth Regiments, on their arrival in this City. A number of the Sons of the Old Bay State were present, measures were adopted, and a Committee appointed to make arrangements for the fitting reception of the returning prisoners.

abstract: The iron-clad war-steamer, built at Mystic Conn., was recently launched, and now lies at Greenpoint, where she will receive her armament and be prepared for sea. She has nearly all her armor, and her engines are finished and partly in. It is expected she will be ready for service in one month from the present time. Her length is 200 feet over all, breadth 37 feet, and depth of hold 12 1/8 feet. Her entire capacity is 1,000 tons.

lead_paragraph: The Secretary of War has issued an order announcing: 1. That from and after to-day, the President takes military possession of all telegraph lines; 2. All telegrams relating to military operations, excepting those from the Department and the Generals commanding, are prohibited transmission; 3. Journals publishing military news, unauthorized, are to be punished; 4. Appoints a military supervisor of messages, and a military superintendent of telegraph offices; 5. This order not to interfere with the ordinary operations of said companies.

abstract: This City has reason to be thankful for the excellent management of the Metropolitan Board of Police. The former slip-shod guardians of society, who used to hang about corner-groceries, and were in intimate relations of friendship with gamblers and pimps, are replaced by a well-dressed, orderly, disciplined force, with much esprit du corps, who are a real terror to evil doers.
lead_paragraph: This City has reason to be thankful for the excellent management of the Metropolitan Board of Police. The former slip-shod guardians of society, who used to hang about corner-groceries, and were in intimate relations of friendship with gamblers and pimps, are replaced by a well-dressed, orderly, disciplined force, with much esprit du corps, who are a real terror to evil doers. The personnel of the force is admirable; we doubt if a finer-looking body of men in physical proportions can be found in the country. The old habits of slovenliness and dawdling are mostly broken up. The men carry themselves well, are neat in person, and respectful to strangers. The "Detective Force" is very active and well managed, and we believe there is no large city in the world where there is less of picking pockets and petty thieving. Of course, there are some troublesome relics of the old system of police, and the force in some wards needs "weeding out" yet. Men are still found who are ready to disgrace the name of an officer of the law, by guilty connivance with criminals, and there is still a lack of thorough military discipline in some portions of the body. Still, on the whole, we may safely compare the orderly condition of our City and its police-management with that of any European city. Crime is on the decrease -- especially among the young -- and is sternly kept under. Deeds of violence occur no more frequently than they must everywhere where five hundred thousand human beings gather together. Every street and lane of the Metropolis, in the darkest hour of the night, is perfectly safe to stranger or citizen. It is true, certain species of crime, as gambling, and the evils connected with prostitution, are reached with more difficulty, but this is due rather to defective legislation than any want of energy in the Police Commissioners.

abstract: The wind yesterday morning blew from the northwest, but not with so much violence as during the preceding night. Most of the vessels detained in the North River on account of the storm, went to sea during the day.
lead_paragraph: The wind yesterday morning blew from the northwest, but not with so much violence as during the preceding night. Most of the vessels detained in the North River on account of the storm, went to sea during the day. The tide at night, and again at noon, was unusually low, in consequence of which the South Ferry boats got aground in their slips on the New-York side several times. On Monday night they ceased running for a couple of hours.

abstract: By the steamer Elm City, the above regiment left New-Haven Monday, and arrived off New-York yesterday morning. Without landing, the men were at once transferred to the steamer Fulton, in order to be conveyed to Ship Island. The numerical strength of the regiment is nearly 1,000 men. Gov. BUCKINGHAM accompanied the corps. The Sons of Connecticut entertained him and the officers of the regiment at the Astor House. It was entirely a social gathering; no speeches were made, and the whole affair passed off pleasantly. From official sources it is stated that this regiment is in a highly efficient state of discipline and drill. Subjoined is a list of the officers:

abstract: The damages by the violent northwest gale of yesterday are extensive. The lofty steeple of the Thirteenth-street Baptist Church was blown down; its weighty and massive bell entirely crushed in the roof and side walls, leaving only the front and east wells standing. The injury is estimated at $10,000. The north wail in falling crushed in the walls of an adjoining dwelling.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Tuesday, Feb. 25.

abstract: The Earl of DERBY said, I seldom occupy you Lordships time with anything personal to myself, or with remarks on what has passed in this House, but in the report in the Times newspaper of what I addressed to the House yesterday, which is not so accurate as its reports generally are, there is oue error I wish to correct. I am represented as having said nearly the...
lead_paragraph: The Earl of DERBY said, I seldom occupy you Lordships time with anything personal to myself, or with remarks on what has passed in this House, but in the report in the Times newspaper of what I addressed to the House yesterday, which is not so accurate as its reports generally are, there is oue error I wish to correct. I am represented as having said nearly the opposite of what I stated in reference to the recognition of the Southern States. The report is that "I think the time is nearly some when the Government may probably be called on to recognized the so far successful revolt of the seceded States." What I said was, that the time has not come when it can properly be called on to recognize the Government representing the successful revolt of the Southern States. I added that, though it is the practice to recognize a de facto Government that has succeeded in establishing itself, I did not think that the resistance of the Southern States had been so successful as to justify us in recognizing them as a Power able to maintain its own independence,

abstract: The Connecticut Mutual Life Assurance Company, vs. The Cleveland, Columbus and Cincinnati Railroad Company. The plaintiffs on the 1st of February, instant, attached funds of the defendants deposited in this City by the defendants, to pay their Eastern stockholders. The suit in which the attach-....
lead_paragraph: The Connecticut Mutual Life Assurance Company, vs. The Cleveland, Columbus and Cincinnati Railroad Company. The plaintiffs on the 1st of February, instant, attached funds of the defendants deposited in this City by the defendants, to pay their Eastern stockholders. The suit in which the attachment issued was commenced to enforce defendants liability as guarantors of the bonds and coupons of the Columbus. Piqua and Indiana Railroad Company, now insolvent. The defendants moved to set aside the summons and attachment, on the ground that the parties are foreign corporations, and the cause of action did not arise in this State. The plaintiffs contended that the cause of action arose in this State, the bonds and coupons being payable at the office of the Ohio Life Insurance and Trust Company, in this City; that the defendants, by a general appearance, waive any irregularity of service, and that, irrespective of any State law, a corporation created in another State was entitled to all the rights and remedies of any citizen of another State in our Courts.
