abstract: This Republic, under the enlightened and liberal administration of President PEREZ, is taking a new lease of prosperity. Political asperities have been softened, and from the tone of the newspapers one would be led to believe that a sort of political millenium had been reached, in which even the outs are as well satisfied as the ins. Business is improving; failures the past fortnight have been few, and those of but little importance; the crops are abundant, the mineral product increasing, and the railroads in process of rapid construction. The only drawback is the unsettled condition of the Arauca Indians; but terms of peace are being brought about with the caciques, and soon these annoyances will cease. A crazy Frenchman, calling himself Orelie I., King of Arauca, had been among the chiefs, and claimed dominion over the people. Some were for acknowledging him, while others were unbelievers. The result was, the arrest, by the Chilian authorities, of the Frenchman, who will be sent to a lunatic asylum.
lead_paragraph: This Republic, under the enlightened and liberal administration of President PEREZ, is taking a new lease of prosperity. abstract: Tennessee seems inclined to return to the Union at once. The moment the rebel armies are driven out of Virginia, she will follow the example. North Carolina will take similar action, just as soon as her people are released from their thraldom, and Louisiana will repeal the ordinance of secession as soon as NewOrleans has fallen into the hands of the National armies, which will be within a month.
lead_paragraph: Tennessee seems inclined to return to the Union at once. The moment the rebel armies are driven out of Virginia, she will follow the example. North Carolina will take similar action, just as soon as her people are released from their thraldom, and Louisiana will repeal the ordinance of secession as soon as NewOrleans has fallen into the hands of the National armies, which will be within a month. A little longer time may be required for Georgia, and two or three years may elapse before the other Gulf States are thoroughly converted from the error of their ways. But the result is certain. Sooner or later we shall have rebellion crushed and the Union restored.

abstract: The People, ex rel. Chas. W. Baker vs. Robt. T. Haws. -- This is the case in which the relator asked to be paid for printing fifteen hundred copies of the City Charter, with Kent's notes. The bill was $4,260. The payment being refused by the Comptroller, a mandamus was asked and obtained, compelling the payment. The Comptroller resisted the motion for the writ upon the ground, that before the Legislature authorized the payment, Baker had been defeated on the merits of his claim in a suit to recover the bill.

abstract: On Monday evening, Capt. JOSEPH LAING, of the Seventy-ninth Regiment, Highland Guard, was presented with a handsome claymore by his friends. Mr. JOHN ARMSTRONG made the presentation address, wherein he stated though Capt. LAING had lost his former sword, it was lost with honor, and on the field of battle; and that he was not deprived of it till he had received his wounds in close contest with the rebels. Capt. LAING, in response, made a brief reply, and favored the company with a graphic account of his experience at the battle of Bull Run. Lieut. IVES, also of the Seventy-ninth, who was made a prisoner at Bull Run, and has just returned from Richmond, was present, as also were Capt. GEORGE HOGG, of the Second New-York Volunteer Artillery, and other officers. To-day, Capt. LAING, having now nearly recovered from his wounds, sails for Beaufort, S.C., in order to join his regiment now stationed there. Lieut. IVES accompanies him.

abstract: A Fort Donelson dispatch to the Democrat of yesterday, says a boat just from Clarksville reports the evacuation of Nashville. The Union citizens of that place sent a boat to Clarksville, which towed one of our gunboats for their protection. The rebels, with Gov. HARRIS, retreated to Murfreesboro. HARRIS burned all the State documents before leaving.

abstract: A skirmish occurred at Independence on the 18th, between a detachment of Ohio Cavalry and a band of rebels headed by QUANTREL PARKER. The latter were routed, with a loss of three killed, several wounded and several taken prisoners. A quantity of arms were also captured. The National loss was one killed and three wounded.

abstract: THE UNION HOME, ETC., FOR THE CHILDREN OF SOLDIERS. The undersigned, who have been requested to act as an Advisory Committee of the Officers and Managers of the "New-York Home and School" for the education and support of children of the officers and soldiers of New-York regiments, having ascertained
lead_paragraph: THE UNION HOME, ETC., FOR THE CHILDREN OF SOLDIERS. -- The undersigned, who have been requested to act as an Advisory Committee of the Officers and Managers of the "New-York Home and School" for the education and support of children of the officers and soldiers of New-York regiments, having ascertained that the said officers and managers have no legal existence as an incorporated society or association, yet approving of the object contemplated by them, do hereby advise that the said officers and managers suspend or discontinue their operations under their present organization; and we recommend that there be formed, for the same or similar objects, a society or association, under the general law for the incorporation of such societies, or by a special act of the Legislature of the State of New-York.

abstract: The House was engaged on Saturday in a discussion of the past and future conduct of the war. Mr. BOYCE, of South Carolina, argued at some length in advocacy of an offensive policy. The plan he proposed was the appointment of a Commander-in-Chief of the army, and leave to him the direction of military operations, and suggested TOOMBS, who possessed the revolutionary spirit.
lead_paragraph: The House was engaged on Saturday in a discussion of the past and future conduct of the war. Mr. BOYCE, of South Carolina, argued at some length in advocacy of an offensive policy. The plan he proposed was the appointment of a Commander-in-Chief of the army, and leave to him the direction of military operations, and suggested TOOMBS, who possessed the revolutionary spirit. In his opinion the great error was not prosecting the war more vigorously in the beginning, when the North was comparatively unprepared, and when her 75,000 three mouths' men were gathered at Washington, as it were, on a kind of Fourth of July celebration.

abstract: Charles E. Breeler vs. George Walsh el al.  This action is on a promissory note of $5,000, and was commenced in November last. The answer, as originally served, merely denied plaintiff's title to the note.
lead_paragraph: Charles E. Breeler vs. George Walsh el al. -- This action is on a promissory note of $5,000, and was commenced in November last. The answer, as originally served, merely denied plaintiff's title to the note. But the defendants now made affidavit that the attorney whom they originally employed did not put in the proper defence, and that as soon as they learned that plaintiff was proceeding to put the cause on the railroad calendar, they employed Beebe, Dean & Donohue, who advised them that an amended answer was necessary. They now moved for leave to put in such answer, stating their true defence.

abstract: The President of the United States, yesterday, approved the Loan and Treasury bill perfected by Congress the day before, and this measure is now the law of the land. It creates a National Currency of United States Notes of the denominations of five dollars and upwards, made lawful money, and a legal tender for all debts, public and private,
lead_paragraph: The President of the United States, yesterday, approved the Loan and Treasury bill perfected by Congress the day before, and this measure is now the law of the land. It creates a National Currency of United States Notes of the denominations of five dollars and upwards, made lawful money, and a legal tender for all debts, public and private, and in all payments to and from the Government, other than for Customs duties to the United States, and Interest on the Public Debt by the United States. The total amount of this currency authorized is not to exceed $150,000,000, including the $60,000,000 of United States Notes issued under the Act of July 17. These being made receivable by that Act, for all public dues, are now authorized to be accepted in place of Gold for Customs Duties; but the whole issue is to be withdrawn and canceled, and regular legal tender United States Notes substituted, as soon as practicable. The Customs Duties, whether in Gold or United States Notes, are specifically pledged for the interest on the Public Debt, which is to be invariably paid in gold.

abstract: WALLACK's THEATRE. -- Mrs. COWLEY's well-known comedy, called "The Belle's Stratagem," one of the most pleasant society pieces of the past generation, was revived here last evening, with an admirable distribution. Mrs. HOEY is seldom seen to better advantage than in the part of Letitia Hardy, where there is scope for her singular contrast of style. The hoydenish exaggeration of the well-bred woman, as well as the little piques of the lady in her own character, were excellently interpreted. Indeed, the former was so satisfactory to the audience that the artist was frequently applauded, and narrowly escaped an encore in her song. Mr. LESTER WALLECK, as Flutter, was the light-headed trifler of the fashionable world that the authoress intended to portray; and Mr. FISHER as Doricourt, was excellent, albeit somewhat mature for a tender swain. Miss FANNY MORANT, as Mrs. Rackett, acted with much dash. Mr. BLAKE, as Hardy, was, as usual, all that could be desired. In these comedies the acting of this gentleman is so uniformly good that we can hardly devise a variation on the usual terms of praise.

abstract: -- When the war against the rebellion was first commenced, the people took it for granted that the National forces were to be easily triumphant everywhere, and important successes gained by Gen. MCCLELLAN in Western Virginia served to confirm this impression. Although there was a little grumbling at the wholesale administration of the oath of allegiance after the battle at Carricksford, there was a spice of magnanimity in releasing 1,500 prisoners, which was, on the whole, gratifying to the national pride. The battle of Bull Run put another phase upon affairs, and there were very few who did not wish that the paroled Georgians and Alabamians were in our custody again, for they would have been a very useful commodity in effecting a restoration of the equilibrium of exchange which had so long been against us. There are symptoms, however, that the overweening confidence which ruled the hour at the outbreak of the rebellion is returning, and it is manifesting itself in the same carelessness regarding the safe custody of the prisoners captured. It was all very well for Gen. BURNSIDE to release, on parole, the twenty-five hundred traitors captured at Roanoke Island. It paid a debt of honor which we had incurred on rebel account, and saved the useless expense of transporting this "elephant," as BURNSIDE styled his unexpected acquisition, to some Northern prison-house; but it is not at all gratifying to hear that Gen. BUSHROD JOHNSON, whom we unwillingly accepted as a substute for the redoubtable ALBERT SIDNEY, has, with his staff, ridden unquestioned out of Fort Donelson, -- whither no body seems to know -- or that the prisoners taken to Chicago are escaping by scores from the camp to which they have been assigned, simply for the want of a sufficient guard. It is impossible to tell what phases of ferocity, unexpected success, or the desperation caused by still further overwhelming defeats may develop among the rebels, and our past experience should lead us to be fully prepared for any emergency which may arise. Will not the proper authorities see to it that the prisoners now in our possession are well cared for?
lead_paragraph: -- When the war against the rebellion was first commenced, the people took it for granted that the National forces were to be easily triumphant everywhere, and important successes gained by Gen. There are symptoms, however, that the overweening confidence which ruled the hour at the outbreak of the rebellion is returning, and it is manifesting itself in the same carelessness regarding the safe custody of the prisoners captured. It was all very well for Gen. BURNSIDE to release, on parole, the twenty-five hundred traitors captured at Roanoke Island. It paid a debt of honor which we had incurred on rebel account, and saved the useless expense of transporting this "elephant," as BURNSIDE styled his unexpected acquisition, to some Northern prison-house; but it is not at all gratifying to hear that Gen. BUSHROD JOHNSON, whom we unwillingly accepted as a substute for the redoubtable ALBERT SIDNEY, has, with his staff, ridden unquestioned out of Fort Donelson, -- whither no body seems to know -- or that the prisoners taken to Chicago are escaping by scores from the camp to which they have been assigned, simply for the want of a sufficient guard. abstract: Editorial regrets temporary lack of telegraphic communication with Fortress Monroe
snippet: Editorial regrets temporary lack of telegraphic communication with Fortress Monroe
lead_paragraph: -- The public has real cause for regret in the temporary failure to complete telegraphic communication with Fortress Monroe. Some weeks ago the TIMES pointed out a few of the advantages which would result from laying a wire between Old Point Comfort and Cape Henry, and one of the first evidences Secretary STANTON gave of the practical earnestness with which he intended to push forward the work of suppressing the rebellion, was in issuing orders for the immediate prosecution of this important undertaking. All the arguments which we formerly urged in favor of the enterprise are as applicable now as they ever were; and what is of more immediate importance, if the order prohibiting the publication of army movements is strictly enforced, Fortress Monroe is about the only point from which we shall be able to procure intelligence of the operations of our forces in Tennessee and Virginia for some time to come. Rebel spectacles, it is true, have never presented our affairs in a very cheerful aspect, and just at present there is little reason to hope for improvement; but a more extended experience will enable us to separate the truth from the false in the reports which may come from these sources, and the meagre information received from Norfolk will go a little way toward appeasing the popular demand for news, which will otherwise soon become so clamorous as to be intolerable even to Mr. STANTON. We take it for granted that our authorities are not to exercise a stricter censorship than is in force in the Confederate States. There the papers are at liberty to publish all they can learn from the enemy, and just at present, thanks to Gen. MCCLELLAN and Secretary STANTON, they are receiving some very valuable lessons by virtue of this license. We do not anticipate that the tables will very soon be turned upon us, and we are therefore all the more anxious to get news as early as possible from the rebel States. Let the line to Fortress Monroe, then, be completed at once. Certainly a single failure cannot decide the fate of the enterprise.

abstract: Rev. Dr. VINTON, of Trinity Church, lectured last evening, at Irving Hall, before the General Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen, on "The Cause and Cure of the Rebellion." He denied the right of revolution, the supremacy of State sovereignty, or the ennobling influences of Slavery, and saw in the triumph of the Union and the Constitution, and the laws, the only cure for the rebellion.

abstract: Caroline A. Floyd Jones, et al. vs. Samuel J. Hallet and Wife. This was an appeal from an order and decree of the Surrogate of Queens County, admitting to probate the will of Charity M. lead_paragraph: Caroline A. Floyd Jones, et al. vs. Samuel J. Hallet and Wife. -- This was an appeal from an order and decree of the Surrogate of Queens County, admitting to probate the will of Charity M. Hallett. Stephen Hallett, the father of the testatrix, owned all that valuable property known as "Hallett's Cove," in the village of Astoria, Long Island. He died intestate, leaving eight children, none of whom were ever married, all living a secluded life, as alleged by the contestants, seldom seeing any one except their colored servants. All died intestate except the testatrix, who was sole survivor of the brothers and sisters. By her will she left her entire property to Samuel J. Haliett, the proponent, and a relative -- although by the contestants claimed to be a distant one. The proponent had been, as appears, for several years the agent of the testatrix, living in the same house with her. The will was contested by twenty-six of the heirs-at-law, who claimed that the testatrix lacked capacity to make it, and that undue influence was used in respect to it.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, after some unimportant business, the bill defining the duties of the Captain of the Port and the Harbor-masters of New-York was considered in Committee of the Whole. The bill authorizes the Governor to appoint eleven Harbor-masters, nine to reside in New-York and two in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, after some unimportant business, the bill defining the duties of the Captain of the Port and the Harbor-masters of New-York was considered in Committee of the Whole. The bill authorizes the Governor to appoint eleven Harbor-masters, nine to reside in New-York and two in Brooklyn. An amendment was moved that three reside in Brooklyn and the rest in New-York, and an effort was made to strike out-entirely the restriction in regard to residence. It was, at last, decided that all should reside in Brooklyn during their term of office, and the bill was reported complete and ordered to a third reading. The bill to amend the Charter of the City of Brooklyn was, on motion of Mr. MURPHY, referred to the Brooklyn Senators to report complete.

The bill for the occupation and cultivation of cotton lands, was then debated until the expiration of the morning hour, after which the bill fixing the number of Representatives was passed, after the addition of an amendment limiting the number to 241. The case of Mr. STARKE' of Oregon, then occupied attention until the adjournment.

abstract: editorials on need for improved system
snippet: editorials on need for improved system
lead_paragraph: We seem destined to be blessed with a great variety of new postal laws. Our Congressional Post-office Committees, after sleeping for years, have at last waked up to the idea that our Post-office can be improved. The people have, by numerous voices, demanded that it should be improved, or else abolished. But, instead of some well-digested bill that would cover all the ground, Mr. COLFAX's Committee are continually bringing up separate measures by piecemeal, till the postal acts of a single session promise to be more complicated than the whole code of LYCURGUS.

abstract: Editorials on plan to create new US Judicial District in NYS
snippet: Editorials on plan to create new US Judicial District in NYS
lead_paragraph: We notice that the House of Representatives, on Tuesday, passed a bill establishing a new Judicial District in this State. It diminishes the territory of this Southern District a little, but practically the only effect of it will be to divide the Northern District into two and this makes the remarks of Mr. DIVEN, who reported the bill, seem rather extraordinary, if correctly reported. He is reported to have alluded to the fact that this City "alone gives more business to the District Court than is transacted in any other District in the United States." True enough, but that seems to us rather an argument against the bill than in favor of it. If Mr. DIVEN would have any one suppose that the placing in another District of the counties above the Highlands, will make any appreciable difference with the business of this District, he is certainly misinformed. The business of this District is the business of the City, and the only way to give relief here, is to give additional Judicial force here. We do not mean to say that the proposed new district may not be needed for the relief of the Northern District, although that has not thus far been so great as to prevent Judge HALL from coming down here now and then, to help transact the business of this District. But this proposed change should be put upon true grounds, and not upon false ones. It will not relieve this District a particle.
headline: {'main': 'National Judicial Districts.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'National Judicial Districts.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- If we are to credit a law item of the 25th inst., Justice STEERS must be held responsible for bad law and bad manners. He is said to have "delivered a sharp reprimand to the Eleventh Precinct Police for arresting some Sunday liquor dealers. The magistrate decided that the prisoners had a right to sell liquor on Sunday, provided they kept their places closed in front and had no noise inside." We will not stop to discuss the wisdom or propriety of administering "a sharp reprimand" from the Bench to officers of the law manifestly intent on the discharge of their duty to the public, while judicial sympathy is exercised toward skulking and most troublesome criminals. Our issue is joined with this magistrate on a question of law and right. Where does Justice STEERS find a warrant for his dictum, that it is "right to sell liquor on Sunday, provided their places are closed in front, &c.? The 21st section of the Excise law of 1857 prohibited the sale, or giving away of any intoxicating drinks on Sunday, by any person licensed to sell liquors. It says nothing about "front doors, "noise," or Justice STEERS. The sale is a misdemeanor, punishable by imprisonment. But, if the dealer be unlicensed, the sale of liquors on any day is a misdemeanor -- the law having been adjudicated and settled by the Court of Appeals, in the case of Behan vs. The People -- and by the very terms of the statute, as well as by the letter of the Metropolitan Police act, patrolmen are bound to make arrests for these offences, whatever may be the condition of "front doors" or rear entrances, and however much or little there may be of "noise" on the premises.

abstract: The Eleventh New-York Volunteers was one of the first regiments which left for the seat of war. It has done good service in the field, and is now stationed at Newports News, Va., and is a favorite regiment with Gen. WOOL. The commanding officer, Col. LOESER, is a West Point graduate of high standing, and has established the character of the regiment for discipline and good conduct. Capt. JOSEFH E. MACFARLAND has been detailed with a recruiting party to fill up toe numbers of the Zouaves, and is now in this City. With the view to promote this object, a meeting of the old members of the Regiment and of the citizens generally, will be held at Runk's Hotel, No. 274 Grand-street, near Forsyth-street, on this (Thursday) evening, at 8 o'clock. The friends of the regiment and the Fire Department generally, are invited to attend.

abstract: Editorial notes decline of Confederate cause in England
snippet: Editorial notes decline of Confederate cause in England
lead_paragraph: Our London correspondent transmits us a copy of the "Blue-book" relating to American affairs just laid before the British Parliament. As might be expected, it is extremely voluminous, consisting of six distinct sets of documents, covering the whole ground on which correspondence has been had between the two Cabinets. Blue-books are not generally accounted the liveliest of reading: but the vital interest that belongs to the questions discussed in this correspondence, creates a life under the ribs even of official protocols and diplomatic circumlocution. We yesterday gave copious excerpts from this bulky body of dispatches; for the rest they must remain as materiel pour servir to be used by the historian who shall write the secret diplomatic history of our most strange eventful times.

lead_paragraph: No notice was taken of the matter at the time, as the shot fell short and did no damage, but on the following day the two vessels returned in company, and commenced a bombardment of the enemy's position. About thirty shells were thrown into the fortification, when the rebels, finding the place too hot, abandoned the work and fled. The Federals did not deem it advisable to follow up their victory by landing.

abstract: -- The preparationsfor the release of State prisoners have taken form in the selection of Gen. DIX and Judge PIERREPOINT to act as a tribunal for the summary disposition of the various cases. abstract: Editorial on Davis reasons for secession as stated in inaugural address
snippet: Editorial on Davis reasons for secession as stated in inaugural address
lead_paragraph: We have thought it not to be wondered at that reckless politicians, who saw the reins of power slipping from their hands, should have betaken themselves to treason and rebellion, in the hope of being able still to retain them. It was not, however, unnatural that the rebels and their allies should not assent to this view, but should place their action upon very different grounds. The difficulty has lain in their inability to agree among themselves as to the real reason of the matter any better than they could agree with us. Mr. STEPHENS said it was in order to establish freedom upon its true corner-stone of Slavery, and to get rid of that element of weakness which pervaded the ancient Constitution, in that it considered freedom as the true basis of freedom. Mr. YANCEY did not admit this. In his view, the South had rebelled on account of the tariffs which they had heretofore carried through the National Congress. Others said it was because of the Abolitionists. Others attributed it solely to the election of Mr. LINCOLN. All these conflicting views must, however, now be abandoned. JEFF. DAVIS must be considered as having a higher authority to speak upon this point than either YANCEY or STEPHENS, and in his Inaugural he has declared very explicitly what was the real cause of the rebellion. He tells us that it was because the rebels "believed that to remain longer in the Union would subject them to a continuance of a disparaging discrimination." We trust that hereafter we shall hear no further discussion on this point. Mr. DAVIS' authority is the highest, and no one could venture to say that the reason which he gives is an improbable or insufficient one. If the rebels have plunged headlong into perjury and treason, into theft and murder, and all the crimes of the calendar; if they have uprooted the peace of a Continent, and brought evils upon the land which will be felt for long years in the sorrows of hearts made desolate, and in heavy burdens to be borne by our children's children; if they have prostrated the prosperity of their own section of the country and quite possibly utterly overthrown the system which, as they claimed, was the foundation of that prosperity -- what are these evils, when weighed in the balance against "a disparaging discrimination?" Before this, all the crimes of the old tyrannies must "pale their ineffectual fires." Let us hear no more of them. We have learned of a yet deeper depth of atrocity than past history has told us of. Henceforth, if any one speaks of dragonnades, of conscriptions, of star-chambers and inquisitions, we shall say triumphantly, what do all these popular wrongs amount to compared with this continuance of a disparaging discrimination?

abstract: observations on allied occupation

lead_paragraph: The Paris Pays announces that Gen. ALMONTE, who has for a long time been aiding the cause which the Powers now represent, and in whose possession some very compromising letters were found when his house was searched by the order of JUAREZ, has set out for Mexico in charge of documents containing propositions for an amicable and satisfactory arrangement of the whole difficulty! Some well-informed parties in Paris think that he really conveys with him secret offers to Gen. URAGA and others to detach them from the National cause of Mexico. If so every friend of that Republic must desire his failure.

abstract: Accounts from Western Virginia represent the Unionists of that region as the victims of the most relentless and destructive persecution on the part of the rebel guerillas. The Congressional Committee on the Conduct of the War have, no doubt, ascertained why Gen. ROSECRANS, by putting his troops in Winter quarters, and retiring, with his Staff, to Wheeling, last November, left these loyal people to be slaughtered and plundered.

abstract: -- The explanations which Earl RUSSELL continues to offer in the House of Lords, give renewed evidence that England is preparing for a year of peace. The British Government will not interfere with the blockade. The British Government will not in any form intervene in the American question. The British Government will not aid in imposing a monarch upon a reluctant population in Mexico. In thus refraining and abstaining, the British Cabinet perfectly responds to the sense of the English people, who demand peace at any sacrifice, except of national honor. To the same effect is a statement given in our Washington correspondence. The estimates both for the navy and army have been materially reduced. Both arms of service, for years carried forward on a war basis, and urged as if the great battle of Armageddon was to be fought in this year of grace, on the shores of the channel, are to be placed on a peace footing. These financial demonstrations are worth a volume of official protests and explanations. Empires which have proclaimed themselves "Peace" have been unpleasantly addicted to war; and so long as budgets bulged with inordinate estimates for armies and navies, War Ministers could hardly pass current as doves. But England and France, having both cut down their martial preparations, are entitled to credit when they assert predilections for peace, and the French Emperor only needs to withdraw his troops from Mexico to establish his claim to the beatitude of the Peace-maker.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, the bill providing for a National foundry and furnace was reported back from the Military Committee, with an amendment striking out the furnace. A substitute for the confiscation bill was introduced by Mr. DAVIS, of Kentucky, and ordered to be printed. The bill to increase the efficiency of the Medical Department of the Army was debated at considerable length, but was not definitely acted upon. The case of Mr. STARKE, of Oregon, was then again considered, and it was finally decided to allow him to take the oath and his seat -- the vote being 26 to 19.

abstract: John Steward, Jr., et al. vs. Horace C. Thurber  This was an action on a promissory note claimed to have been made in Michigan on a Sunday.
lead_paragraph: On the 5th day of September, 1846, the defendant with four others, all residents of Pontiac, Michigan, made their joint and several promissary note payable in four months. The note subsequently became the property of the plaintiffs. Not having been paid at maturity, Thurber, for himself and the other makers, on the 25th day of March, 1847, applied by letter to the plaintiff's agent, who was then in Detroit, to renew the note for 60 days, after payment of interest and charges. To this the agent agreed.

abstract: Last evening a meeting of the members of this Regiment now in this City was held at Runk's Hotel, No. 274 Grand-street. A large number of firemen were present and crammed the hall to the utmost of its limits. Mr. OWEN W. BRENNAN was called to the chair, who introduced Mr. PROSPER W. WETMORE to the meeting.
lead_paragraph: He stated that the object of the meeting was to get the old members of the First fire Zouaves to return to their regiment. It was now in a first state of discipline, and commanded by a highly efficient officer, Col. LOESER, who had graduated at West Point. All members who returned to the regiment would have their pay, during the time they have been absent, given them, and no charge of desertion brought against them. At the conclusion, Mr. WETMORE enjoined all members of the First Fire Zouaves who were present to step up to the platform, and place their names upon the roll, as wishing to return to the regiment. The following then came forward, and signed their names: John Graves, Edwin C. Pomeroy, W.A. Harrison, W.H. Hennessey, T. Neary, James McBride, Patrick Kane, George C. Weatherhead and Francis Coward.

abstract: Capt. CHARLES H. BALDWIN, Acting-Master on board the gunboat Mercedita, writes to his brother in Fall River, from off Pass-a-l'Outre, one of the mouths of the Mississippi, as follows:
lead_paragraph: "About every other day, one of these rebel fast boats called the Ivy has been in the habit of venturing down to mouth of the Pass, and taking notes, we supposed. As we draw too much water, and are not so fast, we have never attempted to chase her; consequently she had grown quite bold, and last Monday she came within the range of our Parrott gun, over which I have supervision, and the Captain says to me, 'Mr. BALDWIN, do you think you can reach her?' I had all the time since we saw her been watching her motions, and replied to the Captain that I thought I could scare her a little. 'At any rate,' says the Captain, 'try it.' I immediately got my gun to bear on her, which she no sooner saw than she began to turn tail up the 'Passe,' but a little too late; my shell went screeching through the air, and struck her just abaft of the smoke-stack, making the splinters fly beautifully. What damage we did we couldn't find out, but I'll assure you she went up the river at full speed, and we have not seen her since. The Captain complimented me on my excellent shot. We hardly thought to reach her.

abstract: As time reveals the nature and proportion of the struggle at Fort Donelson, we find  contrary to our usual experience of reports of battles that the first news understated its importance. So accustomed are we to exaggerations in the dispatches and letters relating...
lead_paragraph: to military operations in this war, that most people unconsciously deduct a large percentage from the accounts of every new event in our campaign. But, in regard to this first great collision of the hostile armies of the West, we find it necessary to add to all our earliest reports. Time and fuller information reveal the battle of Fort Donelson as the greatest battle fought thus far on the American Continent; a three days' desperate struggle between an assailing force of (probably) 30,000 men, and a well-intrenched defending army of from twenty to thirty thousand -- the line of battle reaching for several miles -- the struggle veering to and fro as positions are taken or lost -- the woods and ravines echoing with the crack of thousands of rifles and the boom of at least seventy pieces of artillery on each side. Desperate sorties are made -- batteries are taken, retaken and lost again -- fresh regiment succeeds regiment in the fierce struggle, and in one case, a sally is made with the most determined purpose by some 10,000 men of the besieged force to cut their way through -- an attack which is finally repulsed with great loss. They are three gloomy and deplorable days in the natural world -- though forever glorious in our history. The tough soldiers of the West fight amid rain, and sleet, and snow: they lie down on the frozen ground or in the snow at night, and it is believed that many of the wounded are frozen to death.

abstract: Editorial on martial law being enforced in captured Confederate areas
snippet: Editorial on martial law being enforced in captured Confederate areas
lead_paragraph: dominates in Kentucky, and Gen. GRANT has just declared it in force over West Tennessee. It will probably soon be extended over the whole State, until such time as a new and loyal civil Government can be put in operation. It is impossible for the National Government or the military authorities to recognize in any way the authority of the rebel Governor or the other forsworn traitors now in power in that State, just as it is impossible for them to recognize the authority of the rebel President. They were elected outside of the Constitutional provisions, and have sworn allegiance to another so-called Government. "Martial law," (says Gen. HALLECK, in his valuable work on the "Laws of War,") "derives no authority from the civil law, nor assistance from the civil tribunals, for it overrules, suspends and replaces both. It is from its very nature an arbitrary power, and extends to all the inhabitants of the district where it is in force." The enforcement of martial law, even for a brief time, will work changes in Tennessee, as it has done in Missouri, where it has been so ably and effectively administered by that eminent jurist and soldier, Gen. HALLECK. The writ of habeas corpus and the ordinary personal freedom and the franchises of the citizen will be suspended; hundreds of rebel newspapers will be suppressed; hundreds of rebel functionaries will be expelled from office; treason in every shape will be sternly repressed; and a quick trial and sharp punishment will follow every infringement of the martial code. This is undoubtedly a stern and an extraordinary mode of rule for the heretofore rampant rebels; but, in the interval between the advance of our army and the establishment of a legitimate government, no other law is possible.
headline: {'main': 'MARTIAL LAW IN REBEL STATES', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'MARTIAL LAW IN REBEL STATES', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Dies; Felton, (Prof) Cornelius Conway; of Harvard College
snippet: Dies; Felton, (Prof) Cornelius Conway; of Harvard College
lead_paragraph: CORNELIUS C. FELTON, the President of Harvard College, whose death is announced by telegraph this morning, was one of the most eminent living Greek scholars -- a man of extraordinary natural powers and of wonderful attainments in classical learning. His loss will be deeply deplored by scholars everywhere, as his name was one of the few known over the wide world, and his learning and virtues were universally admired. To the College over which he presided, and to American learning, the loss will be irreparable, while in the groves of Greece itself, of which country be was for some time a resident, he had many admirers and friends. He was born in Newbury, Mass., in 1807; graduated at Harvard in 1827; was appointed tutor in 1829, and Professor of Greek in 1832. In 1834 he was appointed Eliot Professor of Greek Literature, the duties of which place he continued to discharge until recently, when he was chosen President of the College in place of Dr. WALKER, resigned. He published many classical works -- an edition of HOMER; an edition of the Clouds, of ARISTOPHANES; editions of the Panegyricus, of SOCRATES; of the Agamemnon, of AESCHYLUS, and of the Birds, of ARISTOPHANES; a Greek Reader, and aided also in the publication of a work on classical studies. He translated, edited and published also many valuable works on scientific and historical subjects, and made numerous contributions to periodical literature. In 1853 he visited Europe, and again in 1858, on account of his impaired health. Prof. FELTON was a member of the Massachusetts Board of Education, and one of the regents of the Smithsonian Institution. In social life he was very much beloved. He was open-souled, generous and hospitable; and his Homeric banquets are mentioned by more than one eminent traveler. In his loss, American classical learning loses its most illustrious ornament, and the world loses an honorable, a virtuous and a noble man. He died in Chester, Pennsylvania, at the house of his brother, the President of the Philadelphia and Baltimore Railroad.
headline: {'main': 'Death of Professor Felton.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Death of Professor Felton.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, petitions against any more savings banks in this City were presented. A report was made against changing the Usury laws so as to allow short credits at more than the legal rate of interest. A majority report was made in favor of incorporating the State Homoeopathic Medical Society. The Brooklyn Charter Amendment bill was reported complete, and ordered to a third reading. The bills limiting the dividends of Life Insurance Companies, and defining the duties of Captains of the Port and Harbor-masters of New-York, were passed. The Senate will hereafter hold evening sessions on Tuesdays and Thursdays.

lead_paragraph: The above dispatch from Gen. HALLECK, of the capture of Fayetteville, sets at rest the false report promulgated by ALBERT PIKE, that he and PRICE had defeated Gen. CURTIS on his entrance with his column into Arkansas. Fayetteville is nearly thirty miles south of that part of Sugar Creek where PIKE's great victory was said to have been achieved, and, if victory it was for him, he and his followers seem to have fled from it with amazing speed.

abstract: The order of the War Department suspending the publication of news of military movements, naturally provokes the comment of the Press. The Press is the ear of the people. It collects and transmits to te popular sensorium all the passing events of the hour. When the newspaper is bidden to silence, the people...
lead_paragraph: is bidden to be deaf, and its censure to be dumb. The public has, therefore, its incontestible right to question this curtailment of its privileges of hearing and judging the doings of its servants. The same right belongs to the Press, that immediate servant of the people. The journals, which are looked to as the most prompt and trustworthy reporters of intelligence, maintain their repute for promptitude and accuracy, by untiring enterprise and the lavish outlay of money. At great conjoint expense, they support a system of telegraphic communication which reaches over the entire surface of the loyal section, from ocean to ocean. The NEW-YORK TIMES has its special telegraphic reporters at every point of interest, its correspondents with every division of the army. Our readers are able to judge the results of this extended enterprise. The columns of this paper have furnished the earliest and fullest intelligence of those brilliant actions which, during the last six weeks, have done imperishable honor to the soldiers of the Union, as well as to those who planned and directed their movements, and to those who gave to those movements a necessary impulse. With the entire system, which at a cost hardly less than would suffice to sustain an army, has produced results so satisfactory to the public, the order of the War Department is in conflict, and if correctly interpreted as a permanent war measure, must be fatal to newspaper enterprise. Journals whose arrangements are of the same comprehensive and elaborate character as our own, are, therefore, warranted in scrutinizing this step of the Administration with jealous eyes, and only surrendering their well-ascertained privileges upon thorough conviction that the public is best served by misinformation, and that the duty of the Press is to reverse its mission, and propagate ignorance.

abstract: to have a Baron Munchausen as a special dispatch correspondent in the direction of Tennessee. His latest wonderful story relates to the town of Clarksville, but the news is not only improbable, as directly contrary to all other accounts, including the official report of Com. FOOTE to the Navy Department, but quite musty as to date. The latter states that he found the bridges near the town fired by the armed rebels, before retreating upon Nashville, against the remonstrances of the citizens. He communicated amicably with the Mayor -- and Hon. CAVE JOHNSON, formerly Postmaster-General, who is, as he has ever been a Union man in sentiment -- and the quiet occupation of the town was assured by the proclamation of FOOTE that he would respect private property. The gunboat expedition was welcomed by white flags, which could not have been, in the alleged absence of every spark of Union feeling. The remark attributed to Mr. JOHNSON is simply ridiculous, as well as untrue of that gentleman, who at least understands the geographical division of the loyal and rebel sentiment of his own State, to say that the Secessionists will fly to the mountains for safety! Equally ridiculous are the assertions that only one man in the town is loyal, and he sixty years old, or he would have been killed long ago, and that the rebel leaders shipped off a thousand negroes a week since!

abstract: Only Once is the unique title of a collection of original papers, published for the benefit of the New-York Infirmary for Women and Children. Originally it was intended to make a cheap pamphlet of the work, but the eminent names that appeared in the list of contributors, justified an increased expenditure, and the result is before us, in a vision of tinted paper, that will bring gladness to centre tables. Mr. PUTNAM has contributed four excellent plates, that enable the little work to outshine the majority of annuals -- so far as illustration goes. There are steel-plate portraits of BRYANT and JAMES RUSSELL LOWELL; one of Mrs. C.M. SEDGWICK, engraved from a drawing made by FREDERIKA BREMER herself, and now for the first time published, and a fine view of Florence. Bryant, Whittler, Lowell, Page, Rose Tenny, Phoebe Carey, Bayard Taylor, Edna Dean Proctor, and a score of other well-known writers contribute original papers. And the price at which all this is sold, is written modestly down -- "25 cents." Surely, there are few who cannot afford this sum, in such a cause, for Only Once. It is sold at the fair for the benefit of the Infirmary, now in course, at Dodworth's Hall. The entertainment provided at the fair is more varied than is usual on such occasions -- the entertainment being varied by readings and recitations. It is open throughout the day and evening.
lead_paragraph: Only Once is the unique title of a collection of original papers, published for the benefit of the New-York Infirmary for Women and Children. Originally it was intended to make a cheap pamphlet of the work, but the eminent names that appeared in the list of contributors, justified an increased expenditure, and the result is before us, in a vision of tinted paper, that will bring gladness to centre tables. Mr. PUTNAM has contributed four excellent plates, that enable the little work to outshine the majority of annuals -- so far as illustration goes. There are steel-plate portraits of BRYANT and JAMES RUSSELL LOWELL; one of Mrs. C.M. SEDGWICK, engraved from a drawing made by FREDERIKA BREMER herself, and now for the first time published, and a fine view of Florence. Bryant, Whittler, Lowell, Page, Rose Tenny, Phoebe Carey, Bayard Taylor, Edna Dean Proctor, and a score of other well-known writers contribute original papers. abstract: The telegraph has already noticed the presentation of a flag to Commodore FOOTE'S wife by the stu dents of Yale College. PELATIAH PERIT, of this City acknowledges the gift on Mrs. FOOTE'S behalf, as follows:
lead_paragraph: GENTLEMEN: At the request of my friend Mrs. FOOTE, and in her behalf, I beg to thank you for the honor conferred upon her husband by the presentation of the flag which floats above us. And having performed this duty, I may be permitted, I trust, to say a few words in commendation of a valued friend who commands the esteem of the whole community, not only through his valiant deeds, but through his rare moral worth.

abstract: The Board of Councilmen, last evening, received, through Mayor OPDYKE, several secession flags, presented by Brig.-Gen. SMITH, as part of the spoils captured at Fort Donelson. The Tax Levy was taken up, and a number of alterations made from the Comptroller's estimate.
lead_paragraph: Dr. BELLOWS lectured before the American Geographical and Statistical Society, last evening, on "The Importance of Sanitary Science as Illustrated in the Experience of Recent Wars -- Abroad and at Home." He was followed by J. SMITH HOMANS, Esq., who read a paper on "The Comparative Value of the Northern and Southern portions of the United States to England in a Commercial Point of View." Both discourses were much applauded by a large and respectable audience.

abstract: The Commissioners of Health met yesterday at the Mayor's Office, for the purpose of considering and acting upon the subject of vaccination, which had been brought up at a previous meeting, and referred to Dr. LEWIS A. SAYRE, Resident Physician. Dr. SAYRE yesterday presented a long report, dealing largely in statistics, and going so far to show the absolute necessity of general vaccination in a large City like New-York, as to lead to the conclusion that if people will not be vaccinnated when the authorities are willing to cause it to be done free of charge, the law should, for the preservation of the general health, compel them to be vaccinated. The Doctor showed by statistics carefully prepared, that out of one million of persons, the lives of fifty-two thousand were saved by vaccination, and that in armies where, before vaccination was known, the mortality from small pox was enormous, at the present day, and with the strict attention paid to vaccination, the mortality was trifling. A large number of the report was ordered to be printed for general distribution: and the conclusions reached by the Doctor having met the approbation of the Board, the draft of a law presented by him was adopted, and will be at once forwarded to Albany for legislative action.
lead_paragraph: The Commissioners of Health met yesterday at the Mayor's Office, for the purpose of considering and acting upon the subject of vaccination, which had been brought up at a previous meeting, and referred to Dr. LEWIS A. abstract: Dilapidated houses, windows broken in, parlors turned into stalls, the ruins of valuable buildings destroyed by fire, and a general air of mournfulness, were the characteristics of Springfield when first occupied by the advance of Gen. CURTIS' army. A military Governor was immediately appointed, rubbish cleared from the streets of the town, and soon the Union refugees commenced to make their appearance.

abstract: We received by the steamship Hibernian, which arrived at Portland yesterday afternoon, advices from Europe five days later than were brought by the Niagara. She left Liverpool on the 13th, and Londonderry on the 14th inst. American affairs had been debated in the British Parliament. Earl RUSSEL, in answer to a question relative to...
lead_paragraph: British subjects, alleged to be imprisoned by order of the American Government, intimated that great allowance was to be made for the condition of affairs in the United States; that Parliament had granted power to the British Government, in times of trouble, similar to that now delegated to the President, and that persons, under such authority, had frequently been held under arrest in England without being brought to trial. If the persons arrested had been guilty of treasonable conspiracies against the United States Government, he did not see how Her Majesty's Government could interfere. A call was made for the papers relating to the blockade, and Lord RUSSELL said they were in the printer's hands, and would soon be published. The success of the National forces at Mill Spring was looked upon in England as an important one. An order had been received at Portsmouth to reduce the number of men and guns of the ships of war in commission.
